第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——旅行同伴们——一位专员——一位艺术大师——一个探险家——边境上的吉尔·布拉斯——一个年轻人对快乐的期待
—TRAVELLING COMPANIONS.—A COMMISSIONER.—A VIRTUOSO.—A SEEKER OF ADVENTURES.—A GIL BLAS OF THE FRONTIER.—A YOUNG MAN’S ANTICIPATIONS OF PLEASURE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 远西区位于密西西比河畔几百英里外，是一个时常受到大家吹捧的地方。这里绵延着一大片无人居住的土地，既看不到白人的大木屋，也瞧不见印第安人的小棚屋。这里有广袤的草原，有大大小小的树丛点缀其间，并有阿肯色河、加拿大的格兰德河、雷德河和它们的支流缓缓流过。在这肥沃而青翠的大荒原上还游荡着麋鹿、野牛和野马。它们都在这自由的国度里驰骋。事实上，这些地区便是远西区各个部落的狩猎场。那边有奥塞奇人、克里克人、特拉华人，以及其他一些被教化了的部落。他们就住在白人定居者的周围。这边也游弋着波尼族人、科曼奇人的部落，和其他一些凶狠且依然保持独立的部落、大草原上的游牧部落或是落基山脉周边的居民。我所提到的这些地区是这些敌对部落的必争之地，他们都不敢在这里划分边界建立一个永久居住区。在狩猎季节，猎手们和“勇士们”大批地奔赴那边，搭建起暂时的狩猎营地——用树皮和兽皮覆盖着的轻巧的遮阴棚。他们大肆屠杀着大草原上不计其数的食草兽群，满载鹿肉和野牛肉而归；同时，他们还得小心提防危险的邻族。这些冒险远征常常需要人们有尚武的品性：猎手们全副武装，随时准备战斗；他们都充满了攻击性和防卫性，而且必须时刻保持警惕。他们一旦在长途跋涉中遇到敌对部落的猎手，残酷的冲突便不可避免了。他们的营地也总是受到四处游荡的战争团伙的偷袭。猎手们在分散开来追击猎物时，还可能会被埋伏的敌人逮捕或屠杀。在某个阴森的深谷中，水流正冲刷着支离破碎的颅骨和骨架；或者在被遗弃的狩猎营地附近，常常有蛛丝马迹表明，这里曾经有过一场血战，提醒路人他正行走在一个危险的地带。接下来的文字将会描述一次在上述狩猎区里为期一个月的远足——穿越一块尚未被白人开发的地区。
In the often vaunted regions of the Far West, several hundred miles beyond the Mississippi, extends a vast tract of uninhabited country, where there is neither to be seen the log-house of the white man, nor the wigwam of the Indian.It consists of great grassy plains, interspersed with forests and groves, and clumps of trees, and watered by the Arkansas, the Grand Canadian, the Red River, and their tributary streams.Over these fertile and verdant wastes still roam the elk, the buffalo, and the wild horse, in all their native freedom.These, in fact, are the hunting grounds of the various tribes of the Far West.Thither repair the Osage, the Creek, the Delaware and other tribes that have linked themselves with civilization, and live within the vicinity of the white settlements.Here resort also, the Pawnees, the Comanches, and other fierce, and as yet independent tribes, the nomads of the prairies, or the inhabitants of the skirts of the Rocky Mountains.The regions I have mentioned form a debatable ground of these warring and vindictive tribes; none of them presume to erect a permanent habitation within its borders.Their hunters and “Braves” repair thither in numerous bodies during the season of game, throw up their transient hunting camps, consisting of light bowers covered with bark and skins, commit sad havoc among the innumerable herds that graze the prairies, and having loaded themselves with venison and buffalo meat, warily retire from the dangerous neighborhood.These expeditions partake, always, of a warlike character: the hunters are all armed for action, offensive and defensive, and are bound to incessant vigilance.Should they, in their excursions, meet the hunters of an adverse tribe, savage conflicts take place.Their encampments, too, are always subject to be surprised by wandering war parties, and their hunters, when scattered in pursuit of game, to be captured or massacred by lurking foes.Mouldering skulls and skeletons, bleaching in some dark ravine, or near the traces of a hunting camp, occasionally mark the scene of a foregone act of blood, and let the wanderer know the dangerous nature of the region he is traversing.It is the purport of the following pages to narrate a month’s excursion to these noted hunting grounds, through a tract of country which had not as yet been explored by white men.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我是在1832年10月初到达吉布森要塞的。那是远西区的一个边防站，坐落在尼欧肖河或是格兰德河上，河水就在不远处汇入了阿肯色河。我之前已经和一队来自圣路易斯的人沿着密苏里河河岸逆流而上，跋涉了一个月。沿途经过了一些坐落于密苏里州与阿肯色州交界地带上的代理行和教堂。一位由美国政府任命的专员带领着我们这队人行进。他的任务是管理印第安部落从密西西比河以东向西迁移的安居工作。在履行职责的过程中，他走访了各种各样开化了的边远地区。
It was early in October, 1832, that I arrived at Fort Gibson, a frontier post of the Far West, situated on the Neosho, or Grand River, near its confluence with the Arkansas.I had been travelling for a month past, with a small party from St. Louis, up the banks of the Missouri, and along the frontier line of agencies and missions that extends from the Missouri to the Arkansas.Our party was headed by one of the Commissioners appointed by the government of the United States, to superintend the settlement of the Indian tribes migrating from the east to the west of the Mississippi.In the discharge of his duties, he was thus visiting the various outposts of civilization.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这里，请容许我对我们这个小团队的可敬领队赞美几句。他是康涅狄格州上一个小镇的居民，一个尽管经历了长期的法律实践与政坛生涯，但仍然保持着与生俱来的淳朴与仁慈之心的人。在康涅狄格河宁静的河畔，他的大部分时间用在了处理家族内部事务及与执事、长老、市政委员的社交上。可在这时，他突然被征召骑上他的战马，挎上步枪，在渺无人烟的远西区荒原上与半裸的猎人、偏远林区的居民及赤裸的野蛮人混在一起。
And here let me bear testimony to the merits of this worthy leader of our little band.He was a native of one of the towns of Connecticut, a man in whom a course of legal practice and political life had not been able to vitiate an innate simplicity and benevolence of heart.The greater part of his days had been passed in the bosom of his family and the society of deacons, elders, and selectmen, on the peaceful banks of the Connecticut; when suddenly he had been called to mount his steed, shoulder his rifle, and mingle among stark hunters, backwoodsmen, and naked savages, on the trackless wilds of the Far West.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: L.先生是我的另一个旅伴。他出生于英国，却是外国人的后裔，有着欧洲大陆人与生俱来的乐观与随和。因为游历过许多国家，所以从某种意义上来说，他已经成为一个具有很强的适应能力的世界公民了。他身兼数职：植物学家、地质学家、甲虫和蝴蝶的捕捉者、业余音乐爱好者、毫不虚饰的素描画家。总之，他是一个彻头彻尾的艺术大师。另外，他还是一个并不总是很成功却不屈不挠的运动员。没有一个人像他那样同时要做很多事情，也因此没有一个人像他一样越忙越快乐。
Another of my fellow-travellers was Mr. L., an Englishman by birth, but descended from a foreign stock; and who had all the buoyancy and accommodating spirit of a native of the Continent.Having rambled over many countries, he had become, to a certain degree, a citizen of the world, easily adapting himself to any change.He was a man of a thousand occupations; a botanist, a geologist, a hunter of beetles and butterflies, a musical amateur, a sketcher of no mean pretensions, in short, a complete virtuoso; added to which, he was a very indefatigable, if not always a very successful, sportsman.Never had a man more irons in the fire, and, consequently, never was man more busy nor more cheerful.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我的第三个旅伴是陪着L.先生从欧洲来的一位先生，他就像忒勒马科斯一样陪同在他左右，更准确地说，就像他的复制品，总是偶尔给他的“良师益友”带来些困惑和不安。他是一个年轻的瑞士伯爵，不到二十一岁，才华横溢，充满活力，但却兴奋得过了度，总是想去尝试各种疯狂的冒险。
My third fellow-traveller was one who had accompanied the former from Europe, and travelled with him as his Telemachus; being apt, like his prototype, to give occasional perplexity and disquiet to his Mentor.He was a young Swiss Count, scarce twenty-one years of age, full of talent and spirit, but galliard in the extreme, and prone to every kind of wild adventure.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 介绍了我的伙伴们之后，我不得不提及一个不容忽视的人物。他虽然地位低下，却不可或缺、至关重要：护卫、马夫、厨师、支帐篷的人……概括来说，他就是个总管，并且我还想补充一句：他是我们队伍中最爱管闲事和最喜欢捣蛋的人。此人个头不高、又黑又瘦，是法国人与非洲人的混血儿，名叫安托万，但人们亲切地称之为托尼什——一种边境上的吉尔·布拉斯。他过着一种杂乱的生活：有时混迹于白人当中，有时出入于印第安部落，有时受雇于商人、传教士或印第安雇主，有时又加入到奥赛奇人的狩猎队之中。我们在圣路易斯带上了他。在圣路易斯附近，他有一个小农场、一个印第安妻子和一大群同母异父的孩子。然而据他自己所说，他在每个部落都有一个妻子。事实上，如果这个矮小的流浪者所说的关于自己的一切都属实的话，那他就是一个没有道德、没有社会地位、没有原则、没有国家甚至没有自己语言的人，因为他说的是一口夹杂着法语、英语和奥赛奇语的行话。此外，他是个声名狼藉的吹牛者和一流的撒谎者。听他夸夸其谈地讲述他那些令人胆战心惊的英勇行为，以及在战场上、打猎时在千钧一发之际死里逃生的经历是一件很有趣的事。在他口若悬河地讲故事的时候，有时会因一阵阵的大喘气而中断下来，就像他颌上的筋突然出现了错乱；但我更愿意认为这是他被自己脱口而出的谎话噎到了，因为通常我接下来都会马上意识到这是一个弥天大谎。
Having made this mention of my comrades, I must not pass over unnoticed, a personage of inferior rank, but of all-pervading and prevalent importance: the squire, the groom, the cook, the tent man, in a word, the factotum, and, I may add, the universal meddler and marplot of our party.This was a little swarthy, meagre, French creole, named Antoine, but familiarly dubbed Tonish: a kind of Gil Blas of the frontier, who had passed a scrambling life, sometimes among white men, sometimes among Indians; sometimes in the employ of traders, missionaries, and Indian agents; sometimes mingling with the Osage hunters.We picked him up at St. Louis, near which he had a small farm, an Indian wife, and a brood of half-blood children.According to his own account, however, he had a wife in every tribe; in fact, if all this little vagabond said of himself were to be believed, he was without morals, without caste, without creed, without country, and even without language; for he spoke a jargon of mingled French, English, and Osage.He was, withal, a notorious braggart, and a liar of the first water.It was amusing to hear him vapor and gasconade about his terrible exploits and hairbreadth escapes in war and hunting.In the midst of his volubility, he was prone to be seized by a spasmodic gasping, as if the springs of his jaws were suddenly unhinged; but I am apt to think it was caused by some falsehood that stuck in his throat, for I generally remarked that immediately afterward there bolted forth a lie of the first magnitude.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这是一次愉快的旅行，有时我们会住在印第安传教士们的相隔很远的屋子里，但大多数时候，我们在野外靠近溪流的幽静小树林里搭建营地，睡在帐篷里。在行程的后半段，我们往前赶了赶路，希望能够及时赶到吉布森要塞，跟奥赛奇族进行秋季大草原野牛狩猎的猎手们一道而行。实际上，那位年轻的伯爵已经因对这个事的想象而兴奋不已了。大草原壮丽的风景和桀骜不驯的个性已经使他痴迷不已了，并且小托尼什给他讲的关于印第安勇士和美女、关于猎杀野牛和捕捉野马的故事，都使他想要急切地冲到原始生活中去。他是个勇敢而骑技高超的骑士，渴望逐鹿草原。听他充满青春活力地描述和印第安人混在一起，加入他们艰苦的探险时，他预计将会看到什么、会做什么和享受什么，是件很有意思的事。但更有意思的是听小托尼什吹牛。他自愿在伯爵所有的危险活动中做他忠实的侍从：教他如何捕捉野马、放倒野牛，以及赢得印第安公主的芳心。——“要是我们能看到燃烧的大草原就好了。”年轻的伯爵说。——“到那时，我要亲自点火。”小法国人大叫着说。
Our route had been a pleasant one, quartering ourselves, occasionally, at the widely separated establishments of the Indian missionaries, but in general camping out in the fine groves that border the streams, and sleeping under cover of a tent.During the latter part of our tour we had pressed forward, in hopes of arriving in time at Fort Gibson to accompany the Osage hunters on their autumnal visit to the buffalo prairies.Indeed the imagination of the young Count had become completely excited on the subject.The grand scenery and wild habits of the prairies had set his spirits madding, and the stories that little Tonish told him of Indian braves and Indian beauties, of hunting buffaloes and catching wild horses, had set him all agog for a dash into savage life.He was a bold and hard rider, and longed to be scouring the hunting grounds.It was amusing to hear his youthful anticipations of all that he was to see, and do, and enjoy, when mingling among the Indians and participating in their hardy adventure; and it was still more amusing to listen to the gasconadings of little Tonish, who volunteered to be his faithful squire in all his perilous undertakings; to teach him how to catch the wild horse, bring down the buffalo, and win the smiles of Indian princesses;—“And if we can only get sight of a prairie on fire!” said the young Count—“By Gar, Ill set one on fire myself!” cried the little Frenchman.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二章 期望落空
CHAPTER II. ANTICIPATIONS DISAPPOINTED.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——新的计划——准备加入一支探险队——从吉布森要塞启程——弗迪格里斯河的浅滩——一个印第安骑士
—NEW PLANS.—PREPARATIONS TO JOIN AN EXPLORING PARTY.—DEPARTURE FROM FORT GIBSON.—FORDING OF THE VERDIGRIS.—AN INDIAN CAVALIER.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 年轻人的期待往往以失望告终。在我们的行程结束之前，伯爵想要参加野外狩猎的计划就不幸落空了；我们听说奥塞奇的猎手们已经踏上前往野牛出没地区的征程了。可伯爵依然决定，如果有可能的话，他将循着他们的踪迹行走，赶上他们。为此，他在距离吉布森要塞几英里的奥塞奇事务所作了短暂的停留，以询问相关情况和作些准备工作。和他一起留下来的是他的旅伴L.先生，而那位专员和我则继续前往吉布森要塞。一路跟着我们的还有忠诚而又可靠的托尼什。我暗示他，他曾许下承诺要跟随伯爵参加狩猎，却发现这个小跟班只关注自己的利益。他意识到，专员因为他的工作职责，将会在这个地区停留很长一段时间，并很有可能一直雇佣他，而伯爵则只是短暂地停留。这个小吹牛者也就突然间三缄其口了。他不再对年轻的伯爵说任何关于印第安人、野牛及野马之类的事，转而默默地跟着专员的队伍，一路安静地跟着我们前往要塞。
The anticipations of a young man are prone to meet with disappointment.Unfortunately for the Count’s scheme of wild campaigning, before we reached the end of our journey; we heard that the Osage hunters had set forth upon their expedition to the buffalo grounds.The Count still determined, if possible, to follow on their track and overtake them, and for this purpose stopped short at the Osage Agency, a few miles distant from Fort Gibson, to make inquiries and preparations.His travelling companion, Mr. L., stopped with him; while the Commissioner and myself proceeded to Fort Gibson, followed by the faithful and veracious Tonish.I hinted to him his promises to follow the Count in his campaignings, but I found the little varlet had a keen eye to self-interest.He was aware that the Commissioner, from his official duties, would remain for a long time in the country, and be likely to give him permanent employment, while the sojourn of the Count would be but transient.The gasconading of the little braggart was suddenly therefore at an end.He spake not another word to the young Count about Indians, buffaloes, and wild horses, but putting himself tacitly in the train of the Commissioner, jogged silently after us to the garrison.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 然而，一到达要塞，一个漫游大草原的新机会呈现在我们眼前。我们了解到，一队巡逻骑兵，或者是步枪手在三天前刚出发。他们要进行一次从阿肯色河到雷德河的大范围的野外考察，其中还包括一块白人从未涉足过的波尼族人的狩猎地。也就是说，我们有机会在强大护卫队的保护下穿越这些危险而有趣的地区，因为专员可以借着职务之便要求这队新建的步枪手为他效劳，而且他们将要考察的地区也是他此次任务中一些游牧部落的指定定居点。
On arriving at the fort, however, a new chance presented itself for a cruise on the prairies.We learnt that a company of mounted rangers, or riflemen, had departed but three days previous to make a wide exploring tour from the Arkansas to the Red River, including a part of the Pawnee hunting grounds where no party of white men had as yet penetrated.Here, then, was an opportunity of ranging over those dangerous and interesting regions under the safeguard of a powerful escort; for the Commissioner, in virtue of his office, could claim the service of this newly raised corps of riflemen, and the country they were to explore was destined for the settlement of some of the migrating tribes connected with his mission.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们立马制定了计划并即刻付诸实施。吉普森要塞的指挥官派出几个克里克族印第安人去传急令。这几个人要赶上巡逻队并让他们停止行进，直到专员和他的人马与他们会合。由于我们在赶上巡逻队前，还要在野地里行进三到四天，所以指挥官将一支由十四个骑兵步枪手组成的护卫队指派给了我们，并让陆军中尉带队指挥。
Our plan was promptly formed and put into execution.A couple of Creek Indians were sent off express, by the commander of Fort Gibson, to overtake the rangers and bring them to a halt until the Commissioner and his party should be able to join them.As we should have a march of three or four days through a wild country before we could overtake the company of rangers, an escort of fourteen mounted riflemen, under the command of a lieutenant, was assigned us.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们给还在奥塞奇事务所的年轻伯爵及L.先生传话过去，向他们说了我们的新计划及其预期，并邀请他们与我们同行。然而，伯爵却忘不掉他对自己的承诺——要过一种充满乐趣的、真正原始的生活。在回复中，他说他愿意与我们同行，直到我们发现奥塞奇族猎手的踪迹，因为他立志要追随奥塞奇族的猎手，与旷野融为一体。而他忠实的“良师益友”，尽管为这个疯狂的计划而感到悲伤，但还是出于朋友的忠诚而没有离弃他。我们初步约定，第二天早上在事务所与护卫队会合。
We sent word to the young Count and Mr. L. at the Osage Agency; of our new plan and prospects, and invited them to accompany us.The Count, however, could not forego the delights he had promised himself in mingling with absolutely savage life.In reply; he agreed to keep with us until we should come upon the trail of the Osage hunters, when it was his fixed resolve to strike off into the wilderness in pursuit of them; and his faithful Mentor, though he grieved at the madness of the scheme, was too stanch a friend to desert him.A general rendezvous of our party and escort was appointed, for the following morning, at the Agency.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们现在已经作好了充分准备，可以即刻启程。到目前为止，我们的行李由一辆轻便马车拉着，但是马上就要穿越一块无人涉足的地区，一路上将会遇到溪流、沟壑及灌木丛。在这些地方，像马车这样的交通工具是很难通过的。我们将采取猎人的做法——骑在马背上行进，负担越少越好。因此，我们对行李进行了一次严格的、最大幅度的精简。每个人的马背上都搭着一副塞得满满的鞍囊，但也仅够放下少量衣服和自己的大外套。其他的行李则放在驮马上。每人都有一张睡觉用的熊皮和两条毯子，还有一顶庇护用的帐篷，以防生病或遇到坏天气。我们又留心自带了些面粉、咖啡和糖，以及少量用于紧急情况的咸猪肉，因为我们将主要依靠打猎获取食物。
We now made all arrangements for prompt departure.Our baggage had hitherto been transported on a light wagon, but we were now to break our way through an untravelled country, cut up by rivers, ravines, and thickets, where a vehicle of the kind would be a complete impediment.We were to travel on horseback, in hunter’s style, and with as little encumbrance as possible.Our baggage, therefore, underwent a rigid and most abstemious reduction.A pair of saddle-bags, and those by no means crammed, sufficed for each man’s scanty wardrobe, and, with his great coat, were to be carried upon the steed he rode.The rest of the baggage was placed on pack-horses.Each one had a bear-skin and a couple of blankets for bedding, and there was a tent to shelter us in case of sickness or bad weather.We took care to provide ourselves with flour, coffee, and sugar, together with a small supply of salt pork for emergencies; for our main subsistence we were to depend upon the chase.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在我们最近的行程中，还没有被累坏的马继续跟着我们，用来当作驮马或备用马匹。但是旅程漫长而又艰辛，其间我们还将不时打猎，而且，万一遇到敌对的野蛮人，骑手的安全往往就取决于他骑的马的好坏，所以我们很小心地分配着马匹。我得到一匹强壮的银灰色的马，它有点儿粗野，但忠实有力，还有那匹先前一直骑着的、吃苦耐劳的矮种马。它有些疲惫了，所以我让它与那些驮马一起慢慢行进，以备不时之需。
Such of our horses as had not been tired out in our recent journey, were taken with us as pack-horses, or supernumeraries; but as we were going on a long and rough tour, where there would be occasional hunting, and where, in case of meeting with hostile savages, the safety of the rider might depend upon the goodness of his steed, we took care to be well mounted.I procured a stout silver-gray, somewhat rough, but stanch and powerful; and reigned a hardy pony which I had hitherto ridden, and which, being somewhat jaded, was suffered to ramble along with the pack-horses, to be mounted only in case of emergency.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 所有这些工作做完后，我们于10月10日早上离开了吉布森要塞，穿过了前面的那条河，出发前往事务所赴约。骑了几英里之后，我们来到了弗迪格里斯河的浅滩，一大片乱石横陈于树林的旁边。我们便从河岸上下来，排成稀稀拉拉的纵队，依次过河。马匹小心翼翼地踩着一块块石头前行，在湍急而喧哗的水流中谨慎地探寻立足点。
All these arrangements being made, we left Fort Gibson, on the morning of the tenth of October, and crossing the river in front of it, set off for the rendezvous at the Agency.A ride of a few miles brought us to the ford of the Verdigris, a wild rocky scene overhung with forest trees.We descended to the bank of the river and crossed in straggling file, the horses stepping cautiously from rock to rock, and in a manner feeling about for a foothold beneath the rushing and brawling stream.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 和驮马一起殿后的是我们的小个子法国人托尼什。他感觉自己得到了某种程度的提拔，因而非常高兴。在我们之前的行程中，他一直在赶马车，这在他看来好像是一项非常低级的差事，而现在他成了马的主人了。
Our little Frenchman, Tonish, brought up the rear with the pack-horses.He was in high glee, having experienced a kind of promotion.In our journey hitherto he had driven the wagon, which he seemed to consider a very inferior employ; now he was master of the horse.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他像一只栖息在树上的猴子一样坐在一匹马上，边唱边喊，并像印第安人那样高声尖叫。他还不停地用他那夹杂着法语、英语和奥塞奇语的行话咒骂那些什么也听不懂的慵散驮马。
He sat perched like a monkey behind the on one of the horses; he sang, he shouted, he yelped like an Indian, and ever and anon blasphemed the loitering pack-horses in his jargon of mingled French, English, and, Osage, which not one of them could understand.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 穿越浅滩时，我们看到河岸对面有一个骑在马背上的克里克族印第安人。他停在一个岩石壁上观察我们，变成了一道如画般的风景，与他周围的自然风景和谐地融为一体。他身上穿着一件明亮的饰以鲜红色边的蓝色狩猎上衣，头上包着一块色彩明快、有点儿像穆斯林头巾的手帕。这手帕的一端从他的耳边垂下来。他手里拿着一支长步枪，看起来像是一个游荡在野外的阿拉伯人。我们那饶舌又爱管闲事的小个子法国人，用他那粗野的行话对他大喊大叫，但那野蛮人在满足了自己的好奇心之后，摇了摇头，便调转马头，沿着河岸飞奔而去，很快就消失在树林之中。
As we were crossing the ford we saw on the opposite shore a Creek Indian on horseback.He had paused to reconnoitre us from the brow of a rock, and formed a picturesque object, in unison with the wild scenery around him.He wore a bright blue hunting-shirt trimmed with scarlet fringe; a gayly colored handkerchief was bound round his head something like a turban, with one end hanging down beside his ear; he held a long rifle in his hand, and looked like a wild Arab on the prowl.Our loquacious and ever-meddling little Frenchman called out to him in his Babylonish jargon, but the savage having satisfied his curiosity tossed his head in the air, turned the head of his steed, and galloping along the shore soon disappeared among the trees.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第三章 一个印第安人的事务所
CHAPTER III. AN INDIAN AGENCY.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——步枪手——奥塞奇人、克里克人、设阱捕兽者、猎狗、马匹、混血儿——猎手贝蒂
—RIFLEMEN.—OSAGES, CREEKS, TRAPPERS, DOGS, HORSES, HALF-BREEDS.—BEATTE, THE HUNTSMAN.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 越过浅滩之后，我们很快便来到了奥塞奇事务所。在这里，肖托上校有他自己的办公室和弹药库，用来处理印第安人事务及分发礼物和供给品。事务所由几间建在河两岸上的木屋组成，呈现出一片光怪陆离的边塞景象。我们的护卫队就在这里等待着我们的到来。他们中有的人骑在马背上，有的站着，有的坐在倒在地上的树的树干上，还有的在瞄准目标。他们是一群杂七杂八的人：一些人穿着绿色毛毯做的礼服大衣；另一些人穿着皮制狩猎装。但大多数人穿的是令人目瞪口呆的、裁剪不当的衣服，简直就没法穿；他们显然是为了这次艰苦的行程才穿上的。
Having crossed the ford, we soon reached the Osage Agency, where Col. Choteau has his offices and magazines, for the despatch of Indian affairs, and the distribution of presents and supplies.It consisted of a few log houses on the banks of the river, and presented a motley frontier scene.Here was our escort awaiting our arrival; some were on horseback, some on foot, some seated on the trunks of fallen trees, some shooting at a mark.They were a heterogeneous crew; some in frock-coats made of green blankets; others in leathern hunting-shirts, but the most part in marvellously ill-cut garments, much the worse for wear, and evidently put on for rugged service.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这些人旁边的是一群奥塞奇人：一些庄重的家伙，着装和面容都严厉而朴素。他们没有戴任何的装饰品，他们的装束就只是毯子、绑腿和莫卡辛鞋。他们的头顶光光的，头发剪得非常短，只是在头顶上留了笔直的一撮，就像是头盔上的羽冠一样，还有一绺长长的头发拖在后面。他们有罗马人俊美的面容和宽阔的胸膛；而且他们大多都只把毯子裹到腰部，所以上半身和胳膊便裸露在外面，这使他们看上去就像高贵的青铜像。到目前为止，我在西部看到的最俊美的印第安人便是奥塞奇人。那时，他们还没有完全向近在咫尺的文明势力屈服，也没有丢掉自己作为猎手和武士的天性；并且贫穷也使他们无法放纵于奢华的服饰中。
Near by these was a group of Osages: stately fellows; stern and simple in garb and aspect.They wore no ornaments; their dress consisted merely of blankets, leggings, and moccasons.Their heads were bare; their hair was cropped close, excepting a bristling ridge on the top, like the crest of a helmet, with a long scalp-lock hanging behind.They had fine Roman countenances, and broad deep chests; and, as they generally wore their blankets wrapped round their loins, so as to leave the bust and arms bare, they looked like so many noble bronze figures.The Osages are the finest looking Indians I have ever seen in the West.They have not yielded sufficiently, as yet, to the influence of civilization to lay by their simple Indian garb, or to lose the habits of the hunter and the warrior; and their poverty prevents their indulging in much luxury of apparel.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一群衣着华丽的克里克人与他们形成了鲜明对比。一眼瞥过去，你会发现这个部落的人外貌有些东方人的特点。他们穿着五光十色的棉布狩猎衬衫，上面装饰着鲜艳的花边；腰间束着宽宽的腰带，上面缀着珠子；他们的绑腿有的是用鹿皮做的，有的是用绿色或红色的布做的，上面饰以膝带和流苏；他们的莫卡辛鞋也做工巧妙，装饰精美；他们头上还高雅地围着华丽的手帕。
In contrast to these was a gayly dressed party of Creeks.There is something, at the first glance, quite oriental in the appearance of this tribe.They dress in calico hunting shirts, of various brilliant colors, decorate with bright fringes, and belted with broad girdles, embroidered with beads; they have leggings of dressed deer skins, or of green or scarlet cloth, with embroidered knee-bands and tassels; their moccasons are fancifully wrought and ornamented, and they wear gaudy handkerchiefs tastefully bound round their heads.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 除了这些人之外，还有几个拥有各种肤色的设阱捕兽者、猎人、混血儿、克里奥尔人、黑人，以及那些游荡在边境上、难以区分的乌合之众。他们出入于文明世界和野蛮生活之间，就像那些犹豫不决的鸟儿和蝙蝠徘徊于光明与黑暗之间一样。
Besides these, there was a sprinkling of trappers, hunters, half-breeds, creoles, negroes of every hue; and all that other rabble rout of nondescript beings that keep about the frontiers, between civilised and savage life, as those equivocal birds, the bats, hover about the confines of light and darkness.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 事务所所在的这个小村庄一片繁忙，特别是准备用具的铁匠铺：一个魁梧的黑人正在给一匹马钉蹄铁，两个混血儿正在制作铁匙，这是用来熔化铅做子弹用的。一个设阱捕兽的老人穿着皮制狩猎装和莫卡辛鞋，把自己的步枪靠工作台放着，一边指挥着操作，一边闲扯着他的狩猎经历。几条大狗或是悠闲地进出店铺，或是在阳光下打盹；一只小野狗歪着脑袋，竖起一只耳朵，带着小狗们惯有的好奇心看着给马钉蹄铁的过程，好像是在研究这门艺术，又或者是在等着轮到铁匠给自己钉蹄铁。
The little hamlet of the Agency was in a complete bustle; the blacksmith’s shed, in particular, was a scene of preparation; a strapping negro was shoeing a horse; two half-breeds were fabricating iron spoons in which to melt lead for bullets.An old trapper, in leathern hunting frock and moccasons, had placed his rifle against a work-bench, while he superintended the operation, and gossiped about his hunting exploits; several large dogs were lounging in and out of the shop, or sleeping in the sunshine, while a little cur, with head cocked on one side, and one ear erect, was watching, with that curiosity common to little dogs, the process of shoeing the horse, as if studying the art, or waiting for his turn to be shod.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们找到了伯爵和他的同伴，这个所谓的“艺术大师”已经为这段旅程作好了准备。由于他们想赶上奥塞奇人，花点儿时间和他们一起围猎野牛和野马，所以他们也相应地作好了准备：除了用于旅行的马匹之外，他们还准备了一些上等的好马。这些马在行进时跟着大家，只在追赶野牛、野马时才骑。
We found the Count and his companion, the Virtuoso, ready for the march.As they intended to overtake the Osages, and pass some time in hunting the buffalo and the wild horse, they had provided themselves accordingly; having, in addition to the steeds which they used for travelling, others of prime quality, which were to be led when on the march, and only to be mounted for the chase.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 此外，他们还雇佣了一个叫安托万的年轻人，他是法国人和奥塞奇人的混血儿。他什么活都要干：做饭、打猎、照看马匹，但是他却总想什么也不做。和家里那些没出息的子女一样，他也是在父亲执行任务期间出生并长大成人的。另外，作为一个公认的英俊青年，一个边境上的阿多尼斯，他有点儿被宠坏了，又因为他姐姐是一个阔绰的白种商人的情妇，所以他有些想入非非，继而变得更加过分。
They had, moreover, engaged the services of a young man named Antoine, a half-breed of French and Osage origin.He was to be a kind of Jack-of-all-work; to cook, to hunt, and to take care of the horses; but he had a vehement propensity to do nothing, being one of the worthless brood engendered and brought up among the missions.He was, moreover, a little spoiled by being really a handsome young fellow, an Adonis of the frontier, and still worse by fancying himself highly connected, his sister being concubine to an opulent white trader!

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 从我们这方面来说，专员和我都渴望在出发前能够再找到一个精通森林知识的随从，他或许还可以做我们的猎手。因为我们的小个子法国人已经因搭帐篷、做饭和行进时照看驮马而忙得团团转了。于是就有一个这样的人出现在了我们面前，或者不如说是被推荐给了我们，他就是皮埃尔·贝蒂，一个法国人和奥塞奇人的混血儿。推荐他的人向我们保证说：他对这片土地的每个地方都非常熟悉，在狩猎和作战期间，他走遍了这个地方，所以他既可以是向导，又可以是翻译，而且他还是一个一流的猎手。
For our own parts, the Commissioner and myself were desirous, before setting out, to procure another attendant well versed in woodcraft, who might serve us as a hunter; for our little Frenchman would have his hands full when in camp, in cooking, and on the march, in taking care of the pack-horses.Such an one presented himself, or rather was recommended to us, in Pierre Beatte, a half-breed of French and Osage parentage.We were assured that he was acquainted with all parts of the country, having traversed it in all directions, both in hunting and war parties; that he would be of use both as guide and interpreter, and that he was a first-rate hunter.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 老实说，当他第一次出现在我面前时，我并不喜欢他的样子。他当时穿着一身破旧的狩猎装，系着鹿皮绑腿，正在四处瞎逛。他浑身脏兮兮的，满是油污，整身衣服由于经常穿，像是油漆过一样。他看上去大约三十六岁，胸膛宽阔，身体强壮。他的相貌也还不算太糟，跟拿破仑有几分相似，只不过棱角更加分明，他还有着印第安人特有的高颧骨。
I confess I did not like his looks when he was first presented to me.He was lounging about, in an old hunting frock and metasses or leggings, of deer skin, soiled and greased, and almost japanned by constant use.He was apparently about thirty-six years of age, square and strongly built.His features were not bad, being shaped not unlike those of Napoleon, but sharpened up, with high Indian cheek-bones.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 或许是由于他那暗绿色的皮肤，他看起来跟我之前看到的拿破仑的一座久远的半身青铜像非常相似。然而，他表情阴郁，那歪歪斜斜的羊毛呢帽和耳边蓬乱的头发也使他显得更加与众不同。
Perhaps the dusky greenish hue of his complexion, aided his resemblance to an old bronze bust I had seen of the Emperor.He had, however, a sullen, saturnine expression, set off by a slouched woollen hat, and elf locks that hung about his ears.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这就是这个人的尊容，而他的行为举止也同样不招人喜欢。他表情冷冷的，说话言简意赅，不作任何承诺或声明，只是说明他及他的马所必需的服务条件。对此，我们感觉要求有些高，但是他却丝毫没有要降低要求的意思，也不急于跟我们确定雇佣关系。总之，在他的血液里有更多的红种人而不是白种人的成分。别人曾经提醒过我：所有的混血儿都不可信，他们是一个靠不住的、不忠诚的种族。所以如果能避免找皮埃尔·贝蒂给我们提供服务，我将会非常高兴。然而，我们没有时间再去找一个适合我们口味的人了，所以我们不得不当场跟他达成协议。然后，他便开始为这次的旅行做准备，还承诺在我们的晚间宿营地与我们会合。
Such was the appearance of the man, and his manners were equally unprepossessing.He was cold and laconic; made no promises or professions; stated the terms he required for the services of himself and his horse, which we thought rather high, but showed no disposition to abate them, nor any anxiety to secure our employ.He had altogether more of the red than the white man in his composition; and, as I had been taught to look upon all half-breeds with distrust, as an uncertain and faithless race, I would gladly have dispensed with the services of Pierre Beatte.We had no time, however, to look out for any one more to our taste, and had to make an arrangement with him on the spot.He then set about making his preparations for the journey, promising to join us at our evening’s encampment.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 要想准备好这次大草原之旅，我还需要一个东西——一匹能完全信得过的坐骑：我还没有找到一匹真正称心如意的坐骑。我之前买的那匹灰马虽然强壮、耐用，但却很粗暴。在最后一刻，我终于成功地得到了一匹出色的马：一匹深栗色、强壮有力、活泼好动、生机勃勃、状态极佳的马。我兴高采烈地骑上它，并把那匹银灰色的马交给托尼什。他为发现自己成为一个十足的骑手而兴奋不已，我则担心他也许会意识到那句古老而闻名的谚语“马背上的乞丐”的含义。
One thing was yet wanting to fit me out for the Prairies—a thoroughly trustworthy steed: I was not yet mounted to my mind.The gray I had bought, though strong and serviceable, was rough.At the last moment I succeeded in getting an excellent animal; a dark bay; powerful, active, generous-spirited, and in capital condition.I mounted him with exultation, and transferred the silver gray to Tonish, who was in such ecstasies at finding himself so completely en Cavalier, that I feared he might realize the ancient and well-known proverb of “a beggar on horseback.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第四章 启程
CHAPTER IV. THE DEPARTURE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 最终长长的号角声标志着要启程了。巡逻骑兵们排成一队，稀稀拉拉地穿越树林。我们也很快骑上马，跟在他们后边，但却被不听话的驮马给耽搁了。它们不习惯列队前进，所以尽管托尼什不停地咒骂、吆喝，它们还是在灌木丛里四处乱窜。托尼什骑着他那英勇的灰马，肩上扛着一枝长步枪，满脸焦虑地跟着它们，声嘶力竭地喊着、骂着。
The long-drawn notes of a bugle at length gave the signal for departure.The rangers filed off in a straggling line of march through the woods: we were soon on horseback and following on, but were detained by the irregularity of the pack-horses.They were unaccustomed to keep the line, and straggled from side to side among the thickets, in spite of all the pesting and bedeviling of Tonish; who, mounted on his gallant gray, with a long rifle on his shoulder, worried after them, bestowing a superabundance of dry blows and curses.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 所以，我们很快便看不见护卫队了，但还是在尽力跟随他们的踪迹。我们穿过高高的森林和纠缠不清的灌木丛，越过印第安人的棚屋和黑人的小屋，终于在将近日落时分到达了一个边疆农舍。这个农舍的主人是一个移民，名叫贝里希尔。农舍坐落在一个小山上，巡逻骑兵们也已在山脚下的一个环形小树林里的小溪旁安营扎寨了。房主很有礼貌地接待了我们，但是因为他家正流行着传染病，所以他无法给我们提供住处。他本人看上去状况也不太好，尽管他身材高大，但却面如菜色，说话颤颤巍巍，声调忽高忽低。
We soon, therefore, lost sight of our escort, but managed to keep on their track, thridding lofty forests, and entangled thickets, and passing by Indian wigwams and negro huts, until toward dusk we arrived at a frontier farm-house, owned by a settler of the name of Berryhill.It was situated on a hill, below which the rangers had encamped in a circular grove, on the margin of a stream.The master of the house received us civilly, but could offer us no accommodation, for sickness prevailed in his family.He appeared himself to be in no very thriving condition, for though bulky in frame, he had a sallow, unhealthy complexion, and a whiffling double voice, shifting abruptly from a treble to a thorough-bass.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 发现他的木屋几乎成了一个挤满病人的医院之后，我们便下令在农场的空地上安营扎寨。
Finding his log house was a mere hospital, crowded with invalids, we ordered our tent to be pitched in the farm-yard.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的帐篷搭好没过多久，刚雇的随从——贝蒂，那个奥塞奇混血儿便出现了。他是骑着马来的，另外还牵着一匹马，牵的那匹马上似乎驮着为这次远征而精心准备的一些必需品。显然，只要看看他是如何照顾自己和他为紧急情况所做的准备，便可以知道贝蒂是一个“老战士”了。得知自己是被政府雇佣，为专员服务的，他便索取了政府配给的面粉和咸肉，然后把它们放好，以防止风雨。他除了有一匹粗野强壮、用于赶路和提供日常服务的马之外，还有一匹专门用于打猎的马。像他自己一样，这匹马也是一个混血儿，它是家养马和草原上的野马的杂交后代。这是一匹高贵的骏马，有着饱满的精神、矫健的身姿，还有漂亮的臀部。他在事务所时就已经小心翼翼地给它钉上蹄铁了。无论是为了上战场还是为了打猎，他都作好了万全的准备：肩上扛着来复枪，挎着牛角制成的火药筒和子弹袋，腰间别着猎刀，马鞍上放着绳圈——有人告诉我们那是套索，或者叫套马索，是用来捕捉野马的。
We had not been long encamped, when our recently engaged attendant, Beatte, the Osage half-breed, made his appearance.He came mounted on one horse and leading another, which seemed to be well packed with supplies for the expedition.Beatte was evidently an “old soldier,” as to the art of taking care of himself and looking out for emergencies.Finding that he was in government employ, being engaged by the Commissioner, he had drawn rations of flour and bacon, and put them up so as to be weather-proof.In addition to the horse for the road, and for ordinary service, which was a rough, hardy animal, he had another for hunting.This was of a mixed breed like himself, being a cross of the domestic stock with the wild horse of the prairies; and a noble steed it was, of generous spirit, fine action, and admirable bottom.He had taken care to have his horses well shod at the Agency.He came prepared at all points for war or hunting: his rifle on his shoulder, his powder-horn and bullet-pouch at his side, his hunting-knife stuck in his belt, and coils of cordage at his saddle bow, which we were told were lariats, or noosed cords, used in catching the wild horse.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这样的装备使得大草原上的一个印第安猎手和大海上的一艘巡洋舰并无二致——完全独立于世界之外，能够自我保护，自给自足。他能够使自己不依附任何人，自己决定自己的行为方式，自己照顾好自己的财务。我认为贝蒂好像自我感觉很独立而且高人一等，因为我们正行进在这片旷野之中。他一直是一副志得意满与阴沉郁闷参半的样子，仍旧是沉默寡言。他最关心的就是把东西从马背上卸下来并把马儿们牵到一个安全的地方过夜。他一切的行为举止和我们那位夸夸其谈、喋喋不休、手忙脚乱的小法国人形成了最鲜明的对比。后者也似乎对这位新来的人有些嫉妒。他悄悄告诉我们说，这些混血儿脾气暴躁、反复无常，一点儿都靠不住。那个贝蒂很明显打算只关心自己，在我们行进的过程中，他随时都有可能因为突然觉得厌烦或者受到冒犯，在紧急关头弃我们于不顾：他自己有着各种应变的技巧，能在大草原上游刃有余。
Thus equipped and provided, an Indian hunter on a prairie is like a cruiser on the ocean, perfectly independent of the world, and competent to self-protection and self-maintenance.He can cast himself loose from every one, shape his own course, and take care of his own fortunes.I thought Beatte seemed to feel his independence, and to consider himself superior to us all, now that we were launching into the wilderness.He maintained a half proud, half sullen look, and great taciturnity, and his first care was to unpack his horses and put them in safe quarters for the night.His whole demeanor was in perfect contrast to our vaporing, chattering, bustling little Frenchman.The latter, too, seemed jealous of this new-comer.He whispered to us that these half-breeds were a touchy, capricious people, little to be depended upon.That Beatte had evidently come prepared to take care of himself, and that, at any moment in the course of our tour, he would be liable to take some sudden disgust or affront, and abandon us at a moment’s warning: having the means of shifting for himself, and being perfectly at home on the prairies.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第五章 边塞风情
CHAPTER V. FRONTIER SCENES.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——边境上的莱克格斯——林奇的律法——找马遇险——年轻的奥塞奇人
—A LYCURGUS OF THE BORDER.—LYNCH’S LAW.—THE DANGER OF FINDING A HORSE.—THE YOUNG OSAGE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二天早上（10月11日），我们七点半就动身了。我们骑马穿过厚厚的、肥沃的冲积土地。这片土地上杂草丛生、树木成林。我们的行进路线和阿肯色河的西岸平行，希望可以在阿肯色河与雷德福克河的合流点附近赶上巡逻骑兵的大部队。一些克里克人的村庄和农舍零星分布在方圆几英里的土地上。那里的居民看起来已经运用了很多便利条件，初步进入了文明社会，从而繁荣兴旺起来。他们的农场都储备丰富，他们的家看起来舒适而富有。
On the following morning (October 11), we were on the march by half-past seven o’clock, and rode through deep rich bottoms of alluvial soil, overgrown with redundant vegetation, and trees of an enormous size.Our route lay parallel to the west bank of the Arkansas, on the borders of which river, near the confluence of the Red Fork, we expected to overtake the main body of rangers.For some miles the country was sprinkled with Creek villages and farm-houses; the inhabitants of which appeared to have adopted, with considerable facility, the rudiments of civilization, and to have thriven in consequence.Their farms were well stocked, and their houses had a look of comfort and abundance.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们碰到了一些人，他们刚刚参加完一场盛大的球类比赛回来，他们的民族因这种球类比赛而闻名于世。他们中有的步行，有的骑在马背上，通常，骑马的人的后面会坐着一个衣着华丽的女人。他们是个体形匀称的种族，肌肉强健而结实，腿优美而颀长。他们像吉普赛人一样，非常喜欢鲜艳的颜色及华美的装饰。从大草原上远远望去，那些醒目而奇特的目标便是他们。一个人的头上围着一条鲜红色的手帕，头顶上戴着一束像鸡尾一样的黑色羽毛。另一个人则头围一条白色的手帕，头顶一束红色的羽毛；还有一个人，也想头顶一束羽毛，但却因为没有羽毛，于是在头巾里插上了一束鲜艳的漆树枝。
We met with numbers of them returning from one of their grand games of ball, for which their nation is celebrated.Some were on foot, some on horseback; the latter, occasionally, with gaily-dressed females behind them.They are a well-made race, muscular and closely knit, with well-turned thighs and legs.They have a gypsy fondness for brilliant colors and gay decorations, and are bright and fanciful objects when seen at a distance on the prairies.One had a scarlet handkerchief bound round his head, surmounted with a tuft of black feathers like a cocktail.Another had a white handkerchief, with red feathers; while a third, for want of a plume, had stuck in his turban a brilliant bunch of sumach.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在荒野的边缘，我们在一个木屋前停下来问路。这个木屋的主人是一个白人移民，或者叫做无主土地上的合法定居者。他是一个骨瘦如柴的高个儿老头，红头发，细长的脸上双颊深陷，一只眼睛长年习惯性地眨着，就好像他说的一切都有心照不宣的含意。他目前正情绪高涨。他的一匹马丢失了，他确定是被先前驻扎在泥沼旁的零零散散的奥塞奇人在夜间偷走的。但既然他没有丢掉其他东西，也应该知足了。他要给这帮恶棍一个教训。因此，他摘下墙上的来复枪——这可是边境上永恒不变的对与错的强制实施者，给马装上马鞍，打算向沼泽地发起突袭。他的一个同伴手里正拿着来复枪站在那里，准备陪他一起去。
On the verge of the wilderness we paused to inquire our way at a log house, owned by a white settler or squatter, a tall raw-boned old fellow, with red hair, a lank lantern visage, and an inveterate habit of winking with one eye, as if everything he said was of knowing import.He was in a towering passion.One of his horses was missing; he was sure it had been stolen in the night by a straggling party of Osages encamped in a neighboring swamp; but he would have satisfaction!He would make an example of the villains.He had accordingly caught down his rifle from the wall, that invariable enforcer of right or wrong upon the frontiers, and, having saddled his steed, was about to sally forth on a foray into the swamp; while a brother squatter, with rifle in hand, stood ready to accompany him.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们尽力使这个草原上的老征人冷静下来，说他的马也许在邻近的森林里迷路了。但是他却有着边境上的人共有的倾向——把一切罪责归咎于印第安人，所以也就没有什么能阻止他带着武器冲入沼泽地了。
We endeavored to calm the old campaigner of the prairies, by suggesting that his horse might have strayed into the neighboring woods; but he had the frontier propensity to charge everything to the Indians, and nothing could dissuade him from carrying fire and sword into the swamp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 又骑了几英里之后，我们不但失去了巡逻骑兵大部队的踪迹，还被印第安人和移民们留下的各种各样的足迹搞得晕头转向。最后，我们来到了一个木屋前，屋里住着一位白人，这应该是边境上最偏远的一个屋子了。我们发现我们已经偏离了正确的方向。他带我们往回走了一段路，把我们领到了正确的路上。我们沿着这路，终于开始了征程，向着那无边的荒原挺进。
After riding a few miles farther we lost the trail of the main body of rangers, and became perplexed by a variety of tracks made lay the Indians and settlers.At length coming to a log house, inhabited by a white man, the very last on the frontier, we found that we had wandered from our true course.Taking us back for some distance, he again brought us to the right trail; putting ourselves upon which, we took our final departure, and launched into the broad wilderness.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大部队的踪迹就像一条漫无尽头的小路，翻过小山和低谷，越过灌木和荆棘，又延伸至纠缠不清的树丛和开阔的大草原。当一队人穿越荒原时，按照惯例，应像印第安人那样，人和马都挨个儿排成一列。这样，领头的人便会为后面的人开路以节省他们的体力，保持精神。同时，采用这种方式就使得别人无法得知这支队的人数，因为整支队伍只留下了一条窄窄的、踏得平平的小径标明他们前进的方向。
The trail kept on like a straggling footpath, over hill and dale, through brush and brake, and tangled thicket, and open prairie.In traversing the wilds it is customary for a party either of horse or foot to follow each other in single file like the Indians; so that the leaders break the way for those who follow, and lessen their labor and fatigue.In this way, also, the number of a party is concealed, the whole leaving but one narrow well-trampled track to mark their course.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 不久，我们又重新找到了大部队的踪迹。就在这时，我们见到了那位枯瘦如柴、拼命眨眼、策马狂奔的边境骑侠。他正从树林里钻出来，奔下小山坡，他那全副武装的同伴跟在后面。随着他渐渐向我们靠近，他那憔悴而沮丧的面容使我想起了对堂吉诃德的描述，他也同样为英勇的事业而全力以赴，准备穿越敌人藏身的、危险沼泽地里的丛林。
We had not long regained the trail, when, on emerging from a forest, we beheld our raw-boned, hard-winking, hard-riding knight-errant of the frontier, descending the slope of a hill, followed by his companion in arms.As he drew near to us, the gauntness of his figure and ruefulness of his aspect reminded me of the description of the hero of La Mancha, and he was equally bent on affairs of doughty enterprise, being about to penetrate the thickets of the perilous swamp, within which the enemy lay ensconced.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们正在山坡上和他说话，突然看到大约半英里之外有一个奥塞奇人骑着马从一片树林里冒出来，手里还用缰绳牵着另一匹马。我们那拼命眨眼的朋友马上意识到，那人牵着的那匹马正是他在寻找的马。这个奥塞奇人渐渐向我们靠近，他的外貌给我留下了深刻的印象。他大概也就十九或二十岁，但却发育得很好。他有着他部落人所共有的罗马人般的俊美长相。他骑在马上，腰间围着毯子，他那赤裸的上半身简直可以作为雕像的模特。他骑着一匹漂亮的白棕杂色马，是大草原上的野马。马脖子上套着一个宽宽的轭，轭的前面挂着一束被染成鲜红色的马鬃。
While we were holding a parley with him on the slope of the hill, we descried an Osage on horseback issuing out of a skirt of wood about half a mile off, and leading a horse by a halter.The latter was immediately recognized by our hard-winking friend as the steed of which he was in quest.As the Osage drew near, I was struck with his appearance.He was about nineteen or twenty years of age, but well grown, with the fine Roman countenance common to his tribe, and as he rode with his blanket wrapped round his loins, his naked bust would have furnished a model for a statuary.He was mounted on beautiful piebald horse, a mottled white and brown, of the wild breed of the prairies, decorated with a broad collar, from which hung in front a tuft of horsehair dyed of a bright scarlet.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这个年轻人坦然地向我们慢慢地骑了过来。通过翻译贝蒂，他告诉我们，他牵的那匹马误闯进了他们的营地，他现在正带着它回到主人那里去。
The youth rode slowly up to us with a frank open air, and signified by means of our interpreter Beatte, that the horse he was leading had wandered to their camp, and he was now on his way to conduct him back to his owner.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我本来期望那位相貌难看的骑士会万分感谢，可出乎意料的是，这个老家伙竟勃然大怒。他声称是那些印第安人在晚上牵走了他的马，打算早上给他送回来，并因找到它而索要报酬。他确定这是印第安人惯用的伎俩。因此，他想把这个年轻的印第安人绑在树上猛抽一顿；而让他感到惊讶的是，对此我们采取了一种新奇的方式：我们十分愤慨地给了这个印第安人应有的报酬，让他跟着我们走。然而，这就是边境上通常采用的管理条例，用术语来说叫“林奇的律法”。根据这个律法，原告往往又是证人、陪审团、法官和执行人；而仅仅根据假设，被告就要被定罪并接受惩罚。我确信正是因为这个原因，印第安人中间才会积蓄那么多不满和怨恨，并导致了报复行为，最终引发与印第安人的战争。当我将这个光明磊落、长相高贵、举止直爽的年轻奥塞奇人与那个满脸险恶、行事专横的边境居民相比较时，对于谁更应该挨这一顿鞭子，我丝毫没有感到疑惑。
I had expected to witness an expression of gratitude on the part of our hard-favored cavalier, but to my surprise the old fellow broke out into a furious passion.He declared that the Indians had carried off his horse in the night, with the intention of bringing him home in the morning, and claiming a reward for finding him; a common practice, as he affirmed, among the Indians.He was, therefore, for tying the young Indian to a tree and giving him a sound lashing; and was quite surprised at the burst of indignation which this novel mode of requiting a service drew from us.Such, however, is too often the administration of law on the frontier, “Lynch’s law,” as it is technically termed, in which the plaintiff is apt to be witness, jury, judge, and executioner, and the defendant to be convicted and punished on mere presumption; and in this way, I am convinced, are occasioned many of those heart-burnings and resentments among the Indians, which lead to retaliation, and end in Indian wars.When I compared the open, noble countenance and frank demeanor of the young Osage, with the sinister visage and high-handed conduct of the frontiersman, I felt little doubt on whose back a lash would be most meritoriously bestowed.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 因此这个边境居民就只得满足于马的失而复得，而不能根据边境上古老的莱克格斯契约，或者更准确说是德拉古法享受鞭打帮他找到马的人的乐趣了。在同伴的跟随下，他抱怨着踏上了返乡的征程。
Being thus obliged to content himself with the recovery of his horse, without the pleasure of flogging the finder, into the bargain the old Lycurgus, or rather Draco, of the frontier, set off growling on his return homeward, followed by his brother squatter.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 至于那个年轻的奥塞奇人，我们都对他有先入为主的好感；尤其是年轻的伯爵，他这个年龄及他特有的个性是很自然地就会生出同情心来的，所以伯爵非常地喜欢他。尽管非常不合适，但他一定要那个年轻的奥塞奇人在他进入荒野探险时，做他的同伴和侍从。年轻人是很容易被打动的，而且伯爵告诉他，他可以在野牛出没的大草原上安全地狩猎，还能得到一条新毯子，他便调转缰绳，离开了沼泽地和他身后朋友们的宿营地，跟随着伯爵开始了寻找奥塞奇猎手的游荡之旅。
As for the youthful Osage, we were all prepossessed in his favor; the young Count especially, with the sympathies proper to his age and incident to his character, had taken quite a fancy to him.Nothing would suit but he must have the young Osage as a companion and squire in his expedition into the wilderness.The youth was easily tempted, and, with the prospect of a safe range over the buffalo prairies and the promise of a new blanket, he turned his bridle, left the swamp and the encampment of his friends behind him, and set off to follow the Count in his wanderings in quest of the Osage hunters.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这就是在原始国度里人所具有的辉煌独立性。这个年轻人，带着他的来复枪、毯子及马，没有任何预兆地就准备去闯荡世界了。他随身带着自己在世间的所有财物，没有任何浮华的需求，还拥有着个人自由的伟大奥秘。我们这些文明人是奴隶，既是别人的奴隶，更是自己的奴隶；我们的奢侈品就是捆绑我们的枷锁，它阻碍着我们身体的每一个行动，阻止着我们灵魂的每一次冲动。至少这是我当时的想法。虽然我不确定，但是年轻伯爵的满腔热忱告诉我们，他好像比以前更加沉醉于大草原上狂野的骑士精神，他高谈阔论着和奥塞奇人一起时，他可以穿上印第安人的服装并按印第安人的习俗生活。
Such is the glorious independence of man in a savage state.This youth, with his rifle, his blanket, and his horse, was ready at a moment’s warning to rove the world; he carried all his worldly effects with him, and in the absence of artificial wants, possessed the great secret of personal freedom.We of society are slaves, not so much to others as to ourselves; our superfluities are the chains that bind us, impeding every movement of our bodies and thwarting every impulse of our souls.Such, at least, were my speculations at the time, though I am not sure but that they took their tone from the enthusiasm of the young Count, who seemed more enchanted than ever with the wild chivalry of the prairies, and talked of putting on the Indian dress and adopting the Indian habits during the time he hoped to pass with the Osages.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第六章 奥塞奇猎手的踪迹
CHAPTER VI. TRAIL OF THE OSAGE HUNTERS.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——伯爵及其人马的离开——一个被遗弃的战营——一只流浪狗——营地
—DEPARTURE OF THE COUNT AND HIS PARTY.—A DESERTED WAR CAMP.—A VAGRANT DOG.—THE ENCAMPMENT.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在早上追寻大部队踪迹的过程中，我们发现它与另一条踪迹相交叉，这条踪迹穿过树林朝西，径直向阿肯色河方向延伸。混血儿贝蒂在琢磨了一会儿后宣布，这是奥塞奇猎手的足迹，并且一定是通向他们在去狩猎的途中要涉水过河的地方。
In the course of the morning the trail we were pursuing was crossed by another, which struck off through the forest to the west in a direct course for the Arkansas River.Beatte, our half-breed, after considering it for a moment, pronounced it the trail of the Osage hunters; and that it must lead to the place where they had forded the river on their way to the hunting grounds.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这时，年轻的伯爵和他的同伴停了下来，准备离开我们。队伍当中那些最有经验的边疆居民警告他们：这么做是很危险的。他们将会把自己暴露在荒野中；除了一个年轻无知的混血儿和一个更加年轻的印第安人之外，他们没有任何其他的向导、护卫或随从。他们将要和一匹驮马、两匹向导马一起穿过茂密的森林，越过河流和沼泽，而这些只会为他们带来不便。由于奥塞奇人和波尼族人正在打仗，他们可能落入凶残的敌人波尼族武士手中。另外，他们那么少的人和那么值钱的马，将会对那些游荡在边境上的奥塞奇落队人员构成很大的诱惑。这些奥塞奇人很可能会在晚上抢了他们的马，使他们一无所有地在大草原中徒步前行。
Here then the young Count and his companion came to a halt and prepared to take leave of us.The most experienced frontiersmen in the troop remonstrated on the hazard of the undertaking.They were about to throw themselves loose in the wilderness, with no other guides, guards, or attendants, than a young ignorant half-breed, and a still younger Indian.They were embarrassed by a pack-horse and two led horses, with which they would have to make their way through matted forests, and across rivers and morasses.The Osages and Pawnees were at war, and they might fall in with some warrior party of the latter, who are ferocious foes; besides, their small number, and their valuable horses, would form a great temptation to some of the straggling bands of Osages loitering about the frontier, who might rob them of their horses in the night, and leave them destitute and on foot in the midst of the prairies.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 然而，没有什么能抑制住伯爵要与奥塞奇人一起围猎野牛的浪漫狂热。他有一种游戏精神，似乎总是一想到危险便激动不已。他的同伴到了行事更加谨慎的年龄，个性也更加冷静，他确信这次行动很莽撞，但却不能左右他这位年轻朋友那一时的冲动，而且他又如此忠诚，是不会让他独自去冒险的。因此，我们非常遗憾地看着他们脱离护卫队的保护，踏上他们率性而为的征程。我们队伍中的老猎手们都不住地摇着头，混血儿贝蒂预测着他们会遇到的各种困难。我唯一的希望是：他们将很快就遇到足够多的困惑，以使年轻伯爵冷静下来，并促使他重新加入我们。我们带着这种想法缓慢前进着，中午停留了相当长的一段时间。重新开始征程后，阿肯色河进入了我们的视野。它是一条河面宽阔、水流湍急的河流，边上是沙质细美、长满杨柳和棉白杨的沙滩。越过这条河流，我们的目光便流连在一片美丽的原野上。那里有鲜花盛开的平原，有起伏的山地，其间点缀着一片片的小树林和树丛，还有狭长的森林。整体看上去就像是一片完整的、甚至是精心规划过的耕作地，而不是一片自由生长的原野。河的不远处，在一片空旷的高地上，我们经过了一处刚刚被奥塞奇士兵遗弃的营地。帐篷或者是棚屋的框架还残留着，弯成拱形的杆子两头都插入地面：这些杆子是由粗粗细细的树枝缠绕而成的，上面裹着树皮和兽皮。那些熟知印第安人习性的人，能够凭借棚屋的形状和位置来确定这是哪个部落，以及他们是在狩猎还是在进行战略性远征。贝蒂指给我们看，在营地框架中，哪儿是酋长们围着火堆开会的棚屋，哪儿是被仔细踏平并举行过盛大战斗舞蹈的空地。
Nothing, however, could restrain the romantic ardor of the Count for a campaign of buffalo hunting with the Osages, and he had a game spirit that seemed always stimulated by the idea of danger.His travelling companion, of discreeter age and calmer temperament, was convinced of the rashness of the enterprise; but he could not control the impetuous zeal of his youthful friend, and he was too loyal to leave him to pursue his hazardous scheme alone.To our great regret, therefore, we saw them abandon the protection of our escort, and strike off on their hap-hazard expedition.The old hunters of our party shook their heads, and our half-breed, Beatte, predicted all kinds of trouble to them; my only hope was, that they would soon meet with perplexities enough to cool the impetuosity of the young Count, and induce him to rejoin us.With this idea we travelled slowly, and made a considerable halt at noon.After resuming our march, we came in sight of the Arkansas.It presented a broad and rapid stream, bordered by a beach of fine sand, overgrown with willows and cottonwood-trees.Beyond the river, the eye wandered over a beautiful champaign country, of flowery plains and sloping uplands, diversified by groves and clumps of trees, and long screens of woodland; the whole wearing the aspect of complete, and even ornamental cultivation, instead of native wilfulness.Not far from the river, on an open eminence, we passed through the recently deserted camping place of an Osage war party.The frames of the tents or wigwams remained, consisting of poles bent into an arch, with each end stuck into the ground: these are intertwined with twigs and branches, and covered with bark and skins.Those experienced in Indian lore, can ascertain the tribe, and whether on a hunting or a warlike expedition, by the shape and disposition of the wigwams.Beatte pointed out to us, in the present skeleton camp, the wigwam in which the chiefs had held their consultations around the council-fire; and an open area, well trampled down, on which the grand war-dance had been performed.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的旅程继续着。穿过一个树林时，我们碰到了一只孤苦伶仃、饿得半死的狗。它双眼红肿，神情迷茫地沿着足迹徘徊着。虽然差一点儿就被走在最前面的骑兵踩到，但谁也没能引起它的注意，它依旧在马匹之间随意穿梭着。人们很快就大叫它是“疯狗”，一个骑兵还端起了步枪，但被一贯仁慈的专员阻止了。“它眼睛瞎了！”他说，“它是某个贫穷的印第安人的狗，正在通过气味来追寻它的主人。杀害一个如此忠诚的动物是可耻的。”那个骑兵便扛上了来复枪。狗则踉踉跄跄、毫发无伤地穿过了行进的队伍。它的鼻子一直贴在地上，沿着足迹继续着它的旅程，为我们提供了一个狗对主人忠诚的罕见例子。
Pursuing our journey, as we were passing through a forest, we were met by a forlorn, half-famished dog, who came rambling along the trail, with inflamed eyes, and bewildered look.Though nearly trampled upon by the foremost rangers, he took notice of no one, but rambled heedlessly among the horses.The cry of “mad dog” was immediately raised, and one of the rangers levelled his rifle, but was stayed by the ever-ready humanity of the Commissioner.“He is blind!” said he.“It is the dog of some poor Indian, following his master by the scent.It would be a shame to kill so faithful an animal.”The ranger shouldered his rifle, the dog blundered blindly through the cavalcade unhurt, and keeping his nose to the ground, continued his course along the trail, affording a rare instance of a dog surviving a bad name.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约三点钟时，我们来到了骑兵队最近刚刚离开的营地：一个火堆的木头还在冒烟。根据贝蒂的看法，他们离开还不超过一天。由于旁边有很好的水源和大量马吃的豌豆藤，所以我们当夜就在这儿安营扎寨了。
About three o’clock, we came to a recent camping-place of the company of rangers: the brands of one of their fires were still smoking; so that, according to the opinion of Beatte, they could not have passed on above a day previously.As there was a fine stream of water close by, and plenty of pea-vines for the horses, we encamped here for the night.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们在这里呆了一会儿，便听到远处传来了招呼声，然后就看到年轻的伯爵和他的人马穿过森林向我们这边靠近。我们带着满心的欢喜迎接他们进入帐篷，因为他们当初离开我们去冒险使我们非常不安。一次短暂的实验使他们确信，像他们这种没有经验、带着这么些马和这么少随从的旅行者，穿越荒原是既艰辛而又困难的。幸运的是，他们决定在天黑前重新加入我们。在野外露宿一夜就很有可能使他们失去马匹。伯爵已经成功地说服他提挈的骑士随从——那个年轻的奥塞奇人——继续跟着他，还计划在他的帮助下，在大草原上野牛围猎时获得大量的战利品。
We had not been here long, when we heard a halloo from a distance, and beheld the young Count and his party advancing through the forest.We welcomed them to the camp with heartfelt satisfaction; for their departure upon so hazardous an expedition had caused us great uneasiness.A short experiment had convinced them of the toil and difficulty of inexperienced travellers like themselves making their way through the wilderness with such a train of horses, and such slender attendance.Fortunately, they determined to rejoin us before night-fall; one night’s camping out might have cost them their horses.The Count had prevailed upon his protege and esquire, the young Osage, to continue with him, and still calculated upon achieving great exploits, with his assistance, on the buffalo prairies.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第七章 巡逻骑兵的消息
CHAPTER VII. NEWS OF THE RANGERS.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——伯爵和他的印第安随从——树林中的短暂停留——林中的美景——奥塞奇村庄——我们晚间营地的奥塞奇造访者
—THE COUNT AND HIS INDIAN SQUIRE.—HALT IN THE WOODS.—WOODLAND SCENE.—OSAGE VILLAGE.—OSAGE VISITORS AT OUR EVENING CAMP.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 清晨（10月12日），先前被吉布森要塞的指挥官派出去传达快讯、阻止巡逻骑兵队继续前行的那两个克里克人，在回程途中到达了我们的营地。他们已经让那队人马在大约五十英里以外的地方安营扎寨，等待我们的到达。那是阿肯色境内的一个好地方，猎物充足。这条消息使得我们整队人马都充满了生气。日出时分，我们精神焕发，开始了旅程。
In the morning early (October 12th), the two Creeks who had been sent express by the commander of Fort Gibson, to stop the company of rangers, arrived at our encampment on their return.They had left the company encamped about fifty miles distant, in a fine place on the Arkansas, abounding in game, where they intended to await our arrival.This news spread animation throughout our party, and we set out on our march at sunrise, with renewed spirit.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在骑上马时，年轻的奥塞奇人试图往他的野马背上扔一块毛毯。这匹敏感的良驹受到了惊吓，抬起前蹄往后退了去。这匹野马和这个几乎全裸的野蛮人的姿势，很值得画家或雕刻家好好研究研究。
In mounting our steeds, the young Osage attempted to throw a blanket upon his wild horse.The fine, sensible animal took fright, reared and recoiled.The attitudes of the wild horse and the almost naked savage, would have formed studies for a painter or a statuary.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 行进过程中，一路上看着年轻的伯爵和他新加入的追随者在我前面骑着马，我常常为此而感到高兴。没有比勇敢的骑士配乡绅更合适的了。伯爵的马术精湛，并且正如我之前所注意到的那样，他是一个大胆而高雅的骑手。他也非常喜欢让他的马作半旋转式跳跃及意气风发地飞驰。他的衣服是一套艳丽的印第安鹿皮猎装，裁剪合适，染成了漂亮的紫色，上面绣着精美的各色丝绸，仿佛是某个印第安美女为装扮她心爱的酋长而完成的杰作。为了搭配好衣服，他穿上了皮制马裤和鹿皮靴，戴上了一顶军便帽，斜背着一杆上面挂有子弹带的双管枪。这样一来，当他优雅地骑上那匹精力充沛的坐骑时，他便俊美如画了。
I often pleased myself in the course of our march, with noticing the appearance of the young Count and his newly enlisted follower, as they rode before me.Never was preux chevalier better suited with an esquire.The Count was well mounted, and, as I have before observed, was a bold and graceful rider.He was fond, too, of caracoling his horse, and dashing about in the buoyancy of youthful spirits.His dress was a gay Indian hunting frock of dressed deer skin, setting well to the shape, dyed of a beautiful purple, and fancifully embroidered with silks of various colors; as if it had been the work of some Indian beauty, to decorate a favorite chief.With this he wore leathern pantaloons and moccasons, a foraging cap, and a double-barrelled gun slung by a bandoleer athwart his back: so that he was quite a picturesque figure as he managed gracefully his spirited steed.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 那个年轻的奥塞奇人总是骑着他那匹粗野但很好看的杂色马紧随其后。这匹马身上还有几簇漂亮的深红色鬃毛。他光着英俊的头和健美的上身骑在马背上；毛毯围在腰间。他一手拿着他的来复枪，另一只手驾着马，似乎时刻准备只要警报一响，他就和他的年轻领袖一起冲出去，疯狂地袭击敌人或策马狂奔。伯爵怀着年轻人乐观的期待，计划着我们到波尼人猎场里的野牛群中后，他将在他年轻“勇士”的陪伴下进行许多刺激的探险，收获大量猎物。
The young Osage would ride close behind him on his wild and beautifully mottled horse, which was decorated with crimson tufts of hair.He rode with his finely shaped head and bust naked; his blanket being girt round his waist.He carried his rifle in one hand, and managed his horse with the other, and seemed ready to dash off at a moment’s warning, with his youthful leader, on any madcap foray or scamper.The Count, with the sanguine anticipations of youth, promised himself many hardy adventures and exploits in company with his youthful “brave,” when we should get among the buffaloes, in the Pawnee hunting grounds.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 骑了一段路后，我们穿过了一条狭窄但很深的溪流，溪流上横跨着一座结实的桥。这座桥是年代久远的海狸坝上的遗存。那群辛勤地建造了这堤坝的海狸们已经被猎杀光了。头顶上，一队野鹅高高地在空中飞过，它们喧闹地啼叫着，提醒我们一年又要过去了。
After riding some distance, we crossed a narrow, deep stream, upon a solid bridge, the remains of an old beaver dam; the industrious community which had constructed it had all been destroyed.Above us, a streaming flight of wild geese, high in the air, and making a vociferous noise, gave note of the waning year.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约十点半时，我们在一个长有大量豌豆藤的树林里进行了短暂的停留。在这儿，我们松开缰绳让马吃食。我们生起了一堆火，并从一个邻近的泉眼打了水。不一会儿，法国人小托尼什就给我们准备好了一壶提神用的咖啡。大家正一同分享咖啡的时候，一个老奥塞奇人加入了我们。他是刚刚经过这条路的一小支狩猎队中的一员。他正在寻找他那迷路或者是被偷走的马。当混血儿贝蒂听说奥塞奇猎手们也在这个方向上时，他扮了个苦笑的鬼脸。“在我们超过那些猎手之前，”他说，“我们将不会看到野牛。他们就像草原上的烈火一样，把所有的东西都吓跑。”
About half past ten o’clock we made a halt in a forest, where there was abundance of the pea-vine.Here we turned the horses loose to graze.A fire was made, water procured from an adjacent spring, and in a short time our little Frenchman, Tonish, had a pot of coffee prepared for our refreshment.While partaking of it, we were joined by an old Osage, one of a small hunting party who had recently passed this way.He was in search of his horse, which had wandered away, or been stolen.Our half-breed, Beatte, made a wry face on hearing of Osage hunters in this direction.“Until we pass those hunters,” said he, “we shall see no buffaloes.They frighten away every thing, like a prairie on fire.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 早饭结束后，人们用各种各样的方式消遣着。有些人在用他们的来复枪瞄靶射击；有些人头枕着马鞍，身子半埋在厚厚的落叶中睡觉；还有些人围在树下的火堆旁聊天，树枝间不断冒出一圈圈蓝色的烟。马儿们纵情享用着豌豆藤，有的还躺下来在豌豆藤中间打滚。
The morning repast being over, the party amused themselves in various ways.Some shot with their rifles at a mark, others lay asleep half buried in the deep bed of foliage, with their heads resting on their saddles; others gossiped round the fire at the foot of a tree, which sent up wreaths of blue smoke among the branches.The horses banqueted luxuriously on the pea-vines, and some lay down and rolled amongst them.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们处在高大树木的树阴里。它们拥有笔直光滑的树干，像坚实的柱子一样。偶尔有阳光穿过透明的叶子，给多彩的秋天再微微染上一笔，这使我想起了阳光闪烁在哥特式大教堂的彩色玻璃和一根根柱子之间时所产生的效果。不错，我们宽广的西部森林有一种庄严隆重之感，这唤起了我之前曾在那些令人崇敬的大型建筑物里所经历过的相同的感受。风呼呼地掠过林间，不时地给深呼吸提供新鲜空气。
We were overshadowed by lofty trees, with straight, smooth trunks, like stately columns; and as the glancing rays of the sun shone through the transparent leaves, tinted with the many-colored hues of autumn, I was reminded of the effect of sunshine among the stained windows and clustering columns of a Gothic cathedral.Indeed there is a grandeur and solemnity in our spacious forests of the West, that awaken in me the same feeling I have experienced in those vast and venerable piles, and the sound of the wind sweeping through them, supplies occasionally the deep breathings of the organ.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约中午时，号角将马儿们聚集了起来，我们再一次踏上征程，希望在天黑前到达巡逻骑兵的宿营地。老奥塞奇人向我们保证，我们离那儿不会超过十或十二英里远。当我们穿过一个森林时，经过了一个孤零零的池塘，那上面覆盖着我所见过的最美丽的睡莲，还有几只林鸳鸯在其中游弋。林鸳鸯是水禽中最漂亮的一种,因其优雅和绚丽的羽毛而著称。
About noon the bugle sounded to horse, and we were again on the march, hoping to arrive at the encampment of the rangers before night; as the old Osage had assured us it was not above ten or twelve miles distant.In our course through a forest, we passed by a lonely pool, covered with the most magnificent water-lilies I had ever beheld; among which swam several wood-ducks, one of the most beautiful of water-fowl, remarkable for the gracefulness and brilliancy of its plumage.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 又往前走了一段距离之后，我们来到了阿肯色河的岸边。这儿有大量的马蹄印延伸到水中，表明一队奥塞奇猎手近期刚穿过这条河，前往野牛出没的猎场。让马儿在这条河里喝足水之后，我们继续沿着河岸前进，想找一块空地，接着穿过草原。在草原上，当看到远处的烟时，我们都希望这烟是从巡逻骑兵的帐篷里飘出来的。沿着我们猜测应该是属于他们的足迹，我们来到了一片草地。在那儿，一些马正在吃草，然而它们却不是军队的马。又往前走了一段路之后，我们到达了一个位于阿肯色河河岸上的零散的奥塞奇村落。我们的到来产生了不小的轰动。一些老人走上前来，与我们分别握手，而女人和孩子则挤作一团，一边放肆地盯着我们，一边互相说笑。我们发现村庄里的所有年轻人都离开狩猎去了，只留下妇女、孩子和老人。在这里，专员骑在马背上做了一场演说，告诉他的听众他这次任务的主要目的是促进西部各部落间的共同和平，敦促他们放弃所有尚武和嗜杀的观念，不要肆意向波尼人发动进攻。这场由贝蒂来做翻译的演说，似乎对大多数人有很好的安抚作用。他们信誓旦旦地承诺，在他们的有生之年将不会打破和平。其实，他们的年龄和性别让我们有理由相信他们会信守诺言。
After proceeding some distance farther, we came down upon the banks of the Arkansas, at a place where tracks of numerous horses, all entering the water, showed where a party of Osage hunters had recently crossed the river on their way to the buffalo range.After letting our horses drink in the river, we continued along its bank for a space, and then across prairies, where we saw a distant smoke, which we hoped might proceed from the encampment of the rangers.Following what we supposed to be their trail, we came to a meadow in which were a number of horses grazing: they were not, however, the horses of the troop.A little farther on, we reached a straggling Osage village, on the banks of the Arkansas.Our arrival created quite a sensation.A number of old men came forward and shook hands with us all severally; while the women and children huddled together in groups, staring at us wildly, chattering and laughing among themselves.We found that all the young men of the village had departed on a hunting expedition, leaving the women and children and old men behind.Here the Commissioner made a speech from on horseback; informing his hearers of the purport of his mission, to promote a general peace among the tribes of the West, and urging them to lay aside all warlike and bloodthirsty notions, and not to make any wanton attacks upon the Pawnees.This speech being interpreted by Beatte, seemed to have a most pacifying effect upon the multitude, who promised faithfully that, as far as in them lay, the peace should not be disturbed; and indeed their age and sex gave some reason to trust that they would keep their word.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 因为我们还是希望可以在天黑前到达巡逻骑兵的营地，所以我们不停地赶路，直到黄昏时我们才不得不在溪谷边上停下来。巡逻骑兵们在溪谷尽头的树下露营，我们则在湍急的溪流旁满是岩石的小山上搭起了帐篷。天色慢慢变黑了，乌云在空中翻滚，似乎要下雨了。巡逻骑兵们的篝火在溪谷中烧得正旺，照亮了那些围着火堆做饭、吃饭、喝酒的人们，他们的长相如强盗一般。几个我们经过的村庄里来的奥塞奇印第安访客混杂其中，增添了整个场景的野性之美。他们中的三个人走过了来，在我们的篝火旁坐下。他们看起来像铜质纪念雕像般沉默地观察着周围所发生的一切。我们给了他们食物和他们最喜欢的咖啡。所有的印第安人都很喜欢这种在西部风行的饮料。做好晚饭之后，他们在篝火前肩并肩地舒展开身体，然后开始用鼻子哼起了圣歌，用手敲打着胸膛作为伴奏的鼓点。他们的圣歌好像是由一句句齐整的诗句组成，没有悦耳的调子，而是以突兀的感叹词“哼”结尾，听起来就像打嗝。翻译贝蒂告诉我们,这首圣歌与我们有关：我们的长相、对待他们的方式，以及他们对我们的计划所知道的一切。其中他们还提到了年轻的伯爵，他活泼的个性和对印第安知识的渴望都让他们感到高兴。于是他们诙谐地编造了他和印第安美女的故事，这在我们的混血儿看来很好玩。
Still hoping to reach the camp of the rangers before nightfall, we pushed on until twilight, when we were obliged to halt on the borders of a ravine.The rangers bivouacked under trees, at the bottom of the dell, while we pitched our tent on a rocky knoll near a running stream.The night came on dark and overcast, with flying clouds, and much appearance of rain.The fires of the rangers burnt brightly in the dell, and threw strong masses of light upon the robber-looking groups that were cooking, eating, and drinking around them.To add to the wildness of the scene, several Osage Indians, visitors from the village we had passed, were mingled among the men.Three of them came and seated themselves by our fire.They watched every thing that was going on around them in silence, and looked like figures of monumental bronze.We gave them food, and, what they most relished, coffee; for the Indians partake in the universal fondness for this beverage, which pervades the West.When they had made their supper, they stretched themselves, side by side, before the fire, and began a low nasal chant, drumming with their hands upon their breasts, by way of accompaniment.Their chant seemed to consist of regular staves, every one terminating, not in a melodious cadence, but in the abrupt interjection huh! uttered almost like a hiccup.This chant, we were told by our interpreter, Beatte, related to ourselves, our appearance, our treatment of them, and all that they knew of our plans.In one part they spoke of the young Count, whose animated character and eagerness for Indian enterprise had struck their fancy, and they indulged in some waggery about him and the young Indian beauties, that produced great merriment among our half-breeds.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这种即兴创作的方式在原始部落是很普遍的，正是以这种方式，配上一些简单的抑扬顿挫的声调，他们唱遍了所有战争和狩猎中的战利品。印第安人比我想象中更频繁地使用幽默和诙谐。
This mode of improvising is common throughout the savage tribes; and in this way, with a few simple inflections of the voice, they chant all their exploits in war and hunting, and occasionally indulge in a vein of comic humor and dry satire, to which the Indians appear to me much more prone than is generally imagined.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 实际上，我有幸在现实生活中所见到的印第安人和诗歌中描绘的很不一样。他们一点儿也不是那种沉默寡言、不懂变通、没有泪水和欢笑的恬淡寡欢之人。和白人一起时，他们确实是沉默寡言的，因为他们不相信对方的好意，也不明白对方的语言，但白人在这种情形下也同样很沉默。然而，当印第安人在他们自己人中间时，就再也没有人比他们更能聊了。他们一半的时间用来讲述自己在打仗和狩猎时的奇遇及古怪可笑的故事。他们是伟大的模仿者和滑稽演员，善于以模仿与他们交往的白人为乐。而那些白人还以为他们是被自己的庄严及尊贵深深折服了呢！他们还是好奇的观察者，默默地打量着一切，目光敏锐而机警。当有什么特别的东西吸引了他们的注意力时，他们会时不时地互相交换目光或嘀咕几句，不过会把所有的评论留到只剩下自己人时再说。到那时，他们就会给出全面的见解：批评、讽刺、模仿，以及欢笑。
In fact, the Indians that I have had an opportunity of seeing in real life are quite different from those described in poetry.They are by no means the stoics that they are represented, taciturn, unbending, without a tear or a smile.Taciturn they are, it is true, when in company with white men, whose goodwill they distrust, and whose language they do not understand; but the white man is equally taciturn under like circumstances.When the Indians are among themselves, however, there cannot be greater gossips.Half their time is taken up in talking over their adventures in war and hunting, and in telling whimsical stories.They are great mimics and buffoons, also, and entertain themselves excessively at the expense of the whites with whom they have associated, and who have supposed them impressed with profound respect for their grandeur and dignity.They are curious observers, noting every thing in silence, but with a keen and watchful eye; occasionally exchanging a glance or a grunt with each other, when any thing particularly strikes them: but reserving all comments until they are alone.Then it is that they give full scope to criticism, satire, mimicry, and mirth.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在边境上的旅程中，我曾多次感受到他们对自己的狩猎活动的狂热和兴奋，也不时注意到一伙奥塞奇人围在篝火旁，沉浸在最热烈生动的谈话中，直到深夜，他们的笑声还不时地在树林中回荡。至于说泪水，他们有着丰富的储量，有的真诚，有的做作；有时他们也会利用泪水。没有人比他们在亲人或朋友死去时哭得更伤心、更强烈了，他们有固定的时间去墓前悼念哀哭。我曾经在黎明时听到邻近的印第安村落传来的伤心的哭泣声。一些当地居民在那个时刻去墓地为死者凭吊哭泣。我得知，在这种时候，泪水将会像溪流一样沿着他们的脸颊流下。
In the course of my journey along the frontier, I have had repeated opportunities of noticing their excitability and boisterous merriment at their games; and have occasionally noticed a group of Osages sitting round a fire until a late hour of the night, engaged in the most animated and lively conversation; and at times making the woods resound with peals of laughter.As to tears, they have them in abundance, both real and affected; at times they make a merit of them.No one weeps more bitterly or profusely at the death of a relative or friend: and they have stated times when they repair to howl and lament at their graves.I have heard doleful wailings at daybreak, in the neighboring Indian villages, made by some of the inhabitants, who go out at that hour into the fields, to mourn and weep for the dead: at such times, I am told, the tears will stream down their cheeks in torrents.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在我看来，印第安人之于诗意的故事就如牧羊人之于田园传奇一样，都只是想象力的化身罢了。
As far as I can judge, the Indian of poetical fiction is like the shepherd of pastoral romance, a mere personification of imaginary attributes.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的奥塞奇客人们那带着鼻音的圣歌渐渐停止了，他们用毛毯盖着头，很快便睡着了。不一会儿，除了散落的雨滴拍打帐篷的声音之外，一切都归于寂静。
The nasal chant of our Osage guests gradually died away; they covered their heads with their blankets and fell fast asleep, and in a little while all was silent, except the pattering of scattered rain-drops upon our tent.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 早上，印第安访客们和我们一起吃了早餐，但是那个将成为伯爵的骑士侍从，跟他一起在大草原上行侠仗义的奥塞奇青年却不见了。他的野马也不见了。经过一番猜测之后，我们得出了这样的结论：他在夜里以“印第安方式”离开了我们。我们后来确信，是最近碰到的那些奥塞奇人劝他这样做的。他们向他描绘了他去波尼人的猎场探险时可能会遇到的危险：在那儿，他可能会落入他部落的死对头手中；更不难想到的是，他将会受到白人们反复无常的专横行为的困扰。在我为期不长的旅程中，我就亲眼见过有些白人对待可怜的印第安人比对待野蛮的动物好不了多少。实际上，他自己就已经有过一次这种艰难逃脱的经历：因为找到一匹走失的马这样一桩“罪大恶极”的罪行，他差点儿被那个拼命眨眼的边疆开拓者根据“林奇的律法”对他施以极刑。
In the morning our Indian visitors breakfasted with us, but the young Osage who was to act as esquire to the Count in his knight-errantry on the prairies, was nowhere to be found.His wild horse, too, was missing, and, after many conjectures, we came to the conclusion that he had taken “Indian leave” of us in the night.We afterwards ascertained that he had been persuaded so to do by the Osages we had recently met with; who had represented to him the perils that would attend him in an expedition to the Pawnee hunting grounds, where he might fall into the hands of the implacable enemies of his tribe; and, what was scarcely less to be apprehended, the annoyances to which he would be subjected from the capricious and overbearing conduct of the white men; who, as I have witnessed in my own short experience, are prone to treat the poor Indians as little better than brute animals.Indeed, he had had a specimen of it himself in the narrow escape he made from the infliction of “Lynch’s law,” by the hard-winking worthy of the frontier, for the flagitious crime of finding a stray horse.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这个年轻人的离开令我们整队的人都感到遗憾，因为我们都很喜欢他英俊、坦率、有男子气概的外表与平和优雅的举止。他实在是个天生的绅士。然而，没有人比年轻的伯爵更伤心的了，他突然发现自己没了侍从。我因那个奥塞奇人的离开为他本人感到可惜，因为我们本应在整个行程中善待他，并且我也相信，从他庇护人的慷慨品德来看，他本可以带着大量的财宝和印第安毛毯回到他的部落的。
The disappearance of the youth was generally regretted by our party, for we had all taken a great fancy to him from his handsome, frank, and manly appearance, and the easy grace of his deportment.He was indeed a native-born gentleman.By none, however, was he so much lamented as by the young Count, who thus suddenly found himself deprived of his esquire.I regretted the departure of the Osage for his own sake, for we should have cherished him throughout the expedition, and I am convinced, from the munificent spirit of his patron, he would have returned to his tribe laden with wealth of beads and trinkets and Indian blankets.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第八章 欢快的营地
CHAPTER VIII. THE HONEY CAMP.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 下了一晚上的雨终于停了。早上七点钟，我们重新开始了征程，满心相信可以很快就会到达巡逻骑兵的营地。我们骑了不到三四英里，就来到了一棵最近刚刚被斧子砍倒的大树旁，因为这树干的洞里有野蜂蜜，还有一些蜂蜜残片。我们现在确定巡逻骑兵的营地就在不远处。又前进了大约两英里后，几个巡逻骑兵喊叫起来,用手指着一群在林木葱郁的谷底吃草的野马。再走几步我们便来到了一道凸起的山脊的顶部，从这里俯瞰，我们看到了营地。它像是一个杂乱的强盗窝，或是罗宾汉式绿林好汉的地盘。在一个美丽而开阔的森林里，一条小溪缓缓流过之处，有一些用树皮和树干搭就的小屋和毛毯做的帐篷，这些都是因最近的雨而搭建的临时避难所，因为巡逻骑兵一般是露营的。不同的巡逻骑兵穿着各式各样的粗糙的衣服。有些人正在树下生的大堆大堆的火上做饭，有些人在铺展整理鹿皮，有些人在对靶射击，还有些人躺在草地上。营地的一侧有一些切成长条、挂在火堆上方用余火烘烤着的鹿肉；另一侧则放着猎人们最近刚刚带回来的猎物尸体。一堆堆的来复枪靠在树干上，马鞍、马笼头和火药筒都挂在树上，而马儿们则在灌木丛中四处吃着草。
The weather, which had been rainy in the night, having held up, we resumed our march at seven o’clock in the morning, in confident hope of soon arriving at the encampment of the rangers.We had not ridden above three or four miles when we came to a large tree which had recently been felled by an axe, for the wild honey contained in the hollow of its trunk, several broken flakes of which still remained.We now felt sure that the camp could not be far distant.About a couple of miles further some of the rangers set up a shout, and pointed to a number of horses grazing in a woody bottom.A few paces brought us to the brow of an elevated ridge, whence we looked down upon the encampment.It was a wild bandit, or Robin Hood, scene.In a beautiful open forest, traversed by a running stream, were booths of bark and branches, and tents of blankets, temporary shelters from the recent rain, for the rangers commonly bivouac in the open air.There were groups of rangers in every kind of uncouth garb.Some were cooking at large fires made at the feet of trees; some were stretching and dressing deer skins; some were shooting at a mark, and some lying about on the grass.Venison jerked, and hung on frames, was drying over the embers in one place; in another lay carcasses recently brought in by the hunters.Stacks of rifles were leaning against the trunks of the trees, and saddles, bridles, and powder-horns hanging above them, while the horses were grazing here and there among the thickets.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他们热烈欢迎我们的到来。那些巡逻骑兵们围着他们的同伴询问来自要塞的消息，而我们则受到了比恩上校直率简朴的猎人式的接待。他是这支队伍的队长，四十岁上下，充满了活力。他一生中大部分的时光是在边疆上度过的，偶尔参加一些印第安人的战争，所以他是一个完完全全的林中人，是一个一流的猎手。他的穿着很符合自己的性格：皮猎装、皮绑腿，还有一顶皮的军便帽。
Our arrival was greeted with acclamation.The rangers crowded about their comrades to inquire the news from the fort; for our own part, we were received in frank simple hunter’s style by Captain Bean, the commander of the company; a man about forty years of age, vigorous and active.His life had been chiefly passed on the frontier, occasionally in Indian warfare, so that he was a thorough woodsman, and a first-rate hunter.He was equipped in character; in leathern hunting shirt and leggings, and a leathern foraging cap.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们正在和队长交谈的时候，一个老练的猎手走了过来，他的模样让我吃了一惊。他中等身材，但是却强壮结实、饱经风霜；头顶有点儿秃，稀稀拉拉地点缀着一绺绺铁灰色的发卷；一只明亮的黑眼睛闪烁着青春的光芒。他的穿着和队长的差不多，看上去显然是经久耐用的鹿皮制猎衣和绑腿；一个火药筒挂在身旁，一把猎刀别在腰带上，手里拿着一只古老但值得信任的来复枪，毫无疑问，这枪就像一个知心朋友那样珍贵。他请求去打猎，并马上就得到了批准。“那人是老赖安，”他走之后队长说，“这个营地里没有比他更好的猎手了，他肯定会带回猎物的。”
While we were conversing with the Captain, a veteran huntsman approached, whose whole appearance struck me.He was of the middle size, but tough and weather-proved; a head partly bald and garnished with loose iron-gray locks, and a fine black eye, beaming with youthful spirit.His dress was similar to that of the Captain, a rifle shirt and leggings of dressed deer skin, that had evidently seen service; a powder-horn was slung by his side, a hunting-knife stuck in his belt, and in his hand was an ancient and trusty rifle, doubtless as dear to him as a bosom friend.He asked permission to go hunting, which was readily granted.“That’s old Ryan,” said the Captain, when he had gone; “there’s not a better hunter in the camp; he’s sure to bring in game.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一会儿的工夫，我们便卸完了驮马背上的东西，放它们在豌豆藤中休息了。我们支起帐篷，生起火，队长那边送来半只鹿，贝蒂也带来两只野火鸡；烤肉叉上插满了肉，露营用的水壶里也塞满了肉；为了使我们的奢侈享受更为圆满，一个巡逻骑兵送来满满一盆美味的大片蜂蜜，那可是从一棵蜜蜂树上掠夺来的。
In a little while our pack-horses were unloaded and turned loose to revel among the pea-vines.Our tent was pitched; our fire made; the half of a deer had been sent to us from the Captain’s lodge; Beatte brought in a couple of wild turkeys; the spits were laden, and the camp-kettle crammed with meat; and to crown our luxuries, a basin filled with great flakes of delicious honey, the spoils of a plundered bee-tree, was given us by one of the rangers.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的小个子法国人托尼什异常兴奋，袖子撸到胳膊肘上，开始施展自己的厨艺。对此他可是很骄傲，就像对自己打猎、骑马和打仗都技艺高超感到骄傲一样。
Our little Frenchman, Tonish, was in an ecstasy, and tucking up his sleeves to the elbows, set to work to make a display of his culinary skill, on which he prided himself almost as much as upon his hunting, his riding, and his warlike prowess.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第九章 采蜜
CHAPTER IX. A BEE HUNT.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们宿营的美丽森林里有大量的蜜蜂树,也就是有许多野蜜蜂在腐朽的树干里筑巢的树。令人惊讶的是，不计其数的蜜蜂群仅仅在短短的几年时间里，就遍布了整个远西区。印第安人把它们看成是白人的预兆，并且还说，蜜蜂进多少，印第安人就会退多少。我们通常习惯于把嗡嗡作响的蜂巢和农舍或花园联系起来，把这些勤劳的小动物和繁忙的人类居住地联想在一起。我听说这种野蜜蜂在距离边疆很远的地方是很难碰到的。它们已经成为了文明的预兆。自从文明从大西洋岸边推进以来，它们便始终走在文明之前。在蜜蜂首次越过密西西比河那年，有些西部的老居民就在假装感恩了。印第安人惊讶地发现，他们树林中那些腐朽不堪的树里突然间都注满了芬芳的甜蜜。我还听说，没有任何感觉能超越他们第一次奢侈地享用这种免费野味时所引起的贪婪食欲。
The beautiful forest in which we were encamped abounded in bee-trees; that is to say, trees in the decayed trunks of which wild bees had established their hives.It is surprising in what countless swarms the bees have overspread the Far West, within but a moderate number of years.The Indians consider them the harbinger of the white man; and say that, in proportion as the bee advances, the Indian  retire.We are always accustomed to associate the hum of the bee-hive with the farmhouse and flower-garden, and to consider those industrious little animals as connected with the busy haunts of man, and I am told that the wild bee is seldom to be met with at any great distance from the frontier.They have been the heralds of civilization, steadfastly preceding it as it advanced from the Atlantic borders, and some of the ancient settlers of the West pretend to give the very year when the honey-bee first crossed the Mississippi.The Indians with surprise found the mouldering trees of their forests suddenly teeming with ambrosial sweets, and nothing, I am told, can exceed the greedy relish with which they banquet for the first time upon this unbought luxury of the wilderness.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 目前，不计其数的蜜蜂群穿梭于位于大草原边缘或纵横交错于草原之上、延伸到河流尽头冲击河床上的果树林和森林之中。在我看来，这些美丽的地区恰是应了那句对“希望之地”的描述：“流淌着牛奶和蜂蜜的土地”，因为大草原上富足的牧场足以容纳像沙滩上的沙子一样数不胜数的牧群，而花朵则给草原施上了珐琅釉，把它变成了蜜蜂采撷花蜜的天堂。
At present the honey-bee swarms in myriads, in the noble groves and forests which skirt and intersect the prairies, and extend along the alluvial bottoms of the rivers.It seems to me as if these beautiful regions answer literally to the description of the land of promise, “a land flowing with milk and honey;” for the rich pasturage of the prairies is calculated to sustain herds of cattle as countless as the sands upon the seashore, while the flowers with which they are enamelled render them a very paradise for the nectar-seeking bee.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们才在营帐里呆了一小会儿，便有一队人马要出发去找蜜蜂树了。我对这种活动很好奇，很想亲眼目睹一下，于是便欣然答应他们的邀请，同他们一起去。这支队伍由一个采蜜老手和他的搭档带领着：前者是一个有着瘦高身材的家伙，穿着松松垮垮地围在四肢周围的土布衣服，头戴一个与蜂窝像极了的草帽；后者同样穿着粗糙，却没戴帽子，走起路来八字脚，肩上扛着一支长长的来复枪。之后跟着的六七个人，有的带着斧子，有的带着来复枪。为了对付野熊或印第安野人，人们离开营地时都会带上家伙。
We had not been long in the camp when a party set out in quest of a bee-tree; and, being curious to witness the sport, I gladly accepted an invitation to accompany them.The party was headed by a veteran bee-hunter, a tall lank fellow in homespun garb that hung loosely about his limbs, and a straw hat shaped not unlike a bee-hive; a comrade, equally uncouth in garb, and without a hat, straddled along at his heels, with a long rifle on his shoulder.To these succeeded half a dozen others, some with axes and some with rifles, for no one stirs far from the camp without his firearms, so as to be ready either for wild deer or wild Indian.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 走了一段路之后，我们来到了树林边缘一块开阔的沼泽地。在这儿，我们的领头人停了下来，悄悄地赶到了一处低矮的灌木丛下。我发现树丛的上方就是一个蜂巢。我发现的这个蜂巢其实是对野蜜蜂的诱饵。有好几只都在围着它嗡嗡地飞舞，然后冲进小巢。当往自己身上装满蜜之后，它们便飞到空中，然后像出膛的子弹一样，以极快的速度笔直地飞去。猎手们仔细观察着它们所走的路线，然后沿着同样的方向前进，在盘根错节的树根和倒伏的树木之间艰难地蹒跚而行，眼睛还要望着空中。用这种方法，他们跟着带蜜的蜜蜂来到了它们的老巢。这个巢在一棵被蛀空了的橡树树干里，它们在巢的周围嗡嗡地飞了一阵子之后，便钻入了一个离地大约六十英寸的洞里。
After proceeding some distance we came to an open glade on the skirts of the forest.Here our leader halted, and then advanced quietly to a low bush, on the top of which I perceived a piece of honey-comb.This I found was the bait or lure for the wild bees.Several were humming about it, and diving into its cells.When they had laden themselves with honey, they would rise into the air, and dart off in a straight line, almost with the velocity of a bullet.The hunters watched attentively the course they took, and then set off in the same direction, stumbling along over twisted roots and fallen trees, with their eyes turned up to the sky.In this way they traced the honey-laden bees to their hive, in the hollow trunk of a blasted oak, where, after buzzing about for a moment, they entered a hole about sixty feet from the ground.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 此刻，两个采蜜人开始用斧子起劲地砍树的底端，以便把它放倒。同时，所有的旁观者和生手都远远地躲到安全处，以防被倒下的树砸到或遭到里面居民的报复。沉重的砍树声好像并没有惊动或打扰这个最勤劳的群体。它们继续从事着日常工作，有的满载着货物进港，有的匆忙地踏上新的旅程，就好像都市中为钱忙碌的众多商人一样，几乎没有一只蜜蜂意识到即将来临的破产和倒闭。甚至一声宣告树干断裂的巨响，也没能把它们的注意力从那强烈地追求所获得之物的层面上引开。最终大树轰然倒下，从头到尾裂开，把贮藏的所有“公共财宝”展露无遗。
Two of the bee-hunters now plied their axes vigorously at the foot of the tree to level it with the ground.The mere spectators and amateurs, in the meantime, drew off to a cautious distance, to be out of the way of the falling of the tree and the vengeance of its inmates.The jarring blows of the axe seemed to have no effect in alarming or disturbing this most industrious community.They continued to ply at their usual occupations, some arriving full freighted into port, others sallying forth on new expeditions, like so many merchantmen in a money-making metropolis, little suspicious of impending bankruptcy and downfall.Even a loud crack which announced the disrupture of the trunk, failed to divert their attention from the intense pursuit of gain; at length down came the tree with a tremendous crash, bursting open from end to end, and displaying all the hoarded treasures of the commonwealth.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一个猎手马上手执一束点着的干草跑上前去，以防止蜜蜂的攻击。然而，蜜蜂们却没有采取任何攻击行动，也没有寻求报复；它们似乎震惊于这突如其来的灾难，一点儿也没怀疑它的起因，只是继续在废墟上爬动嗡叫，而没有来侵害我们。此刻，每一个队员都过来用勺子和猎刀来挖取出树洞里储存的片状蜂蜜。其中的一些蜜片时间久远，已经变成了深棕色，其他的则是迷人的白色；而蜂巢孔穴中的蜜则几乎是透明的。那些完整的巢穴，被放在了锅里带回营地；而那些树干倒落时破碎了的蜜片，当场就被狼吞虎咽地吃掉了。每一个健壮的采蜜人手里都有一张厚厚的蜜片，手指间滴着蜜汁；它们很快便消失了，其速度就像是逢年过节时，胃口大开的学童吃掉面前的奶油果馅饼一样。
