One of the hunters immediately ran up with a wisp of lighted hay as a defence against the bees.The latter, however, made no attack and sought no revenge; they seemed stupefied by the catastrophe and unsuspicious of its cause, and remained crawling and buzzing about the ruins without offering us any molestation.Every one of the party now fell to, with spoon and hunting-knife, to scoop out the flakes of honey-comb with which the hollow trunk was stored.Some of them were of old date and a deep brown color, others were beautifully white, and the honey in their cells was almost limpid.Such of the combs as were entire were placed in camp kettles to be conveyed to the encampment; those which had been shivered in the fall were devoured upon the spot.Every stark bee-hunter was to be seen with a rich morsel in his hand, dripping about his fingers, and disappearing as rapidly as a cream tart before the holiday appetite of a schoolboy.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 不仅仅是采蜜人从这个倒台的勤劳的群体中受益，蜜蜂们好像也和这些费力获益的人有着相同的习性。我看到许多邻近蜂巢的蜜蜂，急切地扇着翅膀匆匆而来，在邻居的废墟上大捞一把。它们如那些被迫靠岸的印度贸易船上的众多毁船打劫者般，热切、兴奋地忙于抢劫，一头扎入破碎蜂巢的孔穴中，在战利品上贪婪地饱餐一顿，然后挥动着翅膀满载而归。至于那些可怜的废墟主人们，它们似乎没有心情做任何事情，甚至不曾品尝流淌在它们身边的花蜜，而只是前前后后地爬动着，茫然凄凉，就像是我见过的一个可怜的家伙。他站在烧毁的家园旁，双手插在兜里，茫然而沮丧地吹着口哨。
Nor was it the bee-hunters alone that profited by the downfall of this industrious community; as if the bees would carry through the similitude of their habits with those of laborious and gainful man, I beheld numbers from rival hives, arriving on eager wing, to enrich themselves with the ruins of their neighbors.These busied themselves as eagerly and cheerfully as so many wreckers on an Indiaman that has been driven on shore; plunging into the cells of the broken honey-combs, banqueting greedily on the spoil, and then winging their way full-freighted to their homes.As to the poor proprietors of the ruin, they seemed to have no heart to do any thing, not even to taste the nectar that flowed around them; but crawled backward and forward, in vacant desolation, as I have seen a poor fellow with his hands in his pockets, whistling vacantly and despondingly about the ruins of his house that had been burnt.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 那些蜂巢坍塌时不在家的蜜蜂们，现在接二连三地满载着远方的货物回来了，而它们的慌张和迷惑是难以描述的。起初，它们在空中盘旋，愕然地发现这棵倒下的树原本昂着头的地方已经空空如也了。最终，他们似乎是理解了灾难的降临，于是一群群地降落在附近一棵树的干树枝上，好像是在从那里打量这一卧倒的遗址，并嗡嗡地对自己王国的沦陷进行忧伤的悼念。此刻，这倒成了“忧郁的雅克”前来说教的场景。
It is difficult to describe the bewilderment and confusion of the bees of the bankrupt hive who had been absent at the time of the catastrophe, and who arrived from time to time, with full cargoes from abroad.At first they wheeled about in the air, in the place where the fallen tree had once reared its head, astonished at finding it all a vacuum.At length, as if comprehending their disaster, they settled down in clusters on a dry branch of a neighboring tree, whence they seemed to contemplate the prostrate ruin, and to buzz forth doleful lamentations over the downfall of their republic.It was a scene on which the “melancholy Jacques” might have moralized by the hour.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 现在，我们离开了那个地方，树干里还残留着大量的蜂蜜。“它会被害兽收拾干净的。”一个巡逻骑兵说。我问：“什么害兽？”“哦，熊啊，臭鼬啊，浣熊啊，还有负鼠。熊是世界上最会找蜂蜜树的害兽。它们会一起连续几天啃树干，直到啃出一个足够伸进爪子的洞，然后把蜂蜜、蜜蜂，以及所有的一切全部弄出来。”
We now abandoned the place, leaving much honey in the hollow of the tree.“It will all be cleared off by varmint,” said one of the rangers.“What vermin?” asked I.“Oh, bears, and skunks, and racoons, and ’possums.The bears is the knowingest varmint for finding out a bee-tree in the world.They’ll gnaw for days together at the trunk till they make a bole big enough to get in their paws, and then they’ll haul out honey, bees and all.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第十章 营地里的娱乐
CHAPTER X. AMUSEMENTS IN THE CAMP.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——商议——猎人们的食物与盛宴——夜景——营地上的乐曲——爱好音乐的猫头鹰的命运
—CONSULTATIONS.—HUNTERS’ FARE AND FEASTING.—EVENING SCENES.—CAMP MELODY.—THE FATE OF AN AMATEUR OWL.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 等回到营地，我们发现那里是一片欢乐的景象。有些巡逻骑兵在打靶射击，其余的则在跳跃、摔跤、玩各式各样的游戏。他们大多数是第一次出来远征的年轻人，拥有健康的体魄、充沛的精力和意料之中的活泼。并且，除了野外的丛林生活、壮丽无垠的旷野、数不清的猎物和满载而归的探险，我想不出更能使年轻人热血沸腾的了。我们往往把年轻人送到国外，让他们在欧洲过一种奢华而娇气的生活。这让我想到，一次大草原之旅将更有可能培养人刚毅、朴实和独立的品质，尤其能使他们和我们的政治制度保持一致。
On returning to the camp, we found it a scene of the greatest hilarity.Some of the rangers were shooting at a mark, others were leaping, wrestling, and playing at prison bars.They were mostly young men, on their first expedition, in high health and vigor, and buoyant with anticipations; and I can conceive nothing more likely to set the youthful blood into a flow, than a wild wood life of the kind, and the range of a magnificent wilderness, abounding with game, and fruitful of adventure.We send our youth abroad to grow luxurious and effeminate in Europe; it appears to me, that a previous tour on the prairies would be more likely to produce that manliness, simplicity, and self-dependence, most in unison with our political institutions.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 当年轻人沉浸于这些喧闹的游戏中时，一组由队长、医生、其他德高望重的智者及营地的首领组成的小组，正围着一张边境地图或坐或躺在草地上，商讨着我们的位置及接下来的行程。
While the young men were engaged in these boisterous amusements, a graver set, composed of the Captain, the Doctor, and other sages and leaders of the camp, were seated or stretched out on the grass, round a frontier map, holding a consultation about our position, and the course we were to pursue.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的计划是从雷德福克河汇入阿肯色河处穿过阿肯色河，然后继续向西，直到穿过一处叫“十字木林”的开阔疏林带——它几乎是一直从北面的阿肯色河延伸到南面的雷德河——之后，我们将向南前往雷德河。
Our plan was to cross the Arkansas just above where the Red Fork falls into it, then to keep westerly, until we should pass through a grand belt of open forest, called the Cross Timber, which ranges nearly north and south from the Arkansas to Red River; after which, we were to keep a southerly course toward the latter river.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们那经验丰富的奥塞奇猎手，混血儿贝蒂，也被邀请过去参加讨论。“你曾经在这个地方狩过猎吗？”队长问。“是的。”他简洁地回答说。
Our half-breed, Beatte, being an experienced Osage hunter, was called into the consultation.“Have you ever hunted in this direction?” said the Captain.“Yes,” was the laconic reply.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那也许，你能够告诉我们雷德福克河在哪个方位？”
“Perhaps, then, you can tell us in which direction lies the Red Fork?”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “如果你们沿着大草原的边缘行走，将会到达一座光秃秃的、有一大堆石头的小山。”
“If you keep along yonder, by the edge of the prairie, you will come to a bald hill, with a pile of stones upon it.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “我打猎的时候注意到过那座山。”队长说道。
“I have noticed that hill as I was hunting,” said the Captain.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “对啊！那些石头是奥塞奇人堆到那儿用来作路标的：从那儿你们就有可能看到雷德福克河了。”
“Well! those stones were set up by the Osages as a landmark: from that spot you may have a sight of the Red Fork.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那样的话，”队长叫道，“我们明天就能到达雷德福克河，然后穿过它前面的阿肯色河，进入波尼族人的领地，接下来两天之内我们就可以去砸碎野牛的骨头了！”
“In that case,” cried the Captain, “we shall reach the Red Fork to-morrow; then cross the Arkansas above it, into the Pawnee country, and then in two days we shall crack buffalo bones!”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一想到马上就要到达波尼族人充满危险的猎场，以及即将出现的野牛的行踪，他们的眼睛里就都闪烁出了兴奋的光芒。我们进一步的谈话被营地不远处一声刺耳的来复枪响给打断了。
The idea of arriving at the adventurous hunting grounds of the Pawnees, and of coming upon the traces of the buffaloes, made every eye sparkle with animation.Our further conversation was interrupted by the sharp report of a rifle at no great distance from the camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那是老瑞安的来复枪，”队长呼喊道，“我敢担保，一只雄鹿倒下了。”他说得不错，因为没过多久，那个老手就出现了。他叫了一个年轻点儿的巡逻骑兵和他一起回去帮忙抬回猎物。
“That’s old Ryan’s rifle,” exclaimed the Captain; “there’s a buck down, I’ll warrant!”Nor was he mistaken; for, before long, the veteran made his appearance, calling upon one of the younger rangers to return with him, and aid in bringing home the carcass.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 事实上，周围到处都是猎物，所以营地的食物多得吃不完，而且附近至少已经砍倒二十棵蜂蜜树了，所以每个人都陶醉于这奢侈的生活之中。由于猎人式的挥霍浪费，酒宴持续不断地举行着，几乎没有人为明天储备给养。烹饪是以猎人们的方式进行的：将肉穿在尖锐的、笔直地插进土里的山茱萸枝上，使它们能连在一起在火前烤。这样烤肉，肉汁会全部保存在肉里。用这种方式烤出来的肉，即使是尝遍山珍海味的美食家也会垂涎三尺。至于做面包的诸多好方法也无法细说了。不过就是将面粉和水混在一起的面团剁碎了在猪油里炸，也有些人采取了一种更野蛮的方式：把面团绕在棍子的一头，然后在火上烤。我发现，在大草原上用这两种方式做出来的面包都非常美味。一个人只有吃过了猎人们的食物之后，才知道什么是人间真正的美味。
The surrounding country, in fact, abounded with game, so that the camp was overstocked with provisions, and, as no less than twenty bee-trees had been cut down in the vicinity, every one revelled in luxury.With the wasteful prodigality of hunters, there was a continual feasting, and scarce any one put by provision for the morrow.The cooking was conducted in hunter’s style: the meat was stuck upon tapering spits of dogwood, which were thrust perpendicularly into the ground, so as to sustain the joint before the fire, where it was roasted or broiled with all its juices retained in it in a manner that would have tickled the palate of the most experienced gourmand.As much could not be said in favor of the bread.It was little more than a paste made of flour and water, and fried like fritters, in lard; though some adopted a ruder style, twisting it round the ends of sticks, and thus roasting it before the fire.In either way, I have found it extremely palatable on the prairies.No one knows the true relish of food until he has a hunter’s appetite.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 太阳下山前，我们被小托尼什请去参加一个奢华的宴会。毛毯已经围着篝火铺好了，我们在上面坐了下来。我们面前的地上摆着从印第安村庄买来的用枫树根做成的大盘，或者说是大碗，里面装了整整一大锅的东西，有切碎的野火鸡肉、一片片的熏肉及一块块的面团。它旁边还放着另一个相似的碗一样的器皿，里面有很多油炸馅饼。我们聊了一阵火鸡肉之后，小托尼什拿过来两个木制的烤肉叉插在我们面前的地上，上面是在火前烤好的肥美的雄鹿肋排肉，空气里弥漫着令人喜悦的肉香。由于没有盘子，我们不得不像猎人那样，用猎刀把肉成条或成片地切下来，然后蘸上盐和胡椒粉来吃。为了公正地评价托尼什的厨艺和大草原上美味调料，我想说的是，我从没有吃过这么鲜美的鹿肉。我们就着这些食物喝的饮料是在野营用的水壶里煮的咖啡。我们在咖啡里面加了红糖，装在锡杯里喝。只要食物供给充分，只要面粉、咖啡和糖还可以维持供应，这就是我们整个探险过程中典型的宴会。
Before sunset, we were summoned by little Tonish to a sumptuous repast.Blankets had been spread on the ground near to the fire, upon which we took our seats.A large dish, or bowl, made from the root of a maple tree, and which we had purchased at the Indian village, was placed on the ground before us, and into it were emptied the contents of one of the camp kettles, consisting of a wild turkey hashed, together with slices of bacon and lumps of dough.Beside it was placed another bowl of similar ware, containing an ample supply of fritters.After we had discussed the hash, two wooden spits, on which the ribs of a fat buck were broiling before the fire, were removed and planted in the ground before us, with a triumphant air, by little Tonish.Having no dishes, we had to proceed in hunter’s style, cutting off strips and slices with our hunting-knives, and dipping them in salt and pepper.To do justice to Tonish’s cookery, however, and to the keen sauce of the prairies, never have I tasted venison so delicious.With all this, our beverage was coffee, boiled in a camp kettle, sweetened with brown sugar, and drunk out of tin cups: and such was the style of our banqueting throughout this expedition, whenever provisions were plenty, and as long as flour and coffee and sugar held out.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 天色渐渐暗了下来，哨兵们走向营地周围的哨岗。在这个充满印第安人的地方，这种防范是必不可少的。此刻，营地呈现出一幅美丽如画的景象。树林间点点篝火闪耀着，周围围着一群群的巡逻骑兵，有的在地上坐着或躺着，有的或站在闪着红光的火焰边上，或站在火光照不到的阴影里。不少火堆旁充满了欢笑，其间夹杂着响亮的下流笑话和粗俗的呼喊声。显而易见的是，这支部队的成员都是新手，未经训练，他们是从边境上粗野的年轻人中招募来的。他们应征入伍，有的是为了来这里冒冒险，有的是为了了解一下这片土地。他们中许多人都是自己长官的邻居，也已经习惯了把军官当成和自己地位相等的密友和伙伴。他们都不知道军队的纪律和礼貌，也没有人打算为继续自己的军队生涯而去培养这一职业所必需的严谨素质。
As the twilight thickened into night, the sentinels were marched forth to their stations around the camp; an indispensable precaution in a country infested by Indians.The encampment now presented a picturesque appearance.Camp fires were blazing and smouldering here and there among the trees, with groups of rangers round them; some seated or lying on the ground, others standing in the ruddy glare of the flames, or in shadowy relief.At some of the fires there was much boisterous mirth, where peals of laughter were mingled with loud ribald jokes and uncouth exclamations; for the troop was evidently a raw, undisciplined band, levied among the wild youngsters of the frontier, who had enlisted, some for the sake of roving adventure, and some for the purpose of getting a knowledge of the country.Many of them were the neighbors of their officers, and accustomed to regard them with the familiarity of equals and companions.None of them had any idea of the restraint and decorum of a camp, or ambition to acquire a name for exactness in a profession in which they had no intention of continuing.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一些篝火旁的人们正处在一片喧腾嬉戏之中时，另一堆篝火旁突然发出一阵带着鼻音的哼唱。在那里，唱诗班的“歌手们”一起哼出了一首悲怆至极的圣歌曲调。这是由一个中尉领头哼唱的。他高高瘦瘦的，听说是来自边境的一个村庄，原是一个校长兼音乐教师，偶尔也做做卫理公会派的牧师。这庄严而悲凉的圣歌飘荡在夜空之中，我不禁想起了对国民誓约派成员营地里相似圣歌的描述。实际上，我们这支由形态各异、穿着粗俗的各色人等拼凑起来的部队所唱的，并没有使人感到是对这圣歌的侮辱。
While this boisterous merriment prevailed at some of the fires, there suddenly rose a strain of nasal melody from another, at which a choir of “vocalists” were uniting their voices in a most lugubrious psalm tune.This was led by one of the lieutenants; a tall, spare man, who we were informed had officiated as schoolmaster, singing-master, and occasionally as Methodist preacher, in one of the villages of the frontier.The chant rose solemnly and sadly in the night air, and reminded me of the description of similar canticles in the camps of the Covenanters; and, indeed, the strange medley of figures and faces and uncouth garbs, congregated together in our troop, would not have disgraced the banners of Praise-God Barebones.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在唱这首带着鼻音的赞美诗的间隙，一只爱好音乐的猫头鹰开始了它那沉闷的叫声，好像是要比赛似的。马上整个营地都在呼喊：“查理的猫头鹰！查理的猫头鹰！”
In one of the intervals of this nasal psalmody, an amateur owl, as if in competition, began his dreary hooting.Immediately there was a cry throughout the camp of “Charley’s owl! Charley’s owl!"

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这只“无名鸟”似乎每晚都来拜访过营地，并曾经被一个名叫查理的缺根筋的哨兵打了一枪，所以，虽然他辩解说他知道用猫头鹰可以做出不同寻常的好汤来，但只要他值班，就会让人们想起开枪事件。
It seems this “obscure bird” had visited the camp every night, and had been fired at by one of the sentinels, a half-witted lad, named Charley; who, on being called up for firing when on duty, excused himself by saying, that he understood owls made uncommonly good soup.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 其中一个年轻的巡逻骑兵模仿起这种智慧之鸟的叫声。这只鸟径直地盘旋着进入了我们的视线，然后落在了光秃秃的树枝上，映现在火堆的光辉之中。这可不是它的性格啊。年轻的伯爵马上抓起他的猎枪，瞄准之后给了它致命的一枪。转瞬间，那只可怜的预示着凶兆的鸟儿就在地上不断地挣扎了。这时，查理被叫过来做他要喝的猫头鹰汤，但是他拒绝了，理由是这不是他亲手打下来的。
One of the young rangers mimicked the cry of this bird of wisdom, who, with a simplicity little consonant with his character, came hovering within sight, and alighted on the naked branch of a tree, lit up by the blaze of our fire.The young Count immediately seized his fowling-piece, took fatal aim, and in a twinkling the poor bird of ill omen came fluttering to the ground.Charley was now called upon to make and eat his dish of owl-soup, but declined, as he had not shot the bird.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 夜间，我去队长的篝火处拜访了一下。那里烧着一些足够用来烤一整头野牛的巨大树干。在这里有许多一流的猎手和营地的首领。他们有的坐着，有的站着，还有的躺在火堆前的兽皮或毯子上，正讲述着边境上关于狩猎和印第安战争的古老故事。
In the course of the evening, I paid a visit to the Captain’s fire.It was composed of huge trunks of trees, and of sufficient magnitude to roast a buffalo whole.Here were a number of the prime hunters and leaders of the camp, some sitting, some standing, and others lying on skins or blankets before the fire, telling old frontier stories about hunting and Indian warfare.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 夜色更深了，我们注意到，在西边树林的上方，一片火光把天空映成了红色。
As the night advanced, we perceived above the trees to the west, a ruddy glow flushing up the sky.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那一定是奥塞奇猎手点燃了大草原。”队长说道。
“That must be a prairie set on fire by the Osage hunters,” said the Captain.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那是在雷德福克河边上，”贝蒂看着天空说，“那看起来也就只有三英里远，不过也有可能是二十英里。”
“It is at the Red Fork,” said Beatte, regarding the sky.“It seems but three miles distant, yet it perhaps is twenty.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约是在八点半之后，一片美丽的白光渐渐从东方涌现，那是月亮升起的征兆。从队长的住处离开后，我准备去休息。我已经决定不再受帐篷的庇护了，从今以后，我要像巡逻骑兵们那样露宿。一张铺在树下的熊皮是我的床，一副马褡裢就是我的枕头。把自己裹在毯子里之后，我舒服地躺在这种猎人的沙发上，很快便进入了香甜的梦乡，直到破晓的军号声响起时，我才醒来。
About half past eight o’clock, a beautiful pale light gradually sprang up in the east, a precursor of the rising moon.Drawing off from the Captain’s lodge, I now prepared for the night’s repose.I had determined to abandon the shelter of the tent, and henceforth to bivouac like the rangers.A bearskin spread at the foot of a tree was my bed, with a pair of saddle-bags for a pillow.Wrapping myself in blankets, I stretched myself on this hunter’s couch, and soon fell into a sound and sweet sleep, from which I did not awake until the bugle sounded at daybreak.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第十一章 拆帐篷
CHAPTER XI. BREAKING UP OF THE ENCAMPMENT.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——美丽如画的旅行——猎物——营地景色——一个年轻猎手的胜利——老猎手的失败——对一只臭鼬的残害
—PICTURESQUE MARCH.—GAME.—CAMP SCENES.—TRIUMPH OF A YOUNG HUNTER.—ILL SUCCESS OF OLD HUNTERS.—FOUL MURDER OF A POLECAT.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 40830.0——作为信号的号角声响起，哨兵和巡逻兵们从营地周围的岗位上撤了回来解散了。巡逻骑兵们纷纷从睡梦中醒来，很快，营地便呈现出一派忙碌的景象。有的在砍柴生火准备早饭，有的收拾起挡风遮雨的毛毯为出发作准备，还有的飞快地穿过灌木去寻找马，并把它们牵回或赶回营地。在这段忙乱的时间里，树林里高喊声、欢笑声交织成一片。当所有人吃完早饭，打包好行李和野营装备，并放在驮马背上之后，号角声响起，告诉大家备鞍上马出发。八点钟的时候，整支队伍排成一长溜出发了，吆喝声不绝于耳，其中还夹杂着对磨磨蹭蹭的驮马的咒骂声。不一会儿，这个这几天来被不常见的纷乱和喧闹所充斥的森林，又恢复了原始的孤寂。
OCTOBER 14TH.—At the signal note of the bugle, the sentinels and patrols marched in from their stations around the camp and were dismissed.The rangers were roused from their night’s repose, and soon a bustling scene took place.While some cut wood, made fires, and prepared the morning’s meal, others struck their foul-weather shelters of blankets, and made every preparation for departure; while others dashed about, through brush and brake, catching the horses and leading or driving them into camp.During all this bustle the forest rang with whoops, and shouts, and peals of laughter; when all had breakfasted, packed up their effects and camp equipage, and loaded the pack-horses, the bugle sounded to saddle and mount.By eight o’clock the whole troop set off in a long straggling line, with whoop and halloo, intermingled with many an oath at the loitering pack-horses, and in a little while the forest, which for several days had been the scene of such unwonted bustle and uproar, relapsed into its primeval solitude and silence.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这是一个阳光明媚的早上，纯净透明的空气使人心情愉悦。我们继续沿着与阿肯色河平行的路线前进，途经了一片富饶而又景色各异的土地。有时我们不得不穿越覆盖着茂密植物的冲击河谷，那里的参天大树上，缠结的葡萄藤像绳索一样从树枝上悬垂下来；有时我们沿着水流缓慢的小溪前进，那涓涓细流连接着一些像镜子般镶嵌在静谧树林深处的清澈水塘，水里倒映着片片秋叶和湛蓝的天空。有时我们要爬上连绵起伏、乱石林立的小山，在视野开阔山顶上，极目远眺，一边是远方点缀着大小树林的大草原，另一边是阿肯色河之外灰蒙蒙的连绵山峦。
It was a bright sunny morning, with a pure transparent atmosphere that seemed to bathe the very heart with gladness.Our march continued parallel to the Arkansas, through a rich and varied country; sometimes we had to break our way through alluvial bottoms matted with redundant vegetation, where the gigantic trees were entangled with grape-vines, hanging like cordage from their branches; sometimes we coasted along sluggish brooks, whose feebly trickling current just served to link together a succession of glassy pools, imbedded like mirrors in the quiet bosom of the forest, reflecting its autumnal foliage, and patches of the clear blue sky.Sometimes we scrambled up broken and rocky hills, from the summits of which we had wide views stretching on one side over distant prairies diversified by groves and forests, and on the other ranging along a line of blue and shadowy hills beyond the waters of the Arkansas.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们队伍的整体形象与乡间的景色融为一体，长达半英里的队伍蜿蜒在灌木丛林中，行走于山间隘路上，人们穿着各式粗陋的衣服，肩上扛着长来复枪，骑着颜色各异的马匹。驮马也时不时地从队伍中间溜出去，去吃路边的野草，然后托尼什和他的混血儿同伴把它们打回来，并用混杂的咒骂声连珠炮般地驱赶着。时不时地从队伍前端传来的号角声，在林地中回响，在幽谷中回荡，召唤着落伍者并表明前进的方向。整个场景使我想起了对西印度洋海盗穿越南美荒原，袭击西班牙殖民地的描述。
The appearance of our troop was suited to the country; stretching along in a line of upward of half a mile in length, winding among brakes and bushes, and up and down in the defiles of the hills, the men in every kind of uncouth garb, with long rifles on their shoulders, and mounted on horses of every color.The pack-horses, too, would incessantly wander from the line of march, to crop the surrounding herbage, and were banged and beaten back by Tonish and his half-breed compeers, with volleys of mongrel oaths.Every now and then the notes of the bugle, from the head of the column, would echo through the woodlands and along the hollow glens, summoning up stragglers, and announcing the line of march.The whole scene reminded me of the description given of bands of buccaneers penetrating the wilds of South America, on their plundering expeditions against the Spanish settlements.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 有一段时间，我们行走在一个肥沃的河谷，或者说是一片由灌木林围绕的草地，那里高高的野草被前一个晚上在此栖息的野鹿压出了无数的“鹿床”。一些橡树上也留下了想要摘橡树果的熊所攀爬过的痕迹，树皮上熊爪的印记清晰可辨。
At one time we passed through a luxuriant bottom or meadow bordered by thickets, where the tall grass was pressed down into numerous “deer beds,” where those animals had couched the preceding night.Some oak trees also bore signs of having been clambered by bears, in quest of acorns, the marks of their claws being visible in the bark.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这片被包围的草地上开辟道路时，我们看到几只鹿在极度惊慌中蹦蹦跳跳地逃开，直到跑开一段距离之后，它们才停下来，带着这一动物惯有的好奇表情回头观望打破它们孤寂世界的陌生入侵者。四处马上响起了尖锐的枪声，那是队伍中年轻的猎手们打的，但是他们太心急了，没有瞄准，于是野鹿们毫发无伤地窜进了树林深处。
As we opened a glade of this sheltered meadow we beheld several deer bounding away in wild affright, until, having gained some distance, they would stop and gaze back, with the curiosity common to this animal, at the strange intruders into their solitudes.There was immediately a sharp report of rifles in every direction, from the young huntsmen of the troop, but they were too eager to aim surely, and the deer, unharmed, bounded away into the depths of the forest.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 行军途中，我们来到了阿肯色河，但却发现我们仍然位于雷德福克河的下方。由于河拐了一个大弯，所以我们再度离开河岸，继续穿越树林。直到将近八点时，我们才在一处紧挨着一条溪流、由一丛丛高大橡树遮蔽着的美丽盆地上驻扎下来。
In the course of our march we struck the Arkansas, but found ourselves still below the Red Fork, and, as the river made deep bends, we again left its banks and continued through the woods until nearly eight o’clock, when we encamped in a beautiful basin bordered by a fine stream, and shaded by clumps of lofty oaks.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们将马匹们捆住，具体地说，将它们的前腿用绳索或皮带捆住，以限制它们的行动，防止它们从营地走失。然后我们把它们放开，让它们吃草去了。一些巡逻队员和第一流的猎手，向不同的方向进发，去寻找猎物。整个营地里没有了早上的那种高喊声和欢笑声，大家要么忙着生火准备做晚饭，要么在草地上休息。不久，枪声从不同的方向传来。一会儿工夫之后，一个猎手骑着马进入了营地，马背上驮着一只硕大的雄鹿的尸体。又过了一小会儿，几个年轻的猎手徒步走了回来，其中一个肩上扛着一只母鹿的尸体。虽然他和他的同伴因为刚刚开始打猎，所以一起前去，因而受到了其余同伴的嘲笑，但很显然他为自己的猎物感到骄傲，也许这是他第一次打到猎物呢！
The horses were now hobbled, that is to say, their fore legs were fettered with cords or leathern straps, so as to impede their movements, and prevent their wandering from the camp.They were then turned loose to graze.A number of rangers, prime hunters, started off in different directions in search of game.There was no whooping nor laughing about the camp as in the morning; all were either busy about the fires preparing the evening’s repast, or reposing upon the grass.Shots were soon heard in various directions.After a time a huntsman rode into the camp with the carcass of a fine buck hanging across his horse.Shortly afterward came in a couple of stripling hunters on foot, one of whom bore on his shoulders the body of a doe.He was evidently proud of his spoil, being probably one of his first achievements, though he and his companion were much bantered by their comrades, as young beginners who hunted in partnership.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 夜幕刚刚降临，营地的一头就响起了一阵高喊声。马上，一帮年轻的巡逻骑兵游走在各个火堆之间，肩上扛着他们一个凯旋的同伴。他生平第一次打死了一头麋鹿，这也是我们这次远足以来第一次打到这种猎物。当晚，这个名叫米莱伦的年轻猎手成了营地的英雄。此外，他还是“晚宴之父”，因为每个火堆上都在烤他的麋鹿。
Just as the night set in, there was a great shouting at one end of the camp, and immediately afterward a body of young rangers came parading round the various fires, bearing one of their comrades in triumph on their shoulders.He had shot an elk for the first time in his life, and it was the first animal of the kind that had been killed on this expedition.The young huntsman, whose name was M’Lellan, was the hero of the camp for the night, and was the “father of the feast” into the bargain; for portions of his elk were seen roasting at every fire.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 其余的猎手们则空手而归。队长发现了肯定是几天前刚刚经过这里的野牛的踪迹。他还循着一头熊的踪迹追了一段距离，直到最终脚印消失为止。他也在阿肯色河的岸边发现了一只麋鹿，它走到了河口沙洲上。可他还没来得及偷偷拔枪射击，它便退回到树林中去了。
The other hunters returned without success.The Captain had observed the tracks of a buffalo, which must have passed within a few days, and had tracked a bear for some distance until the foot-prints had disappeared.He had seen an elk, too, on the banks of the Arkansas, which walked out on a sand-bar of the river, but before he could steal round through the bushes to get a shot, it had re-entered the woods.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们自己的猎手贝蒂一言不发、闷闷不乐地回来了，他也一无所获。由于他没有给我们带回任何东西，所以我们只好分享属于队长的那份鹿肉了。很显然，贝蒂觉得很丢人，因为他看不起那些巡逻骑兵，认为他们是乳臭未干、毫无经验的山林人；另一方面，他们也看不起他，认为他来自于一个邪恶的种族，还总管他叫“印第安人”。
Our own hunter, Beatte, returned silent and sulky, from an unsuccessful hunt.As yet he had brought us in nothing, and we had depended for our supplies of venison upon the Captain’s mess.Beatte was evidently mortified, for he looked down with contempt upon the rangers, as raw and inexperienced woodsmen, but little skilled in hunting; they, on the other hand, regarded Beatte with no very complacent eye, as one of an evil breed, and always spoke of him as “the Indian.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的小个子法国人托尼什还是喜欢用他那混杂的方言，喋喋不休地自吹自擂，满嘴胡言乱语。队伍里那些爱说笑的人总是拿他寻开心，他们肆无忌惮地奚落和嘲笑他；可是这个小无赖完全被虚荣心和自负所蒙蔽，所以他对所有的讽刺挖苦都不以为意。然而，我必须承认，我们的随从总是在那些边陲强盗们当中出洋相，这使我感到很丢人。甚至连我们的装备也不受欢迎，我听到我们用来打小猎物的双筒枪遭到了很多的讥笑。他们轻蔑地称我们是手持“猎枪”的西部小家伙。松鸡、鹑鸡之类的小东西，甚至是火鸡，他们都瞧不上眼，他们认为步枪是唯一值得猎手装备的武器。
Our little Frenchman, Tonish, also, by his incessant boasting, and chattering, and gasconading, in his balderdashed dialect, had drawn upon himself the ridicule of many of the wags of the troop, who amused themselves at his expense in a kind of raillery by no means remarkable for its delicacy; but the little varlet was so completely fortified by vanity and self-conceit, that he was invulnerable to every joke.I must confess, however, that I felt a little mortified at the sorry figure our retainers were making among these moss-troopers of the frontier.Even our very equipments came in for a share of unpopularity, and I heard many sneers at the double-barrelled guns with which we were provided against smaller game; the lads of the West holding “shot-guns,” as they call them, in great contempt, thinking grouse, partridges, and even wild turkeys as beneath their serious attention, and the rifle the only firearm worthy of a hunter.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二天早上破晓之前，我便被一只狼的悲号给惊醒了。它被鹿肉的香味所吸引，偷偷地徘徊在营地的边缘。黎明第一抹光亮刚刚降临，一个远处小屋里的年轻人便醒了过来。他模仿起一只公鸡啼叫，音色清朗明亮、抑扬顿挫，堪与最老练的公鸡相媲美。马上，另一个屋子传来回应，好像是来自于一只相匹敌的雄鸡。叫声在所有的屋子间回荡，随后又响起了母鸡的咯咯声，鸭子的呷呷声，火鸡的嘎嘎声，以及猪的咕噜声——我们恍如置身于一个农家庭院，所有家禽的叫声在我们周围响成一片。
I was awakened before daybreak the next morning, by the mournful howling of a wolf, who was skulking about the purlieus of the camp, attracted by the scent of venison.Scarcely had the first gray streak of dawn appeared, when a youngster at one of the distant lodges, shaking off his sleep, crowed in imitation of a cock, with a loud clear note and prolonged cadence, that would have done credit to the most veteran chanticleer.He was immediately answered from another quarter, as if from a rival rooster.The chant was echoed from lodge to lodge, and followed by the cackling of hens, quacking of ducks, gabbling of turkeys, and grunting of swine, until we seemed to have been transported into the midst of a farmyard, with all its inmates in full concert around us.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这天早上骑了一小段距离之后，我们来到了一条古老的印第安小径。沿着它我们一路爬上了一座山丘的顶端。那里视野非常开阔，眼前是一望无际的乡村景象：有岩石嶙峋的山脊和高低起伏的丘陵，还有小树林和各种矮树丛点缀其间。朝西面远眺，我们欣喜地发现雷德福克河一路奔腾涌入阿肯色河，而我们正处在两河交汇处的上方。我们费力地下着山，并艰难前行，之后穿过了阿肯色河旁边林木茂盛的冲积河谷。这里，树上都缠绕着葡萄藤，像绳索似的，从这个树干缠到那个树干，从这个树枝绕到那个树枝；这里还有低矮浓密的灌木丛和荆棘，以及大量适于采集的啤酒花草——这一切使我们的马举步维艰。
After riding a short distance this morning, we came upon a well-worn Indian track, and following it, scrambled to the summit of a hill, whence we had a wide prospect over a country diversified by rocky ridges and waving lines of upland, and enriched by groves and clumps of trees of varied tuft and foliage.At a distance to the west, to our great satisfaction, we beheld the Red Fork rolling its ruddy current to the Arkansas, and found that we were above the point of junction We now descended and pushed forward, with much difficulty, through the rich alluvial bottom that borders the Arkansas.Here the trees were interwoven with grape-vines, forming a kind of cordage, from trunk to trunk and limb to limb; there was a thick undergrowth, also, of bush and bramble, and such an abundance of hops, fit for gathering, that it was difficult for our horses to force their way through.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 地面上的许多地方都留下了鹿的脚印，在很多树上我们也发现了熊的掌印。每一个人都警惕起来，希望能惊动某个猎物。突然，队伍的远端响起一阵纷乱的叫嚷声。有人叫喊道：“一头熊！一头熊！”我们都向前拥挤着，想看个究竟。可让我感到苦恼莫名的是，竟是我们的两个宝贝——贝蒂和托尼什，残忍地射杀了一只臭鼬。这只动物之前隐藏在一棵倒在地上的树的树干后面，在那儿它以自己特有的方式拼命保护自己，直到周围的树林里都弥漫着那浓烈的“香味”。
The soil was imprinted in many places with the tracks of deer, and the claws of bears were to be traced on various trees.Every one was on the look-out in the hope of starting some game, when suddenly there was a bustle and a clamor in a distant part of the line.“A bear! a bear! ” was the cry.We all pressed forward to be present at the sport, when to my infinite, though whimsical chagrin, I found it to be our two worthies, Beatte and Tonish, perpetrating a foul murder on a polecat, or skunk!The animal had ensconced itself beneath the trunk of a fallen tree, whence it kept up a vigorous defence in its peculiar style, until the surrounding forest was in a high state of fragrance.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 嘲弄和讥笑立刻从四面八方涌向了这个印第安猎手。人们建议他戴上这只臭鼬的头皮，作为对其赫赫战功的奖励。然而，当发现他和托尼什决意要把这只猎物作为特殊的美味时，他们都摆出一副厌恶的表情，认为他们比食人者强不到哪儿去。
Gibes and jokes now broke out on all sides at the expense of the Indian hunter, and he was advised to wear the scalp of the skunk as the only trophy of his prowess.When they found, however, that he and Tonish were absolutely bent upon bearing off the carcass as a peculiar dainty, there was a universal expression of disgust; and they were regarded as little better than cannibals.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们这两位猎手不光彩的登台亮相使我感到很羞愧，所以我坚决要求他们放弃战利品，重新上路。贝蒂固执而又不情愿地答应了，自己嘀嘀咕咕地落到了队伍后面。然而，托尼什带着他惯有的乐观，高声地赞叹着烤臭鼬的肥美，他发誓说这是所有有经验的印第安美食家公认的最可口的佳肴。我蛮横地重复了好几次命令，才好不容易让他那聒噪的嘴安静下来。然而，一个法国人的活泼天性如果以一种方式压制住了，就会以另一种方式爆发出来。现在托尼什把他的恼怒发泄到对驮马的不断咒骂上。我不愿迁就这两个无赖的情绪，可最终我似乎并不是胜利者。因为一段时间后，落在后面的贝蒂骑马跑到了队伍的前面，重新担当起向导的职责，而我气恼地发现，他的战利品已经被剥了皮，像一只肥肥的小乳猪一样，挂在他马鞍的后面。然而，我悄悄地郑重发誓，我们的篝火绝不能因烤这只臭鼬而受到侮辱。
Mortified at this ignominious debut of our two hunters, I insisted upon their abandoning their prize and resuming their march.Beatte complied with a dogged, discontented air, and lagged behind muttering to himself.Tonish, however, with his usual buoyancy, consoled himself by vociferous eulogies on the richness and delicacy of a roasted polecat, which he swore was considered the daintiest of dishes by all experienced Indian gourmands.It was with difficulty I could silence his loquacity by repeated and peremptory commands.A Frenchman’s vivacity, however, if repressed in one way, will break out in another and Tonish now eased off his spleen by bestowing volleys of oaths and dry blows on the pack-horses.I was likely to be no gainer in the end, by my opposition to the humors of these varlets, for after a time, Beatte, who had lagged behind, rode up to the head of the line to resume his station as a guide, and I had the vexation to see the carcass of his prize, stripped of its skin, and looking like a fat sucking pig, dangling behind his saddle.I made a solemn vow, however, in secret, that our fire should not be disgraced by the cooking of that polecat.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第十二章 跨越阿肯色河
CHAPTER XII. THE CROSSING OF THE ARKANSAS.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们在雷德福克河河口之上大约四分之一英里的地方，到达了河边。但是这里的河岸既陡又疏松，并且水流又深又湍急。因此，在这个地方渡河是不可能的。于是我们又重新开始了穿越森林的痛苦旅程，并让贝蒂先去寻找渡河的地点。我们又继续走了大约一英里之后，他和我们汇合了。他告诉我们附近有个地方河流的大部分是沙洲，剩下的水域马也很容易游过去。
We had now arrived at the river, about a quarter of a mile above the junction of the Red Fork; but the banks were steep and crumbling, and the current was deep and rapid.It was impossible, therefore, to cross at this place; and we resumed our painful course through the forest, dispatching Beatte ahead, in search of a fording place.We had proceeded about a mile farther, when he rejoined us, bringing intelligence of a place hard by, where the river, for a great part of its breadth, was rendered fordable by sand-bars, and the remainder might easily be swam by the horses.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 然后，我们就在这儿停了下来。有些巡逻骑兵拿着斧子，开始精神抖擞地劳作了。他们砍倒岸边的树做成筏子，用来运他们的行李和野营装备。还有一些人又对更远处的河岸勘察了一番，希望可以找到一个更适合渡河的地点，而不愿让他们的马在这深深的河道中冒险。
Here, then, we made a halt.Some of the rangers set to work vigorously with their axes, felling trees on the edge of the river, wherewith to form rafts for the transportation of their baggage and camp equipage.Others patrolled the banks of the river farther up, in hopes of finding a better fording place; being unwilling to risk their horses in the deep channel.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 也正是这时，我们的宝贝贝蒂和托尼什，有了一个展示他们印第安人聪明才智的机会。在我们一两天前经过的那个奥塞奇村庄，他们讨得了一张干野牛皮。现在，这个派上了用场；他们在它上面凿上了许多小孔，把绳子从中穿过去，然后，把它吊起来，直到形成一种深槽。接着又将几根棍子从里面横穿过去，以使它保持形状。我们将野营装备和部分行李放到了这一张牛皮里，并把它带下岸放到了水中。贝蒂将绳子的一头系在牛皮的前端，另一头用牙咬着，然后跳到了水里，拖着皮囊小船一路涉水前进，而托尼什则跟在皮囊后面，一边保持它的平衡，一边推着它。有一段路他们有立足点，可以涉水前进，但在主流处，他们不得不游泳。这个过程中，他们一直用印第安人的方式高声叫喊，直到安全抵达对岸。专员和我对这种印第安人的摆渡方式都非常满意，所以我们也决定用这张牛皮过河。我们的同伴——那个伯爵和L.先生，骑着马沿着河岸继续前进，寻找那几个巡逻骑兵在大约一英里半的地方发现的另一个渡河口。等待我们的摆渡人归来的时候，我碰巧瞥见灌木丛下的一堆行李，并看到了那只臭鼬光溜溜的尸体。它被紧紧地捆扎着，将在晚上的篝火前被烤了吃。我无法抵制住将它扔入河里的欲望。不一会儿，我看着它像一块铅块那样沉入了河底。因此我们的小屋将免受这个美味佳肴所带来的刺鼻气味了。
It was now that our worthies, Beatte and Tonish, had an opportunity of displaying their Indian adroitness and resource.At the Osage village which we had passed a day or two before, they had procured a dry buffalo skin.This was now produced; cords were passed through a number of small eyelet-holes with which it was bordered, and it was drawn up, until it formed a kind of deep trough.Sticks were then placed athwart it on the inside, to keep it in shape; our camp equipage and a part of our baggage were placed within, and the singular bark was carried down the bank and set afloat.A cord was attached to the prow, which Beatte took between his teeth, and throwing himself into the water, went ahead, towing the bark after him; while Tonish followed behind, to keep it steady and to propel it.Part of the way they had foothold, and were enabled to wade, but in the main current they were obliged to swim.The whole way, they whooped and yelled in the Indian style, until they landed safely on the opposite shore.The Commissioner and myself were so well pleased with this Indian mode of ferriage, that we determined to trust ourselves in the buffalo hide.Our companions, the Count and Mr. L., had proceeded with the horses, along the river bank, in search of a ford which some of the rangers had discovered, about a mile and a half distant.While we were waiting for the return of our ferryman, I happened to cast my eyes upon a heap of luggage under a bush, and descried the sleek carcass of the polecat, snugly trussed up, and ready for roasting before the evening fire.I could not resist the temptation to plump it into the river, when it sunk to the bottom like a lump of lead; and thus our lodge was relieved from the bad odor which this savory viand had threatened to bring upon it.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的摆渡人再次携着皮囊小船渡河。皮囊被拖上岸，里面马鞍、马褡裢和其他的行李占了一半的空间，得有百十来磅。当皮囊小船再次被放到水里之后，他们邀请我坐上去。这让我觉得自己很像愚人村里坐着碗出海的愚人。但我还是毫不犹豫而又小心翼翼地走上去了，然后坐在了行李上面。皮囊的边缘沉入水中大约一个巴掌的深度。之后，来复枪、猎枪和其他较小的东西都被递了过来，直到我抗议不能再拿任何东西为止。然后，我们便朝着溪流进发了，皮囊还是像从前那样被人牵着。
Our men having recrossed with their cockle-shell bark, it was drawn on shore, half filled with saddles, saddlebags, and other luggage, amounting to a hundred weight; and being again placed in the water, I was invited to take my seat.It appeared to me pretty much like the embarkation of the wise men of Gotham, who went to sea in a bowl: I stepped in, however, without hesitation, though as cautiously as possible, and sat down on the top of the luggage, the margin of the hide sinking to within a hand’s breadth of the water’s edge.Rifles, fowling-pieces, and other articles of small bulk, were then handed in, until I protested against receiving any more freight.We then launched forth upon the stream, the bark being towed as before.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 带着一种半认真、半滑稽的感觉，我发现自己是这样漂着的：坐在一张野牛皮上，处于一条被一片荒原包围着的、奔腾的河流中，被一个活像魔鬼化身的、一路高声吆喝的半野蛮人牵着。为了满足小托尼什的虚荣心，当到河中央时，我拔出双管枪向左右开火。射击声沿着岸边的树林不断回响，一些巡逻骑兵也高叫着作出回应，这让这个小法国人兴奋不已，他自己完全陶醉于这种印第安人渡河方式的自豪之中。
It was with a sensation half serious, half comic, that I found myself thus afloat, on the skin of a buffalo, in the midst of a wild river, surrounded by wilderness, and towed along by a half savage, whooping and yelling like a devil incarnate.To please the vanity of little Tonish, I discharged the double-barrelled gun, to the right and left, when in the centre of the stream.The report echoed along the woody shores, and was answered by shouts from some of the rangers, to the great exultation of the little Frenchman, who took to himself the whole glory of this Indian mode of navigation.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的旅程愉快地完成了。专员也同样成功地过了河。我们所有的财物都是以相同的方式运过来的。任何人都不可能比小托尼什更能自吹自擂了，当他趾高气扬地在河岸周围逛游时，他兴高采烈地向那些巡逻骑兵们吹嘘他的高超技能和知识。然而，贝蒂则保持着他那骄傲阴郁的神色，不苟言笑。我们对巡逻骑兵们的无知极为蔑视，觉得他被他们小瞧了。他的唯一评论就是：“无论如何，他们现在知道印第安人不是平庸之辈了！”
Our voyage was accomplished happily; the Commissioner was ferried across with equal success, and all our effects were brought over in the same manner.Nothing could equal the vain-glorious vaporing of little Tonish, as he strutted about the shore, and exulted in his superior skill and knowledge, to the rangers.Beatte, however, kept his proud, saturnine look, without a smile.We had a vast contempt for the ignorance of the rangers, and felt that he had been undervalued by them.His only observation was, “Dey now see de Indian good for someting, anyhow!”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们所登陆的这个宽阔河岸的沙地上，混杂着麋鹿、鹿、熊、浣熊、火鸡及水鸟的无数足迹。这个地方的景色美丽多姿：广阔的河面波光粼粼，河两边包围着垂柳和三角叶杨，河谷肥沃，树林茂盛，其中还高耸着巨大的悬铃树，远处环绕着被浓绿的植被所覆盖的岬角。树叶都泛着一种秋季的浅黄色，这给阳光明媚的大地抹上了一层克劳德·洛兰的风景画中所特有的金黄色色调。队长和他的主要同伴——医生正在用一条由原木和树枝扎成的筏子，运送物品渡河；大约一英里半远的地方，一长队的巡逻骑兵正沿着几个沙洲斜向策马渡河。这些都给这番景致增添了些许生气。
The broad, sandy shore where we had landed, was intersected by innumerable tracks of elk, deer, bears, racoons, turkeys, and water-fowl.The river scenery at this place was beautifully diversified, presenting long, shining reaches, bordered by willows and cottonwood trees; rich bottoms, with lofty, forests; among which towered enormous plane trees, and the distance was closed in by high embowered promontories.The foliage had a yellow autumnal tint, which gave to the sunny landscape the golden tone of one of the landscapes of Claude Lorraine.There was animation given to the scene, by a raft of logs and branches, on which the Captain and his prime companion, the Doctor, were ferrying their effects across the stream; and by a long line of rangers on horseback, fording the river obliquely, along a series of sand-bars, about a mile and a half distant.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第十三章 峡谷的宿营
CHAPTER XIII. THE CAMP OF THE GLEN.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 营地谣言——波尼人及其习性——一位猎手的冒险找到马，但弄丢了人
CAMP GOSSIP.—PAWNEES AND THEIR HABITS.—A HUNTER’S ADVENTURE.HORSES FOUND, AND MEN LOST.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 和队长及一些巡逻骑兵汇合后，我们拐进了一个树林，走了大约半英里，然后来到了一个荒凉多石、两旁高耸着石灰石山崖的小山谷。越往里走，道路越狭窄，直到两边山崖交会，几乎形成了一个夹角。在这儿，清澈的泉水从岩石间涌出，并注入一条贯穿整个山谷的银色小溪，滋润着覆盖山谷的草地。
Being joined by the Captain and some of the rangers, we struck into the woods for about half a mile, and then entered a wild, rocky dell, bordered by two lofty ridges of limestone, which narrowed as we advanced, until they met and united; making almost an angle.Here a fine spring of water rose among the rocks, and fed a silver rill that ran the whole length of the dell, freshening the grass with which it was carpeted.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们便在这岩石的隐蔽之处、在高树之间安营扎寨。巡逻骑兵们有的独自行进，有的成群结队地穿过树林，都逐渐加入了我们。他们有的骑着马，有的步行，驱赶着身前驮着沉重行李的马匹。有的行李湿漉漉的，因为之前曾掉到了河里。之前那宽阔的河面和又深又急的水流让骑手们费劲周折、筋疲力尽。他们看上去简直就像是携带着赃物回来的强盗，而这个山谷恰似接应他们撤退的地方。夜幕降临之后，火光映照在这群人和马粗糙的脸上，更增强了这种效果。行李杂乱地堆在一起，步枪成堆地倚在树上，马鞍、缰绳、牛角制成的火药桶悬挂在树干上。
In this rocky nook we encamped, among tall trees.The rangers gradually joined us, straggling through the forest singly or in groups; some on horseback, some on foot, driving their horses before them, heavily laden with baggage, some dripping wet, having fallen into the river; for they had experienced much fatigue and trouble from the length of the ford, and the depth and rapidity of the stream.They looked not unlike banditti returning with their plunder, and the wild dell was a retreat worthy to receive them.The effect was heightened after dark, when the light of the fires was cast upon rugged looking groups of men and horses; with baggage tumbled in heaps, rifles piled against the trees, and saddles, bridles, and powder-horns hanging about their trunks.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在营地里，我们与年轻的伯爵和他的同伴，以及那个年轻的混血儿安托万聚在了一起。他们都成功地渡过了河。然而，让我感到烦恼的是我发现我的两匹马都丢了。我本来是让安托万照看它们的，可是他天生是个粗心大意的人，根本没有好好留神它们。它们有可能在河对岸时就从队伍里走失了。我们安排贝蒂和安托万第二天一早重新渡河，去寻找它们。
At the encampment we were joined by the young Count and his companion, and the young half-breed, Antoine, who had all passed successfully by the ford.To my annoyance, however, I discovered that both of my horses were missing.I had supposed them in the charge of Antoine; but he, with characteristic carelessness, had paid no heed to them, and they had probably wandered from the line on the opposite side of the river.It was arranged that Beatte and Antoine should recross the river at an early hour of the morning, in search of them.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一只肥硕的雄鹿，还有几只野火鸡被带进了营地，再加上一杯咖啡，我们设法做了一顿可口的晚餐。晚饭后，我又去了队长的屋子，那里是营地里的老猎手们商量事情和闲聊谈天的地方。
A fat buck, and a number of wild turkeys being brought into the camp, we managed, with the addition of a cup of coffee, to make a comfortable supper; after which I repaired to the Captain’s lodge, which was a kind of council fire and gossiping place for the veterans of the camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 当我们在一起聊天的时候，我们发现和前几个夜晚一样，一片暗红色的亮光照在林立于西方的悬崖之颠。这应该还是来自于大草原上印第安人的篝火，我们推测他们应该是在阿肯色河的西部。如果是这样的话，那篝火应该是一伙波尼人点的，因为奥塞奇猎手们很少到那个地方去冒险。然而，我们的混血儿却声称它们是奥塞奇人的篝火，他们就在阿肯色河的对岸。
As we were conversing together, we observed, as on former nights, a dusky, red glow in the west, above the summits of the surrounding cliffs.It was again attributed to Indian fires on the prairies; and supposed to be on the western side of the Arkansas.If so, it was thought they must be made by some party of Pawnees, as the Osage hunters seldom ventured in that quarter.Our half-breeds, however, pronounced them Osage fires; and that they were on the opposite side of the Arkansas.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 现在话题转到了波尼人身上，而我们也将进入他们的猎场了。这里总是存在一些野蛮而桀骜不驯的印第安部落。在一段时间内，他们成为边疆的恐怖之源，到处都流传着各种各样关于他们的可怕故事。目前，波尼人就是这样的一个部落。他们游荡在阿肯色河和雷德河之间的区域内，以及德克萨斯州的大草原上。他们被认为是极佳的骑兵，总是骑在大草原上原始种类强悍勇敢的战马背上。他们驰骋于一片片广阔的平原上，平原伸展在阿肯色河、雷德河周围，又穿越德克萨斯州，直到落基山脉脚下。他们有时候猎取鹿和野牛，有时候进行掠夺式的战事远征，因为就像他们的对手——以实玛利的子孙——一样，他们的手要攻打所有人，而所有人的手也要攻打他们。他们中的一些人没有固定居所，而是住在兽皮做的容易打包和运输的帐篷里，所以他们今天在这儿，然后离开，没有人知道他们明天会在哪儿。
The conversation now turned upon the Pawnees, into whose hunting grounds we were about entering.There is always some wild untamed tribe of Indians, who form, for a time, the terror of a frontier, and about whom all kinds of fearful stories are told.Such, at present, was the case with the Pawnees, who rove the regions between the Arkansas and the Red River, and the prairies of Texas.They were represented as admirable horsemen, and always on horseback; mounted on fleet and hardy steeds, the wild race of the prairies.With these they roam the great plains that extend about the Arkansas, the Red River, and through Texas, to the Rocky Mountains; sometimes engaged in hunting the deer and buffalo, sometimes in warlike and predatory expeditions; for, like their counterparts, the sons of Ishmael, their hand is against every one, and every one’s hand against them.Some of them have no fixed habitation, but dwell in tents of skin, easily packed up and transported, so that they are here to-day, and away, no one knows where, to-morrow.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一个经验丰富的猎手讲述了几件关于他们作战方法的轶事。根据他所说的，在大草原之中，如果一队疲惫的商人或猎手被他们发现了，那将是一件很不幸的事。有时，他们会使用计谋偷偷接近目标：他们把一条腿搭在马鞍上，把身子藏起来。这样，在远处看来他们的队伍就像是一队野马。当他们因此而离敌人足够近时，就会突然在马鞍上直起身子，像一阵暴风似的迅疾地刮向敌人。所有人头上的羽毛都迎风飘扬，他们抖动着身上的披风，挥舞着手中的武器，并发出骇人的叫喊。他们试图以这种方式引起马群的恐慌，让它们仓皇而逃，然后他们再去追赶它们并将它们成功带回。
One of the veteran hunters gave several anecdotes of their mode of fighting.Luckless, according to his account, is the band of weary traders or hunters descried by them, in the midst of a prairie.Sometimes, they will steal upon them by stratagem, hanging with one leg over the saddle, and their bodies concealed; so that their troop at a distance has the appearance of a gang of wild horses.When they have thus gained sufficiently upon the enemy, they will suddenly raise themselves in their saddles, and come like a rushing blast, all fluttering with feathers, shaking their mantles, brandishing their weapons, and making hideous yells.In this way, they seek to strike a panic into the horses, and put them to the scamper, when they will pursue and carry them off in triumph.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 根据这个经验丰富的林中人所说，最好的防御方式是隐蔽到一些树林或灌木林中；如果当时什么也没有的话，就下马，并把马围成一个圈，马头挨马头地拴紧，这样它们便不会四散逃离了，然后撤退到某个峡谷，以此作为屏障，或者就地挖个沙坑。在那儿，他们或许就能躲开波尼人的长矛。波尼人主要用弓和箭，还都是些箭法娴熟的弓箭手。他们喜欢围着敌人不停地转圈，并且在马全速奔跑时开弓放箭。他们在大草原上非常有威慑力，因为在那儿，他们的马可以自由驰骋，也没有树会抵挡他们的箭。他们很少跟随着一个飞奔的敌人进入森林。
The best mode of defence, according to this veteran woodsman, is to get into the covert of some wood, or thicket; or if there be none at hand, to dismount, tie the horses firmly head to head in a circle, so that they cannot break away and scatter, and resort to the shelter of a ravine, or make a hollow in the sand, where they may be screened from the shafts of the Pawnees.The latter chiefly use the bow and arrow, and are dexterous archers; circling round and round their enemy, and launching their arrows when at full speed.They are chiefly formidable on the prairies, where they have free career for their horses, and no trees to turn aside their arrows.They will rarely follow a flying enemy into the forest.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 同时，几件轶事也讲述了他们行事之神秘和谨慎，比如他们会偷偷包围营地，等待劫掠或攻击的最佳时机。
Several anecdotes, also, were given, of the secrecy and caution with which they will follow, and hang about the camp of an enemy, seeking a favorable moment for plunder or attack.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “我们从现在开始必须时刻保持警惕，”队长说，“我必须发布书面命令：任何人不经允许不得去打猎或者开枪，否则将受到骑马背带有尖刺的木马的惩罚。”我有一群自由散漫的年轻手下，他们还不习惯边疆的生活方式。教会他们提高警惕是很困难的。我们现在处于一个满是沉默、警觉而又诡计多端的人的土地上。在我们没有丝毫怀疑之时，他们也许已经包围了我们，秘密监视我们的一举一动，并准备袭击所有的落伍者。
“We must now begin to keep a sharp look-out,” said the Captain.“I must issue written orders, that no man shall hunt without leave, or fire off a gun, on pain of riding a wooden horse with a sharp back."I have a wild crew of young fellows, unaccustomed to frontier service.It will be difficult to teach them caution.We are now in the land of a silent, watchful, crafty people, who, when we least suspect it, may be around us, spying out all our movements, and ready to pounce upon all stragglers.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那如果你的人在营地周围巡逻时发现了猎物，你将如何禁止他们开枪呢？”一个巡逻骑兵问道。
“How will you be able to keep your men from firing, if they see game while strolling round the camp?” asked one of the rangers.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “除非是在执勤或者有我的许可，否则他们不可以随身携带枪支。”
“They must not take their guns with them unless they are on duty, or have permission.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “哎呀，队长！”这个巡逻骑兵惊呼道，“这对我可不适用。无论我去哪儿，我的步枪就跟到那儿。我从来没想过要离开它，它就像我自己的一部分一样。没有人能像我一样这么仔细地照看它，也没有什么东西能像我的步枪一样这么认真地照顾我。”
“Ah, Captain!” cried the ranger, “that will never do for me.”Where I go, my rifle goes.I never like to leave it behind; it’s like a part of myself.There’s no one will take such care of it as I, and there’s nothing will take such care of me as my rifle.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那确实是事实。”队长说。一个真正猎手的真挚感情深深触动了他。“每晚我的步枪就像我老婆那样一直陪在我身边，它还一直是我忠实的朋友。”
“There’s truth in all that,” said the Captain, touched by a true hunter’s sympathy.“I’ve had my rifle pretty nigh as long as I have had my wife, and a faithful friend it has been to me.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 此时，那个和队长一样热衷于打猎的医生插话道：“我的一个邻居说，相比之下，我宁愿把老婆借给你，而不是我的步枪。”
Here the Doctor, who is as keen a hunter as the Captain, joined in the conversation: “A neighbor of mine says, next to my rifle, I’d as leave lend you my wife.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “很少有人，”队长评论道，“对他们步枪的照看能达到它们应该被照看的程度。”
“There’s few,” observed the Captain, “that take care of their rifles as they ought to be taken care of.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “对他们的妻子也是如此。”医生狡黠地眨着眼睛回答道。
“Or of their wives either,” replied the Doctor, with a wink.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那是事实。”队长附和道。
“That’s a fact,” rejoined the Captain.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 此时，消息传来：由“老瑞安”带领的四个巡逻骑兵失踪了。他们在河对岸寻找渡河点时和大部队分散了，然后便掉了队，没人知道他们去了哪里。人们对他们进行了诸般猜测，也有人对他们的安全表示担忧。
Word was now brought that a party of four rangers, headed by “Old Ryan,” were missing.They had separated from the main body, on the opposite side of the river, when searching for a ford, and had straggled off, nobody knew whither.Many conjectures were made about them, and some apprehensions expressed for their safety.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “我应该派人去找他们，”队长说，“不过老瑞安和他们一起，他知道如何照顾自己和其他人。如果不是因为有他，我就不能分心照顾其他那么多人了。他在树林里或者大草原上，就像在自己的农家庭院一样自由自在。无论他在哪儿，他都不会走失的。他们有足够的人手来互相照应：四个人警戒，一个人负责生火。”
“I should send to look after them,” said the Captain, “but old Ryan is with them, and he knows how to take care of himself and of them too.”If it were not for him, I would not give much for the rest; but he is as much at home in the woods or on a prairie as he would be in his own farmyard.He’s never lost, wherever he is.There’s a good gang of them to stand by one another; four to watch and one to take care of the fire.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “晚上迷失在陌生而又荒凉的乡间是件可悲的事情。”一个年轻的巡逻骑兵说道。
“It’s a dismal thing to get lost at night in a strange and wild country,” said one of the younger rangers.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “可如果你有一两个人做伴儿的话就没事。”一个年纪大些的说道。“对我而言，如果有一个伙伴可以和我轮流警戒，轮流照看篝火，那么我在这个山谷里就和在家里一样高兴。我可以在这儿躺上几个小时，凝望那颗闪闪发光的星星，而它好像也俯视着营地，似乎是在守卫营地一样。
“Not if you have one or two in company,” said an elder one.“For my part, I could feel as cheerful in this hollow as in my own home, if I had but one comrade to take turns to watch and keep the fire going.”I could lie here for hours, and gaze up to that blazing star there, that seems to look down into the camp as if it were keeping guard over it.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 没错，当你不得不独自警戒时，那些星星们就像是一个伙伴。那颗星星还真有些令人感到愉快，我想它就是昏星，他们称之为金星的那颗。”
“Aye, the stars are a kind of company to one, when you have to keep watch alone.”That’s a cheerful star, too, somehow; that’s the evening star, the planet Venus they call it, I think.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “如果那颗星星是金星的话，”一个之前一起开会的人说道，“那它对我们来说可不是个好兆头。因为我记得在某本书上读到过，说波尼人崇拜那颗星星，并把他们的俘虏献祭给它。所以我觉得，在这地方还是不要看到那颗星星为妙。”我想，他就是那个唱圣歌的校长。
“If that’s the planet Venus,” said one of the council, who, I believe, was the psalm-singing schoolmaster, “it bodes us no good; for I recollect reading in some book that the Pawnees worship that star, and sacrifice their prisoners to it.”So I should not feel the better for the sight of that star in this part of the country.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “啊，”那个中士，也是个训练有素的山林人说道，“不管有没有星星，我都在一个比这儿更荒凉的地方独自呆了好几个晚上，并且我向你保证，我都睡得很香。”“可是，有一次我确实过得很不安。我在穿越汤比格比河附近的一片树林时耽搁了，于是我擦着了火柴，生了一堆火。我睡觉时把马给松开了。不久之后，我听到了狼嚎声。我的马非常害怕，一个劲儿地往我身边挤来，以寻求保护。我把它赶走，但它又返了回来，并且靠得越来越近。它站在那儿看着我和火堆，头不时地往下垂，直打瞌睡，并且前蹄一直晃晃悠悠的，因为它实在是累坏了。又过了一会儿，我听到一声奇怪的凄凉的叫声。起初，我以为那可能是一头猫头鹰。接着我又听到一声，然后便知道了那不是猫头鹰，而是一头美洲豹。我感到很棘手，因为除了一把双刃小折刀，我没有其他的武器。然而，我还是尽最大可能做好防御准备：我把烧焦的小木头堆在一起，万一它接近，就向它投掷。此刻，我的马的陪伴似乎给了我很大的安慰，这可怜的畜生趴在我身边，因为太累了，它很快就睡着了。我继续警戒，不停地垂下脑袋打瞌睡，然后又猛然惊醒，并环顾四周，希望看到美洲豹那双闪闪发光的眼睛向我逼近。但是，不知怎地，疲劳还是压倒了我，于是我便沉沉地睡去了。早上，我在不到六十步的地方发现了美洲豹的足迹。它的爪印有我的两个拳头那么大。很明显，它来来回回地走了好几遍，犹豫着是否要攻击我。幸运的是，它没有这个勇气。”
“Well,” said the sergeant, a thorough-bred woodsman, “star or no star, I have passed many a night alone in a wilder place than this, and slept sound too, I’ll warrant you.”Once, however, I had rather an uneasy time of it.I was belated in passing through a tract of wood, near the Tombigbee River; so I struck a light, made a fire, and turned my horse loose, while I stretched myself to sleep.By and by, I heard the wolves howl.My horse came crowding near me for protection, for he was terribly frightened.I drove him off, but he returned, and drew nearer and nearer, and stood looking at me and at the fire, and dozing, and nodding, and tottering on his fore feet, for he was powerful tired.After a while, I heard a strange dismal cry.I thought at first it might be an owl.I heard it again, and then I knew it was not an owl, but must be a panther.I felt rather awkward, for I had no weapon but a double-bladed penknife.I however prepared for defence in the best way I could, and piled up small brands from the fire, to pepper him with, should he come nigh.The company of my horse now seemed a comfort to me; the poor creature laid down beside me and soon fell asleep, being so tired.I kept watch, and nodded and dozed, and started awake, and looked round, expecting to see the glaring eyes of the panther close upon me; but somehow or other, fatigue got the better of me, and I fell asleep outright.In the morning I found the tracks of a panther within sixty paces.They were as large as my two fists.He had evidently been walking backward and forward, trying to make up his mind to attack me; but luckily, he had not courage.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 40832.0——我拂晓前便醒了。月光从轻盈飘逸的云朵间泻入幽谷。篝火几乎燃尽了，人们裹着毯子，躺在它们周围。伴随着天边的第一抹亮光，我们的猎手贝蒂和年轻的混血儿安托万再次动身，渡河去寻找走失的马匹，几个将步枪落在河对岸的巡逻骑兵也和他们同行。由于河水很深，而且他们必须沿着对角线来顶着湍急的水流过河，所以他们不得不骑着最高大最强壮的马。
October 16th.—I awoke before daylight.The moon was shining feebly down into the glen, from among light drifting clouds; the camp fires were nearly burnt out, and the men lying about them, wrapped in blankets.With the first streak of day, our huntsman, Beatte, with Antoine, the young half-breed, set off to recross the river, in search of the stray horses, in company with several rangers who had left their rifles on the opposite shore.As the ford was deep, and they were obliged to cross in a diagonal line, against a rapid current, they had to be mounted on the tallest and strongest horses.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 到八点时，贝蒂回来了。他找到了马儿们，但是却把安托万给弄丢了。他说，安托万就是个孩子，是一个毫无经验、对森林一无所知的人。他走出了他的视线，然后就失踪了。可是，有许多人可以与他作伴，因为还有几个巡逻骑兵也走失了，并且老瑞安和他的那伙人也没有回来。
By eight o’clock, Beatte returned.He had found the horses, but had lost Antoine.The latter, he said, was a boy, a greenhorn, that knew nothing of the woods.He had wandered out of sight of him, and got lost.However, there were plenty more for him to fall in company with, as some of the rangers had gone astray also, and old Ryan and his party had not returned.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们一直等到第二天早上，希望落伍者们重新归队，但是他们并没有出现。队长总结说，对岸的印第安人对白人很友好，所以不必过于担心失踪者的安全。最大的危险是，他们的马也许会被掉队的奥塞奇人在夜间偷走了。因此，他决定继续前进，只是在营地留下一些殿后的人，等待他们回来。
We waited until the morning was somewhat advanced, in hopes of being rejoined by the stragglers, but they did not make their appearance.The Captain observed, that the Indians on the opposite side of the river, were all well disposed to the whites; so that no serious apprehensions need be entertained for the safety of the missing.The greatest danger was, that their horses might be stolen in the night by straggling Osages.He determined, therefore, to proceed, leaving a rear guard in the camp, to await their arrival.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我坐在山谷上部溪水中一块凸起的岩石上，自娱自乐地看着眼前水流变幻的景象。首先，为出发作准备。马儿们从营地周围被赶了回来，巡逻骑兵们策马奔走在岩石和灌木之间，寻找其他失散到远处的马匹。人们匆忙地收拾着野营装备。水壶和平底锅从一群人手里传到另一群人手里时的吆喝声，人们对倔强难驯的马匹的呵斥声，以及对那些已经装上行李，兀自跑到一边嚼草的马匹的高声咒骂声混合成了一片。而在这一片乱哄哄的声音当中，我们的小个子法国人托尼什的声音格外清晰。
I sat on a rock that overhung the spring at the upper part of the dell, and amused myself by watching the changing scene before me.First, the preparations for departure.Horses driven in from the purlieus of the camp; rangers riding about among rocks and bushes in quest of others that had strayed to a distance; the bustle of packing up camp equipage, and the clamor after kettles and frying-pans borrowed by one mess from another, mixed up with oaths and exclamations at restive horses, or others that had wandered away to graze after being packed, among which the voice of our little Frenchman, Tonish, was particularly to be distinguished.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 号声响起，预示着该上马出发了。整个队伍排成不规则的一列沿着山谷向下前进，穿过广阔的森林，一路曲曲折折，渐渐消失在丛林之间，可是人们的叫嚷声和号角声仍不时地从后方传来。殿后者仍待在山谷下半部分的树下。有的骑在马上，肩上扛着步枪；其他的则坐在火堆旁或者躺在地上，用低低的、懒洋洋的声音闲聊着。他们的马没有上鞍，在周围站着打盹。而其中一个充分利用这段休闲时间的巡逻骑兵，正在一个放在树干上的小镜子前刮着胡子。
The bugle sounded the signal to mount and march.The troop filed off in irregular line down the glen, and through the open forest, winding and gradually disappearing among the trees, though the clamor of voices and the notes of the bugle could be heard for some time afterward.The rear-guard remained under the trees in the lower part of the dell, some on horseback, with their rifles on their shoulders; others seated by the fire or lying on the ground, gossiping in a low, lazy tone of voice, their horses unsaddled, standing and dozing around, while one of the rangers, profiting by this interval of leizure, was shaving himself before a pocket mirror stuck against the trunk of a tree.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 远处的喧闹声和号角声渐渐消失了，山谷恢复了往日的寂静，只是偶尔被火堆旁人们的窃窃低语声，或树林间某个人沉重的口哨声，或秋叶的瑟瑟声所划破。最轻微的一阵风都能把秋叶从树枝上刮落，在空中雪花般盘旋飞舞，预示着一年荣耀的结束。
The clamor of voices and the notes of the bugle at length died away, and the glen relapsed into quiet and silence, broken occasionally by the low murmuring tone of the group around the fire, or the pensive whistle of some laggard among the trees; or the rustling of the yellow leaves, which the lightest breath of air brought down in wavering showers, a sign of the departing glories of the year.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第十四章 射鹿
CHAPTER XIV. DEER-SHOOTING.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——大草原上的生活——漂亮的营地——猎手的幸运——德拉瓦尔人的轶事和他们的迷信
—LIFE ON THE PRAIRIES.—BEAUTIFUL ENCAMPMENT.—HUNTER’S LUCK.—ANECDOTES OF THE DELAWARES AND THEIR SUPERSTITIONS.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 穿过河边林地的外围之后，我们开始爬山，经过一片高低起伏的橡树林间的空地，踏上了一条向西的路。在那儿放眼望去，四周尽是被大大小小的树林和树丛所覆盖的山峦和峡谷。当我们缓慢前进的时候，队伍前边的人发现在大约半英里远的一个绿色山坡上，有四头鹿在吃草。显然，它们没有发现我们的到来，继续非常安静地吃着草。一个年轻的巡逻骑兵从队长那儿得到许可去猎取它们，于是整个队伍长长地排成一排停下，静静地看着他。他缓慢而又小心翼翼地驱动着坐骑，绕了个圈，走到了一片挡在他和鹿之间的树林里。然后他下了马，把马留在树林中，绕着一个土墩爬了过去，从我们的视线里消失了。我们现在紧紧地盯着鹿，它们仍然在吃草，完全没有意识到危险正悄悄临近。很快，传来了一声尖锐的来复枪声。一头硕大的雄鹿猛然跳起，然后倒在了地上；它的同伴们都四散逃跑了。我们整个队伍马上便一哄而散了。队伍中的年轻人急不可待地飞奔出去，渴望能够射杀逃亡的鹿。而追逐的人群中最惹人注目的人物，就是我们那位骑着银灰色马的小个子法国人托尼什。他一看见鹿，就把他的驮马们撇到一边了。号角声响过很长时间之后，我们四散的队伍才重新聚齐，继续我们的旅程。
Having passed through the skirt of woodland bordering the river, we ascended the hills, taking a westerly course through an undulating country of “oak openings,” where the eye stretched over wide tracts of hill and dale, diversified by forests, groves, and clumps of trees.As we were proceeding at a slow pace, those who were at the head of the line descried four deer grazing on a grassy slope about half a mile distant.They apparently had not perceived our approach, and continued to graze in perfect tranquillity.A young ranger obtained permission from the Captain to go in pursuit of them, and the troop halted in lengthened line, watching him in silence.Walking his horse slowly and cautiously, he made a circuit until a screen of wood intervened between him and the deer.Dismounting then, he left his horse among the trees, and creeping round a knoll, was hidden from our view.We now kept our eyes intently fixed on the deer, which continued grazing, unconscious of their danger.Presently there was the sharp report of a rifle; a fine buck made a convulsive bound and fell to the earth; his companions scampered off.Immediately our whole line of march was broken; there was a helter-skelter galloping of the youngsters of the troop, eager to get a shot at the fugitives; and one of the most conspicuous personages in the chase was our little Frenchman Tonish, on his silver-gray; having abandoned his pack-horses at the first sight of the deer.It was some time before our scattered forces could be recalled by the bugle, and our march resumed.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 那天的行程中，我们有两三次被这种匆忙的追逐打断。队伍中的年轻人为进入这片猎物丰富的未开发地区而兴奋不已。他们还都不习惯遵守纪律、约束或秩序。可是，没有一个人比托尼什更难管。由于对自己的狩猎技巧感到强烈自负，并且对自我炫耀有着一种无法抑制的激情，所以一旦有猎物被惊动跑了出来，他就总是会像一只不安分的猎犬那样飞奔过去，然后又常常被狠狠地呵斥住。
Two or three times in the course of the day we were interrupted by hurry-scurry scenes of the kind.The young men of the troop were full of excitement on entering an unexplored country abounding in game, and they were too little accustomed to discipline or restraint to be kept in order.No one, however, was more unmanageable than Tonish.Having an intense conceit of his skill as a hunter, and an irrepressible passion for display, he was continually sallying forth, like an ill-broken hound, whenever any game was started, and had as often to be whipped back.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 最终，他的好奇心得到了有力的抑制。一头肥壮的母鹿连蹦带跳地跑了过来，整支队伍都能看到它。托尼什下了马，端起他的步枪，射了非常棒的一枪。那头母鹿继续跳着。他跳上了马，像个杂技演员那样站在马鞍上，继续紧盯着猎物，好像肯定会看到它倒下。然而，那头母鹿一路高高兴兴地奔了下去。队伍里爆发出一阵哄堂大笑，小个子法国人灰溜溜地坐到马鞍上，开始骂骂咧咧地呵斥那些步履沉重的驮马，似乎它们才是罪魁祸首。于是，一段时间内，我们不再受他那聒噪不休的自吹自擂的折磨了。
At length his curiosity got a salutary check.A fat doe came bounding along in full view of the whole line.Tonish dismounted, levelled his rifle, and had a fair shot.The doe kept on.He sprang upon his horse, stood up on the saddle like a posture-master, and continued gazing after the animal as if certain to see it fall.The doe, however, kept on its way rejoicing; a laugh broke out along the line, the little Frenchman slipped quietly into his saddle, began to belabor and blaspheme the wandering pack-horses, as if they had been to blame, and for some time we were relieved from his vaunting and vaporing.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 行军过程中，我们来到了一个残留的印第安人的旧营地。这个旧营地位于一条美丽溪流的岸边，长满苔藓的地上到处是鹿留下的脚印。由于我们正处在波尼人的领地上，所以我们理所当然地认为这曾是那些可怕的游牧者的营地。但是，仔细观察过这些屋子的形状和分布之后，医生说这可能是一些勇敢的德拉瓦尔人在一次短暂的冒险中进入这片狩猎场时留下的营地。
In one place of our march we came to the remains of an old Indian encampment, on the banks of a fine stream, with the moss-grown sculls of deer lying here and there about it.As we were in the Pawnee country, it was supposed, of course, to have been a camp of those formidable rovers; the Doctor, however, after considering the shape and disposition of the lodges, pronounced it the camp of some bold Delawares, who had probably made a brief and dashing excursion into these dangerous hunting grounds.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 又前进了一段距离之后，我们发现了两英里远的地方有两个骑在马背上的人，他们正沿着一座光秃秃的山丘的边缘和我们平行前进。显然，他们在侦察我们。部队停了下来，盯着他们并不断猜测着。他们是印第安人吗？如果是印第安人，那他们是波尼人吗？在这些充满敌意的平原上行走时，看到远方地平线上巡行的骑手，是一件能激发各种想象和让人躁动不安的事。这就像是战争时，在海上看到一艘帆船，那有可能是一艘私掠船或海盗船。通过一架小型望远镜侦察了那两个骑手之后，我们的猜疑就很快消除了，因为我们发现，原来他们是我们之前留在营地里的两个人。他们是来和我们汇合的，只是走错了路。
Having proceeded some distance farther, we observed a couple of figures on horseback, slowly moving parallel to us along the edge of a naked hill about two miles distant; and apparently reconnoitring us.There was a halt, and much gazing and conjecturing.Were they Indians?If Indians, were they Pawnees?There is something exciting to the imagination and stirring to the feelings, while traversing these hostile plains, in seeing a horseman prowling along the horizon.It is like descrying a sail at sea in time of war, when it may be either a privateer or a pirate.Our conjectures were soon set at rest by reconnoitring the two horsemen through a small spyglass, when they proved to be two of the men we had left at the camp, who had set out to rejoin us, and had wandered from the track.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们今天的行军活力无限，令人愉快。我们正处于一个充满危险的地区，正费力地穿越一片到目前为止除了可能有某个设阱捕兽者之外，没有一个白人踏足过的土地。今天天气非常好，温和宜人，令人愉快。湛蓝的天空中飘着几朵羽毛般轻盈的白云；空气几乎完全透明，纯净而又柔和；美丽的大地一望无际，正沐浴在秋日金黄的阳光下。但是，一切都是那么寂静，毫无生气，荒无人烟。显然，没有人住在这里！好像有一道禁令高悬在这片美丽而又命运多舛的地区之上。那些印第安人也不敢住在这里，只是把它当作一个冒险之地，打几天猎，然后离开。
Our march this day was animating and delightful.We were in a region of adventure; breaking our way through a country hitherto untrodden by white men, excepting perchance by some solitary trapper.The weather was in its perfection, temperate, genial and enlivening; a deep blue sky with a few light feathery clouds, an atmosphere of perfect transparency, an air pure and bland, and a glorious country spreading out far and wide in the golden sunshine of an autumnal day; but all silent, lifeless, without a human habitation, and apparently without a human inhabitant!It was as if a ban hung over this fair but fated region.The very Indians dared not abide here, but made it a mere scene of perilous enterprise, to hunt for a few days, and then away.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约向西走了十五英里之后，我们在一个美丽的半岛上驻扎下来。这个半岛是由一条蜿蜒的小溪围成的，溪水很深，很清澈，几乎凝滞不动。半岛被一个壮观的小树林所覆盖，里面的树木高耸挺拔。几个猎手马上在营地里的喧闹声把周围的猎物吓跑之前，出去寻找猎物了。我们的贝蒂也拿上来复枪独自出发了，踏上了和其他人不同方向的道路。
After a march of about fifteen miles west we encamped in a beautiful peninsula, made by the windings and doublings of a deep, clear, and almost motionless brook, and covered by an open grove of lofty and magnificent trees.Several hunters immediately started forth in quest of game before the noise of the camp should frighten it from the vicinity.Our man, Beatte, also took his rifle and went forth alone, in a different course from the rest.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 而我则躺在树下的草地上望着云朵遐想，尽情享受着这乡间的宁静。真的，我很难想象还有别的一种生活更能有意识地让身心达到如此健康的状态。上午几个小时的骑马行军中穿插着好几次的临时打猎；下午则在一条小溪边上壮观的小树林里宿营；晚上举行鹿肉会餐，把刚杀的鹿架在火炭上烤着吃；还有刚从灌木丛里打来的火鸡和在树上采集的野蜂蜜，所有这些都是城里的美食家们所无法想象的。而在深夜，或者是美美地睡在旷野之中，或者是凝望着闪烁在树木之间的月亮和星星。
For my own part, I lay on the grass under the trees, and built castles in the clouds, and indulged in the very luxury of rural repose.Indeed I can scarcely conceive a kind of life more calculated to put both mind and body in a healthful tone.A morning’s ride of several hours diversified by hunting incidents; an encampment in the afternoon under some noble grove on the borders of a stream; an evening banquet of venison, fresh killed, roasted, or broiled on the coals; turkeys just from the thickets and wild honey from the trees; and all relished with an appetite unknown to the gourmets of the cities.And at night—such sweet sleeping in the open air, or waking and gazing at the moon and stars, shining between the trees!

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 然而，在目前的情况下，我们没有多少理由夸耀自己的食物。白天只猎杀了一头鹿，而我们这一屋并没有分到鹿肉。因此，我们不得不用从上一个营地带来的些许残留的火鸡，加上一两片咸猪肉来填补我们强烈的食欲。然而，这种食物匮乏的情形并没有持续太长的时间。天黑前，一个年轻的猎手满载着猎物回来了。他射杀了一头鹿，然后以一种颇为艺术的方式把它肢解，接着把肉放到一个兽皮制的袋子里，斜挎在肩上，脚步沉重地把它背回了营地。
On the present occasion, however, we had not much reason to boast of our larder.But one deer had been killed during the day, and none of that had reached our lodge.We were fain, therefore, to stay our keen appetites by some scrape of turkey brought from the last encampment, eked out with a slice or two of salt pork.This scarcity, however, did not continue long.Before dark a young hunter returned well laden with spoil.He had shot a deer, cut it up in an artist-like style, and, putting the meat in a kind of sack made of the hide, had slung it across his shoulder and trudged with it to camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 之后不久，贝蒂也出现了，马背上放着一头肥壮的母鹿。这是他带回来的第一个猎物，我很高兴看到他带回来了一个或许可以抹去大家关于臭鼬的记忆的战利品。他一言不发地把猎物放在我们的篝火旁，然后转身去卸马鞍。他简洁地回答了我们关于他打猎的所有问题。然而，如果说贝蒂对他所做过的事遵从着这种印第安人沉默寡言的性情，那么托尼什则通过自吹自擂他想要干什么对此作了补充。既然我们现在在一个很好的猎场里，那他就打算好好利用这块土地。如果我们采纳他的建议，那么从今往后，我们的屋子里将满是猎物。值得庆幸的是，他的夸夸其谈并没有妨碍他工作。这头母鹿被熟练地分割开来，几块肥胖的肋骨被放在火前烤着，咖啡壶也再次被灌满。一小会儿之后，我们便可以奢侈地补偿我们之前匮乏的晚餐了。
Not long after, Beatte made his appearance with a fat doe across his horse.It was the first game he had brought in, and I was glad to see him with a trophy that might efface the memory of the polecat.He laid the carcass down by our fire without saying a word, and then turned to unsaddle his horse; nor could any questions from us about his hunting draw from him more than laconic replies.If Beatte, however, observed this Indian taciturnity about what he had done, Tonish made up for it by boasting of what he meant to do.Now that we were in a good hunting country he meant to take the field, and, if we would take his word for it, our lodge would henceforth be overwhelmed with game.Luckily his talking did not prevent his working, the doe was skilfully dissected, several fat ribs roasted before the fire, the coffee kettle replenished, and in a little while we were enabled to indemnify ourselves luxuriously for our late meagre repast.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 队长到很晚才回来，而且两手空空。当他正在追逐他通常的猎物——鹿时，发现了一处大约有六十头麋鹿的鹿群的脚印。他从未猎杀过这种动物，然而猎杀麋鹿是营地里所有的老猎手所向往的目标。于是，他放弃了对鹿的追逐，而沿着新发现的脚印追踪下去。一段时间之后，他看到了麋鹿，并有好几次开枪射击的机会，但是他却急于打倒跑在前面的一头大雄鹿。最终因发现整个鹿群都有逃脱的危险，他便向一头母鹿开了火。子弹打中了目标，不过那个动物还有足够的力气继续和它的同伴们一起跑一阵子。通过血迹，他断定它受到了致命的一伤，但是夜幕降临，他没法再继续追逐了，于是只能放弃搜索，等待天亮。
The Captain did not return until late, and he returned empty-handed.He had been in pursuit of his usual game, the deer, when he came upon the tracks of a gang of about sixty elk.Having never killed an animal of the kind, and the elk being at this moment an object of ambition among all the veteran hunters of the camp, he abandoned his pursuit of the deer, and followed the newly discovered track.After some time he came in sight of the elk, and had several fair chances of a shot, but was anxious to bring down a large buck which kept in the advance.Finding at length there was danger of the whole gang escaping him, he fired at a doe.The shot took effect, but the animal had sufficient strength to keep on for a time with its companions.From the tracks of blood he felt confident it was mortally wounded, but evening came on, he could not keep the trail, and had to give up the search until morning.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 老瑞安和他的小分队还是没有和我们汇合，我们年轻的混血儿安托万也没有露面。因此，我们决定第二天继续呆在营地里，从而给所有的落伍者充足的时间到达。
Old Ryan and his little band had not yet rejoined us, neither had our young half-breed Antoine made his appearance.It was determined, therefore, to remain at our encampment for the following day, to give time for all stragglers to arrive.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这天晚上，老猎手们的谈话转向了德拉瓦尔人部落。在我们今天的行进过程中，曾经路过他们的一个营地。猎手们讲述了关于他们强大的战斗力和灵巧的狩猎技能的一些轶事。他们过去是奥塞奇人的死敌。虽然奥塞奇人倾向于把他们的勇猛无畏归结于一种古怪的原因，但却很敬畏他们这一点。“看看那些德拉瓦尔人，”他们会说，“腿那么短，根本跑不起来，他们必须站在那儿格斗。”实际上，德拉瓦尔人的腿确实有些短，而奥塞奇人的特点则是四肢修长。
The conversation this evening, among the old huntsmen, turned upon the Delaware tribe, one of whose encampments we had passed in the course of the day; and anecdotes were given of their prowess in war and dexterity in hunting.They used to be deadly foes of the Osages, who stood in great awe of their desperate valor, though they were apt to attribute it to a whimsical cause.“Look at the Delawares,” would they say, “dey got short leg—no can run—must stand and fight a great heap.”In fact the Delawares are rather short legged, while the Osages are remarkable for length of limb.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 无论是战争还是狩猎，德拉瓦尔人的征程总是范围很广而又无所畏惧。他们一小队人也敢深入到那些危险而又充满敌意的旷野，甚至还把他们的营地扎到落基山脉中。这种勇敢的性情，也许是在一定程度上受到了他们的一条迷信的信条的鼓励。他们相信有一种形如巨鹰的保护神，会在他们视线所不及的高空中盘旋，并俯视着他们。有时，当神灵为他们感到高兴时，他便飞到较低的区域，这时便有可能看见他伸展着巨大的翅膀盘旋于白云之间。此时，这个季节就是吉利的：谷物长势良好，他们打猎时也会取得更大的成功。然而，有时他也会生气，继而把怒气通过他的声音——雷发泄出来，或者眨动眼睛，制造闪电，杀死他不喜欢的事物。
The expeditions of the Delawares, whether of war or hunting, are wide and fearless; a small band of them will penetrate far into these dangerous and hostile wilds, and will push their encampments even to the Rocky Mountains.This daring temper may be in some measure encouraged by one of the superstitions of their creed.They believe that a guardian spirit, in the form of a great eagle, watches over them, hovering in the sky, far out of sight.Sometimes, when well pleased with them, he wheels down into the lower regions, and may be seen circling with widespread wings against the white clouds; at such times the seasons are propitious, the corn grows finely, and they have great success in hunting.Sometimes, however, he is angry, and then he vents his rage in the thunder, which is his voice, and the lightning, which is the flashing of his eye, and strikes dead the object of his displeasure.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 德拉瓦尔人会向这个神灵献祭，而他则会偶尔落下翅膀上的一根羽毛以示满意。这些羽毛能让佩戴者隐身，不受伤害。实际上，印第安人通常认为鹰的羽毛拥有神秘而又至高无上的美德。
The Delawares make sacrifices to this spirit, who occasionally lets drop a feather from his wing in token of satisfaction.These feathers render the wearer invisible, and invulnerable.Indeed, the Indians generally consider the feathers of the eagle possessed of occult and sovereign virtues.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 有一次，一群德拉瓦尔人进入波尼人猎场进行勇敢的远足，却被包围在一块大平原上，几乎全军覆没。残余的人马躲避在一个孤零零的圆锥形小山的顶部，这小山处在大草原的中间，看起来几乎像是人工堆砌起来的。在这儿，为首的战士几乎被逼无望，于是他杀了他的马献祭给保护神。突然，一只巨鹰从天空中俯冲下来，用它的爪子抓起祭品，并又爬升到了空中，然后从它的翅膀上抖落下一根大羽毛。这个首领高兴地抓着它，把它固定在前额上。然后领着手下奔下山丘，从敌人中间杀出一条血路，所有人都毫发无损。
At one time a party of the Delawares, in the course of a bold excursion into the Pawnee hunting grounds, were surrounded on one of the great plains, and nearly destroyed.The remnant took refuge on the summit of one of those isolated and conical hills which rise almost like artificial mounds, from the midst of the prairies.Here the chief warrior, driven almost to despair, sacrificed his horse to the tutelar spirit.Suddenly an enormous eagle, rushing down from the sky, bore off the victim in his talons, and mounting into the air, dropped a quill feather from his wing.The chief caught it up with joy, bound it to his forehead, and, leading his followers down the hill, cut his way through the enemy with great slaughter, and without any one of his party receiving a wound.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第十五章 搜寻麋鹿
CHAPTER XV. THE SEARCH FOR THE ELK.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——波尼人的故事
—PAWNEE STORIES.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 黎明时分，营地里的主要猎手们都提起精神，向着不同的方向出发，去寻找这片土地上的猎物。队长的兄弟比恩中士是最先出发的一拨人中的一个，他早饭前便凯旋了。几乎就在营地的边缘，他打死了一头肥壮的母鹿。
With the morning dawn, the prime hunters of the camp were all on the alert, and set off in different directions, to beat up the country for game.The Captain’s brother, Sergeant Bean, was among the first, and returned before breakfast with success, having killed a fat doe, almost within the purlieus of the camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 早饭结束后，队长就骑上他的马，去寻找他前一天晚上打伤的那头麋鹿。他相信它一定受了致命的一击。我决定加入他的搜寻行列。于是，我们一起出发了。同行的还有他那个中士兄弟和一个中尉。两个巡逻骑兵徒步跟着，去带回这个中士之前杀死的那头母鹿。我们没骑多远，便来到了母鹿倒下的地方。那是在一座山丘旁边，一片美丽林地的中央。两个巡逻骑兵马上开始俯身干活。运用真正的猎手才具有的熟练技能，他们把它肢解了，以便运回营地，而我们则继续前进。我们沿路经过倾斜的山坡，穿过灌木丛和稀疏的树林，直到来到了一片因无数麋鹿栖息而把高高的野草压成无数“鹿床”的草地。队长最初就是在这儿惊动那群麋鹿的。对周围仔细地探察了一会儿之后，他指出了它们的“踪迹”；那些脚印和带犄角的牛的一样大。于是，他循着踪迹悄悄前进，其余的人则排成印第安人式的列队跟在他后面。最终，他在那头麋鹿被射中的地方停了下来。周围草上的点点血迹表明，那一枪发挥了作用。从脚印边缘灌木和草皮上的点点血迹可以很明显地看出，那只受伤的动物和兽群里其余的成员一起跑出了一段距离。最终，这些血迹突然消失了。“在这周围的某个地方，”队长说，“那头麋鹿一定是离开了群体。”无论何时，当它们发现自己受了致命伤之后，都将走到一边，找一个偏僻的地方独自死去。
When breakfast was over, the Captain mounted his horse, to go in quest of the elk which he had wounded on the preceding evening; and which, he was persuaded, had received its death-wound.I determined to join him in the search, and we accordingly sallied forth together, accompanied also by his brother, the sergeant, and a lieutenant.Two rangers followed on foot, to bring home the carcass of the doe which the sergeant had killed.We had not ridden far, when we came to where it lay, on the side of a hill, in the midst of a beautiful woodland scene.The two rangers immediately fell to work, with true hunters’ skill, to dismember it, and prepare it for transportation to the camp, while we continued on our course.We passed along sloping hillsides, among skirts of thicket and scattered forest trees, until we came to a place where the long herbage was pressed down with numerous elk beds.Here the Captain had first roused the gang of elks, and, after looking about diligently for a little while, he pointed out their “trail,” the foot-prints of which were as large as those of horned cattle.He now put himself upon the track, and went quietly forward, the rest of us following him in Indian file.At length he halted at the place where the elk had been when shot at.Spots of blood on the surrounding herbage showed that the shot had been effective.The wounded animal had evidently kept for some distance with the rest of the herd, as could be seen by sprinklings of blood here and there, on the shrubs and weeds bordering the trail.These at length suddenly disappeared.“Somewhere hereabout,” said the Captain, “the elk must have turned off from the gang.”Whenever they feel themselves mortally wounded, they will turn aside, and seek some out-of-the-way place to die alone.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这幅一头受伤的鹿的最后时刻的场景中，有些东西会触动一个尚未对“追逐”这一高雅的娱乐方式麻木不仁的人的同情心。然而，这种同情转瞬即逝。人类天生是掠夺性的动物，无论因文明而改变多少，人们还是会轻易陷入其毁灭的本能。我发现我贪婪、残暴的倾向在大草原上与日俱增。
There was something in this picture of the last moments of a wounded deer, to touch the sympathies of one not hardened to the gentle disports of the chase; such sympathies, however, are but transient.Man is naturally an animal of prey; and, however changed by civilization, will readily relapse into his instinct for destruction.I found my ravenous and sanguinary propensities daily growing stronger upon the prairies.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在周围探察了一会儿之后，队长便成功地发现了那头受伤的麋鹿单独的足迹，它是沿着和鹿群成直角的方向转身离开的，进入了一片稀疏开阔的树林。血迹变得越来越模糊、稀少，相隔的距离也越来越远，最终便停止了。而地面非常坚硬，野草被晒得很干，都枯萎了，再也看不到那头动物的脚印了。
After looking about for a little while, the Captain succeeded in finding the separate trail of the wounded elk, which turned off almost at right angles from that of the herd, and entered an open forest of scattered trees.The traces of blood became more faint and rare, and occurred at greater distances: at length they ceased altogether, and the ground was so hard, and the herbage so much parched and withered, that the footprints of the animal could no longer be perceived.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那头麋鹿一定在这周围的某个地方，”队长说，“你们看空中盘旋着的那些美洲鹫就知道了，因为它们总是在某个动物尸体的上方以这种方式盘旋。”然而，那头死了的麋鹿是不可能逃跑的，所以，让我们先追踪活着的那些麋鹿的脚印吧！它们有可能就停在不远处，我们也许能看到它们正在吃草，这样便可以再偷袭它们一次。
“The elk must lie somewhere in this neighborhood,” said the Captain, “as you may know by those turkey-buzzards wheeling about in the air: for they always hover in that way above some carcass.”However, the dead elk cannot get away, so let us follow the trail of the living ones: they may have halted at no great distance, and we may find them grazing, and get another crack at them.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 于是我们返了回来，重新追踪麋鹿鹿群的脚印，一路上曲曲折折地经过了覆盖着稀疏橡树的山丘和河谷。我们时不时地会瞥见蹦蹦跳跳穿过林间空地的鹿，但是队长的注意力并没有被这种低等的猎物所分散，他想要猎杀的只是麋鹿。也有一大群火鸡被我们的马蹄声所惊动，有的迈着它们长长的腿拼命逃窜，其余的则拍动翅膀飞上枝头，在上面伸长了脖子盯着我们。队长不允许任何人向它们开枪，以防惊动麋鹿。他希望可以在附近找到它们。最后，我们来到了树林尽头陡峭的河岸边上。雷德福克河就蜿蜒流淌在我们脚下那宽阔的沙地之间。我们沿着足迹看过去，发现鹿群朝着河岸一路向下，穿过了平坦的沙地，直到河里，说明这群麋鹿在前一夜过了河。“没有必要再继续追了，”队长说，“麋鹿一定是吓坏了，过河之后，可能还会不停地跑上二十英里。”
We accordingly returned, and resumed the trail of the elks, which led us a straggling course over hill and dale, covered with scattered oaks.Every now and then we would catch a glimpse of a deer bounding away across some glade of the forest, but the Captain was not to be diverted from his elk hunt by such inferior game.A large flock of wild turkeys, too, were roused by the trampling of our horses; some scampered off as fast as their long legs could carry them; others fluttered up into the trees, where they remained with outstretched necks, gazing at us.The Captain would not allow a rifle to be discharged at them, lest it should alarm the elk, which he hoped to find in the vicinity.At length we came to where the forest ended in a steep bank, and the Red Fork wound its way below us, between broad sandy shores.The trail descended the bank, and we could trace it, with our eyes, across the level sands, until it terminated in the river, which, it was evident, the gang had forded on the preceding evening.“It is needless to follow on any farther,” said the Captain.“The elk must have been much frightened, and, after crossing the river, may have kept on for twenty miles without stopping.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的小团队便分开了，中尉和中士绕了个圈子去寻找猎物，而队长和我则朝着营地进发。在路上，我们发现了一串一年多前留下的野牛的脚印。这条小径并不比普通的足迹更宽，但脚印却深深地陷在地里，因为这些动物彼此紧挨着排成一列前进。之后不一会儿，我们遇到两个徒步打猎的巡逻骑兵。他们打伤了一头麋鹿，可它却逃跑了。但在追这头麋鹿的时候，他们发现了队长在前一晚击中的那头。他们返身带我们到它那儿去。这是一只高贵的动物，跟一只一岁的小母牛一样大，躺在树林里的一片开阔地里。这儿距离它被打伤的地方大约有一英里半远。我们之前看到的那些美洲鹫正在它上方的空中盘旋着。队长的论断似乎得到了证实。这可怜的动物，显然是在生命消逝之际离弃了没有受伤的同伴，转到一边独自死去。
Our little party now divided, the lieutenant and sergeant making a circuit in quest of game, and the Captain and myself taking the direction of the camp.On our way, we came to a buffalo track, more than a year old.It was not wider than an ordinary footpath, and worn deep into the soil; for these animals follow each other in single file.Shortly afterward, we met two rangers on foot, hunting.They had wounded an elk, but he had escaped; and in pursuing him, had found the one shot by the Captain on the preceding evening.They turned back, and conducted us to it.It was a noble animal, as large as a yearling heifer, and lay in an open part of the forest, about a mile and a half distant from the place where it had been shot.The turkey-buzzards, which we had previously noticed, were wheeling in the air above it.The observation of the Captain seemed verified.The poor animal, as life was ebbing away, had apparently abandoned its unhurt companions, and turned aside to die alone.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 队长和那两个巡逻骑兵立刻开始干活，他们用猎刀给这尸体剥皮并肢解。它里面已经腐烂了，但是还是有足够的肉块从肋骨和腰腿上割下来，堆在了一张展开的兽皮上。他们沿着兽皮的边缘凿出一些洞，把硬皮带穿过去，然后像个口袋一样拎起来，挂在队长的马鞍后面。在此期间，那些美洲鹫一直在头顶上盘旋着，等待着我们离开，然后俯冲下来，在尸体上饱餐一顿。
