第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的处境是：山丘切断了一切，因而视线受阻，看不到远处。于是我们成了谣言的牺牲品。残酷的敌人应该就在附近，一场正面冲突看来在所难免。这时，马匹都被赶进了营地，正冲撞在篝火之间，踩踏在包裹之上。每一个人都尽力准备作战，但这儿还是一片混乱。在先前的火警中，马鞍、缰绳、步枪、火药桶及其他的装备都已经被抓离它们原来的位置，在树林中扔得到处都是。
Our situation, shut in among hills, prevented our seeing to any distance, and left us a prey to all these rumors.A cruel enemy was supposed to be at hand, and an immediate attack apprehended.The horses by this time were driven into the camp, and were dashing about among the fires, and trampling upon the baggage.Every one endeavored to prepare for action; but here was the perplexity.During the late alarm of fire, the saddles, bridles, rifles, powder-horns, and other equipments, had been snatched out of their places, and thrown helter-skelter among the trees.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一个人喊道：“我的马鞍去哪儿了？”另一个人喊道：“有人见过我的步枪吗？”第三个人喊道：“谁能借给我一颗子弹？”他正在给手枪装弹药。“我的子弹盒找不到了。”“上帝啊，帮我给这匹马固定好马鞍吧！”另一个喊道，“它太不老实了，我拿它没办法啊！”在匆忙和担忧之中，他把马鞍给前后放反了。
“Where is my saddle?” cried one.“Has any one seen my rifle?” cried another.“Who will lend me a ball?” cried a third, who was loading his piece.“I have lost my bullet pouch.”“For God’s sake help me to girth this horse!” cried another: “he’s so restive I can do nothing with him.”In his hurry and worry, he had put on the saddle the hind part before!

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 有些人假装无所畏惧，大摇大摆地走动和高声地谈论着；其余的人则沉默不语，不慌不忙地准备着自己的马和武器。就是在后面这些人身上，我得到了最大的依赖感。有些人一想到要遇到印第安人了，很明显地就兴高采烈起来；但没有人比我年轻的瑞士旅行伙伴更兴奋的了。他对野外冒险有着一种狂热。贝蒂则把马牵到营地的后面，把步枪靠在一棵树上，然后一声不吭地坐在篝火旁。与此同时，正忙着做饭的小个子托尼什，在每一次干活停下来的间隙，不是在吹嘘，就是唱歌，或是在咒骂，并假装着不自然的兴高采烈。这使我强烈地怀疑，这些欢欣实际上源于一种发自心底的小小恐惧。
Some affected to swagger and talk bold; others said nothing, but went on steadily, preparing their horses and weapons, and on these I felt the most reliance.Some were evidently excited and elated with the idea of an encounter with Indians; and none more so than my young Swiss fellow-traveller, who had a passion for wild adventure.Our man, Beatte, led his horses in the rear of the camp, placed his rifle against a tree, then seated himself by the fire in perfect silence.On the other hand, little Tonish, who was busy cooking, stopped every moment from his work to play the fanfaron, singing, swearing, and affecting an unusual hilarity, which made me strongly suspect there was some little fright at bottom, to cause all this effervescence.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约有十二个巡逻骑兵一给他们的马上好马鞍，便朝着据说是波尼人袭击猎手的方向冲去了。以防营地遭到攻击，我们现在决定把马放到后面的峡谷。在那儿，它们可以免遭弓箭或子弹的威胁。而且我们也决定把守在峡谷的边缘。峡谷可以作为一个战壕，边缘的树木和灌木丛将足以抵挡敌人的任何弓箭。另外，波尼人对攻打这类隐蔽的地方是很谨慎的。正如我之前曾经说过的那样，他们的战斗都发生在开阔的大草原上，在那儿，骑着迅捷的战马，他们能够像老鹰那样飞扑向敌人，或是围着他们开弓放箭。然而，我也禁不住担心，一旦被这些据说就在附近的骑术精湛且能征善战的野蛮人攻击，我们还会面临很大的危险，因为我们新招募的巡逻骑兵大都缺乏经验和纪律，许多年轻一点儿的还都年轻气盛，似乎一心想要冒险和赢得战功。
About a dozen of the rangers, as soon as they could saddle their horses, dashed off in the direction in which the Pawnees were said to have attacked the hunters.It was now determined, in case our camp should be assailed, to put our horses in the ravine in the rear, where they would be out of danger from arrow or rifle-ball, and to take our stand within the edge of the ravine.This would serve as a trench, and the trees and thickets with which it was bordered, would be sufficient to turn aside any shaft of the enemy.The Pawnees, besides, are wary of attacking any covert of the kind; their warfare, as I have already observed, lies in the open prairie, where, mounted upon their fleet horses, they can swoop like hawks upon their enemy, or wheel about him and discharge their arrows.Still I could not but perceive, that, in case of being attacked by such a number of these well-mounted and war-like savages as were said to be at hand, we should be exposed to considerable risk from the inexperience and want of discipline of our newly raised rangers, and from the very courage of many of the younger ones who seemed bent on adventure and exploit.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 到这时，队长回到了营地，每一个人都挤到他周围打听消息。他告诉我们，他在侦察过程中前进了一段距离，然后慢慢返回营地。途经一座光秃秃的山丘的山梁时，他看到在一座平行的山丘的边缘有什么东西，看上去像是一个人。他停下来仔细查看，可是它纹丝不动，于是他猜测那是一丛灌木或是山后某棵树的树梢。他又重新上路，而它也同样开始沿着平行的方向移动。此刻，它旁边的另一个身影站了起来，此人要么是之前一直躺着，要么是刚刚从山的另一面爬上来的。队长停下来注视着他们；而他们也同样停了下来。然后他躺在草地上，他们则开始走动。当他站起来时，他们又停了下来，好像是在观察他。由于知道印第安人喜欢派侦察兵和哨兵驻守在光秃秃的山顶上，以便获得广阔的视野，因此他的疑虑也因这些人的可疑之举而增加了不少。此时，他把自己的军便帽放在步枪的一端，并在空中挥舞。他们并没有在意这个信号。然后，他又继续前进，直到进入了一片林地的边缘把自己隐藏起来，不被他们看见。避开他们的视线一会儿之后，他又探头张望，这时他看到那两个人已经轻快地跑了过去。他们所走的山丘和他站的位置之间隔着一道弧形的山坳，他们似乎是在尽力在他到达营地之前超过他。由于怀疑他们可能属于某个较大的印第安团伙，正准备伏击或正沿着山丘外侧的山谷移动，所以队长加快了返程的脚步。发现在他与营地之间的高地上有一些巡逻骑兵之后，他便向他们高声叫喊，传话说让他们把马匹赶进去，因为马通常是印第安人最先劫掠的目标。
By this time the Captain reached the camp, and every one crowded round him for information.He informed us, that he had proceeded some distance on his reconnoitring expedition, and was slowly returning toward the camp, along the brow of a naked hill, when he saw something on the edge of a parallel hill, that looked like a man.He paused and watched it; but it remained so perfectly motionless, that he supposed it a bush, or the top of some tree beyond the hill.He resumed his course, when it likewise began to move in a parallel direction.Another form now rose beside it, of some one who had either been lying down, or had just ascended the other side of the hill.The Captain stopped and regarded them; they likewise stopped.He then lay down upon the grass, and they began to walk.On his rising, they again stopped, as if watching him.Knowing that the Indians are apt to have their spies and sentinels thus posted on the summit of naked hills, commanding extensive prospects, his doubts were increased by the suspicious movements of these men.He now put his foraging cap on the end of his rifle, and waved it in the air.They took no notice of the signal.He then walked on, until he entered the edge of a wood, which concealed him from their view.Stopping out of sight for a moment, he again looked forth, when he saw the two men passing swiftly forward.As the hill on which they were walking made a curve toward that on which he stood, it seemed as if they were endeavoring to head him before he should reach the camp.Doubting whether they might not belong to some large party of Indians, either in ambush or moving along the valley beyond the hill, the Captain hastened his steps homeward, and, descrying some rangers on an eminence between him and the camp, he called out to them to pass the word to have the horses driven in, as these are generally the first objects of Indian depredation.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这就是最初使营地陷入骚乱的警报。他们当中一些听过队长描述的人，肯定那些在山上的人就是波尼人的侦察兵，而这些人属于伏击猎人的那个团伙。间或会听到远处传来的枪声，这应该就是那些出发去解救同伴的那些人开的枪。又有几个巡逻骑兵收拾好了装备，朝着开枪的地方策马奔去；另一些人则看起来焦急不安。
Such was the origin of the alarm which had thrown the camp in commotion.Some of those who heard the Captain’s narration, had no doubt that the men on the hill were Pawnee scouts, belonging to the band that had waylaid the hunters.Distant shots were heard at intervals, which were supposed to be fired by those who had sallied out to rescue their comrades.Several more rangers, having completed their equipments, now rode forth in the direction of the firing; others looked anxious and uneasy.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “如果他们像传言那样人数众多，”一个人说道，“而且骑术还像往常那样精湛，那我们拖着疲惫的马，绝不是他们的对手。”
“If they are as numerous as they are said to be,” said one, “and as well mounted as they generally are, we shall be a bad match for them with our jaded horses.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “但是，”队长回应说，“我们有一个坚固的营地，可以抵挡他们的包围。”
“Well,” replied the Captain, “we have a strong encampment, and can stand a siege.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “嗯，可是他们也许会晚上在大草原上放火，把我们驱赶出营地。”
“Ay, but they may set fire to the prairie in the night, and burn us out of our encampment.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那么我们就点火反击！”
“We will then set up a counter-fire!”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 此刻有消息传来说，一个骑在马背上的人接近了营地。
The word was now passed that a man on horseback approached the camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那是我们的一个猎人！”“是克莱门茨！”“他带回了野牛肉！”当这个骑手跑近时，几个声音同时响了起来。
“It is one of the hunters!It is Clements!He brings buffalo meat!” was announced by several voices as the horseman drew near.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 实际上，他是早上出发去追逐那两头野牛的巡逻骑兵中的一个。他骑进了营地，马背上挂满了追逐到的战利品，后面跟着他的同伴。所有的人都安然无恙，并且都满载而归。他们接着讲述了追逐这两头野牛壮丽征程，以及用了多少发子弹才把其中一头打倒在地。
It was, in fact, one of the rangers who had set off in the morning in pursuit of the two buffaloes.He rode into the camp, with the spoils of the chase hanging round his horse, and followed by his companions, all sound and unharmed, and equally well laden.They proceeded to give an account of a grand gallop they had had after the two buffaloes, and how many shots it had cost them to bring one to the ground.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那么，但是波尼人——波尼人——波尼人在哪儿？”
“Well, but the Pawnees—the Pawnees—where are the Pawnees?”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “什么波尼人？”
“What Pawnees?”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “袭击你们的波尼人。”
“The Pawnees that attacked you.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “没有人袭击我们。”
“No one attacked us.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “但是你们一路上没看到印第安人吗？”
“But have you seen no Indians on your way?”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “哦，是啊，我们中的两个来到一个山丘上寻找营地，看到一个人在对面的山上，形迹可疑，他可能是一个印第安人。”
“Oh yes, two of us got to the top of a hill to look out for the camp and saw a fellow on an opposite hill cutting queer antics, who seemed to be an Indian.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “啐！那是我！”队长说。
“Pshaw! that was I!” said the Captain.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 到这儿，一切真相大白了。整个警报是由队长和这两个巡逻骑兵的误解而引发的。至于那三百个波尼人和他们对猎手的袭击，则是有人肆意虚构的。虽然造谣的人应该被追查出来，严加处罚，但谁也没有再进一步提及此事。
Here the bubble burst.The whole alarm had risen from this mutual mistake of the Captain and the two rangers.As to the report of the three hundred Pawnees and their attack on the hunters, it proved to be a wanton fabrication, of which no further notice was taken; though the author deserved to have been sought out, and severely punished.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 看来是没有任何战斗的可能了，每个人现在想到的就是吃饭。这营地里所有人的胃都不约而同地感到饿了。托尼什把他许诺过的美味的牛肉汤和野牛肉端给了我们。这汤里撒了太多的胡椒粉，烤牛肉也表明这头公牛是大草原上的一头老牛；我还从未嚼过这么老的牛肉。不过，这毕竟是我们的第一次牛肉盛宴，所以我们都吃得很开心。而且小个子法国人也不让我们停住嘴，直到逼着我们说他的烹调技术很高超为止，不过喉咙里的胡椒揭穿了我们的谎言。
There being no longer any prospect of fighting, every one now thought of eating; and here the stomachs throughout the camp were in unison.Tonish served up to us his promised regale of buffalo soup and buffalo beef.The soup was peppered most horribly, and the roast beef proved the bull to have been one of the patriarchs of the prairies; never did I have to deal with a tougher morsel.However, it was our first repast on buffalo meat, so we ate it with a lively faith; nor would our little Frenchman allow us any rest, until he had extorted from us an acknowledgment of the excellence of his cookery; though the pepper gave us the lie in our throats.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 夜幕降临了，但老瑞安和他的同伴还没有回来。然而，我们已经习惯了这只林中老公鸡的反常举动了，也没有人再表示对他的担心了。
The night closed in without the return of old Ryan and his companion.We had become accustomed, however, to the aberrations of this old cock of the woods, and no further solicitude was expressed on his account.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一天的疲劳和兴奋之后，整个营地很快就进入了沉沉的睡梦中。但那些站岗的除外，他们比平时更加警惕了，因为不久前我们发现了波尼人的踪迹，我们肯定是在他们的狩猎场内，这都激发了他们的高度警惕。大约十点半时，我们所有人又被一次新的警报从睡梦中惊醒。一个哨兵开了枪，并跑进营地，高声喊叫说附近有印第安人。
After the fatigues and agitations of the day, the camp soon sunk into a profound sleep, excepting those on guard, who were more than usually on the alert; for the traces recently seen of Pawnees, and the certainty that we were in the midst of their hunting grounds, excited to constant vigilance.About half past ten o’clock we were all startled from sleep by a new alarm.A sentinel had fired off his rifle and run into camp, crying that there were Indians at hand.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 每个人都立刻爬了起来。有些人抓起了步枪，有些人正要给马装上马鞍，有些人急匆匆地跑到队长的屋子里，但是却获令返回各自的篝火旁。那个哨兵受到了询问。他宣称自己看到一个印第安人正趴在地上，慢慢靠近营地；于是，他对他开了一枪，然后跑进了营地。队长的意见是，那个所谓的印第安人是一匹狼；他责备这个哨兵擅离职守，命令他回到岗位上。有些人似乎倾向于相信那个哨兵所说的，因为白天发生的事情已经使他们担心可能有埋伏的敌人，他们可能会趁着夜色发动突袭。很长的一段时间里，他们坐在篝火旁，手持步枪，小声地交谈着，竖耳聆听，等待着某个新的警报。然而，再也没有发生什么事。谈话声渐渐消失了，交谈者都昏昏欲睡，最终又酣然入睡。逐渐地，寂静和酣睡又一次笼罩了整个营地。
Every one was on his legs in an instant.Some seized their rifles; some were about to saddle their horses; some hastened to the Captain’s lodge, but were ordered back to their respective fires.The sentinel was examined.He declared he had seen an Indian approach, crawling along the ground; whereupon he had fired upon him, and run into camp.The Captain gave it as his opinion, that the supposed Indian was a wolf; he reprimanded the sentinel for deserting his post, and obliged him to return to it.Many seemed inclined to give credit to the story of the sentinel; for the events of the day had predisposed them to apprehend lurking foes and sudden assaults during the darkness of the night.For a long time they sat round their fires, with rifle in hand, carrying on low, murmuring conversations, and listening for some new alarm.Nothing further, however, occurred; the voices gradually died away; the gossipers nodded and dozed, and sunk to rest; and, by degrees, silence and sleep once more stole over the camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二十三章 海狸坝
CHAPTER XXIII. BEAVER DAM.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——野牛和马的踪迹一条波尼人踪迹——野马——年轻的猎手和熊——改变路线
—BUFFALO AND HORSE TRACKS.A PAWNEE TRAIL.—WILD HORSES.—THE YOUNG HUNTER AND THE BEAR.—CHANGE OF ROUTE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们队伍集合的那天（10月23日）早上，老瑞安和他的同伴还没有回来。但是队长完全相信这个经验丰富的林中人的技巧和才智，所以他并不认为需要为他采取任何措施。
On mustering our forces in the morning (October 23d), old Ryan and his comrade were still missing; but the Captain had such perfect reliance on the skill and resources of the veteran woodsman, that he did not think it necessary to take any measures with respect to him.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们这一天的行程同样是穿越高低起伏、道路崎岖的山乡，时而经过沉闷的褐色星毛栎林，时而被深深的干涸峡谷所隔断。远处大草原上的火明显烧得更加旺盛了。西北风已经刮了好几天了，空气中开始烟雾弥漫，就像是最典型的小阳春天气，人们很难看清任何远处的物体。
Our march this day lay through the same kind of rough rolling country; checkered by brown dreary forests of post-oak, and cut up by deep dry ravines.The distant fires were evidently increasing on the prairies.The wind had been at northwest for several days; and the atmosphere had become so smoky, as in the height of Indian summer, that it was difficult to distinguish objects at any distance.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在上午的行程中，我们跨过了一条很深的溪流。溪上有一个完整的海狸坝，高出溪面三英尺，围出了一个很大的水塘。虽然没有一只海狸将鼻子露出水面，但那里无疑有着好几个这种勤劳动物的家庭。队长不允许我们打扰这种两栖动物。
In the course of the morning, we crossed a deep stream with a complete beaver dam, above three feet high, making a large pond, and doubtless containing several families of that industrious animal, though not one showed his nose above water.The Captain would not permit this amphibious commonwealth to be disturbed.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们现在不断发现野牛和野马的踪迹。我们能够从被踩踏过的草的倒向辨认出，野牛总是方向不变地向南走。很明显，我们正走在这些迁徙的动物群所走过的路上，它们主要都是向南去的。
We were now continually coming upon the tracks of buffaloes and wild horses; those of the former tended invariably to the south, as we could perceive by the direction of the trampled grass.It was evident we were on the great highway of these migratory herds, but that they had chiefly passed to the southward.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 贝蒂通常都会在与我们的队伍相隔几百码的地方，与我们平行前进，以便留意猎物的动静，并用印第安人那锐利的目光留神每一条踪迹。他报告说他发现了一条非常可疑的踪迹。路上有波尼人的莫卡辛鞋踏出的踪迹。他闻到了混合着漆树和烟草的烟味，而这是印第安人常用的。他发现了夹杂着一只狗的脚印的马蹄印，以及绳索拖过地面的痕迹，可能是印第安骑手的长长的马勒，一头拖在了地上。很明显，这不是野马的踪迹。我再次开始担心起老猎手瑞安的安全，因为我非常喜欢这个真正的老猎手。然而，每一个人都表示他们相信，无论瑞安在哪儿，他都是安全的，他知道如何照顾自己。
Beatte, who generally kept a parallel course several hundred yards distant from our line of march, to be on the lookout for game, and who regarded every track with the knowing eye of an Indian, reported that he had come upon a very suspicious trail.There were the tracks of men who wore Pawnee moccasons.He had scented the smoke of mingled sumach and tobacco, such as the Indians use.He had observed tracks of horses, mingled with those of a dog; and a mark in the dust where a cord had been trailed along; probably the long bridle, one end of which the Indian horsemen suffer to trail on the ground.It was evident, they were not the tracks of wild horses.My anxiety began to revive about the safety of our veteran hunter Ryan, for I had taken a great fancy to this real old Leatherstocking; every one expressed a confidence, however, that wherever Ryan was, he was safe, and knew how to take care of himself.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们在已经完成了这一天疲劳行程的大部分，正穿越一片橡树林中的空地时，看到了六匹野马。其中我特别注意到有两匹非常漂亮，一匹是灰色的，另一匹是沙色的。它们高昂着头四处奔腾，长长的尾巴在空中飘动着，和我们那些因旅途劳顿而无精打采的可怜坐骑形成了鲜明的对比。观察了我们一会儿之后，它们便飞奔而去了，穿过一个葱郁的小峡谷，不一会儿又出现在我们的视线中，它们正在跑上一个大约一英里外的斜坡。
We had accomplished the greater part of a weary day’s march, and were passing through a glade of the oak openings, when we came in sight of six wild horses, among which I especially noticed two very handsome ones, a gray and a roan.They pranced about, with heads erect, and long flaunting tails, offering a proud contrast to our poor, spiritless, travel-tired steeds.Having reconnoitred us for a moment, they set off at a gallop, passed through a woody dingle, and in a little while emerged once more to view, trotting up a slope about a mile distant.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 看到这些马，对爱吹嘘的托尼什来说又是一次痛苦的折磨。他已准备好套索和带叉头的棍棒，正打算骑着那匹疲惫的马去追逐那些野马，却又一次被命令回到驮马那儿。一天的行程中，我们向西南方向前进了十四英里。之后，我们便在十字木林北部边界上的一条清澈小河边上安营扎寨了，而这条小河处在一直延伸到落基山脚下的广阔大草原的边缘。松开缰绳放马儿们去吃草时，它们的脖铃中都被塞满了草。这是为了防止它们叮当响，而被某个游荡的波尼人部族听见。
The sight of these horses was again a sore trial to the vaporing Tonish, who had his lariat and forked stick ready, and was on the point of launching forth in pursuit on his jaded horse, when he was again ordered back to the pack-horses.After a day’s journey of fourteen miles in a southwest direction, we encamped on the banks of a small clear stream, on the northern border of the Cross Timber; and on the edge of those vast prairies, that extend away to the foot of the Rocky Mountains.In turning loose the horses to graze, their bells were stuffed with grass to prevent their tinkling, lest it might be heard by some wandering horde of Pawnees.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 猎手们此刻都朝着不同的方向出去了，但是却收获寥寥，只带回营地一头鹿。一个年轻的巡逻骑兵，讲了一个关于自己冒险的长长的故事。他绕过一片深谷中的灌木丛时，打伤了一头雄鹿，并清楚听到它倒在了灌木丛中。他停下来修理了一下出了故障的步枪保险栓，并重新装上了子弹，然后跑到了灌木丛的边缘去寻找他的猎物。接着，他听到了一阵低沉的咆哮声。他拨开树枝，偷偷探出头向谷底张望，看到了一头巨大的熊沿着一条小河的干燥河床一边拖动着鹿的尸体，一边向四五匹多管闲事、似乎想和它分享晚餐的狼咆哮着。
Our hunters now went out in different directions, but without much success, as but one deer was brought into the camp.A young ranger had a long story to tell of his adventures.In skirting the thickets of a deep ravine he had wounded a buck, which he plainly heard to fall among the bushes.He stopped to fix the lock of his rifle, which was out of order, and to reload it; then advancing to the edge of the thicket, in quest of his game, he heard a low growling.Putting the branches aside, and stealing silently forward, he looked down into the ravine and beheld a huge bear dragging the carcass of the deer along the dry channel of a brook, and growling and snarling at four or five officious wolves, who seemed to have dropped in to take supper with him.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这个巡逻骑兵向熊开了一枪，不过没有打中。布鲁因坚守着阵地和和他的战利品，似乎准备投入战斗。那些显然饿坏了的狼，也只是后退了一小段距离。随着夜幕降临，这个年轻的巡逻骑兵对这个荒芜而又黑暗的地方，以及碰到的这些陌生的伙伴感到恐惧。所以他悄悄地撤退了，两手空空地回到了营地。在这儿，讲述了他的故事之后，他被那些更有经验的伙伴们痛快地取笑了一番。
The ranger fired at the bear, but missed him.Bruin maintained his ground and his prize, and seemed disposed to make battle.The wolves, too, who were evidently sharp set, drew off to but a small distance.As night was coming on, the young hunter felt dismayed at the wildness and darkness of the place, and the strange company he had fallen in with; so he quietly withdrew, and returned empty handed to the camp, where, having told his story, he was heartily bantered by his more experienced comrades.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 晚上，老瑞安跋涉回了营地，后面跟着他的徒弟。和往常一样，他受到了亲切的祝贺。他昨天打猎时迷路了，于是整晚露宿在外面。但是，早上发现了我们的踪迹后，就跟了上来。他在海狸坝那儿呆了一会儿，欣赏筑坝的技巧及其坚固的构造。“这些海狸，”他说，“都是些勤劳的小家伙。据我所知，它们是最聪明的淘气鬼，我相信水塘底下还有一大堆呢。”
In the course of the evening, old Ryan came straggling into the camp, followed by his disciple, and as usual was received with hearty gratulations.He had lost himself yesterday, when hunting, and camped out all night, but had found our trail in the morning, and followed it up.He had passed some time at the beaver dam, admiring the skill and solidity with which it had been constructed.“These beavers,” said he, “are industrious little fellows.They are the knowingest varment as I know; and I warrant the pond was stocked with them.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “对，”队长说，“我敢肯定我们经过的大多数小河里都满是海狸。我打算整个冬天都来这些水域下网。”
“Aye,” said the Captain, “I have no doubt most of the small rivers we have passed are full of beaver.I would like to come and trap on these waters all winter.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “但是你不会遭到印第安人的袭击吗？”一个同伴问道。
“But would you not run the chance of being attacked by Indians?” asked one of the company.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “哦，至于这个嘛，这里冬天是足够安全的。直到春天这里才会有印第安人。我最多只需要两个同伴。逮捕海狸时，三个人比一大群人安全多了。他们可以保持安静，很少需要开枪。”一头熊可以供他们吃两个月，熊身上的每一部分都可以得到充分利用。
“Oh, as to that, it would be safe enough here, in the winter time.There would be no Indians here until spring.I should want no more than two companions.Three persons are safer than a large number for trapping beaver.They can keep quiet, and need seldom fire a gun.”A bear would serve them for food, for two months, taking care to turn every part of it to advantage.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们当下又举行了一场商讨会来确定将来的行程。到目前为止，我们一直走的是西边的一条路，并且已经穿过了十字木林，来到了西部大草原的边缘。可是，我们还是在一片非常崎岖的食物稀少的区域。目前已经到了草枯萎的季节了，这个大草原也提供不了牧草。旅程的一段时间里维持我们的坐骑生存、长在灌木丛底下的豌豆藤也几乎消失了。过去几天里，这些可怜的动物们体力和精气神都日渐衰竭。印第安人在大草原上点着的火从北边、南边，以及西边向我们靠近；它们也可能从东边蔓延过来，在我们和边疆之间留下一片焦土，我们的马匹在那儿也许就要挨饿了。
A consultation was now held as to our future progress.We had thus far pursued a western course; and, having traversed the Cross Timber, were on the skirts of the Great Western Prairie.We were still, however, in a very rough country, where food was scarce.The season was so far advanced that the grass was withered, and the prairies yielded no pasturage.The pea-vines of the bottoms, also, which had sustained our horses for some part of the journey, were nearly gone, and for several days past the poor animals had fallen off wofully both in flesh and spirit.The Indian fires on the prairies were approaching us from north, and south, and west; they might spread also from the east, and leave a scorched desert between us and the frontier, in which our horses might be famished.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 因此大家决定不再向西前进了，而是转头更多地向东走，以便尽快到达加拿大人河的北部支流。我们希望在那儿可以找到充足的幼藤。在每年的这个季节里，幼藤是对马匹来说最有营养的牧草了。同时，它也吸引了大量的猎物。然后，我们在这儿限制了一下去远西区的旅程，准备花一天多点儿的时间沿着克萨斯州的边界线走。
It was determined, therefore, to advance no further to the westward, but to shape our course more to the east, so as to strike the north fork of the Canadian, as soon as possible, where we hoped to find abundance of young cane, which, at this season of the year, affords the most nutritious pasturage for the horses; and, at the same time, attracts immense quantities of game.Here then we fixed the limits of our tour to the Far West, being within little more than a day’s march of the boundary line of Texas.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二十四章 面包匮乏
CHAPTER XXIV. SCARCITY OF BREAD.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——邂逅野牛——野火鸡——一头野公牛倒下了
—RENCONTRE WITH BUFFALOES.—WILD TURKEYS.—FALL OF A BUFFALO BULL.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 早上，天空明快而晴朗，但营地里却没有了往常的欢乐。农家庭院的音乐会结束了：没有了公鸡的打鸣声，也没有了狗叫声；更听不到歌声或是笑声了。每个人都安静而严肃地进行着自己的工作。旅行的新奇劲儿都消耗殆尽了。一些年轻人和他们的马儿们一样，由于长途旅行而疲惫不堪。他们中大多数人都不习惯猎手的生活，开始抱怨生活必需品的匮乏。他们最不满的就是面包的匮乏，他们已经好几天没能吃到面食了。那些经常遭受这种匮乏的老猎手们，则对此很不在乎。而贝蒂在印第安人群中时，就已经习惯了几个月没有面食的生活了，仅仅把它当成是一种奢侈品。“面包，”他会轻蔑地说，“只是小孩子喜欢吃的东西。”
The morning broke bright and clear, but the camp had nothing of its usual gayety.The concert of the farmyard was at an end; not a cock crew, nor dog barked; nor was there either singing or laughing; every one pursued his avocations quietly and gravely.The novelty of the expedition was wearing off.Some of the young men were getting as way-worn as their horses; and most of them, unaccustomed to the hunter’s life, began to repine at its privations.What they most felt was the want of bread, their rations of flour having been exhausted for several days.The old hunters, who had often experienced this want, made light of it; and Beatte, accustomed when among the Indians to live for months without it, considered it a mere article of luxury.“Bread,” he would, say scornfully, “is only fit for a child.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约七点四十五时，我们背离了远西区地区，沿着一个地势平缓的山谷向东南方向前进。骑了几英里之后，一直与我们保持平行、沿着我们右侧一个光秃秃小山的山脊行走的贝蒂，突然叫喊起来并发出信号，似乎是有什么东西在围向这座小山来拦截我们。一些在我附近的人叫喊说那是一伙波尼人。周围的灌木丛使我们看不到假想敌的靠近。我们听到密集的丛林中传来一阵脚步声。我的马朝着那个地方看了看，嘴里喷着鼻息，耳朵竖了起来。这时，我们看到几头被贝蒂惊动的、体型巨大的野牛拥挤着穿过灌木丛，直接朝我们奔来。一看到我们，它们马上调头，然后沿着一条山间的隘路跑去。马上，十来支步枪同时开火。队伍中响起一片欢呼声，有一半的人急忙去追，而我也是其中一员。我们中的大多数人很快便止步了，停止了这场追逐，因为其间要穿过桦树林和荆棘丛，以及一个非常危险的峡谷。几个巡逻骑兵坚持追逐了一会儿，不过最终也还是一个个地慢慢加入了队伍。他们中有一个人是步行回来的。在全速追逐时，他被甩了下来，他的步枪因此而摔坏了，而他的马则保持着骑手的精神，继续追赶野牛去了。他沦落到了一个可悲的境地：身处波尼人的狩猎场，却既没有马，又没有武器。
About a quarter before eight o’clock, we turned our back upon the Far West, and set off in a southeast course, along a gentle valley.After riding a few miles, Beatte, who kept parallel with us, along the ridge of a naked hill to our right, called out and made signals, as if something were coming round the hill to intercept us.Some who were near me cried out that it was a party of Pawnees.A skirt of thickets hid the approach of the supposed enemy from our view.We heard a trampling among the brushwood.My horse looked toward the place, snorted and pricked up his ears, when presently a couple of large buffalo bulls, who had been alarmed by Beatte, came crashing through the brake, and making directly toward us.At sight of us they wheeled round, and scuttled along a narrow defile of the hill.In an instant half a score of rifles cracked off; there was a universal whoop and halloo, and away went half the troop, helter-skelter in pursuit, and myself among the number.The most of us soon pulled up, and gave over a chase which led through birch and brier, and break-neck ravines.Some few of the rangers persisted for a time; but eventually joined the line, slowly lagging one after another.One of them returned on foot; he had been thrown while in full chase; his rifle had been broken in the fall, and his horse, retaining the spirit, of the rider, had kept on after the buffalo.It was a melancholy predicament to be reduced to; without horse or weapon in the midst of the Pawnee hunting grounds.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 就我而言，我最近真够幸运的，通过又一次的交换，我得到了这支队伍中最好的马匹。它是一匹纯种的栗色马，有着极好的耐力、漂亮的形体和最温顺的性格。
For my own part, I had been fortunate enough recently, by a further exchange, to get possession of the best horse in the troop; a full-blooded sorrel of excellent bottom, beautiful form, and most generous qualities.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这种情况下，好像是一个人和他的马互换了角色。由于我身下骑有了一个既精神又温顺，异常听话而又行动从容、迅捷、灵活的动物，我感觉自己非常像另一种生物。几天之后，它几乎像一只小狗那样一直粘着我：当我不骑马时，它就跟着我；早上，它会来到我身旁，以引起我的注意，让我抚摸它；当我坐在树下看书时，它会把嘴凑到我和书之间。我对我这位默默无语的大草原伙伴的感觉，使我依稀意识到了阿拉伯人对驮着他们行走于沙漠中的马匹的依恋之情。
In such a situation it almost seems as if a man changes his nature with his horse.I felt quite like another being, now that I had an animal under me, spirited yet gentle, docile to a remarkable degree, and easy, elastic, and rapid in all his movements.In a few days he became almost as much attached to me as a dog; would follow me when I dismounted, would come to me in the morning to be noticed and caressed; and would put his muzzle between me and my book, as I sat reading at the foot of a tree.The feeling I had for this my dumb companion of the prairies, gave me some faint idea of that attachment the Arab is said to entertain for the horse that has borne him about the deserts.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 又骑了几公里之后，我们来到了一片漂亮的草地，一条宽阔清澈的小河蜿蜒而过，河岸上长着优质的牧草。我们立刻在这儿停了下来，停在了一片美丽的榆树林中一个奥赛奇人的旧营地上。我们刚刚下马，便响起了一片射击火鸡的枪声。因为有一大群火鸡散落在这个小树林里，证明这是这儿些单纯的鸟类最喜爱的栖息地。它们飞到树上，栖坐在树枝上，探出长长的脖子，愚蠢而又惊讶地凝视着一切，直到有十八只同胞被打了下来。
After riding a few miles further, we came to a fine meadow with a broad clear stream winding through it, on the banks of which there was excellent pasturage.Here we at once came to a halt, in a beautiful grove of elms, on the site of an old Osage encampment.Scarcely had we dismounted, when a universal firing of rifles took place upon a large flock of turkeys, scattered about the grove, which proved to be a favorite roosting-place for these simple birds.They flew to the trees, and sat perched upon their branches, stretching out their long necks, and gazing in stupid astonishment, until eighteen of them were shot down.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在屠杀的高峰期，有消息传来说在一个临近的草地上有四头野牛。现在，因为有了更好的猎物，猎手们便放弃了火鸡。那些疲惫的马匹又一次被人骑上，被驱赶着去追逐野牛。不一会儿，我们便看到了野牛，它们看起来像高高的绿色牧草中的褐色小山丘。贝蒂尽力跑到它们前面，迫使它们回头向我们跑来，这样那些没有经验的猎手也许会有机会下手。它们围着一个乱石嶙峋的小山的底部奔跑着，很快就从我们的视线中消失了。我们当中有一些人力图穿越这个小山，但却陷入了一片布满葡萄藤的浓密树林中。我的马在它的上一个骑手的胯下就曾追捕过野牛，现在它就像我一样兴奋，尽力想要穿越这片灌木丛。最终，我们从中解脱了出来，飞奔过了那个小山。我发现，我们的小个子法国人托尼什正高高兴兴地骑在马背上，围着一头被他打成重伤而无法逃跑的、体型巨大的野牛打转。他一直盯着它，直到我们赶上来。看到这个巨大的动物和它奇异的攻击者，感觉就像是壮丽和滑稽混杂在一起。这头野牛一直站立着，把它长满蓬乱长毛的脑袋正对着敌人。它的嘴大大地张着，露出了干燥的舌头，眼睛像是燃烧着的煤块，尾巴愤怒地竖立着。它不时会无力地扑向它那可以轻易避开它的攻击、并在它面前做着各种滑稽动作的敌人。
In the height of the carnage, word was brought that there were four buffaloes in a neighboring meadow.The turkeys were now abandoned for nobler game.The tired horses were again mounted, and urged to the chase.In a little while we came in sight of the buffaloes, looking like brown hillocks among the long green herbage.Beatte endeavored to get ahead of them and turn them towards us, that the inexperienced hunters might have a chance.They ran round the base of a rocky hill, that hid us from the sight.Some of us endeavored to cut across the hill, but became entrapped in a thick wood, matted with grape-vines.My horse, who, under his former rider, had hunted the buffalo, seemed as much excited as myself, and endeavored to force his way through the bushes.At length we extricated ourselves, and galloping over the hill, I found our little Frenchman, Tonish, curvetting on horseback round a great buffalo which he had wounded too severely to fly, and which he was keeping employed until we should come up.There was a mixture of the grand and the comic, in beholding this tremendous animal and his fantastic assailant.The buffalo stood with his shaggy front always presented to his foe; his mouth open, his tongue parched, his eyes like coals of fire, and his tail erect with rage; every now and then he would make a faint rush upon his foe, who easily evaded his attack, capering and cutting all kinds of antics before him.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们又朝这头野牛开了几枪，子弹都没有打进它那庞大的身躯，都不足以致命。它缓慢而又庄重地后退到一条浅浅的小河中。只要攻击者们一逼近，它就会回过头来对着他们。当在这片水中时，它在那儿站稳脚跟，似乎准备抵御围攻。然而，一颗更为致命的步枪子弹射进了它的躯体，全身猛烈地颤抖了一下。它掉过头去试图涉过这条小溪，不过踉跄了几步之后，便慢慢地倒向一边，死去了。一个英雄倒下了，我们因屠杀了它而感到有点儿羞愧。但是，打了最初的一两枪之后，我们便照旧争辩说这是在让这个可怜的动物摆脱苦难，以此聊以自慰。
We now made repeated shots at the buffalo, but they glanced into his mountain of flesh without proving mortal.He made a slow and grand retreat into the shallow river, turning upon his assailants whenever they pressed upon him; and when in the water, took his stand there as if prepared to sustain a siege.A rifle-ball, however, more fatally lodged, sent a tremor through his frame.He turned and attempted to wade across the stream, but after tottering a few paces, slowly fell upon his side and expired.It was the fall of a hero, and we felt somewhat ashamed of the butchery that had affected it; but, after the first shot or two, we had reconciled it to our feelings, by the old plea of putting the poor animal out of his misery.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这天晚上还有两头野牛也被猎杀了，但都是公牛。每年的这个季节，它们的肉又瘦又硬。晚餐中，一头肥壮的雄鹿为我们提供了更加可口的肉食。
Two other buffaloes were killed this evening, but they were all bulls, the flesh of which is meagre and hard, at this season of the year.A fat buck yielded us more savory meat for our evening’s repast.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二十五章 包围野马
CHAPTER XXV. RINGING THE WILD HORSE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们大约在八点时，离开了野牛营地，辛苦而又疲惫地前进了两个小时，穿过了一座座小山，小山被参差不齐且稀稀拉拉的矮栎树林覆盖，也被深谷隔断。我发现在这些橡树中，有许多极矮的树，有些都不超过一英尺，却都结满了小小的橡栗。实际上，整个十字木林有许多橡树果实。这里有一种松橡树，它可以结出一种吃起来很甜美的橡栗，在这个季节的早些时候就已经成熟了。
We left the buffalo camp about eight o’clock, and had a toilsome and harassing march of two hours, over ridges of hills, covered with a ragged meagre forest of scrub-oaks, and broken by deep gullies.Among the oaks I observed many of the most diminutive size; some not above a foot high, yet bearing abundance of small acorns.The whole of the Cross Timber, in fact, abounds with mast.There is a pine-oak which produces an acorn pleasant to the taste, and ripening early in the season.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约在上午十点左右，我们来到了一条通往山谷的起伏山丘的路上，雷德河的北支流也穿过这个山谷。一片宽约半英里的美丽草地上，点缀着秋天黄灿灿的花朵。这草地沿着山脚一直延伸到两三英里之外，紧挨着河的对岸，河两岸则围着三角叶杨树。厌倦了棕色森林的单调和沉默之后，这些颜色鲜亮的树叶使人眼前一亮，令人愉悦不已。
About ten o’clock in the morning, we came to where this line of rugged hills swept down into a valley, through which flowed the north fork of the Red River.A beautiful meadow about half a mile wide, enamelled with yellow autumnal flowers, stretched for two or three miles along the foot of the hills, bordered on the opposite side by the river, whose banks were fringed with cottonwood trees, the bright foliage of which refreshed and delighted the eye, after being wearied by the contemplation of monotonous wastes of brown forest.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这个草地上极好地布满了各种小树林和丛林，它们分布得错落有致，好像是人工布置的一样。当我们向这个清爽而又令人愉悦的山谷放眼望去时，看到右侧大约一英里处，有一群野马在一片绿色的草坪上安静地吃着草。而在我们左侧几乎同样远的地方有几头野牛，有的正在吃草，其余的则在一丛三角叶杨的树阴下，躺在又高又密的杂草中歇息、反刍。整个场面看上去就像是一位富裕农场主在其奢华产业中的一个广阔美丽的牧场，而他的牛正在草地上吃着草。
The meadow was finely diversified by groves and clumps of trees, so happily dispersed, that they seemed as if set out by the hand of art.As we cast our eyes over this fresh and delightful valley, we beheld a troop of wild horses, quietly grazing on a green lawn, about a mile distant to our right, while to our left, at nearly the same distance, were several buffaloes; some feeding, others reposing and ruminating among the high rich herbage, under the shade of a clump of cottonwood trees.The whole had the appearance of a broad beautiful tract of pasture land, on the highly ornamented estate of some gentleman farmer, with his cattle grazing about the lawns and meadows.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一场关于作战的商议马上就展开了，我们决定要在眼前的这个绝佳机会中大捞一把，并试一试狩猎中常用的所谓包围野马的策略。这需要一大批骑术精湛的骑手。他们各自四散到不同方向上去，相互间隔一定的距离，然后慢慢地围成一个周长为两三公里的圈，以便包围猎物。这必须要做得非常小心，因为野马是大草原上最警觉的居住者，如果迎着风，它在很远处就可以闻到猎手的气息。
A council of war was now held, and it was determined to profit by the present favorable opportunity, and try our hand at the grand hunting manoeuvre, which is called ringing the wild horse.This requires a large party of horsemen, well mounted.They extend themselves in each direction, singly, at certain distances apart, and gradually form a ring of two or three miles in circumference, so as to surround the game.This has to be done with extreme care, for the wild horse is the most readily alarmed inhabitant of the prairie, and can scent a hunter at a great distance, if to windward.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 围成一个圈之后，两三个骑手策马奔向这些马，而它们则向反方向逃窜。然而，只要它们一接近包围圈的边界，都有一个猎手挺身而出，迫使它们折返回去。这样，它们在每一个点上都会受到阻拦和驱赶，只能围着这个有魔力的圈子不停地奔跑，直到精疲力尽。而这时，猎手就很容易把马骑到它们身旁，扔出套索套住它们的脑袋了。然而，速度最快、勇气最大、脚力最好的一流马匹还是容易突破包围逃走，所以被抓到的一般都是二流马。
The ring being formed, two or three ride toward the horses, who start off in an opposite direction.Whenever they approach the bounds of the ring, however, a huntsman presents himself and turns them from their course.In this way, they are checked and driven back at every point; and kept galloping round and round this magic circle, until, being completely tired down, it is easy for the hunters to ride up beside them, and throw the lariat over their heads.The prime horses of most speed, courage, and bottom, however, are apt to break through and escape, so that, in general, it is the second-rate horses that are taken.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们现在正准备抓这种马。驮马们都被带到了树林里，紧紧地拴在了树上，以防野马们奔跑的时候，它们会跟着一起逃窜。然后，一个中尉命令二十五个人沿着峡谷边缘，在山旁的狭长树林里悄悄前进。他们彼此相距大约五十码，埋伏在树林的边缘，直到马匹朝他们那个方向逃窜时，才前进或现身。二十五个人获令穿过山谷，以类似的方式沿着河对岸埋伏在树丛中。大约相同人数的第三支队伍，沿着山谷的下部一字排开，和两翼形成呼应之势。贝蒂和我们的另一个混血儿安托万，以及总是爱管闲事的托尼什，准备在丛林中绕一个圈，前往山谷的上部，到野马的背后，把它们赶进我们围成的这个口袋中，两翼的人则在后面支援，进而形成一个完整的围圈。
Preparations were now made for a hunt of the kind.The pack-horses were taken into the woods and firmly tied to trees, lest, in a rush of the wild horses, they should break away with them.Twenty-five men were then sent under the command of a lieutenant, to steal along the edge of the valley within the strip of wood that skirted the hills.They were to station themselves about fifty yards apart, within the edge of the woods, and not advance or show themselves until the horses dashed in that direction.Twenty-five men were sent across the valley, to steal in like manner along the river bank that bordered the opposite side, and to station themselves among the trees.A third party, of about the same number, was to form a line, stretching across the lower part of the valley, so as to connect the two wings.Beatte and our other half-breed, Antoine, together with the ever-officious Tonish, were to make a circuit through the woods so as to get to the upper part of the valley, in the rear of the horses, and to drive them forward into the kind of sack that we had formed, while the two wings should join behind them and make a complete circle.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 侧翼的队伍悄悄地分散开，隐藏在山谷的两侧。剩下的人则就地展开，就像一条横贯的锁链。此时，那些野马似乎闻到了敌人的味道，它们使劲吸着气，喷着鼻息四处张望。最后，它们慢慢地向河流跑去，消失在一片绿色的河岸之后。在此，我们便可以看到追逐的规则了——树林中的猎手挺身而出，不声不响地拦住它们，然后驱赶它们调头。然而，不幸的是，我们得先解决那如野火般不受控制的小个子法国人。当看到它们向河边跑去时，他没有安静地呆在山谷的右边等着野马过来，而是从隐蔽的树林中冲了出去，骑着伯爵的一匹备用马，穿过草地拼命地追赶它们。这使整个局面都崩溃了。所有的混血儿和十几个巡逻骑兵也加入了追逐的行列。他们都越过了绿色的河岸。不一会儿，野马们又出现了，它们飞奔下山谷，法国人、混血儿及巡逻骑兵都策马在它们后面高声鬼叫着。原本埋伏在山谷中，准备用来拦阻并把这些逃亡者驱赶回去的防线都毫无用处了。它们被追赶者追得太急了，所以惊慌地冲破防线，顺着草原奔了下去。整支队伍都加入了仓促的追逐之中。一些巡逻骑兵没了帽子，头发在耳边飞舞；另一些则把手帕系在了头上。那些在草地上静静反刍的大型野牛站了起来，惊讶地凝视了片刻草地上的这阵骚乱，然后扭过头，摆动着沉重的身躯开始逃跑。它们很快便被追上了。这两群动物由于山谷两边的收缩而被堵到了一起，它们都在匆忙而慌张地奔跑着。野牛、野马、狂野的猎人，牛蹄声、马蹄声、猎人的呐喊声，在树林中混成了一片。
The flanking parties were quietly extending themselves, out of sight, on each side of the valley, and the residue were stretching themselves, like the links of a chain, across it, when the wild horses gave signs that they scented an enemy; snuffing the air, snorting, and looking about.At length they pranced off slowly toward the river, and disappeared behind a green bank.Here, had the regulations of the chase been observed, they would have been quietly checked and turned back by the advance of a hunter from among the trees, unluckily, however, we had our wild-fire Jack-o’-lantern little Frenchman to deal with.Instead of keeping quietly up the right side of the valley, to get above the horses, the moment he saw them move toward the river, he broke out of the covert of woods, and dashed furiously across the plain in pursuit of them, being mounted on one of the led horses belonging to the Count.This put an end to all system.The half-breeds and half a score of rangers joined in the chase.Away they all went over the green bank; in a moment or two the wild horses reappeared, and came thundering down the valley, with Frenchman, half-breeds, and rangers galloping and yelling like devils behind them.It was in vain that the line drawn across the valley attempted to check and turn back the fugitives.They were too hotly pressed by their pursuers; in their panic they dashed through the line, and clattered down the plain.The whole troop joined in the headlong chase, some of the rangers without hats or caps, their hair flying about their ears, others with handkerchiefs tied round their heads.The buffaloes, who had been calmly ruminating among the herbage, heaved up their huge forms, gazed for a moment with astonishment at the tempest that came scouring down the meadow, then turned and took to heavy-rolling flight.They were soon overtaken; the promiscuous throng were pressed together by the contracting sides of the valley, and away they went, pell-mell, hurry-scurry, wild buffalo, wild horse, wild huntsman, with clang and clatter, and whoop and halloo, that made the forests ring.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 最终，野牛们跑进了一个岸边的灌木丛，而马儿们则冲进了一条山间的狭窄隘路，它们的追赶者紧随其后。贝蒂超过了其中几匹，他把目光锁定在一匹漂亮的波尼人的马上。它的耳朵上有裂口，背上有马鞍的痕迹。他拼命地追着它，却在树林中追丢了。在这些野马中，有一匹漂亮的黑色母马由于怀有小马而相当疲乏了。慌忙奔上隘路时，它被绊了一跤，摔倒在地上。一个年轻的巡逻骑兵从马上跳了下来，抓住了它的鬃毛和嘴巴。另一个巡逻骑兵也下了马，过来帮助他。这匹母马猛烈地挣扎着，又踢又咬，用前蹄防卫，但脑袋上被套上了一条套索后，挣扎也变得无济于事。然而，过了好长一段时间，它才停止了暴跳、猛窜，不再用蹄子四处踢打。于是，这两个巡逻骑兵用两根长长的套索牵着它在山谷中前进。这样，他们就能够在两侧与它保持足够远的距离，以免被它踢到，并且，它一朝着某一个方向冲过去，便会被另一个方向的人狠狠地拉回来。就这样，它的脾气渐渐缓和了。
At length the buffaloes turned into a green brake on the river bank, while the horses dashed up a narrow defile of the hills, with their pursuers close at their heels.Beatte passed several of them, having fixed his eye upon a fine Pawnee horse, that had his ears slit, and saddle-marks upon his back.He pressed him gallantly, but lost him in the woods.Among the wild horses was a fine black mare, far gone with foal.In scrambling up the defile, she tripped and fell.A young ranger sprang from his horse, and seized her by the mane and muzzle.Another ranger dismounted, and came to his assistance.The mare struggled fiercely, kicking and biting, and striking with her fore feet, but a noose was slipped over her head, and her struggles were in vain.It was some time, however, before she gave over rearing and plunging, and lashing out with her feet on every side.The two rangers then led her along the valley by two long lariats, which enabled them to keep at a sufficient distance on each side to be out of the reach of her hoofs, and whenever she struck out in one direction, she was jerked in the other.In this way her spirit was gradually subdued.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 至于爱虚张声势的小个子托尼什，由于他的轻率之举而毁了整个行动，但却得到了意料之外的收获——他抓住了一匹漂亮的乳白色的小马。这匹马大约有七个月大，所以没有力气跟上同伴。这个反复无常的小法国人已经欣喜若狂了。看到他和他的战利品让人感觉很搞笑。那匹小马又跳又踢，挣扎着想要逃跑，而托尼什则抱住它的脖子，和它扭作一团，然后跳上马背做出各种滑稽古怪的动作，就像是一只猴子和一只小猫在一起。然而，最让我感到惊讶的是，看到这些一直享受着大草原上无拘无束的自由的可怜动物们，一旦被抓到，便很快就屈服于人类的控制。接下来那两三天的行程中，那匹母马和小马同备用马一起前进，变得非常地驯服。
As to little Scaramouch Tonish, who had marred the whole scene by his precipitancy, he had been more successful than he deserved, having managed to catch a beautiful cream-colored colt, about seven months old, which had not strength to keep up with its companions, The mercurial little Frenchman was beside himself with exultation.It was amusing to see him with his prize.The colt would rear and kick, and struggle to get free, when Tonish would take him about the neck, wrestle with him, jump on his back, and cut as many antics as a monkey with a kitten.Nothing surprised me more, however, than to witness how soon these poor animals, thus taken from the unbounded freedom of the prairie, yielded to the dominion of man.In the course of two or three days the mare and colt went with the led horses, and became quite docile.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二十六章 涉过北支流
CHAPTER XXVI. FORDING OF THE NORTH FORK.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——十字木林的沉闷景色——夜晚马的奔跑——奥塞奇远征队——一场和平演说的效果——野牛——野马
—DREARY SCENERY OF THE CROSS TIMBER.—SCAMPER OF HORSES IN THE NIGHT.—OSAGE WAR PARTY.—EFFECTS OF A PEACE HARANGUE.—BUFFALO.—WILD HORSE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 重返旅程，我们涉过了雷德河的北支流，这是一条湍急的小河流，河水非常清澈，这在大草原上是很难看到的。很明显，它的源头在高地上，有充足的泉水供给。越过这条河之后，我们又开始攀登于山丘之间，在其中一座山上放眼望去，整个十字木林地区尽收眼底，但却是一幅凄凉的景象：山连着山，树林挨着树林，所有的事物都染着悲凉的赤褐色。偶尔，这儿或那儿会有一排绿色的三角叶杨、悬铃木或柳树点缀在山谷的小溪两旁。一队野牛正沿着远处一座小山的侧面慢慢往上爬，在这荒蛮之景中成了一大特色。向左侧望去，越过崎岖的山丘、峡谷和起伏的森林，便会看到大约十英里外有一个大草原，一直延伸到湛蓝的地平线上。就像是在礁石和浪花之间，远眺静谧的大海。不幸的是，我们的路线不是在那个方向上，我们还必须在这个沉闷的十字木林里前进几英里。
Resuming our march, we forded the North Fork, a rapid stream, and of a purity seldom to be found in the rivers of the prairies.It evidently had its sources in high land, well supplied with springs.After crossing the river, we again ascended among hills, from one of which we had an extensive view over this belt of cross timber, and a cheerless prospect it was; hill beyond hill, forest beyond forest, all of one sad russet hue—excepting that here and there a line of green cottonwood trees, sycamores, and willows, marked the course of some streamlet through a valley, A procession of buffaloes, moving slowly up the profile of one of those distant hills, formed a characteristic object in the savage scene.To the left, the eye stretched beyond this rugged wilderness of hills, and ravines, and ragged forests, to a prairie about ten miles off, extending in a clear blue line along the horizon.It was like looking from among rocks and breakers upon a distant tract of tranquil ocean.Unluckily, our route did not lie in that direction; we still had to traverse many a weary mile of the “cross timber.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们傍晚时在一个山谷中扎了营。这营地紧挨着一个几乎干涸的池塘，头上是一片稀稀拉拉的榆树，树枝上部不可思议地附着一簇簇槲寄生。晚上，那匹小野马不断地轻声嘶叫着。大约在黎明前两个小时，营地边缘突然传来了一阵动物惊跑乱窜的声音，或是马的奔跑声。马蹄声中还掺杂着鼻息声和嘶鸣声，大多数巡逻骑兵都被这声音惊醒了。他们静静地听着，直到这声音像一场刮过去的飓风，消失在远方。像往常一样，这噪声最先被认为是某个专门劫掠的印第安部族发出的，但等到天亮后，人们却发现邻近的一个草地上有几匹野马。人一靠近，它们就撒蹄跑开了。人们现在才知道是一群马在夜间奔过了我们营地。大家大体召集了一下马匹，发现有些分散到了相对较远的地方，还有几匹找不到了。然而，我们却看到它们的蹄印深陷在泥土中，这表明它们全速奔向了荒野。它们的主人沿着蹄印，疲惫不堪地出发去寻找它们。
We encamped toward evening in a valley, beside a scanty pool, under a scattered grove of elms, the upper branches of which wore fringed with tufts of the mystic mistletoe.In the course of the night, the wild colt whinnied repeatedly; and about two hours before day, there was a sudden stampedo, or rush of horses, along the purlieus of the camp, with a snorting and neighing, and clattering of hoofs, that startled most of the rangers from their sleep, who listened in silence, until the sound died away like the rushing of a blast.As usual, the noise was at first attributed to some party of marauding Indians, but as the day dawned, a couple of wild horses were seen in a neighboring meadow, which scoured off on being approached.It was now supposed that a gang of them had dashed through our camp in the night.A general mustering of our horses took place, many were found scattered to a considerable distance, and several were not to be found.The prints of their hoofs, however, appeared deeply dinted in the soil, leading off at full speed into the waste, and their owners, putting themselves on the trail, set off in weary search of them.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 黎明时天气晴朗，可是上午天又变得灰蒙蒙、低沉沉的，预示着一场秋季暴风雨的来临。我们安静而又严肃地重新踏上旅程，穿过一片崎岖而又阴郁的区域。从这里的最高点，我们可以看到无限向西延伸的大草原。行进了大约两三个小时之后，在穿越一片好似巨大的棕色荒原的枯萎草地时，我们看到远处有七个奥塞奇战士迎面而来。在这孤寂的荒野中看到任何人，都是一件有趣的事情，就像是在大海上和另一艘船联络。其中一个印第安人带领着他的同伴们，昂首挺胸、气宇非凡地向我们走来。他是一个英俊的小伙子，穿着猩红色的长外衣，绑着用鹿皮做的、流苏镶边的绑腿。他头上插着一根白色的羽毛，带着某种战士的气质向我们走来，一只手晃动着弓箭。
We had a ruddy daybreak, but the morning gathered up gray and lowering, with indications of an autumnal storm.We resumed our march silently and seriously, through a rough and cheerless country, from the highest points of which we could descry large prairies, stretching indefinitely westward.After travelling for two or three hours, as we were traversing a withered prairie, resembling a great brown heath, we beheld seven Osage warriors approaching at a distance.The sight of any human being in this lonely wilderness was interesting; it was like speaking a ship at sea.One of the Indians took the lead of his companions, and advanced toward us with head erect, chest thrown forward, and a free and noble mien.He was a fine-looking fellow, dressed in scarlet frock and fringed leggings of deer skin.His head was decorated with a white tuft, and he stepped forward with something of a martial air, swaying his bow and arrows in one hand.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们通过翻译贝蒂和他进行了一番交谈，得知他和他的同伴们一直在和他们部落的主力一起猎杀野牛，并且非常成功。他还告诉我们，在接下来的一天中，我们将会到达位于加拿大人大河河岸的大草原，还会发现大量的猎物。他又补充说，由于狩猎结束了，猎手们都在回家的路上，所以他和他的同伴们一起组成了一支远征队，去伏击一些波尼人的营地，希望能带回一些动物的头皮或马匹。
We held some conversation with him through our interpreter, Beatte, and found that he and his companions had been with the main part of their tribe hunting the buffalo, and had met with great success; and he informed us, that in the course of another day’s march, we would reach the prairies on the banks of the Grand Canadian, and find plenty of game.He added, that as their hunt was over, and the hunters on their return homeward, he and his comrades had set out on a war party, to waylay and hover about some Pawnee camp, in hopes of carrying off scalps or horses.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 到这时，他那些最初站在远处的同伴也走上前来加入了他。他们中有三个人带着普通的猎枪，其余的则配备着弓箭。当他们站着和我们的翻译交流，被一群巡逻骑兵包围着时，我不得不赞叹这些野蛮人漂亮的脸庞、宽阔的胸膛，以及优雅的态度和高尚的举止。我们试图让他们中的一个人加入我们，因为我们渴望看到他用弓箭捕杀野牛的场景。他最初似乎也想跟我们走，不过他的同伴们却劝他不要这么做。
By this time his companions, who at first stood aloof, joined him.Three of them had indifferent fowling-pieces; the rest were armed with bows and arrows.I could not but admire the finely shaped heads and busts of these savages, and their graceful attitude and expressive gestures, as they stood conversing with our interpreter, and surrounded by a cavalcade of rangers.We endeavored to get one of them to join us, as we were desirous of seeing him hunt the buffalo with his bow and arrow.He seemed at first inclined to do so, but was dissuaded by his companions.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 值得尊敬的专员这时记起了他作为调解员的使命。他进行了一番演说，劝他们放弃所有侵犯波尼人的行动，并告诉他们：他们在华盛顿的“父亲”计划停止他的红种孩子们之间的一切战争。他还向他们保证，他被派到这个边境上来是为了建立全面和平。因此，他让他们安安静静地回家，保证波尼人将不会再骚扰他们，反而很快就会把他们视为兄弟。
The worthy Commissioner now remembered his mission as pacificator, and made a speech, exhorting them to abstain from all offensive acts against the Pawnees; informing them of the plan of their father at Washington, to put an end to all war among his red children; and assuring them that he was sent to the frontier to establish a universal peace.He told them, therefore, to return quietly to their homes, with the certainty that the Pawnees would no longer molest them, but would soon regard them as brothers.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这些印第安人以其惯有的沉默和庄重听着这场演说，之后，他们几个相互交谈了几句，然后便和我们告别，继续穿越大草原。
The Indians listened to the speech with their customary silence and decorum; after which, exchanging a few words among themselves, they bade us farewell, and pursued their way across the prairie.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 翻译贝蒂脸上隐隐的一丝笑容使我感到很好奇。于是，我私下里问他那些印第安人听了这场演说后，彼此说了些什么。他说，那个首领向他的同伴评论说，既然他们伟大的“父亲”想要这么快地停止一切战争，那么他们有必要充分利用留给他们的这一点儿时间。所以，他们以加倍的热情出发，去实施他们的盗马计划了！
Fancying that I saw a lurking smile in the countenance of our interpreter, Beatte, I privately inquired what the Indians had said to each other after hearing the speech.The leader, he said, had observed to his companions, that, as their great father intended so soon to put an end to all warfare, it behooved them to make the most of the little time that was left them.So they had departed, with redoubled zeal, to pursue their project of horse-stealing!

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 和那些印第安人分开后不久，我们便发现，在我们左侧的一个湿软山谷的灌木丛中有三头野牛。我和队长，以及几个巡逻骑兵一起去追赶它们。悄悄穿过一片难缠的小树林之后，带头的队长进到了射程以内，并从侧面打伤了其中的一头。它们三个都在惊慌之下拼命逃窜。穿过灌木丛、草丛、沼泽和泥潭，凭着它们巨大的体重，压倒了一切障碍物。很快，队长和巡逻骑兵便放弃了追逐，因为这有可能累垮他们的坐骑。然而，我却沿着受伤公牛的足迹追了下去，希望能够尽量靠近它，以便用上提供给我的唯一武器——手枪。但我还没来得及用，野牛就到了一个山石嶙峋、覆盖着星毛栎和刺藤的山丘脚下，并冲向前去，满含着愤怒一路冲撞了过去。在那儿，而只有疯子才会继续追下去。
We had not long parted from the Indians before we discovered three buffaloes among the thickets of a marshy valley to our left.I set off with the Captain and several rangers, in pursuit of them.Stealing through a straggling grove, the Captain, who took the lead, got within rifle-shot, and wounded one of them in the flank.They all three made of in headlong panic, through thickets and brushwood, and swamp and mire, bearing down every obstacle by their immense weight.The Captain and rangers soon gave up a chase which threatened to knock up their horses; I had got upon the traces of the wounded bull, however, and was in hopes of getting near enough to use my pistols, the only weapons with which I was provided; but before I could effect it, he reached the foot of a rocky hill, covered with post-oak and brambles, and plunged forward, dashing and crashing along, with neck or nothing fury, where it would have been madness to have followed him.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这场追逐使我向一侧跑得非常远，我花了好长时间才重新找到队伍的踪迹。当我慢慢地攀爬一个小山的时候，一匹漂亮的黑色母马正绕着山顶腾跃，直到我离它非常近时，它才发现我。一看到我，它便立即开始后退，然后调头，全速跑进了山谷，然后跑上了对面的山丘。它的鬃毛和尾巴飞扬起来，如空气般行动自如。我一直凝视着它，直到它跑出了我的视野。我默默祈祷这样生机勃勃的动物永远不要成为鞭子和马勒下卑微的奴役，而是永远在大草原上自由地驰骋。
The chase had led me so far on one side, that it was some time before I regained the trail of our troop.As I was slowly ascending a hill, a fine black mare came prancing round the summit, and was close to me before she was aware.At sight of me she started back, then turning, swept at full speed down into the valley, and up the opposite hill, with flowing mane and tail, and action free as air.I gazed after her as long as she was in sight, and breathed a wish that so glorious an animal might never come under the degrading thraldom of whip and curb, but remain a free rover of the prairies.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二十七章 恶劣天气下的宿营
CHAPTER XXVII. FOUL WEATHER ENCAMPMENT.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 猎熊轶事——印第安人对征兆的看法——对死者的顾忌
ANECDOTES OF BEAR HUNTING.—INDIAN NOTIONS ABOUT OMENS.—SCRUPLES RESPECTING THE DEAD.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在追赶队伍时，我发现他们正在一个茂密的林地深处扎营，有一条小溪从中横穿而过，流淌于严重坍塌的河堤之间。在各个方向上不时传来步枪发出的清脆枪声，惊起了许多火鸡。它们或是在灌木丛中四散奔逃，或是飞到树上。我们才停留了一小会儿，蒙蒙的细雨便引来了那场酝酿已久的秋季暴风雨。我们立刻采取措施挡风遮雨：我们支起帐篷，将马鞍、马褡裢、装着咖啡、糖和盐的包裹，以及其他任何可能被雨水淋坏的东西堆放在帐篷下面。贝蒂、托尼什和安托万把带枝杈的木桩插到土里，把杆子横架在它们上面作为椽子，并覆以树皮和动物皮，以此搭起了一个棚屋，或者一个遮棚。倾斜的一面对着风，而敞开的一面对着火。那些巡逻骑兵用树皮和动物皮搭起了类似的棚屋，或者是把毯子撑开放在用带枝杈的木桩支撑的杆子上，并在前面生一大堆火。
On overtaking the troop, I found it encamping in a rich bottom of woodland, traversed by a small stream, running between deep crumbling banks.A sharp cracking off of rifles was kept up for some time in various directions, upon a numerous flock of turkeys, scampering among the thickets, or perched upon the trees.We had not been long at a halt, when a drizzling rain ushered in the autumnal storm that had been brewing.Preparations were immediately made to weather it; our tent was pitched, and our saddles, saddlebags, packages of coffee, sugar, salt, and every thing else that could be damaged by the rain, were gathered under its shelter.Our men, Beatte, Tonish, and Antoine, drove stakes with forked ends into the ground, laid poles across them for rafters, and thus made a shed or pent-house, covered with bark and skins, sloping toward the wind, and open toward the fire.The rangers formed similar shelters of bark and skins, or of blankets stretched on poles, supported by forked stakes, with great fires in front.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这些预防措施非常及时。这场连绵的阴雨，时断时续地下了两天。我们刚刚到达时平静流淌的溪水，现在涨成了混沌翻滚的急流，而森林也差不多快变成沼泽地了。人们或是聚集在他们用动物皮和毯子搭建的棚屋下，或是蜷缩着围坐在篝火旁。几柱浓烟盘旋在树林间，在空气中慢慢散开，给这个林地笼上了一层蓝色的烟薄。我们那些可怜的、困顿的马儿们，因旅途劳顿及牧草短缺而被折磨坏了，无精打采地站在雨中，低着脑袋，耷拉着耳朵，喷着鼻息，眼睛半睁半闭地打着瞌睡。每一阵微风掠过树枝时，都会刮落一些枯黄的秋叶，飘散在它们周围。
These precautions were well timed.The rain set in sullenly and steadily, and kept on, with slight intermissions, for two days.The brook which flowed peacefully on our arrival, swelled into a turbid and boiling torrent, and the forest became little better than a mere swamp.The men gathered under their shelters of skins and blankets, or sat cowering round their fires; while columns of smoke curling up among the trees, and diffusing themselves in the air, spread a blue haze through the woodland.Our poor, way-worn horses, reduced by weary travel and scanty pasturage, lost all remaining spirit, and stood, with drooping heads, flagging ears, and half-closed eyes, dozing and steaming in the rain, while the yellow autumnal leaves, at every shaking of the breeze, came wavering down around them.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 然而，尽管天气很糟糕，我们的猎手们却没有闲着。在雨停的间歇，他们会骑马出去巡游整个林地。远方不时的尖锐枪声，预示着某一头鹿的死亡。大量的鹿肉被带了回来。一些人忙着在棚屋下给猎物剥皮，把肉切开，或是在篝火周围摆上烤肉叉和野营水壶，之后在整个营地里举行一种粗陋的宴会，更准确地说，是狼吞虎咽。一些人仍继续在挥动着斧子工作，单调的伐木声在林间回响。轰隆！某棵大树轰然倒下。几分钟之后，它的枝杈就会在营地巨大的篝火里熊熊燃烧，发出噼里啪啦声。而某个曾经在它的树阴下蹦跳的不幸的鹿，现在正在它上面烤着。
Notwithstanding the bad weather, however, our hunters were not idle, but during the intervals of the rain, sallied forth on horseback to prowl through the woodland.Every now and then the sharp report of a distant rifle boded the death of a deer.Venison in abundance was brought in.Some busied themselves under the sheds, flaying and cutting up the carcasses, or round the fires with spits and camp kettles, and a rude kind of feasting, or rather gormandizing, prevailed throughout the camp.The axe was continual at work, and wearied the forest with its echoes.Crash! some mighty tree would come down; in a few minutes its limbs would be blazing and crackling on the huge camp fires, with some luckless deer roasting before it, that had once sported beneath its shade.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 天气的变化可害苦了我们的小个子法国人。他那除了骨头就是筋的瘦弱身躯，此刻正遭受着风湿病痛的折磨。他牙疼、耳朵疼——他的脸紧绷着——几乎浑身上下哪儿都刺疼；可所有这些好像只会让他更加不安分，他在篝火旁坐立不安，他不停地烤肉、炖肉、呻吟、谩骂并诅咒。
The change of weather had taken sharp hold of our little Frenchman.His meagre frame, composed of bones and whip-cord, was racked with rheumatic pains and twinges.He had the toothache—the earache—his face was tied up—he had shooting pains in every limb; yet all seemed but to increase his restless activity, and he was in an incessant fidget about the fire, roasting, and stewing, and groaning, and scolding, and swearing.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的贝蒂神情冷峻而又羞愧地打猎回来了。他碰到了一头体积庞大的熊，用步枪子弹打伤了它。这头熊奔向了那条水流满涨而又湍急的小溪。贝蒂随后就追了上去，用猎刀砍向它的臀部。每一次攻击时，这头熊都会狂怒地扑向他，并露出可怕的、白森森的牙齿。贝蒂在小溪中找到一个立足点之后，得以用步枪将它赶跑。当他连游带淌地跟着过了河，试图击倒它时，那头熊却成功地爬过一片灌木丛逃走了，于是贝蒂沮丧地放弃了追逐。
Our man Beatte returned grim and mortified, from hunting.He had come upon a bear of formidable dimensions, and wounded him with a rifle-shot.The bear took to the brook, which was swollen and rapid.Beatte dashed in after him and assailed him in the rear with his hunting-knife.At every blow the bear turned furiously upon him, with a terrific display of white teeth.Beatte, having a foothold in the brook, was enabled to push him off with his rifle, and, when he turned to swim, would flounder after, and attempt to hamstring him,the bear, however, succeeded in scrambling off among the thickets, and Beatte had to give up the chase.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这次冒险虽没带回任何猎物，但至少在夜晚的火堆周围引发人们谈论了几件关于猎熊的轶事，而其中灰熊显然成了主角。无论是在印第安人还是在白种人中间，这种强悍凶猛的动物都是猎人的故事中最受欢迎的主题。它那巨大的爪子常被作为一种奖励戴在印第安勇士的脖子上，这可比人的头皮更加荣耀。现在除了在高地草原和落基山脉周围，人们几乎看不到灰熊。其他的熊在被打伤和激怒时，也会非常可怕，但在可以逃走的情况下，它们很少作战。在我们西部荒原的所有动物中，独有灰熊很容易就无缘无故产生敌意。它那庞大的体积和惊人的力气使它成为了一个令人恐惧的对手。尽管身中数枪并被猎刀砍伤多处，但它顽强的生命力仍让那些老练的猎手也束手无策。
This adventure, if it produced no game, brought up at least several anecdotes, round the evening fire, relative to bear hunting, in which the grizzly bear figured conspicuously.This powerful and ferocious animal is a favorite theme of hunter’s story, both among red and white men; and his enormous claws are worn round the neck of an Indian brave as a trophy more honorable than a human scalp.He is now scarcely seen below the upper prairies and the skirts of the Rocky Mountains.Other bears are formidable when wounded and provoked, but seldom make battle when allowed to escape.The grizzly bear alone, of all the animals of our Western wilds, is prone to unprovoked hostility.His prodigious size and strength make him a formidable opponent; and his great tenacity of life often baffles the skill of the hunter, notwithstanding repeated shots of the rifle, and wounds of the hunting-knife.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一件有关这种情形的轶事，向我们展现了边疆猎手们司空见惯的险情和死里逃生的场景。一个猎手在追逐一头鹿时，掉进了其中一个漏斗形的深坑中。这是大草原上暴雨后的积水沉降形成的，被称作落水洞。让他感到无比惊恐的是：他在洞底碰到了一头巨大的灰熊。这个猛兽向他扑来，一场殊死搏斗由此展开。在搏斗中，这个可怜的猎手被严重撕伤、咬伤，一条腿和一只胳膊也被折断了。但他最终却成功地杀死了他凶残的对手。因为伤得太严重了，他根本不能移动，所以他一连数日都呆在洞底，靠着生的熊肉维持生命。在那段时间里，他任由伤口就那么敞着，让其慢慢地完全愈合。最终，他爬到了洞口，来到了广阔的大草原上。他费力地爬向一个由几乎干涸的小溪形成的沟壑。在那儿，他美美地喝了一顿水，这给他注入了新的活力。然后，他从一个水塘爬到另一个水塘，靠吃一些小鱼和小蛙维持生命。
One of the anecdotes related on this occasion, gave a picture of the accidents and hard shifts to which our frontier rovers are inured.A hunter, while in pursuit of a deer, fell into one of those deep funnel-shaped pits, formed on the prairies by the settling of the waters after heavy rains, and known by the name of sink-holes.To his great horror, he came in contact, at the bottom, with a huge grizzly bear.The monster grappled him; a deadly contest ensued, in which the poor hunter was severely torn and bitten, and had a leg and an arm broken, but succeeded in killing his rugged foe.For several days he remained at the bottom of the pit, too much crippled to move, and subsisting on the raw flesh of the bear, during which time he kept his wounds open, that they might heal gradually and effectually.He was at length enabled to scramble to the top of the pit, and so out upon the open prairie.With great difficulty he crawled to a ravine, formed by a stream, then nearly dry.Here he took a delicious draught of water, which infused new life into him; then dragging himself along from pool to pool, he supported himself by small fish and frogs.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一天，他看到一匹狼在附近的大草原上捕杀了一头鹿。他马上从沟壑里爬了过去，赶走了那匹狼，躺在鹿的尸体旁，直到饱餐了好几顿，体力大大恢复了之后，他才离开。
One day he saw a wolf hunt down and kill a deer in the neighboring prairie.He immediately crawled forth from the ravine, drove off the wolf, and, lying down beside the carcass of the deer, remained there until he made several hearty meals, by which his strength was much recruited.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 回到那条沟壑后，他沿着小溪一路前进，直到它变成了一条小河。他顺着这条河漂流而下，直到来到它汇入密西西比河的地方。他刚好在河口处发现了一棵带杈的树，他费力地把它弄到水中，骑在上面，让自己漂荡在这条大河的滚滚水流之中。他用这种方法一路漂着，直到到达康瑟尔布拉夫斯要塞的对面。幸好他是白天到达的，否则他很可能漂过这个孤零零的要塞而不为人所知，消失在滚滚水流中。要塞里面的人发现了他之后，便派出一艘独木舟去解救他，他被带上岸时已经奄奄一息了。在那儿，他的伤很快便好了，但却留下了终生的残疾。
Returning to the ravine, he pursued the course of the brook, until it grew to be a considerable stream.Down this he floated, until he came to where it emptied into the Mississippi.Just at the mouth of the stream, he found a forked tree, which he launched with some difficulty, and, getting astride of it, committed himself to the current of the mighty river.In this way he floated along, until he arrived opposite the fort at Council Bluffs.Fortunately he arrived there in the daytime, otherwise he might have floated, unnoticed, past this solitary post, and perished in the idle waste of waters.Being descried from the fort, a canoe was sent to his relief, and he was brought to shore more dead than alive, where he soon recovered from his wounds, but remained maimed for life.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 贝蒂经历了一场和熊的搏斗之后，显得筋疲力尽、狼狈不堪。他在那条溪水中搞得浑身都湿透了，再加上最近天气的变化，他四肢风湿痛的老毛病又犯了。尽管他通常是个勇敢无畏、吃苦耐劳的家伙，这时他坐在篝火旁也难免垂头丧气，甚至抱怨一顿。尽管正处于人生的黄金时期，拥有强壮的身躯和看起来钢铁般结实的体格，他却自称自己仅有一副残躯。实际上，他是一个活生生的边陲野外生活之艰辛的纪念碑。他露出左胳膊，向我们展示了以前风湿发作后留下的扭曲和收缩了的肌肉。这是一种经常折磨印第安人的疾病。因为裸露于变化无常的天气中，他们并没有像许多人想象的那样，铸就了一副对季节的变化无动于衷的完美身躯。他浑身满是各种伤痕，有些是打猎时留下的，还有些是在印第安战场上留下的。有一次他从马上摔下来，摔断了右胳膊；还有一次他的坐骑和他一起摔倒，压断了他的左腿。
Our man Beatte had come out of his contest with the bear very much worsted and discomfited.His drenching in the brook, together with the recent change of weather, had brought on rheumatic pains in his limbs, to which he is subject.Though ordinarily a fellow of undaunted spirit, and above all hardship, yet he now sat down by the fire, gloomy and dejected, and for once gave way to repining.Though in the prime of life, and of a robust frame, and apparently iron constitution, yet, by his own account, he was little better than a mere wreck.He was, in fact, a living monument of the hardships of wild frontier life.Baring his left arm, he showed it warped and contracted by a former attack of rheumatism; a malady with which the Indians are often afflicted; for their exposure to the vicissitudes of the elements does not produce that perfect hardihood and insensibility to the changes of the seasons that many are apt to imagine.He bore the scars of various maims and bruises; some received in hunting, some in Indian warfare.His right arm had been broken by a fall from his horse; at another time his steed had fallen with him, and crushed his left leg.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “我几乎所有骨头都断过，都找不到一块完好的地方了，”他说，“无论现在发生什么，我都毫不在乎了。”“但是，”停了一会儿之后他补充道，“尽管如此，无论如何也只有很强壮的家伙才能放倒我。”
“I am all broke to pieces and good for nothing,” said he; “I no care now what happen to me any more.”“However,” added he, after a moment’s pause, “for all that, it would take a pretty strong man to put me down, anyhow.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 了解了他所讲述的关于自己的各种细节后，我感觉到有必要对他进行一番评价。他居住在尼欧肖河畔的一个奥塞奇小村庄，或者是在奥塞奇部落附近。那里是由一个来自哈得孙河岸名叫雷夸的可敬传教士监管的。他努力教授这些野蛮人农耕的技术，把他们变成农夫和牧人。在边疆之旅的最近一次行程中，我拜访了雷夸管辖的那块农耕教区，觉得比起那些仅仅沿着边疆传教、布道的使团，他这样做更能给那些贫穷的印第安人带来实实在在的好处。
I drew from him various particulars concerning himself, which served to raise him in my estimation.His residence was on the Neosho, in an Osage hamlet or neighborhood, under the superintendence of a worthy missionary from the banks of the Hudson, by the name of Requa, who was endeavoring to instruct the savages in the art of agriculture, and to make husbandmen and herdsmen of them.I had visited this agricultural mission of Requa in the course of my recent tour along the frontier, and had considered it more likely to produce solid advantages to the poor Indians than any of the mere praying and preaching missions along the border.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在那附近，皮埃尔·贝蒂有他自己的小农场、印第安妻子和混血儿孩子。他还帮助雷夸先生努力教化当地人，改善奥塞奇部落的居住条件。贝蒂从小就是一个天主教徒，对他信奉的宗教非常虔诚。他说，他不能和雷夸先生一起祷告，但却可以和他一起工作。他对有益于他的野蛮朋友和邻居的事情常常表现出极大的热情。实际上，尽管他父亲曾经是法国人，他自己也是在白人中长大的，但显然他有着更多印第安人的特点，内心也更向往他母亲的民族。当他向我谈及可怜的印第安人在与边疆粗暴的殖民者打交道时所遭受到的不公正待遇和侵犯时，当他讲述奥塞奇部落每况愈下、岌岌可危的处境，说人数锐减、士气瓦解、几乎忍气吞声地活在他们曾经像英雄般出入的土地上时，我看到他血脉贲张、鼻翼翕动，显得义愤填膺；但他会用一种强烈的印第安人自控方式努力将这种感情抑制住，并把它憋回到自己心中。
In this neighborhood, Pierre Beatte had his little farm, his Indian wife, and his half-breed children; and aided Mr. Requa in his endeavors to civilize the habits, and meliorate the condition of the Osage tribe.Beatte had been brought up a Catholic, and was inflexible in his religious faith; he could not pray with Mr. Requa, he said, but he could work with him, and he evinced a zeal for the good of his savage relations and neighbors.Indeed, though his father had been French, and he himself had been brought up in communion with the whites, he evidently was more of an Indian in his tastes, and his heart yearned toward his mother’s nation.When he talked to me of the wrongs and insults that the poor Indians suffered in their intercourse with the rough settlers on the frontiers; when he described the precarious and degraded state of the Osage tribe, diminished in numbers, broken in spirit, and almost living on sufferance in the land where they once figured so heroically, I could see his veins swell, and his nostrils distend with indignation; but he would check the feeling with a strong exertion of Indian self-command, and, in a manner, drive it back into his bosom.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他毫不犹豫地讲述了一个他和他的奥塞奇族人，追逐、报复对他们犯下滔天罪行的一伙白人的故事。我发现在这场对决中，贝蒂表现得完全像个印第安人。
He did not hesitate to relate an instance wherein he had joined his kindred Osages, in pursuing and avenging themselves on a party of white men who had committed a flagrant outrage upon them; and I found, in the encounter that took place, Beatte had shown himself the complete Indian.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他曾多次跟随奥塞奇亲戚和波尼人打仗。他还讲述了一场就发生在这片狩猎场边界上的小冲突，其中有好几个波尼人被杀死了。他说，在我们的旅程途中，应该会经过那儿附近，还可以看到被杀者未被掩埋的尸骨和头颅。队伍里的外科医生也参与了我们的谈话。当听到这个消息时，他马上竖起了耳朵。他带着几分颅相学家的味道，承诺如果贝蒂可以帮他弄来其中的一副头骨的话，他愿意给他丰厚的报酬。
He had more than once accompanied his Osage relations in their wars with the Pawnees, and related a skirmish which took place on the borders of these very hunting grounds, in which several Pawnees were killed.We should pass near the place, he said, in the course of our tour, and the unburied bones and skulls of the slain were still to be seen there.The surgeon of the troop, who was present at our conversation, pricked up his ears at this intelligence.He was something of a phrenologist, and offered Beatte a handsome reward if he would procure him one of the skulls.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 贝蒂目瞪口呆而又一脸严肃地看了他一会儿。
Beatte regarded him for a moment with a look of stern surprise.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “不，”他最终说道，“这太不好了！”我足够勇敢——我不怕杀人。但还是让死者独自安息吧！
“No!” said he at length, “dat too bad!”I have heart strong enough—I no care kill, but let the dead alone!

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他补充说道，有一次在和一群白人一起旅行时，他和一个医生睡在同一个帐篷里，发现在他的包裹里有一副波尼人的头骨。他马上离开了那个医生的帐篷，和他们分道扬镳了。“他试图哄骗我，”贝蒂说，“但我说不，我们必须分开——我不和这种人为伍。”
He added, that once in travelling with a party of white men, he had slept in the same tent with a doctor, and found that he had a Pawnee skull among his baggage: he at once renounced the doctor’s tent, and his fellowship.“He try to coax me,” said Beatte, “but I say no, we must part—I no keep such company.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在他精神沮丧的片刻，他玩起了印第安人常玩的预测未来的迷信把戏。他用手撑着下巴，凝视着火堆，坐了好长一会儿。我发现，他的思绪漂荡回了他那坐落在尼欧肖河岸上的简陋的家。他说他确信当他回去时会发现某个家人病了或是死了：他的左眼在过去两天里总是跳个不停，这是一种预示着某种不幸的征兆。
In the temporary depression of his spirits, Beatte gave way to those superstitious forebodings to which Indians are prone.He had sat for some time, with his cheek upon his hand, gazing into the fire.I found his thoughts were wandering back to his humble home, on the banks of the Neosho; he was sure, he said, that he should find some one of his family ill, or dead, on his return: his left eye had twitched and twinkled for two days past; an omen which always boded some misfortune of the kind.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 就是这些琐碎的小事，被放大成征兆后，就可以动摇这些具有钢铁般意志的男人的灵魂。最最细微的神秘而凶险的征兆，就足以让一个猎手或是一个战士无心于自己的事业，或者使他满脑子都是对即将到来的不幸的忧虑。正是这种荒野中孤独而又野蛮的流浪者所惯有的迷信倾向，使得那些预言家和梦想家有了强大的影响力。
Such are the trivial circumstances which, when magnified into omens, will shake the souls of these men of iron.The least sign of mystic and sinister portent is sufficient to turn a hunter or a warrior from his course, or to fill his mind with apprehensions of impending evil.It is this superstitious propensity, common to the solitary and savage rovers of the wilderness, that gives such powerful influence to the prophet and the dreamer.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 贝蒂的大半辈子都与奥赛奇人生活在一起，而奥赛奇人仍在很大程度上保留着原始的迷信幻想和迷信仪式。他们都相信灵魂和身体分离后仍然会继续存在，并且会带有在世时所有的爱好和习惯。在贝蒂他家附近的一个奥塞奇村庄里，为首的一位战士失去了他唯一的孩子。那是一个漂亮的女孩，年龄还很小很小。她所有的玩物都和她葬在了一起。她最喜欢的小马也被杀了，埋在她旁边的墓穴里，这样她就有可能在幽冥之地骑着它了。
The Osages, with whom Beatte had passed much of his life, retain these superstitious fancies and rites in much of their original force.They all believe in the existence of the soul after its separation from the body, and that it carries with it all its mortal tastes and habitudes.At an Osage village in the neighborhood of Beatte, one of the chief warriors lost an only child, a beautiful girl, of a very tender age.All her playthings were buried with her.Her favorite little horse, also, was killed, and laid in the grave beside her, that she might have it to ride in the land of spirits.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这儿，我补充一个小故事，这是我在旅程中穿过贝蒂所在的村庄时听说的，它可以说明奥塞奇族人的迷信。一个奥塞奇的大部族，在一条名叫尼卡南萨的美丽的河流旁驻扎了一段时间。在他们中间有个年轻的猎手，他是这个部落最勇敢、最优雅的一名战士。他原本是要和一个奥塞奇女孩结婚的，这个女孩因为长得非常漂亮，被称作“草原之花”。这个年轻的猎手让她和她的亲戚在营地上住一段时间，自己前往圣路易斯，去处理猎物，并为新娘买回一些首饰。离开了几星期之后，他回到了尼卡南萨河岸。但却发现营地已经不见了，只有光秃秃的帐篷架子和熄灭了的篝火的痕迹，表明这是营地原本所在的地方。他看到，在远处有个女人坐在河边，似乎是在哭泣。那是他订了婚的新娘。他跑过去抱住她，但她却悲伤地闪开了。他担心至少是某种不幸降临到了这个营地。
I will here add a little story, which I picked up in the course of my tour through Beatte’s country, and which illustrates the superstitions of his Osage kindred.A large party of Osages had been encamped for some time on the borders of a fine stream, called the Nickanansa.Among them was a young hunter, one of the bravest and most graceful of the tribe, who was to be married to an Osage girl, who, for her beauty, was called the Flower of the Prairies.The young hunter left her for a time among her relatives in the encampment, and went to St. Louis, to dispose of the products of his hunting, and purchase ornaments for his bride.After an absence of some weeks, he returned to the banks of the Nickanansa, but the camp was no longer there; and the bare frames of the lodges and the brands of extinguished fires alone marked the place.At a distance he beheld a female seated, as if weeping, by the side of the stream.It was his affianced bride.He ran to embrace her, but she turned mournfully away.He dreaded lest some evil had befallen the camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “我们的人去哪儿了？”他喊道。
“Where are our people?” cried he.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “他们都去了瓦格拉什卡河岸。”
“They are gone to the banks of the Wagrushka.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那你一个人在这儿干什么？”
“And what art thou doing here alone?”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “等你。”
“Waiting for thee.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那让我们赶快去与我们在瓦格拉什卡河岸的族人会合吧。”
“Then let us hasten to join our people on the banks of the Wagrushka.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他把包裹交给她让她拿着，并按照印第安人的风俗走在了前面。
He gave her his pack to carry, and walked ahead, according to the Indian custom.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他们来到了一处地方，可以看到远处营地的炊烟从河边的林地中袅袅升起。这个女孩坐在了一棵树的脚下。“我们一起回去不合适，”她说，“我在这儿等着。”
They came to where the smoke of the distant camp was seen rising from the woody margin of the stream.The girl seated herself at the foot of a tree.“It is not proper for us to return together,” said she; “I will wait here.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这个年轻的猎手独自前往营地，而迎接他的却是族人们阴郁的脸色。
The young hunter proceeded to the camp alone, and was received by his relations with gloomy countenances.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “发生什么不幸的事情？”他说，“你们为什么全都这么难过呢？”
“What evil has happened,” said he, “that ye are all so sad?”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 没有人回答他。
No one replied.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他去找他最喜欢的姐姐，求她前去寻找他的新娘，把她带到营地里来。
He turned to his favorite sister, and bade her go forth, seek his bride, and conduct her to the camp.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “哎呀！”她喊叫道。“我怎么去找她啊？”她死了好几天了。
“Alas!” cried she, “how shall I seek her?”She died a few days since.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 此刻，那个年轻女孩的亲戚们都围着他，痛哭流涕。但他却拒绝相信这个不幸的消息。“就在刚刚，”他喊道，“我还把她独自留下，她还好端端的。跟我来，我带你们去见她。”
The relations of the young girl now surrounded him, weeping and wailing; but he refused to believe the dismal tidings.“But a few moments since,” cried he, “I left her alone and in health; come with me, and I will conduct you to her,”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他把他们带到她坐的那棵树那儿，但她却不见了，而他的包裹则躺在地上。未婚妻死亡的事实给他的内心带来沉重的打击，他倒在地上死去了。
He led the way to the tree where she had seated herself, but she was no longer there, and his pack lay on the ground.The fatal truth struck him to the heart; he fell to the ground dead.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我几乎是一字不差地将别人讲述给我的这个简单的故事讲述出来的。我听这个故事时，正躺在晚间营地的篝火旁，据说营地就驻扎在这个故事发生的鬼魅之河的河岸。
I give, this simple story almost in the words in which it was related to me, as I lay by the fire in an evening encampment on the banks of the haunted stream where it is said to have happened.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二十八章 一场秘密的远征
CHAPTER XXVIII. A SECRET EXPEDITION.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——鹿的叫声——施了魔法的子弹
—DEER BLEATING.—MAGIC BALLS.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二天早上，那些留在上一个营地寻找失散的马匹的巡逻骑兵们和我们会合了。他们一路追踪，穿过灌木丛和其他障碍物，越过溪流，跑了很远，直到最终发现它们在一片大草原的边缘啃着牧草。它们一直头朝着要塞的方向，很明显它们在沿着回家的路吃着草，丝毫没有注意到突然降临到自己身上的大草原上那无限的自由。
On the following morning we were rejoined by the rangers who had remained at the last encampment, to seek for the stray horses.They had tracked them for a considerable distance through bush and brake, and across streams, until they found them cropping the herbage on the edge of a prairie.Their heads were in the direction of the fort, and they were evidently grazing their way homeward, heedless of the unbounded freedom of the prairie so suddenly laid open to them.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 中午时，天气依然晴朗。我发现混血儿和托尼什正在偷偷地商议着什么。结果是请求我们让托尼什离开几个小时，允许他加入他的同伴们的一场大规模突袭。我们反对说，托尼什受疼痛折磨得太厉害，不能参加这种活动。但他极度渴望参加这次秘密行动，所以当允许他去时，他似乎立刻忘记了周身的病痛。
About noon the weather held up, and I observed a mysterious consultation going on between our half-breeds and Tonish; it ended in a request that we would dispense with the services of the latter for a few hours, and permit him to join his comrades in a grand foray.We objected that Tonish was too much disabled by aches and pains for such an undertaking; but he was wild with eagerness for the mysterious enterprise, and, when permission was give him, seemed to forget all his ailments in an instant.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 他们三个很快便全副武装地骑到马背上了；肩上扛着步枪，头上扎着头巾，显然是准备策马狂奔。当他们经过营地不同的帐篷时，尽管骑在前面、沉默寡言的贝蒂不时地勒住马，回过头以一种责备的目光狠狠地瞪着小个子法国人，但虚荣的他仍忍不住向周围的人吹嘘他即将要去完成的使命。然而，让这个喋喋不休的托尼什表现得像个“印第安人”是很难的。
In a short time the trio were equipped and on horseback; with rifles on their shoulders and handkerchiefs twisted round their heads, evidently bound for a grand scamper.As they passed by the different lodges of the camp, the vainglorious little Frenchman could not help boasting to the right and left of the great things he was about to achieve; though the taciturn Beatte, who rode in advance would every now and then check his horse, and look back at him with an air of stern rebuke.It was hard, however, to make the loquacious Tonish play “Indian.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 有几个猎手同样也动身出去了。第一流的老林中人瑞安，下午很早便满载着猎物回来了。他猎杀了一头雄鹿和两头肥壮的雌鹿。当他站在战利品旁边时，一群巡逻骑兵把他团团围住，而我也凑上前去，发现他们正在讨论一种有时用于猎鹿的技巧的好处。这个技巧包括一种叫做“咩咩叫”的乐器，用来模仿幼鹿的叫声，以便引诱雌鹿跑进步枪的射程内。“咩咩叫”也有各种各样的，适用于无风或是有风的天气，可以模仿不同年龄的小鹿的叫声。被它们欺骗的可怜动物，由于担心自己的孩子，有时会跑到离猎人很近的地方。“我曾用‘咩咩叫’引诱一头雌鹿，”一个年轻的猎手说道，“直到它跑到与我只隔二十码的地方，几乎成了我的囊中之物。“我三次举起步枪，但却不忍心射击，因为这头可怜的雌鹿看起来如此地忧愁，使我有点儿心软了。我想到了我自己的妈妈，以及当我还是一个孩子的时候，她是如何整天为我担心的。所以，最终我高呼一声，把这头雌鹿吓得立刻跑出了步枪的射程。”
Several of the hunters, likewise, sallied forth, and the prime old woodman, Ryan, came back early in the afternoon, with ample spoil, having killed a buck and two fat does.I drew near to a group of rangers that had gathered round him as he stood by the spoil, and found they were discussing the merits of a stratagem sometimes used in deer hunting.This consists in imitating, with a small instrument called a bleat, the cry of the fawn, so as to lure the doe within reach of the rifle.There are bleats of various kinds, suited to calm or windy weather, and to the age of the fawn.The poor animal, deluded by them, in its anxiety about its young, will sometimes advance close up to the hunter.“I once bleated a doe,” said a young hunter, “until it came within twenty yards of me, and presented a sure mark.I levelled my rifle three times, but had not the heart to shoot, for the poor doe looked so wistfully, that it in a manner made my heart yearn.I thought of my own mother, and how anxious she used to be about me when I was a child; so to put an end to the matter, I gave a halloo, and started the doe out of rifle-shot in a moment.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “你做的是正确的，”忠厚的老瑞安喊道，“就我而言，我从不用‘咩咩叫’引诱鹿。我曾和带着‘咩咩叫’的猎手们一起打猎，我让他们把‘咩咩叫’扔掉了。利用母亲对孩子的爱，是一种很卑鄙的手段。”
“And you did right,” cried honest old Ryan.“For my part, I never could bring myself to bleating deer.I’ve been with hunters who had bleats, and have made them throw them away.It is a rascally trick to take advantage of a mother’s love for her young.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 傍晚时，我们的三位“勇士”结束了秘密的偷袭，回来了。还没看到他们，托尼什的声音就已经使大家注意到他们回来了，因为他在扯着嗓门高喊，把整个营地的注意力都吸引了过去。他们马匹那迟缓的步态和大汗淋漓的腹部，表明它们经历了一场艰苦的奔驰。走到跟前时，我们发现它们浑身都挂满了肉，就像是一个屠夫的屠宰场。实际上，他们搜寻了延伸到森林之外的一整片大草原，而那里布满了成群的野牛。贝蒂在几天前和奥塞奇人的交谈中，就了解到了关于这个大草原及草原上的动物的信息。但他却一直保守着这个秘密，不让巡逻骑兵知道，这样他和他的同伴们便可以捷足先登了。如果托尼什不是在吹牛的话，他们本可以杀死几十头野牛，但他们猎杀了四头，就已经感到心满意足了。
Toward evening our three worthies returned from their mysterious foray.The tongue of Tonish gave notice of their approach long before they came in sight; for he was vociferating at the top of his lungs, and rousing the attention of the whole camp.The lagging gait and reeking flanks of their horses, gave evidence of hard riding; and, on nearer approach, we found them hung round with meat like a butcher’s shambles.In fact, they had been scouring an immense prairie that extended beyond the forest, and which was covered with herds of buffalo.Of this prairie, and the animals upon it, Beatte had received intelligence a few days before, in his conversation with the Osages, but had kept the information a secret from the rangers, that he and his comrades might have the first dash at the game.They had contented themselves with killing four; though, if Tonish might be believed, they might have slain them by scores.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这些消息，以及他们带回来的野牛肉，使整个营地都欢喜雀跃起来。每个人都兴奋地期待着去那个大草原上猎杀野牛。托尼什再一次成了营地的圣人，他口若悬河地对围坐在篝火旁竖耳倾听的听众讲了足足一个小时。他现在比之前更能吹嘘自己作为射击能手的高超枪法了。他把自己在前半部分旅程中没有什么战绩，统统归咎于“运气不好”，或是“中邪了”。发现听众竟然轻易地相信了自己，于是，他又讲述了一个类似的故事，宣称是自己的遭遇，但显然是从他的奥塞奇亲戚那来听来的一个故事。
These tidings, and the buffalo meat brought home in evidence, spread exultation through the camp, and every one looked forward with joy to a buffalo hunt on the prairies.Tonish was again the oracle of the camp, and held forth by the hour to a knot of listeners, crouched round the fire, with their shoulders up to their ears.He was now more boastful than ever of his skill as a marksman.All his want of success in the early part of our march he attributed to being “out of luck,” if not “spell-bound;” and finding himself listened to with apparent credulity, gave an instance of the kind, which he declared had happened to himself, but which was evidently a tale picked up among his relations, the Osages.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 据他所说，有一天在打猎时，他看到从峡谷中跑出来一头白鹿，那时他大约十四岁。他爬过去准备射击，但却发现一头接一头的鹿跑了出来，直到一共来了七头，全部都是雪白雪白的。爬到足够近之后，他挑出其中一头，朝它开了枪，但却没起作用。那头鹿依旧平静地立在那儿。他装上弹药并再次射击，但又没打中。于是，他持续地射击目标，却不断地射失目标，直到所有的弹药都被用光了，鹿却依然毫发无伤。他怀着对自己原本高超的枪法十分绝望的心情回到了家，却得到了一位老奥塞奇猎人的安慰。他说这些白鹿都拥有魔法保护的生命，也只能被一种特殊的子弹杀死。
According to this account, when about fourteen years of age, as he was one day hunting, he saw a white deer come out from a ravine.Crawling near to get a shot, he beheld another and another come forth, until there were seven, all as white as snow.Having crept sufficiently near, he singled one out and fired, but without effect; the deer remained unfrightened.He loaded and fired again and missed.Thus he continued firing and missing until all his ammunition was expended, and the deer remained without a wound.He returned home despairing of his skill as a marksman, but was consoled by an old Osage hunter.These white deer, said he, have a charmed life, and can only be killed by bullets of a particular kind.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这个老印第安人给托尼什铸了几颗子弹，但铸子弹时却不让他看，也不告诉他所需的原料及需要经过的神秘仪式。
