The old Indian cast several balls for Tonish, but would not suffer him to be present on the occasion, nor inform him of the ingredients and mystic ceremonials.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 得到了这些子弹之后，托尼什再次出发去寻找白鹿，并成功地找到了它们。他先尝试着用普通的子弹，但却像以前一样没打中。然而，一颗施过魔法的子弹马上便把一头漂亮的雄鹿打倒在地了。于是，鹿群中其余的鹿便马上逃得无影无踪了，并且再也没有出现过。
Provided with these balls, Tonish again set out in quest of the white deer, and succeeded in finding them.He tried at first with ordinary balls, but missed as before.A magic ball, however, immediately brought a fine buck to the ground.Whereupon the rest of the herd immediately disappeared and were never seen again.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 40845.0——早上天气昏暗低沉，快到八点时，太阳挣扎着出来了，照亮了整片树林。行军号发出了准备出发的信号。现在营地陷入了一片忙乱、喧闹和欢乐的景象。有些人正在骂骂咧咧地追逐着自己的马匹，有些人正骑在光溜溜的马背上，驱赶着同伴的马匹。有些人正在拆除用来支撑湿漉漉的毛毯作避难所的杆子；还有些人正在打包所有能够带走的东西，并放在走过来的驮马的背上；而其余的人则在拆卸他们受潮的步枪，重新装上弹药，以为下一场狩猎做准备。
October 29th.—The morning opened gloomy and lowering; but toward eight o’clock the sun struggled forth and lighted up the forest, and the notes of the bugle gave signal to prepare for marching.Now began a scene of bustle, and clamor, and gayety.Some were scampering and brawling after their horses, some were riding in bare-backed, and driving in the horses of their comrades.Some were stripping the poles of the wet blankets that had served for shelters; others packing up with all possible dispatch, and loading the baggage horses as they arrived, while others were cracking off their damp rifles and charging them afresh, to be ready for the sport.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约十点钟时，我们开始了行程。我慢吞吞地跟在队伍的尾部，跟着大部队涉过浑浊的小溪，并列队穿过迷宫般的树林。我总是被落在后面，直到最后一名落伍者消失在树林中，远处的号角声也从耳际散去。于是，我得以看到荒原再次变得寂静、孤独。此时，我们上一个喧闹的营地呈现出一片被遗弃的、荒凉的景象。周围树林中的许多地方被践踏得一片泥泞。许多树都被放倒了，有些被砍得支离破碎，一些巨大的碎片散落在地上；帐篷杆子都被掀去了覆盖物；篝火的余烬旁，还残留着一些穿在木叉上的烤鹿肉和烤牛肉，上面有饥饿的猎手用刀子砍切过的痕迹；四周还散落着兽皮、羊角、鹿角、野牛和鹿的骨头、生的大块腿肉，以及未拔毛的火鸡——在猎物丰富的地方，年轻的猎手就是很容易犯这种胡乱挥霍浪费的毛病。同时，二十来只甚至是四十来只红头美洲鹫早就在空中挥动着翅膀，准备一旦营地被抛弃就马上俯冲到营地来。
About ten o’clock, we began our march.I loitered in the rear of the troop as it forded the turbid brook, and defiled through the labyrinths of the forest.I always felt disposed to linger until the last straggler disappeared among the trees and the distant note of the bugle died upon the ear, that I might behold the wilderness relapsing into silence and solitude.In the present instance, the deserted scene of our late bustling encampment had a forlorn and desolate appearance.The surrounding forest had been in many places trampled into a quagmire.Trees felled and partly hewn in pieces, and scattered in huge fragments; tent-poles stripped of their covering; smouldering fires, with great morsels of roasted venison and buffalo meat, standing in wooden spits before them, hacked and slashed by the knives of hungry hunters; while around were strewed the hides, the horns, the antlers, and bones of buffaloes and deer, with uncooked joints, and unplucked turkeys, left behind with that reckless improvidence and wastefulness which young hunters are apt to indulge when in a neighborhood where game abounds.In the meantime a score or two of turkey-buzzards, or vultures, were already on the wing, wheeling their magnificent flight high in the air, and preparing for a descent upon the camp as soon as it should be abandoned.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二十九章 广阔的大草原
CHAPTER XXIX. THE GRAND PRAIRIE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——捕猎野牛
—A BUFFALO HUNT.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 向南前进了大约两个小时之后，我们终于在接近正午时走出了沉闷的十字木林。让我们感到无比高兴的是，我们看到“广阔的大草原”向我们的左右两边延伸出去。我们可以根据河岸上的绿色森林带明显地辨别出蜿蜒而辽阔的加拿大人河，以及许多较小的河流。整幅风景既广阔又美丽。看到这无边无际的富饶原野，人总会感到心境开阔，而对我这个刚从“密林之牢”逃离的人来说，这种感觉更加强烈。
After proceeding about two hours in a southerly direction, we emerged toward mid-day from the dreary belt of the Cross Timber, and to our infinite delight beheld “the great Prairie” stretching to the right and left before us.We could distinctly trace the meandering course of the main Canadian, and various smaller streams, by the strips of green forest that bordered them.The landscape was vast and beautiful.There is always an expansion of feeling in looking upon these boundless and fertile wastes; but I was doubly conscious of it after emerging from our “close dungeon of innumerous boughs.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 从一个高地上，贝蒂指出了他和他的同伴猎杀野牛的地方。我们还发现远处有几个黑色的物体在移动，他说那是牛群的一部分。队长决定改变行程，前往距此大约一英里的一个林木茂盛的低洼地，在那儿驻扎一两天，进行一次常规的野牛捕杀行动，以补给食物。当整支队伍排成一队沿着山坡向驻扎地前进时，贝蒂向我和我的伙伴们提议，让我们跟着他走，并承诺把我们带到可以好好消遣的地方。因此，我们离开了大部队，沿着另一个方向前往大草原。我们穿过一个小峡谷，爬上一个坡度平缓的高地。到达山顶时，我们看到大约一英里外有一群野马。贝蒂马上注意到了它们，将猎杀野牛的事抛到了九霄云外。他骑着那匹强壮的半野的马，马鞍的前鞍桥上挂着一个套索，拍马去追了；而我们则继续待在一个高地上，非常关切地注视着他的行动。借助着一条狭长的林地，他偷偷地前进，希望在被发现之前靠近它们。它们发现他后，便马上四散逃开了。我们看到他沿着地平线飞奔着，就像是一艘全速追逐商船的私掠船。最终，他越过了一个山脊，进入一个浅浅的山谷。一会儿之后，他出现在对面的山上，迫近了马群中的一匹。他很快便与它齐头并进，似乎在努力想套住猎物。但他们又一同消失在山下，我们再也看不到他们了。原来，他套住了一匹强壮的马，却没法控制它，在试图控制它时还弄掉了套索。
From a rising ground Beatte pointed out the place where he and his comrades had killed the buffaloes; and we beheld several black objects moving in the distance, which he said were part of the herd.The Captain determined to shape his course to a woody bottom about a mile distant, and to encamp there for a day or two, by way of having a regular buffalo hunt, and getting a supply of provisions.As the troop defiled along the slope of the hill toward the camping ground, Beatte proposed to my messmates and myself, that we should put ourselves under his guidance, promising to take us where we should have plenty of sport.Leaving the line of march, therefore, we diverged toward the prairie; traversing a small valley, and ascending a gentle swell of land.As we reached the summit, we beheld a gang of wild horses about a mile off.Beatte was immediately on the alert, and no longer thought of Buffalo hunting.He was mounted on his powerful half-wild horse, with a lariat coiled at the saddle-bow, and set off in pursuit; while we remained on a rising ground watching his manoeuvres with great solicitude.Taking advantage of a strip of woodland, he stole quietly along, so as to get close to them before he was perceived.The moment they caught sight of him a grand scamper took place.We watched him skirting along the horizon like a privateer in full chase of a merchantman; at length he passed over the brow of a ridge, and down into a shallow valley; in a few moments he was on the opposite hill, and close upon one of the horses.He was soon head and head, and appeared to be trying to noose his prey; but they both disappeared again below the hill, and we saw no more of them.It turned out afterward that he had noosed a powerful horse, but could not hold him, and had lost his lariat in the attempt.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 等他回来期间，我们看到两头野牛跑下一个山坡，奔向一条河流。这条河流曲折穿过了一个树木葱郁的溪谷。我和年轻的伯爵试图在树木的掩护下靠近它们。当距离它们尚有三四百码远时，它们便发现了我们，于是调头退回了高地。我们策马穿过溪谷，去追逐它们。那沉重的头和肩膀，使野牛跑上山时很费力，但这也加快了它们下山时的速度。因此，我们便具有了优势。尽管因为这些逃亡者身上特殊的气息使我们的马匹不敢接近，但我们还是很快逼近了它们。伯爵带着一支装满弹药的双管枪，他开了枪，却没有打中。那些公牛此刻改变了方向：狂奔下山。由于它们向着不同的方向逃窜，我们便也单个儿分头行动。我带着的是一对在吉布森要塞借的老式铜管手枪，可以明显地看出它们已经身经数战了。如果猎手可以骑马接近野牛，并在全速前进中向它开枪射击，手枪对于捕杀野牛是非常有效的。然而，常用于边陲地区的、又长又重的步枪则不容易操纵，也不易在马背上瞄准射击。因此，我的目标便是让野牛进入手枪的射程内。这并不是一件非常容易的事。我稳稳地骑在一匹有着出色速度和健美臀部的马上，它似乎也对这场追逐非常兴奋。我们很快赶上了猎物。但每当马上就要和它们平行时，它便会匆忙避向一旁，两只耳朵呈叉状向前竖起，露出厌恶和警觉的神色。这并不奇怪。在所有的动物中，野牛在猎手的紧追之下，会露出最最凶暴的神色。它那布满蓬乱毛发的庞大躯体上，拱着两只弯曲的黑色短牛角；眼睛像煤一样闪着幽光；嘴巴张着，露出干燥的半月形舌头；它那一簇直立的尾巴在空中飞舞着——它简直就是一幅愤怒和恐惧交织的完美景象。
While we were waiting for his return, we perceived two buffalo bulls descending a slope, toward a stream, which wound through a ravine fringed with trees.The young Count and myself endeavored to get near them under covert of the trees.They discovered us while we were yet three or four hundred yards off, and turning about, retreated up the rising ground.We urged our horses across the ravine, and gave chase.The immense weight of head and shoulders causes the buffalo to labor heavily up hill; but it accelerates his descent.We had the advantage, therefore, and gained rapidly upon the fugitives, though it was difficult to get our horses to approach them, their very scent inspiring them with terror.The Count, who had a double-barrelled gun loaded with ball, fired, but it missed.The bulls now altered their course, and galloped down hill with headlong rapidity.As they ran in different directions, we each singled out one and separated.I was provided with a brace of veteran brass-barrelled pistols, which I had borrowed at Fort Gibson, and which had evidently seen some service.Pistols are very effective in buffalo hunting, as the hunter can ride up close to the animal, and fire at it while at full speed; whereas the long heavy rifles used on the frontier, cannot be easily managed, nor discharged with accurate aim from horseback.My object, therefore, was to get within pistol shot of the buffalo.This was no very easy matter.I was well mounted on a horse of excellent speed and bottom, that seemed eager for the chase, and soon overtook the game; but the moment he came nearly parallel, he would keep sheering off, with ears forked and pricked forward, and every symptom of aversion and alarm.It was no wonder.Of all animals, a buffalo, when close pressed by the hunter, has an aspect the most diabolical.His two short black horns, curve out of a huge frontier of shaggy hair; his eyes glow like coals; his mouth is open, his tongue parched and drawn up into a half crescent; his tail is erect, and tufted and whisking about in the air, he is a perfect picture of mingled rage and terror.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我好不容易驱马来到足够近的地方，然后瞄准射击，可让我懊恼的是，两把枪都没打中目标。不幸的是，这些老爷枪的保险栓都磨损过度了，所以在飞奔过程中，火药从火药池中被摇晃了出来。打完最后一枪后，我已经逼近野牛了。这时，在绝望之下，它突然掉头，喷着鼻息向我猛扑过来。我的马被惊得扬起前踢，在原地旋转了半圈，猛地跳开了。由于我双手举着枪，身体重心侧在马的一边，险些被抛到野牛的脚蹄之下。
It was with difficulty I urged my horse sufficiently near, when, taking aim, to my chagrin, both pistols missed fire.Unfortunately the locks of these veteran weapons were so much worn, that in the gallop, the priming had been shaken out of the pans.At the snapping of the last pistol I was close upon the buffalo, when, in his despair, he turned round with a sudden snort and rushed upon me.My horse wheeled about as if on a pivot, made a convulsive spring, and, as I had been leaning on one side with pistol extended, I came near being thrown at the feet of the buffalo.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 马跳跃了三四下，使我们摆脱了敌人的威胁。而仅仅是为了自卫而不顾一切扑过来的野牛，又马上开始逃跑了。拢住我那惊魂未定的坐骑，给手枪重新填上弹药之后，我立刻又策马追赶那头野牛，而它也放慢了速度好喘口气。当我靠近时，它又开始全力狂奔，沉重的身体一起一伏，全速冲过了灌木丛和溪谷。它那沉重的脚步声，惊动了几只躲藏在隐蔽处的鹿和狼，吓得它们慌忙穿过荒野，四散逃跑。
Three or four bounds of the horse carried us out of the reach of the enemy; who, having merely turned in desperate self-defence, quickly resumed his flight.As soon as I could gather in my panic-stricken horse, and prime the pistols afresh, I again spurred in pursuit of the buffalo, who had slackened his speed to take breath.On my approach he again set off full tilt, heaving himself forward with a heavy rolling gallop, dashing with headlong precipitation through brakes and ravines, while several deer and wolves, startled from their coverts by his thundering career, ran helter-skelter to right and left across the waste.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 穿过大草原全速追逐猎物，绝不像人们想象的那样是一件容易的事。人们只会想到广阔而又平坦的草原。确实，高草原上的狩猎场，不会像低草原那样，有那么多难缠的开花植物及长长的牧草，而主要覆盖着较短的野牛草。但其上也有着不少山丘和溪谷，到处都可能被雨后洪流冲成的较深的裂隙和沟壑所隔断；这些平坦表面下的裂隙几乎成了猎人行进中的陷阱，在他们全速奔驰时，突然挡住他们，或者是给他们带来肢体或生命的危害。平原上也有着许多小动物挖的洞，马蹄很容易深陷进去，把自己和骑手都摔倒。上一场雨覆盖了这个大草原的许多地区，原本坚硬的地面上积起了一层薄薄的水，马跑过时会溅起一路水花。其他的地方还会有无数的浅坑，直径大约八到十英尺，这是那些野牛像猪那样在沙地和泥地里打滚造成的。这些坑都注满了水，像镜子一样闪烁着，所以马要不断地越过它们或是从旁边绕行。我们也来到了大草原中难走的地区，到处都被裂缝和沟壑所隔断。野牛为了逃生，丝毫不注意脚下的路。它无暇沿着沟壑的边缘寻找一条更安全的路，而是直接就顺着极陡的坡道俯冲了下去。最终，我们来到了一条横跨整个大草原的很深的裂隙旁。这裂隙是由一条冬河冲刷而成的，嶙峋的岩石裸露在外面，形成了一条长长的峡谷，两旁是岩石和泥土混杂的、正掉着碎屑的陡峭悬崖。野牛从其中的一个悬崖，连跳带摔地俯冲了下去，然后沿着谷底一路疾奔。我看到没有继续追的必要，便停了下来，在悬崖边上静静地凝视着它，直到它消失在蜿蜒曲折的沟壑之间。
A gallop across the prairies in pursuit of game is by no means so smooth a career as those may imagine, who have only the idea of an open level plain.It is true, the prairies of the hunting ground are not so much entangled with flowering plants and long herbage as the lower prairies, and are principally covered with short buffalo grass; but they are diversified by hill and dale, and whore most level, are apt to be cut up by deep rifts and ravines, made by torrents after rains; and which yawning from an even surface are almost like pitfalls in the way of the hunger, checking him suddenly, when in full career, or subjecting him to the risk of limb and life.The plains, too, are beset by burrowing holes of small animals, in which the horse is apt to sink to the fetlock, and throw both himself and his rider.The late rain had covered some parts of the prairie, where the ground was hard, with a thin sheet of water, through which the horse had to splash his way.In other parts there were innumerable shallow hollows, eight or ten feet in diameter, made by the buffaloes, who wallow in sand and mud like swine.These being filled with water, shone like mirrors, so that the horse was continually leaping over them or springing on one side.We had reached, too, a rough part of the prairie, very much broken and cut up; the buffalo, who was running for life, took no heed to his course, plunging down break-neck ravines, where it was necessary to skirt the borders in search of a safer descent.At length we came to where a winter stream had torn a deep chasm across the whole prairie, leaving open jagged rocks, and forming a long glen bordered by steep crumbling cliffs of mingled stone and clay.Down one of these the buffalo flung himself, half tumbling, half leaping, and then scuttled along the bottom; while I, seeing all further pursuit useless, pulled up, and gazed quietly after him from the border of the cliff, until he disappeared amidst the windings of the ravine.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 现在没有什么可留恋的了，于是我调转马头，去和同伴们汇合。开始时，这有点儿困难。追逐野牛的热情，让我不辨东西地飞奔了很长一段距离。现在，我发现自己处在一片孤零零的荒野之中，四周是此起彼伏的清一色光秃秃的大地。由于没有路标和明显的特征，一个没有经验的人或许会不知所措，很容易像在茫茫大海中那样迷了路。今天又是一个阴天，无法靠太阳辨别方向。唯一的方法便是沿着我的马来时的脚印往回走，但是在那些草皮被烘干的地方，我经常找不到马蹄印。
Nothing now remained but to turn my steed and rejoin my companions.Here at first was some little difficulty.The ardor of the chase had betrayed me into a long, heedless gallop.I now found myself in the midst of a lonely waste, in which the prospect was bounded by undulating swells of land, naked and uniform, where, from the deficiency of landmarks and distinct features, an inexperienced man may become bewildered, and lose his way as readily as in the wastes of the ocean.The day, too, was overcast, so that I could not guide myself by the sun; my only mode was to retrace the track my horse had made in coming, though this I would often lose sight of, where the ground was covered with parched herbage.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 对一个不熟悉大草原的人来说，独自在大草原上会有一种难以言喻的孤独感。与之相比，森林里的孤独感便算不了什么了。在那儿，视野被树木遮挡住了，只留下自由的想象力去勾勒外面更加生气勃勃的场景。但在这儿，放眼望去，茫茫无际的景色里没有一个人影。在这儿会有一种远远超越人类居住界限的感觉，感到自己好像是在一个荒芜的世界中行进。当马儿沿着之前奔驰过的地方慢慢往回走，追逐的兴奋劲消逝之后，我对这些情形的感觉特别强烈。荒野上的寂静不时被远方一群塘鹅的叫声打破，它们像幽灵一般沿着一个浅浅的水塘走动着。有时还会听到空中乌鸦不祥的叫声，偶尔还会有一匹恶狼从我的眼前急促奔过，等达到了安全的距离之后，它便会坐下来仰天哀嚎，这凄厉的叫声给周围孤寂的荒野更增添了几分悲凉。
To one unaccustomed to it, there is something inexpressibly lonely in the solitude of a prairie.The loneliness of a forest seems noting to it.There the view is shut in by trees, and the imagination is left free to picture some livelier scene beyond.But here we have an immense extent of landscape without a sign of human existence.We have the consciousness of being far, far beyond the bounds of human habitation; we feel as if moving in the midst of a desert world.As my horse lagged slowly back over the scenes of our late scamper, and the delirium of the chase had passed away, I was peculiarly sensible to these circumstances.The silence of the waste was now and then broken by the cry of a distant flock of pelicans, stalking like spectres about a shallow pool; sometimes by the sinister croaking of a raven in the air, while occasionally a scoundrel wolf would scour off from before me: and, having attained a safe distance, would sit down and howl and whine with tones that gave a dreariness to the surrounding solitude.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 前进了一段时间之后，我看到远处一座小山的边缘有一个骑手，很快认出那人就是伯爵。他也和我一样一无所获。我们很快便和我们那知名的伙伴——那个艺术大师汇合了。他鼻梁上架着一副眼镜，在马背上射了两三枪，但什么也没打中。
After pursuing my way for some time, I descried a horseman on the edge of a distant hill, and soon recognized him to be the Count.He had been equally unsuccessful with myself; we were shortly after rejoined by our worthy comrade, the Virtuoso, who, with spectacles on nose, had made two or three ineffectual shots from horseback.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们决定再努力一次之后，才去寻找营地。放眼环顾周围的荒野，我们看到大约两英里处有一群散落的野牛，它们安静地在一片小树林和灌木丛旁边吃着草。人们很容易就会把它们想象成一群在公用牧地边上吃草的家养牛，这些树林可能还遮蔽了某个低矮的农舍。
We determined not to seek the camp until we had made one more effort.Casting our eyes about the surrounding waste, we descried a herd of buffalo about two miles distant, scattered apart, and quietly grazing near a small strip of trees and bushes.It required but little stretch of fancy to picture them so many cattle grazing on the edge of a common, and that the grove might shelter some lowly farmhouse.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们现在计划包围这群野牛。我们决定绕到它们的另一侧，把它们朝我们所知的营地驻扎的方向赶。否则，这场追逐有可能把我们带得非常远，让我们没法在黄昏前返回营地。因此，我们小心翼翼地蹑足缓行。偶尔看到牛群中任何一头停止吃草，便马上止住脚步。幸运的是，风从它们那个方向吹来，否则，它们可能早已嗅到我们的气息，警觉起来了。就这样，我们成功地包围了这群野牛，而没有惊动它们。这群野牛大约共有四十头；公牛、母牛和小牛都有。分散开一定距离之后，我们便开始平行地慢慢向它们靠近，希望可以在不被发现的情况下，偷偷靠近些。然而，它们开始慢慢离开，每走一两步就停下来吃口草。这时，一头之前没被我们发现、躺在我们左侧的树丛下午睡的公牛突然从它的隐藏处站了起来，飞奔着加入了它的同伴。我们还离得相当远，但猎物已经被惊动了。我们加快了脚步，它们也猛然狂奔起来，于是开始了一场全速的追逐。
We now formed our plan to circumvent the herd, and by getting on the other side of them, to hunt them in the direction where we knew our camp to be situated: otherwise the pursuit might take us to such a distance as to render it impossible to find our way back before nightfall.Taking a wide circuit, therefore, we moved slowly and cautiously, pausing occasionally, when we saw any of the herd desist from grazing.The wind fortunately set from them, otherwise they might have scented us and have taken the alarm.In this way we succeeded in getting round the herd without disturbing it.It consisted of about forty head, bulls, cows, and calves.Separating to some distance from each other, we now approached slowly in a parallel line, hoping by degrees to steal near without exciting attention.They began, however, to move off quietly, stopping at every step or two to graze, when suddenly a bull that, unobserved by us, had been taking his siesta under a clump of trees to our left, roused himself from his lair, and hastened to join his companions.We were still at a considerable distance, but the game had taken the alarm.We quickened our pace, they broke into a gallop, and now commenced a full chase.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 由于地势平坦，它们跑起来非常快，彼此摩肩接踵地跑成了一列。殿后的是两三头公牛，而其中的最后一头，从它那庞大的体积、端庄的前额和黝黑的皮毛看来，俨然是这群牛中的族长，它似乎已经作为君王，统治了这大草原很长时间了。
As the ground was level, they shouldered along with great speed, following each other in a line; two or three bulls bringing up the rear, the last of whom, from his enormous size and venerable frontlet, and beard of sunburnt hair, looked like the patriarch of the herd; and as if he might long have reigned the monarch of the prairie.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这些庞大的动物看上去既可怕又滑稽：它们拖着巨大的身躯跑着，笨重的头和肩膀起伏不定；它们的尾巴竖着，就像是哑剧中的一排丑角，末端猛烈而又古怪地舞动着；而眼睛则恶狠狠地瞪着，流露出惊骇和愤怒的神色。
There is a mixture of the awful and the comic in the look of these huge animals, as they bear their great bulk forward, with an up and down motion of the unwieldy head and shoulders; their tail cocked up like the queue of Pantaloon in a pantomime, the end whisking about in a fierce yet whimsical style, and their eyes glaring venomously with an expression of fright and fury.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 有时，我会和它们平行前进，但却不能使马跑进手枪的射程中。因为在前一次追逐时，它被那头野牛的攻击吓坏了。最终，我成功了。但希望还是落空了，我的手枪又一次没能射中目标。我的同伴们，则因他们的马脚力稍逊，行路过多而更加疲惫，而不能赶上这群牛。最终，跟在牛群后面的L.先生放弃了追赶，他举起双管枪，瞄准目标长距离地扫射。子弹正好打中了一头野牛的腰部上方，打断了它的脊梁骨，使它倒在了地上。他停下来下马杀猎物，而我则借了他那还有一发子弹的枪，策马全速奔跑，又一次赶上了伯爵正在追逐的、一路逃窜发出巨响的牛群。手持现在的武器，我便没有必要驱动坐骑跑到那么近的地方了。因此，我一边和它们并行奔跑，一边瞄准了一头野牛，幸运地打中它之后，它便立刻倒在了地上。那颗子弹打中了野牛身上一个致命的部位。它没法从跌倒的地方移动半步，只好躺在那儿痛苦地挣扎着，而其他野牛则继续在大草原上拼命逃窜。
For some time I kept parallel with the line, without being able to force my horse within pistol shot, so much had he been alarmed by the assault of the buffalo in the preceding chase.At length I succeeded, but was again balked by my pistols missing fire.My companions, whose horses were less fleet, and more way-worn, could not overtake the herd; at length Mr. L., who was in the rear of the line, and losing ground, levelled his double-barrelled gun, and fired a long raking shot.It struck a buffalo just above the loins, broke its back-bone, and brought it to the ground.He stopped and alighted to dispatch his prey, when borrowing his gun, which had yet a charge remaining in it, I put my horse to his speed, again overtook the herd which was thundering along, pursued by the Count.With my present weapon there was no need of urging my horse to such close quarters; galloping along parallel, therefore, I singled out a buffalo, and by a fortunate shot brought it down on the spot.The ball had struck a vital part; it could not move from the place where it fell, but lay there struggling in mortal agony, while the rest of the herd kept on their headlong career across the prairie.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我下了马，把它拴住，以防止其走失，然后走上前去观察猎物。我不是一个爱好运动的人，是猎物庞大的体积和冒险追逐的兴奋劲儿，驱使我获得了这一不同寻常的功绩。现在，兴奋劲儿已经过去，看着这躺在我脚边挣扎、流血的可怜动物，一股同情怜悯之情油然而生。而它那曾经激发了我巨大热情的庞大身躯和重要意义，现在却增加了我的负疚感。似乎我给自己的牺牲品所施加的痛苦，是和它的体积成正比的。好像和毁灭体积较小的动物相比，现在所浪费的生命是其一百倍。
Dismounting, I now fettered my horse to prevent his straying, and advanced to contemplate my victim.I am nothing of a sportsman; I had been prompted to this unwonted exploit by the magnitude of the game, and the excitement of an adventurous chase.Now that the excitement was over, I could not but look with commiseration upon the poor animal that lay struggling and bleeding at my feet.His very size and importance, which had before inspired me with eagerness, now increased my compunction.It seemed as if I had inflicted pain in proportion to the bulk of my victim, and as if it were a hundred-fold greater waste of life than there would have been in the destruction of an animal of inferior size.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这可怜的动物仍在痛苦地垂死挣扎着，这更增加了我事后良心的不安。显然，它受到了致命的一击，但可能还要好长时间才能死去。不能把它留在这儿，让它活生生地被那些老早就闻到它的血腥味、躲在远处嚎叫着、等着我离去的狼撕成碎片；也不能让那些在空中盘旋着、发出不祥的嘎嘎叫声的乌鸦蚕食它。现在，让它死去，使它脱离痛苦倒成了仁慈之举。因此，我给其中的一把手枪装上弹药，并向这头野牛靠近了些。我发现，这样冷静地给一个受伤的动物补上一枪和热血追逐中的射击是完全不同的。于是，瞄准它前肩后面的位置，我的手枪总算有一次打中了目标。这颗子弹一定是打穿了心脏，因为它剧烈地抽搐了一下，然后便一动不动了。
To add to these after-qualms of conscience, the poor animal lingered in his agony.He had evidently received a mortal wound, but death might be long in coming.It would not do to leave him here to be torn piecemeal, while yet alive, by the wolves that had already snuffed his blood, and were skulking and howling at a distance, and waiting for my departure; and by the ravens that were flapping about, croaking dismally in the air.It became now an act of mercy to give him his quietus, and put him out of his misery.I primed one of the pistols, therefore, and advanced close up to the buffalo.To inflict a wound thus in cold blood, I found a totally different thing from firing in the heat of the chase.Taking aim, however, just behind the fore-shoulder, my pistol for once proved true; the ball must have passed through the heart, for the animal gave one convulsive throe and expired.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我站在自己鲁莽之下杀死的牺牲品面前默然沉思，暗暗自责，我的马则在旁边吃着草。这时，我的同伴——好动的艺术大师走了过来。他个身手敏捷的人，在“狩猎”这项高雅的艺术中更加有经验，更加无情。他很快便割下了野牛的舌头，交给我作为带回营地的战利品。
While I stood meditating and moralizing over the wreck I had so wantonly produced, with my horse grazing near me, I was rejoined by my fellow-sportsman, the Virtuoso; who, being a man of universal adroitness, and withal, more experienced and hardened in the gentle art of “venerie,” soon managed to carve out the tongue of the buffalo, and delivered it to me to bear back to the camp as a trophy.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第三十章 一个伙伴失踪了
CHAPTER XXX. A COMRADE LOST.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——寻找营地——专员、野马和野牛——狼的小夜曲
—A SEARCH FOR THE CAMP.—THE COMMISSIONER, THE WILD HORSE, AND THE BUFFALO.—A WOLF SERENADE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们现在开始关心起年轻的伯爵来。按他平日急躁的性子，他坚持驱赶着那疲惫不堪的马追牛群，直到同样杀死一头野牛后，他才愿意回来。就这样，他一直到处追着它们，偶尔徒劳地开上一枪，直到他和野牛群都在远处变得模糊起来，最终隆起的山岗、成片的树林和灌木丛将他们彻底淹没了。
Our solicitude was now awakened for the young Count.With his usual eagerness and impetuosity he had persisted in urging his jaded horse in pursuit of the herd, unwilling to return without having likewise killed a buffalo.In this way he had kept on following them, hither and thither, and occasionally firing an ineffectual shot, until by degrees horseman and herd became indistinct in the distance, and at length swelling ground and strips of trees and thickets hid them entirely from sight.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 等到我与我那位爱狩猎的朋友会合时，年轻的伯爵早已不见踪影了。我们就这个问题商量了一番。夜晚将要来临。如果去追他，虽然在昏暗的天色下我们不会完全失去他的踪迹，但追上他以前，天就一定已经黑了。那我们就更难找到回营地的路了——即使是现在，我们要回去也很难。因此，我们决定快马加鞭尽快回到营地，派我们的混血儿及一些习惯于在大草原上游弋的老练猎手去寻找我们的伙伴。
By the time my friend, the amateur, joined me, the young Count had been long lost to view.We held a consultation on the matter.Evening was drawing on.Were we to pursue him, it would be dark before we should overtake him, granting we did not entirely lose trace of him in the gloom.We should then be too much bewildered to find our way back to the encampment; even now, our return would be difficult.We determined, therefore, to hasten to the camp as speedily as possible, and send out our half-breeds, and some of the veteran hunters, skilled in cruising about the prairies, to search for our companion.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 因此，我们开始向着我们认为是营地的方向进发。疲劳的马匹已经跑不动了，只能慢行。渐渐浓重的暮色压向我们，景色也变得越来越模糊了。我们试图辨别出早上注意到的各种路标，但却无济于事。大草原上的景色都如此相似，除了印第安人或是老练的林中人之外，其他任何人都会被迷惑了双眼。最终，夜晚降临了。我们期待可以看到远处营地的火光，听到吃草的马脖子上悬挂的铃铛的声响。有一两次，我们以为找到他们了，但我们错了。除了昆虫单调的鸣叫声，偶尔伴着习习晚风传来的野狼凄凉的嚎叫声，别的我们什么也听不到。我们开始考虑是否要在夜间停止前进，找个灌木丛的背风处露营。我们带着点火的工具，手边也有大量的木柴，野牛的舌头可以让我们充饥。
We accordingly set forward in what we supposed to be the direction of the camp.Our weary horses could hardly be urged beyond a walk.The twilight thickened upon us; the landscape grew gradually indistinct; we tried in vain to recognize various landmarks which we had noted in the morning.The features of the prairies are so similar as to baffle the eye of any but an Indian, or a practised woodman.At length night closed in.We hoped to see the distant glare of campfires; we listened to catch the sound of the bells about the necks of the grazing horses.Once or twice we thought we distinguished them; we were mistaken.Nothing was to be heard but a monotonous concert of insects, with now and then the dismal howl of wolves mingling with the night breeze.We began to think of halting for the night, and bivouacking under the lee of some thicket.We had implements to strike a light; there was plenty of firewood at hand, and the tongues of our buffaloes would furnish us with a repast.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 正准备下马时，我们听到了一声步枪的枪声，很快又听到了召集守夜的号声。我们沿着那个方向一直前进，很快便看到了营地的篝火闪烁在远处一个冲击山谷的茂密树林中。
Just as we were preparing to dismount, we heard the report of a rifle, and shortly after, the notes of the bugle, calling up the night guard.Pushing forward in that direction, the camp fires soon broke on our sight, gleaming at a distance from among the thick groves of an alluvial bottom.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 进入营地后，我们见到了一幅粗野的猎手狂吃痛饮的场景。今天战果累累，所有人都参加了狩猎。大家猎杀了八头野牛，雷鸣般的枪声还在从四周响起。所有人都尽情享受着烤腿肉、烤髓骨和多汁的隆肉等大草原上美食家中威名远扬的美食。我们兴高采烈地下马，加入了他们的欢宴，因为我们从早上开始便一直骑在疲劳的马背上，什么东西也没吃。
As we entered the camp, we found it a scene of rude hunters’ revelry and wassail.There had been a grand day’s sport, in which all had taken a part.Eight buffaloes had been killed; roaring fires were blazing on every side; all hands were feasting upon roasted joints, broiled marrow-bones, and the juicy hump, far-famed among the epicures of the prairies.Right glad were we to dismount and partake of the sturdy cheer, for we had been on our weary horses since morning without tasting food.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 至于那位我们在这个多事之日的一大早便与之分开的、可敬的专员朋友，现在正躺在一个帐篷的角落里。在这场成功的狩猎活动中，他已被折腾得精疲力尽了。
As to our worthy friend, the Commissioner, with whom we had parted company at the outset of this eventful day, we found him lying in a corner of the tent, much the worse for wear, in the course of a successful hunting match.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们的贝蒂似乎非常热衷于给专员提供一个超群出从、满足他打猎愿望的机会。他把专员扶上自己的那匹半野的马，驱赶它去追逐一头早已被猎手吓坏的、体型庞大的野牛。这匹马像它的主人一样无所畏惧，还像他一样秉性中有一股凶狠的邪恶之气。另外，它已被训练得对猎物非常熟悉了。因此一旦看到野牛或闻到其气味，它便带着并不情愿的猎手四处狂奔，并且无论去哪儿——上山下坡、趟河越溪、跨沟穿谷——直到它追上猎物才停止。它径直朝着野牛凑了上去，而不是避开它。专员几乎是出于自卫，把双管枪中的两发子弹都射向了敌人。这一猛烈攻击起了作用，不过却不是致命的。野牛愤怒地转向它的追逐者，而这匹被主人训练过的马马上转身避开了。这头野牛跟着又扑了过来。这位可敬的专员，在千钧一发之际，从枪套中拔出了他专用的手枪，向尾追的野牛开了枪。子弹正好射中了野牛的胸部，使得野牛向前轰然倒地。
It seems that our man, Beatte, in his zeal to give the Commissioner an opportunity of distinguishing himself, and gratifying his hunting propensities, had mounted him upon his half-wild horse, and started him in pursuit of a huge buffalo bull, that had already been frightened by the hunters.The horse, which was fearless as his owner, and, like him, had a considerable spice of devil in his composition, and who, besides, had been made familiar with the game, no sooner came in sight and scent of the buffalo, than he set off full speed, bearing the involuntary hunter hither and thither, and whither he would not—up hill and down hill—leaping pools and brooks—dashing through glens and gullies, until he came up with the game.Instead of sheering off, he crowded upon the buffalo.The Commissioner, almost in self-defence, discharged both barrels of a double-barrelled gun into the enemy.The broadside took effect, but was not mortal.The buffalo turned furiously upon his pursuer; the horse, as he had been taught by his owner, wheeled off.The buffalo plunged after him.The worthy Commissioner, in great extremity, drew his sole pistol from his holster, fired it off as a stern-chaser, shot the buffalo full in the breast, and brought him lumbering forward to the earth.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 专员回到营地后，所有人都称赞他的非凡战绩。但他却受到了重创，疲惫不堪。除了他自己，所有人都认为他要捕杀野牛时必然是一个强壮的骑手，一个胜利者。他对所有的赞美和祝贺都置若罔闻，只是对摆在他面前的留给猎手的食物还有一点胃口，然后很快便回到帐篷里摊开四肢躺下了。他宣称什么也不能吸引他再骑上那匹该死的半印第安马了，他这辈子再也不想捕猎野牛了。
The Commissioner returned to camp, lauded on all sides for his signal exploit; but grievously battered and way-worn.He had been a hard rider perforce, and a victor in spite of himself.He turned a deaf ear to all compliments and congratulations; had but little stomach for the hunter’s fare placed before him, and soon retreated to stretch his limbs in the tent, declaring that nothing should tempt him again to mount that half devil Indian horse, and that he had had enough of buffalo hunting for the rest of his life.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 由于现在天色太黑，所以无法派人去寻找年轻的伯爵。但是，人们却不断地放枪、吹号，以便指引他回到营地——或许迷路的他碰巧能听到。但是随着夜晚的到来，他一直没有现身。天空中看不到一颗能为他指路的星星，于是我们判断，无论他在哪儿，他已经放弃在黑夜中穿行并就地露营等待这黎明的到来。
It was too dark now to send any one in search of the young Count.Guns, however, were fired, and the bugles sounded from time to time, to guide him to the camp, if by chance he should straggle within hearing; but the night advanced without his making his appearance.There was not a star visible to guide him, and we concluded that wherever he was, he would give up wandering in the dark, and bivouac until daybreak.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这是一个阴冷多云的夜晚。营地附近被杀野牛的尸体吸引了大量的狼。这些狼围着它们，非常绝望地哀嚎个不停。忧伤的声音拖成了长长的音符，听起来抑扬顿错，给周围的荒野平添了几分荒凉之气。在大草原上，没有什么比狼半夜的哀嚎更让人感到忧郁的了。这夜晚阴郁而又狂野，周围荒野上充斥着狼那凶残的叫声，更让我们感到郁闷的是，我们年轻且无经验的同伴此时正孤身一人，身处险境。但是，我们相信当黎明再度到来时，他将会找到回营地的路。然后，今晚所发生的所有事情将会仅仅被回忆成满足他冒险口味的佳肴。
It was a raw, overcast night.The carcasses of the buffaloes killed in the vicinity of the camp had drawn about it an unusual number of wolves, who kept up the most forlorn concert of whining yells, prolonged into dismal cadences and inflexions, literally converting the surrounding waste into a howling wilderness.Nothing is more melancholy than the midnight howl of a wolf on a prairie.What rendered the gloom and wildness of the night and the savage concert of the neighboring waste the more dreary to us, was the idea of the lonely and exposed situation of our young and inexperienced comrade.We trusted, however, that on the return of daylight, he would find his way back to the camp, and then all the events of the night would be remembered only as so many savory gratifications of his passion for adventure.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第三十一章 寻找迷路的伙伴
CHAPTER XXXI. A HUNT FOR A LOST COMRADE,

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 早上来临了，可一两个小时过去之后，还是没有一点儿伯爵的消息。我们因此开始不安起来，没有指南针的帮助，他可能迷路，向着某个相反的方向走去了。因此，落伍者常常会迷失好几天。让我们更加感到焦虑的是：他没有带足干粮，而且对野外生存一窍不通，很容易落到某个潜伏在暗处或是散落在各处的野蛮人群手中。
The morning dawned, and an hour or two passed without any tidings of the Count.We began to feel uneasiness lest, having no compass to aid him, he might perplex himself and wander in some opposite direction.Stragglers are thus often lost for days; what made us the more anxious about him was, that he had no provisions with him, was totally unversed in “woodcraft,” and liable to fall into the hands of some lurking or straggling party of savages.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 因此，一吃完早饭，我们便开始召集志愿者到处去搜寻伯爵。十几个巡逻骑兵骑上一些脚力最佳、精力最充沛的马匹，背上步枪，很快便准备好出发了。混血儿贝蒂、安托万，以及小个子法国混血儿，也热情地加入到这场搜寻行动中。于是我和L.先生带领着搜寻队前往我们进行那场小小的狩猎活动时和伯爵分开的地方。我们一并开始穿越大草原了。骑了几英里之后，我们来到了被我们猎杀的两头野牛的尸首旁。一大批饿极了的狼早就在那儿拼命大啃了。当我们靠近时，它们不情愿地撤退了，躲到几百码的地方怯生生地看着我们，等着我们离去，它们好回来继续享用它们的美餐。
As soon as our people, therefore, had made their breakfast, we beat up for volunteers for a cruise in search of the Count.A dozen of the rangers, mounted on some of the best and freshest horses, and armed with rifles, were soon ready to start; our half-breeds Beatte and Antoine also, with our little mongrel Frenchman, were zealous in the cause; so Mr. L. and myself taking the lead, to show the way to the scene of our little hunt where we had parted company with the Count, we all set out across the prairie.A ride of a couple of miles brought us to the carcasses of the two buffaloes we had killed.A legion of ravenous wolves were already gorging upon them.At our approach they reluctantly drew off, skulking with a caitiff look to the distance of a few hundred yards, and there awaiting our departure, that they might return to their banquet.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我带贝蒂和安托万来到了年轻的伯爵独自继续追逐野牛的地方。这就像是让猎狗闻闻气味一样。他们立刻就从野牛的足迹中分辨出了他的马的脚印，并迅速地出发，眼睛盯着路面，沿着一条几乎笔直的路线，一直向上走了一英里。这时，来到了兽群分散开、到处跑的一片草地上。在这儿，马蹄印变得曲折迂回、重复并且常常相互交叉。我们的混血儿们就像是失去嗅迹的猎狗一样。当我们停下来等着他们解开谜团时，贝蒂突然发出了一声印第安人惯有的高喊声，或者说是尖声急叫了一声，并指向远处的一座小山。专心地看了一会儿之后，我们发现山顶上有一个骑手。“那是伯爵！”贝蒂高喊道，并飞奔了出去，整个队伍也跟在他后面。一会儿之后，他勒住了马。另一个身影骑着马出现在了山脊上。这完全改变了事态。伯爵是独自走失的，营地里没有其他的人失踪。如果这两个骑手中的其中一个果真是伯爵，那另一个一定是个印第安人。如果是个印第安人，那极有可能是个波尼人。也许他们两个都是印第安人，是某个隐藏在附近的部落的侦察兵。当我们就此进行仓促的讨论时，那两个骑手从山的侧面溜了下去，不见了踪影。其中一个巡逻骑兵认为，也许山丘的后面有一队落伍的波尼人，伯爵很可能已经落入他们手中了。这种看法在这个小小的队伍里引起一片震惊。在混血儿们的带领下，所有的马立刻飞奔起来。那些年轻的巡逻骑兵们一想到要和印第安人展开一场小规模的战斗，便都兴奋地在马上狂喊不止。这场要么危险，要么一无所获的疾驰把我们带到了山丘的边缘，并揭开了我们的误解。在一个峡谷中，我们发现那两个骑手正站在他们所猎杀的一头野牛旁边。原来他们是两个巡逻骑兵，在无人察觉的情况下，比我们早一点儿离开了营地。他们沿着直线一路来到这里，而我们则在大草原上绕了一个大圈。
I conducted Beatte and Antoine to the spot whence the young Count had continued the chase alone.It was like putting hounds upon the scent.They immediately distinguished the track of his horse amidst the trampings of the buffaloes, and set off at a round pace, following with the eye in nearly a straight course, for upward of a mile, when they came to where the herd had divided, and run hither and thither about a meadow.Here the track of the horse’s hoofs wandered and doubled and often crossed each other; our half-breeds were like hounds at fault.While we were at a halt, waiting until they should unravel the maze, Beatte suddenly gave a short Indian whoop, or rather yelp, and pointed to a distant hill.On regarding it attentively, we perceived a horseman on the summit.“It is the Count!” cried Beatte, and set off at full gallop, followed by the whole company.In a few moments he checked his horse.Another figure on horseback had appeared on the brow of the hill.This completely altered the case.The Count had wandered off alone; no other person had been missing from the camp.If one of these horsemen were indeed the Count, the other must be an Indian.If an Indian, in all probability a Pawnee.Perhaps they were both Indians; scouts of some party lurking in the vicinity.While these and other suggestions were hastily discussed, the two horsemen glided down from the profile of the hill, and we lost sight of them.One of the rangers suggested that there might be a straggling party of Pawnees behind the hill, and that the Count might have fallen into their hands.The idea had an electric effect upon the little troop.In an instant every horse was at full speed, the half-breeds leading the way; the young rangers as they rode set up wild yelps of exultation at the thoughts of having a brush with the Indians.A neck or nothing gallop brought us to the skirts of the hill, and revealed our mistake.In a ravine we found the two horsemen standing by the carcass of a buffalo which they had killed.They proved to be two rangers, who, unperceived, had left the camp a little before us, and had come here in a direct line, while we had made a wide circuit about the prairie.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这个小插曲到此结束了，突如其来的兴奋也告一段落。我们又再次慢慢地、冷静地折回那片草地，但过了好长一段时间，混血儿们才重新找到了伯爵的踪迹。在最终找到伯爵的踪迹之后，他们继续跟着野牛和马交错重叠的脚印前进，直到来到马蹄印不再和野牛的脚印混杂，而开始单独在大草原上蜿蜒伸展的地方，但这脚印却一直朝着和营地相反的方向。伯爵显然是在这儿放弃了追逐牛群，转而努力寻找回营地的路。但由于夜幕降临，他迷失了方向，也完全辨不清指南针上的方向了。
This episode being at an end, and the sudden excitement being over, we slowly and coolly retraced our steps to the meadow; but it was some time before our half-breeds could again get on the track of the Count.Having at length found it, they succeeded in following it through all its doublings, until they came to where it was no longer mingled with the tramp of buffaloes, but became single and separate, wandering here and there about the prairies, but always tending in a direction opposite to that of the camp.Here the Count had evidently given up the pursuit of the herd, and had endeavored to find his way to the encampment, but had become bewildered as the evening shades thickened around him, and had completely mistaken the points of the compass.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这整场搜寻过程中，混血儿们在追踪足迹上显示了敏锐的眼力，而印第安人也因此而闻名于世。尤其是贝蒂，他像一只老练的猎狗那样锲而不舍。有时，他会策马轻快地小跑一阵，眼睛紧盯着他坐骑前方的地面，并清晰地辨别出草皮上的踏痕。而这痕迹对我来说除非是凑近细看，否则便什么也看不到。有时，他会缓辔徐行，聚精会神地盯着对我来说一无所有的地面。然后，他会下马，抓着马笼头一步步小心翼翼地前进，头低着查看四周的地面，寻找着指示他前进的蛛丝马迹。在有些地方，土壤很硬并且草皮凋零，他会完全找不到足迹。这时，他会前后左右地反复徘徊，寻找线索；有时会回到他失去线索的地方，换一个方向重新前进。如果这也不行，那他就会去检查附近河流的河岸，或是峡谷底部的沙地，希望可以找到伯爵路过的痕迹。当他再次找到足迹后，他便会重新上马，继续前行。最终，穿过一条被侵蚀的河岸上留着深深的马蹄印的小溪之后，我们来到了一片干燥的高草原。在这儿，我们的混血儿们被彻底难倒了。尽管他们搜索了每一个方向，但却看不到任何一个脚印。最终，贝蒂停了下来，沮丧地直摇头。
In all this quest our half-breeds displayed that quickness of eye, in following up a track, for which Indians are so noted.Beatte, especially, was as staunch as a veteran hound.Sometimes he would keep forward on an easy trot; his eyes fixed on the ground a little ahead of his horse, clearly distinguishing prints in the herbage which to me were invisible, excepting on the closest inspection.Sometimes he would pull up and walk his horse slowly, regarding the ground intensely, where to my eye nothing was apparent.Then he would dismount, lead his horse by the bridle, and advance cautiously step by step, with his face bent towards the earth, just catching, here and there, a casual indication of the vaguest kind to guide him onward.In some places where the soil was hard and the grass withered, he would lose the track entirely, and wander backward and forward, and right and left, in search of it; returning occasionally to the place where he had lost sight of it, to take a new departure.If this failed he would examine the banks of the neighboring streams, or the sandy bottoms of the ravines, in hopes of finding tracks where the Count had crossed.When he again came upon the track, he would remount his horse, and resume his onward course.At length, after crossing a stream, in the crumbling banks of which the hoofs of the horse were deeply dented, we came upon a high dry prairie, where our half-breeds were completely baffled.Not a foot-print was to be discerned, though they searched in every direction; and Beatte, at length coming to a pause, shook his head despondingly.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这时，一小群鹿从附近的一个山谷中跑了出来，跳跃着从我们面前经过。贝蒂从他的马背上挺身而起，举起步枪射击，并轻微地打伤了其中的一头，但却没有把它打倒。枪声还没有落下，我们便听到远处传来一声长长的呼喊。我们环顾四周，却什么也没看到。接着，我们又听到一声长长的呼喊，最终看到从森林的边缘冒出一个骑手。一眼看去我们便知道了那是年轻的伯爵，大家都不约而同地高呼雀跃起来，并飞奔过去迎接他。这对双方来说都是一次愉快的会面，因为我们一直因他年轻又没有经验而焦虑不安；而对他来说，满足了冒险欲望的他，能再一次回到朋友当中是非常值得欣喜的。
Just then a small herd of deer, roused from a neighboring ravine, came bounding by us.Beatte sprang from his horse, levelled his rifle, and wounded one slightly, but without bringing it to the ground.The report of the rifle was almost immediately followed by a long halloo from a distance.We looked around, but could see nothing.Another long halloo was heard, and at length a horseman was descried, emerging out of a skirt of forest.A single glance showed him to be the young Count; there was a universal shout and scamper, every one setting off full gallop to greet him.It was a joyful meeting to both parties; for, much anxiety had been felt by us all on account of his youth and inexperience, and for his part, with all his love of adventure, he seemed right glad to be once more among his friends.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 就像我们所猜测的那样，在前一天晚上，他完全搞错了方向，而且一直游荡到天黑才想到了露宿。晚上很冷，但他却不敢生火，以防那些潜伏中的印第安人部落因此而发现他。他用小毛巾把马腿缚住，留它在草原的空阔处吃草。而他自己则爬到一棵树上，把马鞍固定在一个树杈上，让自己安全地背靠树干坐下，准备度过一个偶尔被狼的嚎叫声所打断的沉闷且不安的夜晚。他非常高兴自己失望了。白天的劳累让他很快便熟睡过去；他高兴地梦到了他那在瑞士的家，直到天光大亮时，他才醒来。
As we supposed, he had completely mistaken his course on the preceding evening, and had wandered about until dark, when he thought of bivouacking.The night was cold, yet he feared to make a fire, lest it might betray him to some lurking party of Indians.Hobbling his horse with his pocket handkerchief, and leaving him to graze on the margin of the prairie, he clambered into a tree, fixed his saddle in the fork of the branches, and placing himself securely with his back against the trunk, prepared to pass a dreary and anxious night, regaled occasionally with the howlings of the wolves.He was agreeably disappointed.The fatigue of the day soon brought on a sound sleep; he had delightful dreams about his home in Switzerland, nor did he wake until it was broad daylight.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 然后，他从歇息的树上爬了下来，骑上马，来到了一个山丘光秃秃的顶部。从那里，他看到自己周围是一片杳无人迹的荒原，但不远处逶迤的加拿大人大河穿越在林地边界之间。见到这条河给了他安慰，他想，如果自己找不到回营地的路，或者自己的同伴找不到他，那他可以沿着这条河走，这河一定可以把他带到某个边防站或是印第安人村落的。所以我们这次偶然的捕猎野牛事件就这样结束了。
He then descended from his roosting-place, mounted his horse, and rode to the naked summit of a hill, whence he beheld a trackless wilderness around him, but, at no great distance, the Grand Canadian winding its way between borders of forest land.The sight of this river consoled him with the idea that, should he fail in finding his way back to the camp, or in being found by some party of his comrades, he might follow the course of the stream, which could not fail to conduct him to some frontier post, or Indian hamlet.So closed the events of our hap-hazard buffalo hunt.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第三十二章 草原犬鼠的王国
CHAPTER XXXII. REPUBLIC OF PRAIRIE DOGS.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 当我们从寻找年轻伯爵的征途归来时，我得知猎手们在距离营地大约一英里的山丘的平顶上发现了一洞或是被称为一村的草原犬鼠。之前我听说过一些关于这些小动物的习性和特征，于是我决定去看看这个团体。实际上，草原犬鼠是远西区地区的珍奇动物之一。旅行者们喜欢讲述关于它们的精彩故事，并不时赋予它们一种理性生物所拥有的精明特征及社交习性，还说它们拥有自己的民主政府和内部系统，几乎类似于人们通常给予海狸的评价那样。
On returning from our expedition in quest of the young Count, I learned that a burrow, or village, as it is termed, of prairie dogs had been discovered on the level summit of a hill, about a mile from the camp.Having heard much of the habits and peculiarities of these little animals, I determined to pay a visit to the community.The prairie dog is, in fact, one of the curiosities of the Far West, about which travellers delight to tell marvellous tales, endowing him at times with something of the politic and social habits of a rational being, and giving him systems of civil government and domestic economy, almost equal to what they used to bestow upon the beaver.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 草原犬鼠是一种鼠兔类动物，体积和兔子差不多大。它们生性活泼好动，反应机智，行动迅速，敏感且有点儿任性。草原犬鼠是群居动物，非常喜欢与别的犬鼠一起住在一个大的群体中，有时会绵延好几英亩的地方。在那儿，无数的小土堆标识着这些居民地下洞穴的入口。那些被踩踏出来的、像街道和小巷一样的小径，则显示出它们的好动和不安分。根据别人对它们的描述，它们总是在不停地运动、做事，以及处理公共事务。它们东奔西跑，似乎是在相互串门互道家长里短，或是在凉爽的夜晚聚集在一起开会，又或是一场阵雨之后，在旷野中互相打闹嬉戏。有时，尤其是在月光明亮的时候，它们会狂欢到半夜，像小狗那样用一种短促微弱的声调叫喊着。然而，就算是它们正处在嬉闹狂欢的高潮，只要有一点儿的警报，它们也会立马消失在自己的洞穴中，整个村落变得空荡荡的，一片死寂。如果被追捕者死死按住，没有任何逃脱的希望，它们便会显示出一副好斗的姿态，露出想要愤怒反抗而又无能为力的古怪神情。
The prairie dog is an animal of the coney kind, and about the size of a rabbit.He is of a sprightly mercurial nature; quick, sensitive, and somewhat petulant.He is very gregarious, living in large communities, sometimes of several acres in extent, where innumerable little heaps of earth show the entrances to the subterranean cells of the inhabitants, and the well beaten tracks, like lanes and streets, show their mobility and restlessness.According to the accounts given of them, they would seem to be continually full of sport, business, and public affairs; whisking about hither and thither, as if on gossiping visits to each other’s houses, or congregating in the cool of the evening, or after a shower, and gambolling together in the open air.Sometimes, especially when the moon shines, they pass half the night in revelry, barking or yelping with short, quick, yet weak tones, like those of very young puppies.While in the height of their playfulness and clamor, however, should there be the least alarm, they all vanish into their cells in an instant, and the village remains blank and silent.In case they are hard pressed by their pursuers, without any hope of escape, they will assume a pugnacious air, and a most whimsical look of impotent wrath and defiance.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 草原犬鼠无法在自己的家中过一种独立而又不被打扰的生活。听说猫头鹰和响尾蛇会和它们同住，不过它们是作为受邀的贵客还是不受欢迎的侵入者，则是一个有争议的问题。这些猫头鹰是一个奇特的种类，似乎具有鹰的特征。但它们要比普通的猫头鹰个头更高，站得更直，看上去更加警觉，也飞得更高。它们不仅会在夜间远足，在大白天也会出发远行。
The prairie dogs are not permitted to remain sole and undisturbed inhabitants of their own homes.Owls and rattlesnakes are said to take up their abodes with them; but whether as invited guests or unwelcome intruders, is a matter of controversy.The owls are of a peculiar kind, and would seem to partake of the character of the hawk; for they are taller and more erect on their legs, more alert in their looks and rapid in their flight than ordinary owls, and do not confine their excursions to the night, but sally forth in broad day.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 有些人说猫头鹰只住在草原犬鼠因某个亲属死去而丢弃的、将要毁坏的洞穴中，因为他们认为这种小动物非常敏感，它们不愿继续住在亲眼看到一个亲友死去的地方。其他一些有想象力的推测者则认为猫头鹰有些像是草原犬鼠的管家；还有一种类似的说法是，在某种程度上，它们是指导老师，教小犬鼠们如何叫喊。
Some say that they only inhabit cells which the prairie dogs have deserted, and suffered to go to ruin, in consequence of the death in them of some relative; for they would make out this little animal to be endowed with keen sensibilities, that will not permit it to remain in the dwelling where it has witnessed the death of a friend.Other fanciful speculators represent the owl as a kind of housekeeper to the prairie dog; and, from having a note very similar, insinuate that it acts, in a manner, as family preceptor, and teaches the young litter to bark.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 至于响尾蛇，尽管人们认为它比马屁精或骗子好不了多少，并以此取巧获得了这些诚实、轻信的小犬鼠的关心，让它们怀着万分沉重的心情接待了它，但在这个非常有趣的家庭里它到底扮演什么角色，到目前为止还没有得到任何令人满意的结论。确定的是，如果它扮演的是马屁精的角色，那它有时会用超出正常应得报酬的东西来安慰自己，因为在它的胃里，不时会发现这个家庭的年幼成员。
As to the rattlesnake, nothing satisfactory has been ascertained of the part he plays in this most interesting household; though he is considered as little better than a sycophant and sharper, that winds himself into the concerns of the honest, credulous little dog, and takes him in most sadly.Certain it is, if he acts as toad-eater, he occasionally solaces himself with more than the usual perquisites of his order; as he is now and then detected with one of the younger members of the family in his maw.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这些就是我所能够搜集到的关于这种大草原上的小居民的一些内部系统特征。它们和它们的小人国似乎在远西区地区的猎手们中间引起了一些离奇古怪的猜测和滑稽可笑的评论。
Such are a few of the particulars that I could gather about the domestic economy of this little inhabitant of the prairies, who, with his pigmy republic, appears to be a subject of much whimsical speculation and burlesque remarks among the hunters of the Far West.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 接近傍晚时，我和一个伙伴才出发去拜访这个新奇的穴群。不幸的是，在白天的行程中有些巡逻骑兵已经侵袭了这个穴群。他们射杀了两三个居民，使整个敏感的集体陷入一片混乱。当我们靠近时，可以看到许许多多的居民坐在各自的洞口处，而哨兵则似乎是站在外面保持警戒。一看到我们，哨兵们马上跑进洞里去发警报；于是，所有居民都发出一声短促的叫喊，并潜入洞中，脚后跟在空中轻快地舞动着，好像是在翻筋斗。
It was toward evening that I set out with a companion, to visit the village in question.Unluckily, it had been invaded in the course of the day by some of the rangers, who had shot two or three of its inhabitants, and thrown the whole sensitive community in confusion.As we approached, we could perceive numbers of the inhabitants seated at the entrances of their cells, while sentinels seemed to have been posted on the outskirts, to keep a look-out.At sight of us, the picket guards scampered in and gave the alarm; whereupon every inhabitant gave a short yelp, or bark, and dived into his hole, his heels twinkling in the air as if he had thrown a somersault.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们穿过了这覆盖了大约三十英亩土地的整个穴群或王国，但却连一个居民的痕迹也看不到。我们尽力把步枪的通条伸进洞穴来探测它们，但却触不到任何犬鼠、猫头鹰或是响尾蛇。悄悄地移动了一小段距离之后，我们一动不动地趴在地上，静静地观察了好久。不久之后，一个小心谨慎的老年犬鼠慢慢地探出了鼻子，但立刻又缩回去了。更远处，另一只犬鼠完全探出了身子。但一瞥到我们，它便翻了个筋斗，重新跳进洞中。最终，一些住在穴群另一端的犬鼠见到一直没有什么动静，便鼓起勇气偷偷溜了出来，匆忙跑到远处的一个洞穴里，那里可能是与它家亲戚或是平日闲聊的朋友的住处。它们为亲戚朋友的安全担心，也希望可以与之就刚刚发生的事件交换意见。
We traversed the whole village, or republic, which covered an area of about thirty acres; but not a whisker of an inhabitant was to be seen.We probed their cells as far as the ram-rods of our rifles would reach, but could unearth neither dog, nor owl, nor rattlesnake.Moving quietly to a little distance, we lay down upon the ground, and watched for a long time, silent and motionless.By and by, a cautious old burgher would slowly put forth the end of his nose, but instantly draw it in again.Another, at a greater distance, would emerge entirely; but, catching a glance of us, would throw a somersault, and plunge back again into his hole.At length, some who resided on the opposite side of the village, taking courage from the continued stillness, would steal forth, and hurry off to a distant hole, the residence possibly of some family connection, or gossiping friend, about whose safety they were solicitous, or with whom they wished to compare notes about the late occurrences.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 还有一些更加大胆的犬鼠三五成群地聚集在街道和公共场所，似乎是要讨论刚刚发生在全体国民身上的暴行，以及对它们同伴的残忍谋杀。
Others, still more bold, assembled in little knots, in the streets and public places, as if to discuss the recent outrages offered to the commonwealth, and the atrocious murders of their fellow-burghers.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们从地上站起来向前走去，想要更清楚地观察它们的公共活动。这时，犬鼠群中响起一声接一声的尖叫，会议立刻解散，犬鼠的脚在空中朝各个方向飞快地舞动，刹那间它们全部消失在地下了。
We rose from the ground and moved forward, to take a nearer view of these public proceedings, when yelp! yelp! yelp!—there was a shrill alarm passed from mouth to mouth; the meetings suddenly dispersed; feet twinkled in the air in every direction; and in an instant all had vanished into the earth.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 黄昏迫使我们结束了观察，但我所听到的关于这些精明小动物的道德品质，却在我的脑海中产生了一连串的奇特比较。回到营地后，这种比较还在进行。深夜，当所有人都入睡后，我依旧醒着，躺在那儿好静静听着外面的声响，依稀可以听到远处穴群传来的喧闹尖锐的叫声。我情不自禁地想象着这些居民闹哄哄地聚在一起，夸夸其谈地争辩着，制定着公共安全计划，并为王国的权利和尊严遭到侵犯和损坏而进行辩护。
The dusk of the evening put an end to our observations, but the train of whimsical comparisons produced in my brain by the moral attributes which I had heard given to these little politic animals, still continued after my return to camp; and late in the night, as I lay awake after all the camp was asleep, and heard in the stillness of the hour, a faint clamor of shrill voices from the distant village, I could not help picturing to myself the inhabitants gathered together in noisy assemblage and windy debate, to devise plans for the public safety, and to vindicate the invaded rights and insulted dignity of the republic.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第三十三章 营地里的会议
CHAPTER XXXIII. A COUNCIL IN THE CAMP.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——归家的理由——丢失马——分队离开回家——沼泽——野马——营地的夜景——猫头鹰，黎明的先兆
—REASONS FOR FACING HOMEWARD.—HORSES LOST.—DEPARTURE WITH A DETACHMENT ON THE HOMEWARD ROUTE.—SWAMP.—WILD HORSE.—CAMP SCENES BY NIGHT.—THE OWL, HARBINGER OF DAWN.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 准备早饭期间，我们举行了一场关于接下来的动向的会议。在过去的一两天里，巡逻骑兵中已经流露出了不满的征兆。他们大多不习惯大草原上的生活，对它的贫瘠及军营的种种限制感到不安。面包严重短缺，并且他们对不断的旅行也感到疲倦了。实际上，远足的新鲜感和兴奋劲儿已经荡然无存了。他们已经捕猎过鹿、熊、麋鹿、野牛和野马，也再已没有能引起他们兴趣的猎物了。因此，人们普遍开始想调头回家。
While breakfast was preparing, a council was held as to our future movements.Symptoms of discontent had appeared for a day or two past among the rangers, most of whom, unaccustomed to the life of the prairies, had become impatient of its privations, as well as the restraints of the camp.The want of bread had been felt severely, and they were wearied with constant travel.In fact, the novelty and excitement of the expedition were at an end.They had hunted the deer, the bear, the elk, the buffalo, and the wild horse, and had no further object of leading interest to look forward to.A general inclination prevailed, therefore, to turn homeward.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 还有一些重要的原因使得队长和指挥官们采纳了这个建议。我们的马匹大多都因长时间旅行和狩猎而累坏了。由于缺乏优质牧草，并且晚上为防止它们被印第安人劫掠，我们还总是把它们拴起来，所以它们也日渐消瘦了。上一场雨也似乎把稀疏的草皮上所残留的那一点点儿营养给冲刷掉了。自从在暴风雨中扎营后，我们的马匹就很快没有精神头儿，没有力气了。受到精心照料的马匹，早已经习惯了饲料，以及马厩和农场里有规律且充足的营养供给。所以它们已丧失在大草原上旅行的勇气和精神了。在我们所进行的所有这种远足中，我们最偏爱的是强壮耐劳的印第安马。它们一般是一种北美野马或其的杂交品种。它们可以承受所有艰辛劳顿，也不怕牧草匮乏，依靠大草原上的野草即可茁壮成长。
Grave reasons disposed the Captain and his officers to adopt this resolution.Our horses were generally much jaded by the fatigues of travelling and hunting, and had fallen away sadly for want of good pasturage, and from being tethered at night, to protect them from Indian depredations.The late rains, too, seemed to have washed away the nourishment from the scanty herbage that remained; and since our encampment during the storm, our horses had lost flesh and strength rapidly.With every possible care, horses, accustomed to grain, and to the regular and plentiful nourishment of the stable and the farm, lose heart and condition in travelling on the prairies.In all expeditions of the kind we were engaged in, the hardy Indian horses, which are generally mustangs, or a cross of the wild breed, are to be preferred.They can stand all fatigues, hardships, and privations, and thrive on the grasses and the wild herbage of the plains.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 而我们人呢，在行动中表现也得缺乏深谋远虑。在旅途中，无论我们何时碰到猎物，都会抓住一切机会飞奔着去追赶猎物。他们没有注意保持马的体力和精力，马匹都耗尽了力气，疲惫不堪。在这样的旅程中，要尽最大可能地让马可以安静地行走，每天平均的行程不应超过十英里。
Our men, too, had acted with little forethought; galloping off whenever they had a chance, after the game that we encountered while on the march.In this way they had strained and wearied their horses, instead of husbanding their strength and spirits.On a tour of the kind, horses should as seldom as possible be put off of a quiet walk; and the average day’s journey should not exceed ten miles.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们希望可以尽快前进到达雷德河边上的低洼地，那儿有大量的幼藤——每年的这个季节对牲畜最有营养的草料。现在，我们还需要几天时间才能回去，但在这期间，许多马匹可能会精疲力竭。这也正是印第安人狩猎部族放火烧大草原的时候。这片土地上所有的牧草都已经干枯了，很容易点燃。我们和要塞之间的大草原很可能被某个返程的奥塞奇部族点燃，这种危险与日俱增，我们可能就只能在一片焦土上穿行了。总之，我们在这个季节出发得太晚，或是在旅程的开始阶段闲荡得太多了，所以就没法按照原定的计划结束旅程了。况且，如果我们继续前进，就会面临另一个危险：我们将损失大部分的马匹，除了要遭受其他各种不便外，还不得不步行回去。于是，我们决定放弃继续前行，转而向东南方向前进，以便尽快回到吉布森要塞。
We had hoped, by pushing forward, to reach the bottoms of the Red River, which abound with young cane, a most nourishing forage for cattle at this season of the year.It would now take us several days to arrive there, and in the meantime many of our horses would probably give out.It was the time, too, when the hunting parties of Indians set fire to the prairies; the herbage, throughout this part of the country, was in that parched state, favorable to combustion, and there was daily more and more risk that the prairies between us and the fort would be set on fire by some of the return parties of Osages, and a scorched desert left for us to traverse.In a word, we had started too late in the season, or loitered too much in the early part of our march, to accomplish our originally intended tour; and there was imminent hazard, if we continued on, that we should lose the greater part of our horses; and, besides suffering various other inconveniences, be obliged to return on foot.It was determined, therefore, to give up all further progress, and, turning our faces to the southeast, to make the best of our way back to Fort Gibson.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 决议一经采纳，大家立刻就迫不及待地行动起来。但是，有几匹马失踪了，其中包括队长和外科医生的马。有人去寻找它们了，可直到早上还是没有任何消息。同时，我们的队伍已经整装待发了。专员决定带着他原先那由一个中尉和十四个巡逻骑兵组成的护卫队先走，留下队长和大部队在方便的时候出发。于是，十点钟时，我们在贝蒂的指引下启程了。他曾在这片土地上打过猎，知道返回要塞的直行路线。
This resolution being taken, there was an immediate eagerness to put it into operation.Several horses, however, were missing, and among others those of the Captain and the Surgeon.Persons had gone in search of them, but the morning advanced without any tidings of them.Our party, in the meantime, being all ready for a march, the Commissioner determined to set off in the advance, with his original escort of a lieutenant and fourteen rangers, leaving the Captain to come on at his convenience, with the main body.At ten o’clock we accordingly started, under the guidance of Beatte, who had hunted over this part of the country, and knew the direct route to the garrison.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们沿着大草原的边缘，朝东南方向前进了一段距离。一路上，我们看到了各种各样的野生动物：鹿、白狼、黑狼，还有野牛和野马。对于野马，我们的混血儿们和托尼什都徒劳地追赶过，但也只能让他们本来就劳累不堪的坐骑更加疲惫罢了。实际上，在这种艰难的追逐中，被捕获的野马也仅仅是马群中体质较弱、最没有脚力的马匹。而猎人的马则常常会因此跑得精疲力尽。实际上，猎人是在冒着牺牲一匹好马的危险去捕捉一匹劣马。在这种情况下，马背上的托尼什是一个十足的小魔鬼。他以累垮自己骑过的所有坐骑而出名。他成功地将我在旅程之初让他骑的那匹强壮的灰色马累得跛了脚，几乎残废。
For some distance we skirted the prairie, keeping a southeast direction; and in the course of our ride we saw a variety of wild animals, deer, white and black wolves, buffaloes, and wild horses.To the latter, our half-breeds and Tonish gave ineffectual chase, only serving to add to the weariness of their already jaded steeds.Indeed it is rarely that any but the weaker and least fleet of the wild horses are taken in these hard racings; while the horse of the huntsman is prone to be knocked up.The latter, in fact, risks a good horse to catch a bad one.On this occasion, Tonish, who was a perfect imp on horseback, and noted for ruining every animal he bestrode, succeeded in laming and almost disabling the powerful gray on which we had mounted him at the outset of our tour.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 前进了几英里之后，我们离开了大草原，并折向东行，走上了贝蒂所说的一条奥塞奇人之前的战道。这条路引导我们穿过了一条崎岖的乡间小道，这儿满是低矮的树林和藤蔓缠绞的灌木丛，有的地方还被各种很深的沟壑、溪流所隔断。溪流中欢快地奔流着利特尔河源头的水。走了大约十四英里之后，三点钟左右时，我们在一个小山谷的几片水塘边扎了营。我们从上一个营地带来了一些食物，于是便津津有味地吃起了炖牛肉、烤鹿肉、带馅煎饼、熊油炸的带馅面团，以及一种黄花泡成的茶——我们发现整个旅程中它成了像咖啡一样受欢迎的饮料。实际上，根据西方人的习俗，自从咖啡出现以来，它就成了每餐必备、没必要夸耀的饮品了。先将咖啡豆放在一个煎锅里随便烘烤一下，然后倒入一个皮袋，用一块圆石碾碎，之后放在我们主要的、也几乎是唯一的厨具野营水壶里，加上河水或溪水煮。在大草原上这些水因为泥土的关系颜色比较深，因此使水里有很多颗粒物悬浮在其中。实际上，在旅行过程中，我们尝过了每一种土壤的味道。我们汲取的水的味道不同，颜色也是五花八门，可以和药剂师店铺里的各种药水的颜色相媲美。至少在每年的这个季节，纯净清澈的水在大草原上是罕见的奢侈品。晚饭结束后，我们派出哨兵在我们简陋狭小的营地周围巡逻，并把兽皮和毯子铺在现在几乎没有任何树叶的树底下，然后酣然入睡，直到天亮。
After proceeding a few miles, we left the prairie, and struck to the east, taking what Beatte pronounced an old Osage war track.This led us through a rugged tract of country, overgrown with scrubbed forests and entangled thickets, and intersected by deep ravines, and brisk-running streams, the sources of Little River.About three o’clock, we encamped by some pools of water in a small valley, having come about fourteen miles.We had brought on a supply of provisions from our last camp, and supped heartily upon stewed buffalo meat, roasted venison, beignets, or fritters of flour fried in bear’s lard, and tea, made of a species of the golden-rod, which we had found, throughout our whole route, almost as grateful a beverage as coffee.Indeed our coffee, which, as long as it held out, had been served up with every meal, according to the custom of the West, was by no means a beverage to boast of.It was roasted in a frying-pan. without much care, pounded in a leathern bag, with a round stone, and boiled in our prime and almost only kitchen utensil, the camp kettle, in “branch” or brook water; which, on the prairies, is deeply colored by the soil, of which it always holds abundant particles in a state of solution and suspension.In fact, in the course of our tour, we had tasted the quality of every variety of soil, and the draughts of water we had taken might vie in diversity of color, if not of flavor, with the tinctures of an apothecary’s shop.Pure, limpid water is a rare luxury on the prairies, at least at this season of the year.Supper over, we placed sentinels about our scanty and diminished camp, spread our skins and blankets under the trees, now nearly destitute of foliage, and slept soundly until morning.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 黎明时天气非常好。营地里再次充满欢声笑语，一想到很快便可以抵达要塞，开怀大嚼面包和蔬菜，每个人都高兴不已。甚至是我们那位沉默稳重的贝蒂，也受到了这种场景的鼓舞。当他策马上路时，我听到他用鼻子哼唱着一首几乎已经失传的印第安人小调。然而，所有这些短暂的快乐很快便随着旅程的劳累而渐渐消失了，因为我们又开始穿越和昨天一样崎岖、多山且布满灌木的乡间了。在上午的行程中，我们到达了利特尔河河谷，这是一片宽阔的冲击河谷。当下，河水已经溢出了河岸，并淹没了河谷的一大片区域。棘手的问题是，我们要把河流本身和它所淹没的宽阔水域区分开来，并找到可以涉水而过的地方；但河水到处都很深，十分泥泞，被侵蚀的河岸也很陡峭。因此，我们在贝蒂的带领下，在这条弯曲的小河流的几个转弯处徘徊了好久，感觉自己陷入了一个由沼泽、灌木丛和死水塘组成的、没路可走的迷宫。有时候，我们疲倦的马匹得费九牛二虎之力拖着四肢往前走很长一段距离，水花不时溅到马镫上，马蹄则不时磕磕绊绊地陷入草根和倒伏的植物中。有时候，我们不得不艰难地穿越长着刺藤和葡萄藤的密集灌木丛。这些藤蔓植物几乎快把我们从马鞍上拽下去。在一个地方，一匹驮马陷入了泥潭，倒向了一边，我们只得费力地解救它。无论走到哪儿，只要是泥土裸露在外或是有沙洲的地方，我们便会看到无数的熊、狼、野马、火鸡和水禽的足迹。这说明这个河谷可以给猎人提供丰富的猎物。然而，由于大家都已经厌倦了打猎，又加上过于疲劳，所以大家不再对这些足迹感到兴奋了。但在旅行刚开始时，这可是会引发他们狂热的期盼的。现在，他们唯一的愿望便是坚持走到要塞。
We had a beautiful daybreak.The camp again resounded with cheerful voices; every one was animated with the thoughts of soon being at the fort, and revelling on bread and vegetables.Even our saturnine man, Beatte, seemed inspired on this occasion; and as he drove up the horses for the march, I heard him singing, in nasal tones, a most forlorn Indian ditty.All this transient gayety, however, soon died away amidst the fatigues of our march, which lay through the same kind of rough, hilly, thicketed country as that of yesterday.In the course of the morning we arrived at the valley of the Little River, where it wound through a broad bottom of alluvial soil.At present it had overflowed its banks, and inundated a great part of the valley.The difficulty was to distinguish the stream from the broad sheets of water it had formed, and to find a place where it might be forded; for it was in general deep and miry, with abrupt crumbling banks.Under the pilotage of Beatte, therefore, we wandered for some time among the links made by this winding stream, in what appeared to us a trackless labyrinth of swamps, thickets, and standing pools.Sometimes our jaded horses dragged their limbs forward with the utmost difficulty, having to toil for a great distance, with the water up to the stirrups, and beset at the bottom with roots and creeping plants.Sometimes we had to force our way through dense thickets of brambles and grapevines, which almost pulled us out of our saddles.In one place, one of the pack-horses sunk in the mire and fell on his side, so as to be extricated with great difficulty.Wherever the soil was bare, or there was a sand-bank, we beheld innumerable tracks of bears, wolves, wild horses, turkeys, and water-fowl; showing the abundant sport this valley might afford to the huntsman.Our men, however, were sated with hunting, and too weary to be excited by these signs, which in the outset of our tour would have put them in a fever of anticipation.Their only desire, at present, was to push on doggedly for the fortress.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 最终，我们成功找到了一个可以涉水过河的地方，从那儿渡过了利特尔河，渡河时水和泥都漫到了马肚带上。然后我们停留了一个半小时，以检查一下湿漉漉的包裹，也让马匹休息一下。
At length we succeeded in finding a fording place, where we all crossed Little River, with the water and mire to the saddle-girths, and then halted for an hour and a half, to overhaul the wet baggage, and give the horses time to rest.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们重新踏上征程，来到了一块宜人的小草地，周围环绕着一片榆树和三叶杨树组成的小树林，而在草地中央，一匹漂亮的黑马正在吃草。走在前面的贝蒂示意我们停下，而骑着一匹母马的他一步步地慢慢靠上前去，同时逼真地模仿着马嘶鸣的声音。这匹大草原上高贵的骏马凝视了一会儿，鼻子深吸着空气，一边竖起耳朵嘶叫着，一边殷勤地围着母马轻盈地跳跃。但距离贝蒂还是太远了，让他无法向它扔出套索。这是一个庄严高贵的生灵，浑身透着与生俱来的骄傲和荣耀。令人羡慕的是，它的头高傲而又漫不经心地昂着，一举一动都透着自由，马蹄踏草地时也充满了弹力。贝蒂发现无法让马进入可以使用套索的距离内，而且它已开始后退，警觉性也有所提高之后，便从马鞍上溜了下来，举起步枪，视线越过他那匹母马的背部瞄准目标，显然是想要擦伤这匹马。我心头一紧，不禁为这一高贵生灵的安全而担忧，于是大叫了一声，想让贝蒂住手。但已经来不及了；就在我脱口而出的瞬间，他扣动了扳机。幸运的是，他射得没有像往常那么准，我心满意足地看到那匹黝黑的骏马安然无恙地冲入了树林。
On resuming our march, we came to a pleasant little meadow, surrounded by groves of elms and cottonwood trees, in the midst of which was a fine black horse grazing.Beatte, who was in the advance, beckoned us to halt, and, being mounted on a mare, approached the horse gently, step by step, imitating the whinny of the animal with admirable exactness.The noble courser of the prairie gazed for a time, snuffed the air, neighed, pricked up his ears, and pranced round and round the mare in gallant style; but kept at too great a distance for Beatte to throw the lariat.He was a magnificent object, in all the pride and glory of his nature.It was admirable to see the lofty and airy carriage of his head; the freedom of every movement; the elasticity with which he trod the meadow.Finding it impossible to get within noosing distance, and seeing that the horse was receding and growing alarmed, Beatte slid down from his saddle, levelled his rifle, across the back of his mare, and took aim, with the evident intention of creasing him.I felt a, throb of anxiety for the safety of the noble animal, and called out to Beatte to desist.It was too late; he pulled the trigger as I spoke; luckily he did not shoot with his usual accuracy, and I had the satisfaction to see the coal-black steed dash off unharmed into the forest.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 离开这个山谷的时候，我们沿着起伏的山丘和崎岖的树林上行，这给马匹及骑手都带来了不少麻烦。峡谷里也是红色的土壤，通常还非常陡峭，在下行时，马儿们要四蹄并拢，简直就是滑下去的，然后又要像猫一样蹿上对面。在山谷的灌木丛中，黑刺李和柿子到处可见。我们一行人都急不可待地离开队伍，跑去采摘这些蹩脚的野果——这么长时间以来，大家一直只能吃到动物肉，他们是多么渴望能吃到某些蔬菜类的东西啊！
On leaving this valley, we ascended among broken hills and rugged, ragged forests, equally harassing to horse and rider.The ravines, too, were of red clay, and often so steep that, in descending, the horses would put their feet together and fairly slide down, and then scramble up the opposite side like cats.Here and there, among the thickets in the valleys, we met with sloes and persimmon, and the eagerness with which our men broke from the line of march, and ran to gather these poor fruits, showed how much they craved some vegetable condiment, after living so long exclusively on animal food.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 大约三点半时，我们在草地上的一条小溪边安营扎寨，在那儿我们那些饿得半死的马匹可以吃点儿稀稀拉拉的牧草。由于贝蒂在行程途中猎杀了一头肥硕的母鹿，我们的一个同伴还猎杀了一只硕大的火鸡，因此我们并不缺食物。
About half past three we encamped near a brook in a meadow, where there was some scanty herbage for our half-famished horses.As Beatte had killed a fat doe in the course of the day, and one of our company a fine turkey, we did not lack for provisions.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 那是一个极美的秋夜。太阳落山之后，地平线上抹着一层纯净的苹果绿，这绿色到了一片柔美的湖水那里却渐变渐深，最终转成了青紫色。一抹四周镶着琥珀色和金色的狭长的红褐色云彩飘浮在西方。云彩下面是如钻石般闪烁着纯净光芒的星星。与这番景象相呼应的是各种昆虫的夜曲。所有的叫声混杂在一起，和谐地组成了一段阴沉而又忧伤的乐章。我发现这种音调总是能对我的大脑起到一种舒缓镇静的作用，让它进入安静的冥想状态。
It was a splendid autumnal evening.The horizon, after sunset, was of a clear apple green, rising into a delicate lake which gradually lost itself in a deep purple blue.One narrow streak of cloud, of a mahogany color, edged with amber and gold, floated in the west, and just beneath it was the evening star, shining with the pure brilliancy of a diamond.In unison with this scene, there was an evening concert of insects of various kinds, all blended and harmonized into one sober and somewhat melancholy note, which I have always found to have a soothing effect upon the mind, disposing it to quiet musings.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 接下来的夜晚静谧而美丽。一弯秋季的新月发出暗淡的光芒，月落之后，天边又划过一颗漂亮的流星。那些疲惫的巡逻骑兵围着篝火低声交谈了一阵之后，便早早地躺下休息了，于是整个夜景似乎只属于我一个人。就这样在大草原上露宿，躺着凝视繁星是一件十分惬意的事情；就像是在海上，站在航船的甲板上仰望繁星一样，感觉就像是自己拥有了整个苍穹。在这种孤独的景象中，一个人便会明白，东方的牧羊者是怎样在夜晚看守他们的羊群时和这些美丽的星星相伴，进而成为天文学家的了。无数个夜晚，当凝视它们温柔的光芒时，我脑海中不禁会浮现出约伯优雅的语句：“你能系住昴星的结，或是解开参星的带吗？”不知是什么缘故，我感觉今晚特别能感受到天空的庄严肃穆。当这样躺在空旷的苍穹之下时，我似乎是在吸入纯净无污染的空气，精神倍感愉快，甚至有些陶醉。我时睡时醒，当我睡着时，梦中也会带着醒着时那种想入非非的喜悦。天快亮时，一个哨兵过来坐在我身旁，他是队伍中年龄最大的一个。他又累又困，迫不及待地想要换岗。我发现他之前也凝视过天空，但感受却不一样。
The night that succeeded was calm and beautiful.There was a faint light from the moon, now in its second quarter, and after it had set, a fine starlight, with shooting meteors.The wearied rangers, after a little murmuring conversation round their fires, sank to rest at an early hour, and I seemed to have the whole scene to myself.It is delightful, in thus bivouacking on the prairies, to lie awake and gaze at the stars; it is like watching them from the deck of a ship at sea when at one view we have the whole cope of heaven.One realizes, in such lonely scenes, that companionship with these beautiful luminaries which made astronomers of the eastern shepherds, as they watched their flocks by night.How often, while contemplating their mild and benignant radiance, I have called to mind the exquisite text of Job: “Canst thou bind the secret influences of the Pleiades, or loose the bands of Orion?”I do not know why it was, but I felt this night unusually affected by the solemn magnificence of the firmament; and seemed, as I lay thus under the open vault of heaven, to inhale with the pure untainted air, an exhilarating buoyancy of spirit, and, as it were, an ecstasy of mind.I slept and waked alternately; and when I slept, my dreams partook of the happy tone of my waking reveries.Toward morning, one of the sentinels, the oldest man in the troop, came and took a seat near me; he was weary and sleepy, and impatient to be relieved.I found he had been gazing at the heavens also, but with different feelings.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “如果星星没有欺骗我的话，”他说，“那天快亮了。”
“If the stars don’t deceive me,” said he, “it is near day-break.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “这毫无疑问，”躺在旁边的贝蒂说，“我刚刚听到一只猫头鹰叫了。”
“There can be no doubt of that,” said Beatte, who lay close by.“I heard an owl just now.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “那么，猫头鹰是在黎明时叫吗？”我问道。
“Does the owl, then, hoot toward daybreak?” asked I.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “是的，先生，就像公鸡打鸣一样。”
“Aye, sir, just as the cock crows.”

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 这是我之前没有意识到的关于鸟类习惯的有用知识。星星和猫头鹰都没有欺骗相信它们的追随者。不久之后，东方就出现了一道微弱的亮光。
This was a useful habitude of the bird of wisdom, of which I was not aware.Neither the stars nor owl deceived their votaries.In a short time there was a faint streak of light in the east.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第三十四章 废弃的克里克人营地
CHAPTER XXXIV. OLD CREEK ENCAMPMENT.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——食物短缺——坏天气——疲惫的行军——一座猎手的桥
—SCARCITY OF PROVISIONS.—BAD WEATHER.—WEARY MARCHING.—A HUNTER’S BRIDGE.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 今天（11月2日）上午经过的区域不再那么崎岖了，景色也比我们之前走过的地方更加宜人。十一点时，我们抵达了一片广阔的大草原，看到在左侧大约六英里处有一条绿色的林带——那是阿肯色河北支流的标志。在这片大草原边缘，一个用参天大树隐藏着一条小溪的宽敞树林里，有着一处废弃的克里克人狩猎营地的痕迹。这些树的树皮上，有用木炭胡乱画的猎人和印第安女子的图像，还有各种记号和象形文字。我们的混血儿们解释说，这表示猎人们是从这个营地回家的。
The country through which we passed this morning (November 2d), was less rugged, and of more agreeable aspect than that we had lately traversed.At eleven o’clock, we came out upon an extensive prairie, and about six miles to our left beheld a long line of green forest, marking the course of the north fork of the Arkansas.On the edge of the prairie, and in a spacious grove of noble trees which overshadowed a small brook, were the traces of an old Creek hunting camp.On the bark of the trees were rude delineations of hunters and squaws, scrawled with charcoal; together with various signs and hieroglyphics, which our half-breeds interpreted as indicating that from this encampment the hunters had returned home.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 就在这片美丽的宿营地，我们午休了一下。在树下休息时，我们听到不远处传来叫喊声。很快，前两天被我们留在后面的队长和大部分骑手出现了在灌木丛中。他们跨过小溪，被我们兴高采烈地接入营地。队长和医生并没有找到他们的马匹，所以不得不在大部分时间里步行；不过他们还是以比平时更快的速度赶了上来。
In this beautiful camping ground we made our mid-day halt.While reposing under the trees, we heard a shouting at no great distance, and presently the Captain and the main body of rangers, whom we had left behind two days since, emerged from the thickets, and crossing the brook, were joyfully welcomed into the camp.The Captain and the Doctor had been unsuccessful in the search after their horses, and were obliged to march for the greater part of the time on foot; yet they had come on with more than ordinary speed.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们在大约一点时重新踏上了征程，继续向东走，逐渐斜着靠近北支流。当我们找到一个比较好的宿营地时，天色已经很晚了。这里的河床都干涸了，这个大草原上也有许多地方被印第安狩猎队放火烧过了。最终，我们在一个小冲积河谷里找到了水，那里好歹也有些牧草。
We resumed our march about one o’clock, keeping easterly, and approaching the north fork obliquely; it was late before we found a good camping place; the beds of the streams were dry, the prairies, too, had been burnt in various places, by Indian hunting parties.At length we found water in a small alluvial bottom, where there was tolerable pasturage.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二天早上，东方的天空中出现了闪电，响起了低沉沉的隆隆雷声，乌云开始在地平线周围聚集。贝蒂预言说要下雨了，风向将转北。在行进过程中，一群黑雁从北方飞来，掠过我们的头顶。“风来了！”贝蒂说。风确实几乎立刻开始从那个方向吹来，不时夹杂着阵阵雨点。大约九点半时，我们涉水过了加拿大人河的北支流，一点左右就安营扎寨了，以便猎手有时间到周围地区搜寻猎物，因为整个营地开始严重缺乏食物了。大多数的巡逻骑兵都年轻、冒失、没有经验。在食物还充足时，我们就劝他们把肉切成长条晒干，驮些在各自的马背上，以备将来不时之需，但他们却不听。每次离开一个营地时，他们便会把大量的肉扔得到处都是，相信上帝和步枪会在将来为自己提供食物。结果便是，任何暂时性的猎物匮乏或是狩猎时运气不好，几乎都会在营地里引发一场饥荒。例如这次，他们把许多野牛肉留在大草原上的营地里，又由于一直急于行军，没有时间打猎，所以现在食物短缺，只能忍饥挨饿。有些人从前一天早上开始便没吃过一丁点儿东西了。在野牛营地里狂吃大嚼的时候，他们才不会相信这么快就会遭受这种饥饿之苦。
On the following morning there were flashes of lightning in the east, with low, rumbling thunder, and clouds began to gather about the horizon.Beatte prognosticated rain, and that the wind would veer to the north.In the course of our march, a flock of brant were seen overhead, flying from the north.“There comes the wind!” said Beatte; and, in fact, it began to blow from that quarter almost immediately, with occasional flurries of rain.About half past nine o’clock, we forded the north fork of the Canadian, and encamped about one, that our hunters might have time to beat up the neighborhood for game; for a serious scarcity began to prevail in the camp.Most of the rangers were young, heedless, and inexperienced, and could not be prevailed upon, while provisions abounded, to provide for the future, by jerking meat, or carry away any on their horses.On leaving an encampment, they would leave quantities of meat lying about, trusting to Providence and their rifles for a future supply.The consequence was, that any temporary scarcity of game, or ill-luck in hunting, produced almost a famine in the camp.In the present instance, they had left loads of buffalo meat at the camp on the great prairie; and, having ever since been on a forced march, leaving no time for hunting, they were now destitute of supplies, and pinched with hunger.Some had not eaten anything since the morning of the preceding day.Nothing would have persuaded them, when revelling in the abundance of the buffalo encampment, that they would so soon be in such famishing plight.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 猎手们回来了，结果很不理想。猎物早已被比我们早到的印第安人狩猎队吓得跑出这片区域了。十几只野火鸡被带了回来，但一头鹿也没看见。巡逻骑兵们开始留意火鸡，甚至草原松鸡。一直以来，他们都认为这种猎物是不值得开枪的。
The hunters returned with indifferent success.The game had been frightened away from this part of the country by Indian hunting parties, which had preceded us.Ten or a dozen wild turkeys were brought in, but not a deer had been seen.The rangers began to think turkeys and even prairie-hens deserving of attention; game which they had hitherto considered unworthy of their rifles.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 晚上很冷，风很大，不时也会有零星的雨点落下。但是，我们生起了熊熊的篝火，所以还算舒适。晚上，一群大雁飞过营地，在空中呱呱地高声叫着，预示着冬天将要来临了。
The night was cold and windy, with occasional sprinklings of rain; but we had roaring fires to keep us comfortable.In the night, a flight of wild geese passed over the camp, making a great cackling in the air; symptoms of approaching winter.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二天早上我们很早便出发了，朝东北方向沿着一伙克里克印第安人的足迹前进，这样便可以使我们可怜的马儿们走起来轻松一点儿。我们踏进了一片漂亮的原野。在一块隆起的高地上，我们看到了一幅壮观的景象：广阔的大草原上匀称地点缀着各种树林，远方环绕着连绵的小山，所有的一切都抹着一层多姿多彩而又柔和的秋色。猎物也更多了。我们右侧的草丛中跃出一头漂亮的雄鹿，并全速飞奔而去。一个叫奇尔德斯的年轻巡逻骑兵站在地上，端起步枪朝它开了一枪，子弹打断了这头跳跃的鹿的脖子，使它脑袋前倾扑倒在地上。在停下来休息之前，人们又猎杀了一头雄鹿和一头母鹿，还有几只火鸡。于是，饥饿的队伍又获得食物了。
We set forward at an early hour the next morning, in a northeast course, and came upon the trace of a party of Creek Indians, which enabled our poor horses to travel with more ease.We entered upon a fine champaign country.From a rising ground we had a noble prospect, over extensive prairies, finely diversified by groves and tracts of woodland, and bounded by long lines of distant hills, all clothed with the rich mellow tints of autumn.Game, too, was more plenty.A fine buck sprang up from among the herbage on our right, and dashed off at full speed; but a young ranger by the name of Childers, who was on foot, levelled his rifle, discharged a ball that broke the neck of the bounding deer, and sent him tumbling head over heels forward.Another buck and a doe, besides several turkeys, were killed before we came to a halt, so that the hungry mouths of the troop were once more supplied.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 急行了二十五英里后，大约三点时，我们在一个小树林里扎起了营。之前的这段路对马匹来说确实是个严峻的考验。队伍的领头半部分扎营完毕后很久，后面部分的人才不时三三两两地进入营地。我们的一匹驮马大约在九英里前就精疲力竭了，不久之后，贝蒂的一匹矮种马也累得不行了。许多其余的马看起来也很憔悴、虚弱，我们开始怀疑它们能否撑到要塞。晚上下起了大雨，黎明时天气也是乌云密布。但是，营地里还是又洋溢起了以前的那种快乐。巡逻骑兵们昨晚吃得很好，精神也恢复了，都期待着尽快抵达要塞。我们启程前，贝蒂艰难地带着他那匹矮种马回到了营地。然而，那匹驮马彻底累垮了，我们不得不将它抛弃。那匹野母马生下了小马，加上一路奔走的疲劳，也没法继续前进了。因此，它和那匹矮种马被留在了这个营地里。这儿有水及很好的牧草，它们有可能会恢复体力，我们以后或许还能再找到它们，把它们带回要塞。
About three o’clock we encamped in a grove after a forced march of twenty-five miles, that had proved a hard trial to the horses.For a long time after the head of the line had encamped, the rest kept straggling in, two and three at a time; one of our pack-horses had given out, about nine miles back, and a pony belonging to Beatte, shortly after.Many of the other horses looked so gaunt and feeble, that doubts were entertained of their being able to reach the fort.In the night there was heavy rain, and the morning dawned cloudy and dismal.The camp resounded, however, with something of its former gayety.The rangers had supped well, and were renovated in spirits, anticipating a speedy arrival at the garrison.Before we set forward on our march, Beatte returned, and brought his pony to the camp with great difficulty.The pack-horse, however, was completely knocked up and had to be abandoned.The wild mare, too, had cast her foal, through exhaustion, and was not in a state to go forward.She and the pony, therefore, were left at this encampment, where there was water and good pasturage; and where there would be a chance of their reviving, and being afterward sought out and brought to the garrison.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们在八点左右启程，劳神费力地走了一天。有时要翻过崎岖的山丘，有时要穿越起伏的大草原。雨水使得土地变得又滑又湿，所以我们的坐骑总是立足不稳。一些巡逻骑兵下了马，他们的马匹已经没有力气驮他们了。我们在上午的行程中停顿了一下，马儿们却累得连吃草的力气都没有了。其中几匹躺了下来，很难让它们重新站起来。我们的队伍呈现出一片愁苦不堪的面貌，艰难地缓缓前进。整个队伍稀稀拉拉地行走在长达三英里的山丘和河谷之间，拉成了长长的一溜。人们三四个一组，各组之间隔得很远；有的骑在马背上，有的步行，还有几个落伍者远远地落在后面。四点钟左右，我们在一片宽阔的树林里停了下来，准备过夜。树林旁有一条很深很窄的河流，名叫利特尔北支流或是“深深的克里克”。大部队好不容易进入营地时，天色已经很晚了，许多马匹已经精疲力竭了。由于溪水太深，我们涉不过去，所以只好等到第二天早上再想办法过去。但几个混血儿却在晚上牵着马匹游到了对岸，以让它们吃到更好的牧草，河水也显然在上涨。夜晚很冷，天气十分恶劣。寒风呼啸着穿过树林，卷起了干燥的树叶，在空中打着转儿。我们用巨大的树干生起了很旺的火，这虽然没能让大家高兴起来，至少也给我们带来了些许安慰。
We set off about eight o’clock, and had a day of weary and harassing travel; part of the time over rough hills, and part over rolling prairies.The rain had rendered the soil slippery and plashy, so as to afford unsteady foothold.Some of the rangers dismounted, their horses having no longer strength to bear them.We made a halt in the course of the morning, but the horses were too tired to graze.Several of them lay down, and there was some difficulty in getting them on their feet again.Our troop presented a forlorn appearance, straggling slowly along, in a broken and scattered line, that extended over hill and dale, for three miles and upward, in groups of three and four, widely apart; some on horseback, some on foot, with a few laggards far in the rear.About four o’clock, we halted for the night in a spacious forest, beside a deep narrow river, called the Little North Fork, or Deep Creek.It was late before the main part of the troop straggled into the encampment, many of the horses having given out.As this stream was too deep to be forded, we waited until the next day to devise means to cross it; but our half-breeds swam the horses of our party to the other side in the evening, as they would have better pasturage, and the stream was evidently swelling.The night was cold and unruly; the wind sounding hoarsely through the forest and whirling about the dry leaves.We made long fires of great trunks of trees, which diffused something of consolation if not cheerfulness around.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二天上午，队长允许大家出去打猎，十二点前回来就行，因为营地的食物又不够了。我们安营扎寨的林木茂密的低洼地有大量的野火鸡，大家猎杀了许多。同时，我们也在为过河做准备，而河水一夜之间涨了好几英尺；我们决定砍倒一些树当桥梁用。
