The next morning there was general permission given to hunt until twelve o’clock; the camp being destitute of provisions.The rich woody bottom in which we were encamped abounded with wild turkeys, of which a considerable number were killed.In the meantime, preparations were made for crossing the river, which had risen several feet during the night; and it was determined to fell trees for the purpose, to serve as bridges.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 队长、医生及营地其他的一两个首领都很精通木活，他们用专业眼光检查长在河岸边的树，最终挑出了几棵最大、倾斜角度也最合适的树。然后，斧头便有力地砍在了树根上，以确保树倒下后可以直接横跨河面。由于它们长度不够，到不了对岸，所以需要一些人游过去砍倒对面的树，使它们接起来。他们最终踩着河底，摇摇晃晃地穿过了这又深又急的河水，顺便把一些可以带走的包裹带了过去。可我们却仍需小心翼翼、一步一步地沿着树干和主枝前进。一部分树干完全没入了水中，水一直淹到我们的腰部。然后，大多数的马都游了过去，但也有一些太虚弱了，不敢下到水流中去，显然是精疲力竭，不能再前进了。因此，队长命令十二个人留下来看护这些马，直到它们通过休息和放牧恢复足够的体力来走完全程。队长答应，我们一到达要塞，他便会派人给他们送来面粉和其他必需品。
The Captain and Doctor, and one or two other leaders of the camp, versed in woodcraft, examined, with learned eye, the trees growing on the river bank, until they singled out a couple of the largest size, and most suitable inclinations.The axe was then vigorously applied to their roots, in such a way as to insure their falling directly across the stream.As they did not reach to the opposite bank, it was necessary for some of the men to swim across and fell trees on the other side, to meet them.They at length succeeded in making a precarious footway across the deep and rapid current, by which the baggage could be carried over; but it was necessary to grope our way, step by step, along the trunks and main branches of the trees, which for a part of the distance were completely submerged, so that we were to our waists in water.Most of the horses were then swam across, but some of them were too weak to brave the current, and evidently too much knocked up to bear any further travel.Twelve men, therefore, were left at the encampment to guard these horses, until, by repose and good pasturage, they should be sufficiently recovered to complete their journey; and the Captain engaged to send the men a supply of flour and other necessaries, as soon as we should arrive at the fort.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第三十五章 瞭望陆地
CHAPTER XXXV. A LOOK-OUT FOR LAND.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: ——艰苦的旅行及饥饿的停顿——一个边疆农舍——到达要塞
—HARD TRAVELLING AND HUNGRY HALTING.—A FRONTIER FARMHOUSE.—ARRIVAL AT THE GARRISON.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一点多一点儿时，我们再次开始了疲惫的行程。那天余下的时间及接下来的一整天，我们都在进行辛苦的旅行。我们在路上翻过了一些乱世嶙峋的山岗，穿过几个被刚下的一场雨弄得湿软而又泥泞的、广阔的大草原。在大草原上，我们还不时被涨成洪流的小河阻断了去路。我们那些可怜的马匹非常虚弱，我们费了好大劲儿才带它们穿过了很深的峡谷及湍急的水流。在穿行泥泞的草原上时，它们每走一步都蹄底打滑，踉踉跄跄。所以，我们大多数人不得不下马，步行完成大部分的行程。整个队伍都非常饥饿，每个人看起来都开始变得焦虑、憔悴，觉得每多走一英里，路就会变得更长。有一次，在翻越一座山丘时，贝蒂爬到一棵很高的树上放眼远眺，就像海上爬上桅顶的水手一样。他下来后，带来了令人振奋的消息。他看到在左侧绵延着一条林带，他知道那就是阿肯色河边缘的林带。他还认出了远处一些界标。由此，他总结说，我们距离要塞不超过四十英里。大家发出了像在海上颠簸飘摇的水手看到陆地一样的叫喊声。
It was a little after one o’clock when we again resumed our weary wayfaring.The residue of that day and the whole of the next were spent in toilsome travel.Part of the way was over stony hills, part across wide prairies, rendered spongy and miry by the recent rain, and cut up by brooks swollen into torrents.Our poor horses were so feeble, that it was with difficulty we could get them across the deep ravines and turbulent streams.In traversing the miry plains, they slipped and staggered at every step, and most of us were obliged to dismount and walk for the greater part of the way.Hunger prevailed throughout the troop; every one began to look anxious and haggard, and to feel the growing length of each additional mile.At one time, in crossing a hill, Beatte climbed a high tree, commanding a wide prospect, and took a look-out, like a mariner from the mast-head at sea.He came down with cheering tidings.To the left he had beheld a line of forest stretching across the country, which he knew to be the woody border of the Arkansas; and at a distance he had recognized certain landmarks, from which he concluded that we could not be above forty miles distant from the fort.It was like the welcome cry of land to tempest-tossed mariners.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 实际上，我们很快便看到远处葱茏的山谷中有烟飘起。那应该是要塞附近一支克里克人或是奥塞奇印第安人的狩猎队生的火。大家都欢呼起来，因为我们终于看到人的踪迹了。我们现在信心满满地认为，很快便可以到达散落在这片无人居住的荒原边缘的克里克印第安人的边疆村落了。而饥饿而步履沉重的巡逻骑兵们也精神大振，热切地期盼着农家的美味佳肴。他们细数着每一样可口诱人的佳肴，直到对这顿想象中的盛宴垂涎欲滴。
In fact we soon after saw smoke rising from a woody glen at a distance.It was supposed to be made by a hunting-party of Creek or Osage Indians from the neighborhood of the fort, and was joyfully hailed as a harbinger of man.It was now confidently hoped that we would soon arrive among the frontier hamlets of Creek Indians, which are scattered along the skirts of the uninhabited wilderness; and our hungry rangers trudged forward with reviving spirit, regaling themselves with savory anticipations of farmhouse luxuries, and enumerating every article of good cheer, until their mouths fairly watered at the shadowy feasts thus conjured up.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 然而，在结束了鞍马劳顿的一天之后，等待我们的却是一个饥饿的夜晚。我们在阿肯色河的一条支流的河岸上扎了营。营地建在了一个已被飓风摧残、颇具规模的小树林的残迹之上。一小股疾风从树林中强行穿过，一路上令许多树瑟瑟发抖，折断了许多树枝，甚至将一些树连根拔起，只留下树根在空中飞舞；所有的树都倒向同一个方向，就像是那些被猎人踏倒的、易碎易折的芦苇一样。
A hungry night, however, closed in upon a toilsome day.We encamped on the border of one of the tributary streams of the Arkansas, amidst the ruins of a stately grove that had been riven by a hurricane.The blast had torn its way through the forest in a narrow column, and its course was marked by enormous trees shivered and splintered, and upturned, with their roots in the air; all lay in one direction, like so many brittle reeds broken and trodden down by the hunter.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 在这儿，我们不必费力用斧子砍伐树木便有足够的燃料。很快篝火便在这寒冷的空气中熊熊燃烧起来，照亮了整个树林。但是，唉！我们没有肉可以烤。营地里食物短缺几乎要发展成饥荒了。除了那些带着少量风干肉条，或者甚至是带着上一顿中啃了一半的骨头的人之外，其余人都很不开心。至于我们，我们比隔壁那些人幸运多了，我们中有一个人打到了一只火鸡。我们既没有面包就着吃，也没有盐当作料。我们只是把它放到水中简单地煮一煮，然后把水当成汤来喝，而拿着每一小块鸡肉在空荡荡的盐袋里刮来刮去，希望可以刮上某个盐粒，给这清淡无味的鸡肉添些滋味。
Here was fuel in abundance, without the labor of the axe; we had soon immense fires blazing and sparkling in the frosty air, and lighting up the whole forest; but, alas! we had no meat to cook at them.The scarcity in the camp almost amounted to famine.Happy was he who had a morsel of jerked meat, or even the half-picked bones of a former repast.For our part, we were more lucky at our mess than our neighbors; one of our men having shot a turkey.We had no bread to eat with it, nor salt to season it withal.It was simply boiled in water; the latter was served up as soup, and we were fain to rub each morsel of the turkey on the empty salt-bag, in hopes some saline particle might remain to relieve its insipidity.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 当晚非常寒冷，我们周围的所有物体都覆盖上了一层冰晶，皎洁的月光洒在上面，闪闪发光。我们所躺的毛皮周围的水也结冰了。第二天早上，我发现裹着自己的毯子上覆盖着一层白色的冰霜；但我却从未睡得这么舒适过。
The night was biting cold; the brilliant moonlight sparkled on the frosty crystals which covered every object around us.The water froze beside the skins on which we bivouacked, and in the morning I found the blanket in which I was wrapped covered with a hoar frost; yet I had never slept more comfortably.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 吃完了一顿由几块鸡骨头和一杯没有糖的咖啡组成的简单早餐之后，我们便早早地撤营上路了，因为饥饿是旅行灵敏的加速器。包括那些高高的野草在内，整个大草原都披着一层霜，在阳光下闪闪发光。我们看到大群大群的草原鸡或盘旋在林木间，或成排地蹲在光秃秃的树枝上，等着太阳融化野草及牧草上的冰霜。我们的巡逻骑兵们再也不会对这种低等猎物不屑一顾了，而是跑出队伍，像以前追逐鹿一样急切地追着这些松鸡。
After a shadow of a breakfast, consisting of turkey bones and a cup of coffee without sugar, we decamped at an early hour; for hunger is a sharp quickener on a journey.The prairies were all gemmed with frost, that covered the tall weeds and glistened in the sun.We saw great flights of prairie-hens, or grouse, that hovered from tree to tree, or sat in rows along the naked branches, waiting until the sun should melt the frost from the weeds and herbage.Our rangers no longer despised such humble game, but turned from the ranks in pursuit of a prairie-hen as eagerly as they formerly would go in pursuit of a deer.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 现在，每一个人都急切地前进着，焦急地盼望着可以在天黑前抵达某个人类居住的地方。这些可怜的马匹们虽然已经没有多少力气了，骑手们还是一个劲儿地催促着它们前进，因为他们认为很快就能通过休息和足够的草料来补偿它们现在的劳累了。但距离似乎比之前想象的更远了，我们用来作为路标的地平线上的青山也随着我们的前进而后退着。我们的每一步都变得很艰辛，不时还会有可怜的马匹筋疲力尽地累倒在地。它的主人几乎费尽力气才能把它扶起来，并把它强行牵到河岸上可能会有稀疏牧草的某条河的河边，然后留它在那里听天由命。在这些被这样留在路上的坐骑中就有伯爵的一匹备用马。作为主要的猎手，伯爵在追逐野马时总是一马当先。然而，我们打算一抵达要塞便马上派出一队人带着谷物，把可以存活下来的马匹带回去。
Every one now pushed forward, anxious to arrive at some human habitation before night.The poor horses were urged beyond their strength, in the thought of soon being able to indemnify them for present toil, by rest and ample provender.Still the distances seemed to stretch out more than ever, and the blue hills, pointed out as landmarks on the horizon, to recede as we advanced.Every step became a labor; every now and then a miserable horse would give out and lie down.His owner would raise him by main strength, force him forward to the margin of some stream, where there might be a scanty border of herbage, and then abandon him to his fate.Among those that were thus left on the way, was one of the led horses of the Count; a prime hunter, that had taken the lead of every thing in the chase of the wild horses.It was intended, however as soon as we should arrive at the fort, to send out a party provided with corn, to bring in such of the horses as should survive.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 上午的行程中，我们发现了印第安人的足迹，在不同的方向上相互交叉，这证明我们一定是已经处在人类居住区的边缘了。最终，在穿越一个树林的边缘时，我们看到了两三间木屋掩映在大草原边界上的高大树木下。这些木屋是克里克印第安人的住房，旁边紧挨着一些小农田。即使是那些到处都是奢侈品这一现代文明产物的奢华别墅，也得不到我们此时此刻所给予这些小木屋的热烈欢呼。
In the course of the morning, we came upon Indian tracks, crossing each other in various directions, a proof that we must be in the neighborhood of human habitations.At length, on passing through a skirt of wood, we beheld two or three log houses, sheltered under lofty trees on the border of a prairie, the habitations of Creek Indians, who had small farms adjacent.Had they been sumptuous villas, abounding with the luxuries of civilization, they could not have been hailed with greater delight.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 一些巡逻骑兵骑上前去向他们讨要食物；而大部分人则继续前进，寻找白人居住的地方。有人告诉我们白人居住的地方离这儿也不远。队伍很快便消失在树林中，我则沿着他们的踪迹缓慢前进，因为我那匹原本敏捷宽厚的坐骑此时已经步履蹒跚，每一步都走得很艰难。而我也已疲惫不堪，没有力气下马步行了。
Some of the rangers rode up to them in quest of food; the greater part, however, pushed forward in search of the habitation of a white settler, which we were told was at no great distance.The troop soon disappeared among the trees, and I followed slowly in their track; for my once fleet and generous steed faltered under me, and was just able to drag one foot after the other, yet I was too weary and exhausted to spare him.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们就以这种方式缓慢前进着，直到转过一片茂密的树丛时，一间边疆农舍突然映入我们的眼帘。那是一间被几棵参天大树所遮蔽的低矮木屋，但它的周围却似乎是一片富足与安逸之地。这儿有一个马厩和牲口棚，还有几个装满稻谷的粮仓，而哼哼叫唤的猪群、咯咯叫着的火鸡和母鸡，以及趾高气扬的公鸡在这个农家庭院里成群结队地闲逛着。
In this way we crept on, until, on turning a thick clump of trees, a frontier farmhouse suddenly presented itself to view.It was a low tenement of logs, overshadowed by great forest trees, but it seemed as if a very region of Cocaigne prevailed around it.Here was a stable and barn, and granaries teeming with abundance, while legions of grunting swine, gobbling turkeys, cackling hens and strutting roosters, swarmed about the farmyard.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我的那匹疲惫不堪、饿得半死的马，听到这熟悉的声音后，不禁抬起头，竖起了耳朵。它喉咙里发出一声咕噜声，像是一声干笑，然后迅速地摆动着尾巴，朝一个装满金黄玉米穗的仓库凑了过去。我费了好大力气才阻止住它，把它驱赶到木屋的门口。仅仅往里面一瞥，便足以勾起我全部的食欲。巡逻骑兵的队长和他手下的军官们正围坐在一个三条腿的桌子旁，桌上摆着满满的一盘热气腾腾的煮牛肉和芜菁。我立刻翻身下马，把它松开任由它跑向装满玉米的仓库，自己则走进了这座食物丰盛的“宫殿”。一个脾气很好的、胖胖的黑女人在门口迎接了我。她是这间房子的女主人，她的丈夫是个白人，现在不在家。我称赞她是这个荒野中的一个黑精灵，可以突然在荒漠中变出一桌丰盛的美食，而这美食又确确实实摆在我们面前。转瞬间，她从火堆里拽出一个大铁锅，这个铁锅能与埃及著名的烧肉锅，或是《麦克白》中女巫的大锅相媲美。把一只陶制的棕色盘子放在地上之后，她又把那只硕大的锅的一侧斜了过来，从里面倒出各式各样的大块牛肉，紧接着是一大堆芜菁，然后是满满的一盘肉汤。她咧着嘴笑着把这个端给我，并为这简单的食物及盛食物的粗陋餐具而感到抱歉。简单的食物！粗陋的餐具！煮牛肉和芜菁，还有盛它们的陶制盘子！向一个来自大草原的饿得半死的人送上这样的美味佳肴，还有那些美妙的面包和黄油，难道还需要感到抱歉吗？老天啊，这简直是盛宴啊！
My poor jaded and half-famished horse raised his head and pricked up his ears at the well-known sights and sounds.He gave a chuckling inward sound, something like a dry laugh; whisked his tail, and made great leeway toward a corn-crib, filled with golden ears of maize, and it was with some difficulty that I could control his course, and steer him up to the door of the cabin.A single glance within was sufficient to raise every gastronomic faculty.There sat the Captain of the rangers and his officers, round a three-legged table, crowned by a broad and smoking dish of boiled beef and turnips.I sprang off my horse in an instant, cast him loose to make his way to the corn-crib, and entered this palace of plenty.A fat good-humored negress received me at the door.She was the mistress of the house, the spouse of the white man, who was absent.I hailed her as some swart fairy of the wild, that had suddenly conjured up a banquet in the desert; and a banquet was it in good sooth.In a twinkling, she lugged from the fire a huge iron pot, that might have rivalled one of the famous flesh-pots of Egypt, or the witches’ caldron in Macbeth.Placing a brown earthen dish on the floor, she inclined the corpulent caldron on one side, and out leaped sundry great morsels of beef, with a regiment of turnips tumbling after them, and a rich cascade of broth overflowing the whole.This she handed me with an ivory smile that extended from ear to ear; apologizing for our humble fare, and the humble style in which it was served up.Humble fare! humble style!Boiled beef and turnips, and an earthen dish to eat them from!To think of apologizing for such a treat to a half-starved man from the prairies; and then such magnificent slices of bread and butter!Head of Apicius, what a banquet!

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: “饥饿之火”被平息之后，我才想起了我的马。然而，它就像一个老兵一样，把自己照顾得很好。我发现它专注地围着盛放印第安玉米的仓库，灵巧地从栅栏间将突出来的玉米穗挑出来嚼着吃。我很抱歉地打断了它享用美餐，而它只得长叹一口气，确切地说是叽里咕噜地抱怨了一阵，便不情愿地离开了。然而，我急切地想要和我的旅行同伴们会合。他们经过这个农舍时并没有停留，而是继续向阿肯色河河岸前进，希望可以在天黑前抵达奥塞奇事务所。因此，我离开了决定在这个食物丰盛的农家过夜的队长及他的部队，向我们的黑皮肤女主人告别，然后继续策马前进。
“The rage of hunger” being appeased, I began to think of my horse.He, however, like an old campaigner, had taken good care of himself.I found him paying assiduous attention to the crib of Indian corn, and dexterously drawing forth and munching the ears that protruded between the bars.It was with great regret that I interrupted his repast, which he abandoned with a heavy sigh, or rather a rumbling groan.I was anxious, however, to rejoin my travelling companions, who had passed by the farmhouse without stopping, and proceeded to the banks of the Arkansas; being in hopes of arriving before night at the Osage Agency.Leaving the Captain and his troop, therefore, amidst the abundance of the farm, where they had determined to quarter themselves for the night, I bade adieu to our sable hostess, and again pushed forward.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 骑了大约一英里后，我来到了穿过一片片美丽森林的阿肯色河的河畔，我的同伴们正在河边等着。一伙衣着鲜艳、看起来像是快活的热带鸟的克里克印第安人，正忙着用一个小舟帮我们的人将包裹运过河去。与此同时，我们的马匹享用了另一场盛宴——河边有两个很大的仓库里堆满了印第安玉米。我们不得不时刻关注着这些饿得半死的可怜牲畜，以防它们因贪吃而伤了身体。
A ride of about a mile brought me to where my comrades were waiting on the banks of the Arkansas, which here poured along between beautiful forests.A number of Creek Indians, in their brightly colored dresses, looking like so many gay tropical birds, were busy aiding our men to transport the baggage across the river in a canoe.While this was doing, our horses had another regale from two great cribs heaped up with ears of Indian corn, which stood near the edge of the river.We had to keep a check upon the poor half-famished animals, lest they should injure themselves by their voracity.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 所有的包裹都被运到对岸后，我们也上了这条小舟，并牵着我们的马，让它们游过河。我很担心，怕这些身体虚弱的马儿们，会顶不住水流的冲击。但是，它们吃的那顿印第安玉米大餐，又使它们充满了力气和精神头。它们看上去很兴奋，似乎本能地意识到马上就要到家了，很快便可以得到休息，吃到丰盛的食物了。所以，我们一上岸恢复行程，它们便开始轻快地飞奔了起来，一直跑了长达七英里的路程，即使在穿越森林时我们也没有下马。
The baggage being all carried to the opposite bank, we embarked in the canoe, and swam our horses across the river.I was fearful, lest in their enfeebled state, they should not be able to stem the current; but their banquet of Indian corn had already infused fresh life and spirit into them, and it would appear as if they were cheered by the instinctive consciousness of their approach to home, where they would soon be at rest, and in plentiful quarters; for no sooner had we landed and resumed our route, than they set off on a hand-gallop, and continued so for a great part of seven miles, that we had to ride through the woods.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 我们傍晚时分便抵达了位于弗迪格里斯河岸的事务所，大约一个月前我们就是在这儿出发的。我们在这儿度过了一个舒适的夜晚，但是习惯了露天宿营之后，房屋的封闭性在某种程度上竟有些令人讨厌。环境似乎是封闭的，也缺乏新鲜空气；当我晚上醒来凝望着四周的一片漆黑时，我不禁怀念起星星那美妙的陪伴来。
It was an early hour in the evening when we arrived at the Agency on the banks of the Verdigris River, whence we had set off about a month before.Here we passed the night comfortably quartered; yet, after having been accustomed to sleep in the open air, the confinement of a chamber was, in some respects, irksome.The atmosphere seemed close, and destitute of freshness; and when I woke in the night and gazed about me upon complete darkness, I missed the glorious companionship of the stars.

第一章 波尼族印第安人的狩猎场: 第二天早上，吃完早饭后，我再次出发，陪着可敬的专员前往吉布森要塞。到那儿时，我们全都衣衫褴褛，风尘仆仆，皮肤黝黑，但个个儿都身体健壮，精神抖擞。我的波尼人狩猎场之旅就这样结束了。
The next morning, after breakfast, I again set forward, in company with the worthy Commissioner, for Fort Gibson, where we arrived much tattered, travel-stained, and weather-beaten, but in high health and spirits;—and thus ended my foray into the Pawnee Hunting Grounds.
